HEADLINE: Men on TV: Dumb as Posts And Proud of It

BYLINE: By ANITA GATES

 BODY:
HOMER SIMPSON doesn't bother me. When he sits on his sofa, directly across from the television set, beer in hand, slack-jawed, with a blank stare to represent a brain set on stall, I don't really believe that our nation's nuclear power plants are operated by his kind. At least I know that Matt Groening, who created Homer and his sallow-faced, bug-eyed family, did not intend him as a role model.
Homer is, after all, just a really famous cartoon. If he were the only heterosexual adult male on television who seemed inordinately pleased with himself and blissfully unaware of his low I.Q., prime time would be in good shape. But in recent months I've been noticing his live-action counterparts. 
 Sometimes they can be caught in precisely the same pose. There's the title character of "The King of Queens" (Kevin James), whose lifelong dream is still to turn his basement into a private hideaway for watching sports on big-screen television. An episode of "Everybody Loves Raymond" begins with the title character's father and brother (Peter Boyle and Brad Garrett) seemingly hypnotized in front of a televised football game. When Raymond (Ray Romano) greets them, they respond with a single simultaneous grunt. And on reruns of "Friends," Chandler (Matthew Perry) and Joey (Matt LeBlanc) -- witty, upwardly mobile Manhattan bachelors -- veg out for sports telecasts in their matching recliner chairs. (Chandler has since been resocialized by moving in with Monica.)
But television sports mania is not these characters' only fault. Men in a growing number of comedies are depicted as rude, crude, sex-crazed, sexist, childish and blindly egotistical.
The curmudgeonly title character of "Becker" (Ted Danson), a middle-aged doctor, says things like: "If you want to know about women, you don't ask a woman. If you want to know about meat, do you ask a cow?" When a patient tells him that an injection hurt, Becker replies, "Grow up, will you?" On "Friends," Joey eats steak with his fingers at Ross's wedding reception. On "Dharma and Greg," Greg (Thomas Gibson), a respectable married lawyer, can't have his wife (Jenna Elfman) work at his office because every time he looks at her, his legal training and his self-discipline vanish and he has to have sex with her, right there on the desk. Prime time gives us grown men who can't stop giggling in church, bawdy male magazine publishers married to women half their age and men who stick Montblanc pens up their noses in order to meet women in the emergency room. Anyone who watches television regularly could get the impression that one of the two sexes on this planet is not only dimwitted and uncouth but darned proud of it.
In their desperate attempt to lure male viewers (and all the dollars advertisers believe they are ready to spend), the powers that be in television seem to have decided to appeal to the lowest common denominator. And it's remarkably low.
Maybe this glorification of the dumb started with the research. Men, as any pollster can tell you, do watch football -- a contest in which, its fans point out, the best men really do win and it's all about sheer ability, not politics or personality, at least during the game itself. Men also watch wrestling, in which hypermasculine, hyperstrong men take on outrageous personas and act out the battle between good and evil. So what do the programming experts decide? Rather than developing or buying series that might appeal to those fascinations with ability, victory versus defeat or good versus evil, they give us shows about men watching football and wrestling. And doing little else. Now little boys across America want to grow up to be just like them.
Seriously. The last time Children Now, a California media advocacy group, surveyed 10- to 17-year-old boys, the top television role models they named were all sitcom characters, most of them a little off-kilter. One was Tim the tool guy (Tim Allen), the inept handyman who liked to growl to demonstrate his manliness on "Home Improvement." But he was a responsible husband and father -- and at least partly facetious. Two were smart-mouthed New York single guys from "Seinfeld": Jerry Seinfeld's namesake character, a likable enough stand-up comedian, and Kramer (Michael Richards), a complete lunatic who spent most of the show's eight-year run unemployed and couldn't manage to walk into a room without falling down. The two other people boys wanted to be like were, God help us, Homer Simpson and his chip-off-the-old-block son, Bart, whose contribution to the English language so far has been the admonition, "Eat my shorts."
Come on. Prime time is strewn with noble, brave, dedicated, attractive male characters that any little boy might be proud to emulate. Why does no one want to be Dr. John Carter (Noah Wyle) or Dr. Peter Benton (Eriq LaSalle) from "E.R."? Or Bobby Donnell (Dylan McDermott) on "The Practice"? Or any of the police officers on "N.Y.P.D. Blue"? A lot of these characters are single, good-looking, making good money and doing quite well with women. Presumably the younger boys are in bed by 10 p.m., when many of the serious dramas are on the air. But there could be two other answers.
First, these characters are all working themselves to death. As television dramas have become more realistic, they have increasingly depicted adults as stressed out, physically exhausted and in almost constant moral agony, often fighting uphill battles against the idiots at their hospitals, law offices, precincts and other workplaces.
Fox Mulder (David Duchovny) on "The X-Files," for instance, may be a big, tough, handsome F.B.I. agent who carries a gun and is smarter than everybody else (except his partner, Scully, played by Gillian Anderson), but he's also a little deranged, what with his fixation on flying saucers and government plots, and his immediate superiors constantly try to thwart him. Moreover, the man hasn't had a date in ages. If this unspoken, slowly building sexual-tension thing with Scully doesn't work out when the series ends, Mulder could end up alone for life.
So maybe it's just that 12-year-olds don't want to grow up to be burned-out, sleep-deprived misfits. The Peter Pan syndrome isn't all about fear of commitment, you know. Or -- more horrible thought -- maybe Dr. Carter, Dr. Benton, Bobby Donnell and the rest actually turn into slack-jawed, beer-drinking, sports-watching zombies after hours. Sure, medicine, law and law enforcement are demanding fields, but Perry Mason (Raymond Burr) always looked fresh, well rested and sure of himself. Marcus Welby (Robert Young) was cool, calm and collected for seven seasons. Of course, in their day, series heroes were almost infallible; neither of them had to deal with actually losing cases or patients.
Second, it may be simply that young men aren't watching these particular would-be role models. The dramas that feature sensitive, intelligent male adults are often shows with predominantly female audiences. You think George Clooney became the most bankable star on "E.R." because of heterosexual male viewers? And the more emotionally mature and aware the male character, the more likely it is that he's being written for a series aimed largely at women to begin with.
Take Rick (Billy Campbell), the boyish, fortyish divorced architect in "Once and Again," ABC's freshman drama about divorced parents in love. Rick is so sensitive that the first time he and Lily (Sela Ward), a fortyish divorced bookstore owner, meet, he gently, reassuringly tells her daughter how to take care of her soccer injury. On "Providence," NBC's treacly drama about Dr. Sydney Hansen (Melina Kanakaredes), a plastic surgeon who leaves her superficial Los Angeles life behind to move back to her hometown in Rhode Island, Sydney's father (Mike Farrell) is a sensitive type. You can tell because he's a veterinarian who's really gentle with pets and often sits around looking sad because his wife died. Sydney even actually finds love interests who open up. One, dealing with a health crisis not long ago, confessed to Sydney: "Some things are hard to admit. Some are even harder to say. I don't want to go through this alone." Good role model in terms of emotional communication, but it's doubtful that a lot of growing boys were watching; "Providence" is the prime-time equivalent of a chick flick.
Anyway, that guy was actually acknowledging that he needed help, that he was willing to be less than completely in control. The author Susan Faludi suggests that in our culture men have come to believe they aren't real men if they aren't in control. And in our culture it's hard to be in control of anything, which is what those workplace-based dramas often reveal. Even today's doctors, lawyers and cops are shown losing to forces beyond their -- oops, there's that word again -- control. In "Stiffed: The Betrayal of the American Man," Ms. Faludi also says that at the turn of the 21st century, men are searching for a way to recapture the masculine camaraderie and purpose of World War II, their fathers' proving ground.
From the look of things, they are settling for camaraderie alone. But there's no reason that characters who watch football games and get a little drunk together can't be good human beings as well. Television's quintessential sensitive guy, Hawkeye Pierce of "M*A*S*H," as played by Alan Alda, was the class clown of his Korean War medical unit, an usually successful seducer of women and a dedicated martini drinker. Well, at least that was true at the beginning of the series; maybe the writers decided that viewers couldn't handle a character so complicated that he had those "faults" and yet was both wise enough to see war for the horrible waste that it is and sentimental enough to have sympathy for the other side. So they cleaned Hawkeye up as the seasons passed. Our loss.
It's not that the male television oaf is anything new. Chester A. Riley of "The Life of Riley," as played by both Jackie Gleason and William Bendix, was a classic big, dumb lug. But at least he was a little embarrassed about it.
And Riley was funny. Yes, it's important to remember that all of the current shows with idiotic male characters are comedies, and comedy thrives on exaggeration. Lucy Ricardo, the beloved heroine of "I Love Lucy," reinforced every 20th-century stereotype of women: she couldn't handle money, loved to gossip, took good care of her man and was singularly ditsy, but she didn't know how good she had it just being a housewife and mother. The female sitcom heroines that followed avoided that kind of automatic sexism. On "The Mary Tyler Moore Show," Mary Richards's problem was being too nice. On "Murphy Brown," the title character's problem was just the opposite.
Of course, any attempt in the year 2000 to base a female character on the old stereotypes would cause an outcry among viewers. Just look at the objections to "Ally McBeal," whose title character wears short skirts and worries as much about her love life as her law career. David E. Kelley, the show's creator, is actually an equal-opportunity stereotypist. The men on "Ally McBeal" are just as superficial and insecure as the women.
THE demands of political correctness could be part of the problem as well. All that stored-up tension from being careful not to offend women, black people, gay people, animal rights activists or any nationality on earth comes out in the creation of grotesque male characters. As long as men are in power, they are the one group that television can ridicule without fear of reprisal.
Take a classic episode of "The Simpsons," in which Homer and Marge's intelligent, cheerful daughter Lisa goes into a funk when she realizes she has Homer's genes and so is destined to grow up to be just as big an idiot as he is. (This is a man who once threw his own wallet into the fireplace, so pickpockets would not be able to get it during his coming trip to New York.) Lisa's parents try to reassure her by gathering lots of Simpson relatives together, but they turn out to be jerks and failures of various kinds. Until Lisa starts meeting the female Simpsons, who are brain surgeons and professors and rocket scientists. "The defective Simpson gene is on the Y chromosome," one of the women explains, so it affects only the family's men.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Long Island;
High-Tech Companies Seek Space Near the Train

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

 BODY:
THE desirability of a Long Island office building has traditionally been determined by rental price, amenities and a location close to major highways. Now, with fast-growing high-technology companies competing for skilled personnel, a new ingredient has been added: proximity to train stations and other public transportation so that companies can more easily tap into New York City's vast labor pool, or even reach out to workers in New Jersey and Connecticut.
"The way these companies know they can grow their businesses is to get into these central locations where they can attract a lot of employees," said Gus P. Nuzzolese, a senior managing director at the Sutton & Edwards commercial brokerage firm in Lake Success. "What makes a software company a great company is the quality of people it hires." 
 The vast majority of workers on Long Island, including those from the city, commute by car. But companies like the FatWire Corporation, which is about to move into its new headquarters at 330 Old Country Road in Mineola in a deal brokered by Mr. Nuzzolese, see proximity to a train station as a way of getting a competitive edge in attracting employees.
"One of the most strategic things about locating here is that it is one block from the Long Island Rail Road station, because about half our people come from Queens, Brooklyn and Manhattan," said Mark Fasciano, FatWire's president and a co-founder. His partners in the company are Ari Kahn, chief technical officer, and John Murcott, vice president of development services.
FatWire, like some other blossoming software companies, was started by its founders in a private house -- in FatWire's case over a garage in Oyster Bay. Now, three and a half years later, the company, which produces content-management software for the development and maintenance of complex Web sites, counts I.B.M. and major dot-com companies among its clients. FatWire has 55 employees, and its executives say it expects to have a staff of 120 by the end of the year.
It recently received $9.25 million in venture capital financing and will be almost tripling its space, moving from 6,000 square feet in Port Washington to 17,400 square feet in the Mineola building.
"When we were wrestling with the problem of looking for more space, the question came up, why not relocate to Silicon Alley?," said Mr. Fasciano, referring to the technology areas in downtown Manhattan. "The answer is we have much more flexibility on Long Island, where costs are much lower. And part of the culture of developing technology companies and software companies is that you need peace and space and a pleasant work environment because people are putting in tremendous hours."
One reason FatWire has been able to fill its recruitment needs, said Mr. Fasciano, whose Web site's recruiting section includes the sentence, "You won't need a car to work here," "is because our recruiting pool is not just Long Island."
A SHORTAGE in the local labor force, especially involving high technology, has some economists worrying that future economic growth could be threatened. The February unemployment rate was 3 percent in Nassau and 3.9 percent in Suffolk. In the 12 months that ended last December, the Long Island economy generated 43,000 new jobs, while the resident labor force expanded by only 11,400 workers, not enough to keep pace with job growth, said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, a Commack-based business group.
Richard W. Kruse, a founder and the vice chairman of the Long Island Software and Technology Network -- LISTnet -- estimated that for every seven openings on Long Island in the high-technology sector there is only one applicant. Although Long Island's colleges and universities have some of the finest computer science programs in the country, Mr. Kruse said, the current need is for experienced people.
Many engineers who might have used their skills in the high-tech sector moved elsewhere after the demise of Long Island's defense industry, he said. "We are grabbing young people coming out of school," he said, "but they're entry level, and we miss the experienced worker."
Mr. Kruse is also president of the Stratem Computer Group in Great River, a company that installs computer networks and provides consulting services, and of Connectem.com in Bethpage, a software company that provides wireless software solutions.
LISTnet, the nonprofit group he helped found, is headquartered in Great River at the Long Island Technology Center. The group was formed two and a half years ago to further the growth of high technology on Long Island. Initially, it had six members; now it has 800.
Garry D. Silivanch, president of Global Data Services, an executive recruiting firm in Northport, said he expected the shortage of high-technology workers to worsen. "Demand is on the increase, everyone is becoming computer literate, business applications especially in Web development are in great demand, and a lot of people are going into Wall Street jobs and not into technology sciences," he said.
One reason employers are looking to New York City to fill their employment needs is that many immigrants with computer and programming skills are coming from Russia, India and elsewhere in Asia and are settling in the city, said Chris Klepeis, director of recruiting services at Invision.com, a Commack-based company that offers services that include e-business consulting and Web page design. Ms. Klepeis is also the Web administrator for LIjobs.com, a Web recruiting site where Long Island high-tech companies can post job offerings.
"There has been an explosion of companies trying to stay on the cutting edge of technology, and to do that they have to bring in people who know that technology," she said.
When Vacation.com decided to consolidate four regional offices it leased new office space close to a train station, selecting Franklin Avenue in Garden City, where it has taken 18,000 square feet at 1225 Franklin Avenue, one of four buildings in the 450,000-square-foot Franklin Avenue Plaza complex. Vacation.com, a travel services marketing company, will start moving into its new offices in May.
"Employees with the technology skills we need are very tough to find, and by being close to the railroad we opened ourselves up to a much broader employee talent pool," said Richard C. Knodt, the company's president.
THE company links together more than 9,800 North American travel agencies on its Web site, where vacation and travel business products are offered to consumers. It also helps the agencies establish their own Web sites.
It too has had explosive growth. Started 18 months ago, it now employs more than 100 people in offices on Long Island, in St. Paul, Minn., and Boston, and in its executive offices in Washington.
The company recently bought four travel agencies in Bay Shore, Rockville Centre and West Islip and in New City in Rockland County and is combining their personnel in Garden City. It employs 52 people on Long Island, but is seeking 12 more in such areas as Web site design, sales and marketing and customer service, Mr. Knodt said.
Employers say they have no problem getting workers to commute from the city if the trip is made easy. "It's an easy sell when you compare standing on a subway train for a half hour to sitting on a Long Island Rail Road train for a half hour," said Daniel M. Pess, chief financial officer of QueryObject Systems Corporation, a Roslyn-based software company. "Suffolk wouldn't work for us because it would be a much harder sell if you tell people they have to sit on a train for an hour and a half."
The two-year-old Roslyn company develops software that allows organizations that use large and complex amounts of data the ability to analyze the data more quickly and in more detail. An Internet subsidiary is called IQO.com. It moved to Roslyn, next to the train station, from Uniondale last October with 33 employees and has since added 11 more workers, all from New York City and New Jersey. It is looking for more space in Roslyn because it expects to add as many as 50 employees over the next 12 months, Mr. Pess said.
Given Nassau's tight office market, finding space not only in prime buildings but in prime buildings close to transportation is easier said than done, commercial brokers say.
Richard Someck, a senior executive director at Sutton & Edwards, said the solution he found for a client -- MaterialNet.com -- that needed more space but wanted to find something as convenient to the train as its location at 170 Great Neck Road in Great Neck was a bus to the train. The eight-month-old company provides an Internet marketplace for nonprecious metals, including steel, iron, aluminum, copper and brass.
Mr. Someck found 20,000 square feet at 5 Dakota Drive in Lake Success, which has direct bus service to the Great Neck station, placing Manhattan within a 55-minute commute. The lease was signed in late March, and the company began moving in last week. It plans to add 100 employees to the 40 it now employs.
"In this tight labor market we want to attract top talent, so being near public transportation was very important to us," said Rob G. Heller, MaterialNet.com's chief financial officer. "People come out here because we share our vision with them, they believe in us, and they love the environment."

HEADLINE: Rent Regulation In New York City

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Anne Gilman's 10-year saga with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal "After Agency's Reversal, a Tenant Faces Eviction," March 5 certainly inspires sympathy for her plight -- and blame rests squarely with our tortured rent-regulation system.
The fact that she and her then spouse agreed pay $2,000 a month rent on a formerly rent-controlled apartment clearly makes it a "fair market" rent. What then "convinced" Ms. Gilman that she was being overcharged? 
 The bizarre element in the regulation scheme is that price has little relation to value. We all know about wildly divergent rents for identical apartments. The Gilmans valued the apartment at $2,000 and agreed to pay it; they should have abided by their agreement.
A million unregulated tenants in New York City rent apartments without government interference; others purchase houses, co-ops and condominiums without consulting a government price sheet. What justification is there for one group to regularly renegotiate and appeal the commitments they have voluntarily signed?
How about a word of sympathy for the owner who signed a contract in good faith, had his income slashed in half and was assigned a $50,000 penalty, all by an agency that took 10 years to make a series of incompetent and contradictory decisions. With the help of lawyers on both sides, everyone, including the taxpayers, will wind up worse off than when they started.
 
KATHLEEN ELVIN
 Vice President
 Small Property Owners
 of New York

LENGTH: 910 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
No Chicken. No Beef. Just Hog Wild.

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

DATELINE: MICKLETON

 BODY:
In 1865, Jeremiah Haines's great-great-grandmother began taking in the neighbors' hogs to make ends meet during the winter. The widow, who had a house full of children, would make pork sausage and scrapple and cure and smoke bacon until springtime when she and her family could farm.
Today, Mr. Haines uses the same recipes used by Rachel Haines in the 1800's. He doesn't farm the way her family did, and he processes the pork year round, not just in the winter. 
 The business, Haines Pork Store, has moved a mile down the road from her farmhouse and instead of just attracting the neighbors, it has customers who drive more than an hour to get their Easter ham, a crown roast for Christmas or pork to eat with sauerkraut for New Year's Day. And while they are there, most customers will pick up a pork roast with the special seasonings, a recipe developed by Mr. Haines's father, Jeremiah Ellison Haines.
"People will come a ways to get it because we are so small we can cater to individual customers," Mr. Haines said. "Some people like to talk to us. We get to know people, what trips they've been on and who's in their family."
The shop, on Kings Highway in this rural community, is tucked between farmhouses in East Greenwich, a Gloucester County township made up of three towns with a total population of about 5,000. And as in many old farming towns in South Jersey, the fields are being sold to developers and the houses are going up 10 and 20 at a time.
Inside, the brown ceramic tile floor is spotless and the stainless-steel counters are gleaming. Mr. Haines, 55, works with his son-in-law, Harry Sheldon, and one fulltime employee. During busy times of the year, like Easter, when the line is out the door and all the way to the street, he brings in other family members or college students to help.
Mr. Haines can often be found in the back grinding sausage with 180 pounds of pig hanging under a plastic covering waiting to be processed. Hogs are purchased and cleaned in Pennsylvania before being brought to the shop.
There's no chicken for sale. No cole slaw. No rolls. Just pork, though you can get lard for 40 cents a pound and some recipe sheets to guide you in preparing pork.
There are pig mobiles hanging from the ceiling, and photographs of Mr. Haines's relatives decorate the walls, including one of his great-grandfather taking the meat by horse and wagon into Philadelphia to sell it at the city markets.
Dallas Hockman, vice president of marketing for the National Pork Producers Council, said in a telephone interview that there were probably only a handful of shops around the country like Haines, where a store has stayed in the same location, owned by the same family for more than 100 years.
But in the last five years, speciality stores featuring pork have been opening around the country as part of the trend of gearing shops to consumers who want something they can't get in a supermarket.
"We're seeing an emerging trend of more specialization in the marketplace," said Mr. Hockman. "They're looking for something different as evident by the cars we drive, the clothes we wear and the sodas we drink."
Even though pork is third in the types of meat Americans consume -- behind chicken and beef -- it has made a comeback in the last decade, Mr. Hockman said. The successful 14-year-old marketing campaign of "the other white meat" showed consumers that pork producers had created a leaner product, he said. Last year, 54 pounds of pork per person was consumed in the United States, as against 46 pounds in 1996.
Mr. Haines doesn't rely on advertising or marketing to keep his business steady. He considers all stores competition for him, but he hasn't seen his business drop in recent years -- even with the opening of a farmer's market in a neighboring town and new supermarkets dotting the highways.
But it does surprise Mr. Haines that people will travel so far. Customers will often tell him that they remember coming to the store with their parents or grandparents.
One of them is Connie Starr, who drives 30 minutes from Bellmawr every six to eight weeks to get pork roasts. Last month she came by to order her Easter ham. The shop usually sells about 500 hams the week before Easter and even more during the Christmas season.
"It's chaos near Easter, but it's still worth it," Ms. Starr said. "I'll buy anything he has. I love it. It's a family thing. I've never gone anywhere else to get my pork products. When you bring your kids in here, they're in awe of it."
Sue Costill, the town clerk of East Greenwich, who lives down the road from the shop, said she is used to folks stopping and asking her where "that pork store" is.
Mr. Haines says he didn't plan to spend his life in the family business. He received a master's degree from Cornell in agricultural economics, and thought he would work for a large company. But in the 1960's -- when farming became tougher economically -- his father began concentrating on the retail business and in the early 1970's asked his son to help run the store.
"I wanted out of the small town and into the real world," he said. "But when I came back, I was glad I did."
Customers like Peg Manochi of Haddonfield, who are willing to drive 25 miles to get there, are the heart of the business. Ms. Manochi was brought to the shop by a neighbor five years ago and has been coming back regularly ever since.
"I thought I had found pork heaven," she said.

HEADLINE: Fuel Cells: Energy Partners at Odds

BYLINE: By VALERIE COTSALAS 

DATELINE: UPTON

 BODY:
THERE was something about the white canopy covering the rows of metal folding chairs -- and about seeing Christie Brinkley perched on one of those chairs -- that lifted the drab surroundings at the Brookhaven National Laboratory into the surreal.
Ms. Brinkley and her husband, the architect Peter Cook, who are East End homeowners and active environmentalists, recently joined politicians, engineers and reporters to hear Energy Secretary Bill Richardson introduce a cleaner energy technology that seems to have pitted two energy partners against each other. 
 Mr. Richardson was joined by Richard M. Kessel, chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, to announce a joint venture between his department, LIPA and a manufacturer, Plug Power Inc., to bring fuel cells to the Island.
"The rise of heating oil and gas prices has provided the nation with a real challenge," Secretary Richardson said. "This fuel cell technology offers such promise: turning natural gas directly into electricity."
Fuel cells are fed a constant supply of natural gas, which is converted to electricity in a chemical process with no combustion. The cells create little pollution: a relatively small amount of carbon dioxide. The major byproducts are water and heat, which can be used for heating.
A seven-kilowatt fuel cell will power the average home and provide enough heat to keep it warm in winter. Three cells have been installed at a B.N.L. laboratory building in a trial, and tests are planned at the Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, Hofstra University in Hempstead and the State University of New York at Stony Brook.
"We have to have a variety in our engineering mix so that we're not dependent on oil and fossil fuels," Mr. Kessel said.
But life is rarely that simple, as any visitor will learn at the small model of a fuel cell in the Hicksville offices of KeySpan Energy. KeySpan owns the plants that provide electricity to LIPA customers; LIPA maintains the transmission lines.
More than a week before the Brookhaven ceremony, KeySpan announced its own fuel cell program, with one cell to be installed in late summer at the New York Institute of Technology in Westbury. This cell is also made by Plug Power, of Latham, N.Y., and distributed by GE MicroGen.
Now KeySpan is claiming exclusive rights to provide fuel cells on the Island.
"We have an agreement with GE that gives us the opportunity to test 30 of their units on Long Island," said David Manning, senior vice president of KeySpan Energy. "By the end of that testing cycle, we have the right to become the exclusive utility provider of these units."
But LIPA also believes it can win an exclusive agreement to distribute the cells after it tests six of the units.
"We do have an agreement with GE MicroGen for the testing of prototype fuel cell units, and that agreement does contain the possibility of an exclusive commercial relationship in the future," said Bert J. Cunningham, LIPA's vice president for communications. He added that any agreement would require approval by the utility's board and the state comptroller.
Deepening the confusion, GE MicroGen, whose brand name is on the cells, denies having an exclusive agreement with either company.
"Essentially, what KeySpan has is an agreement to test fuel cell systems," said GE MicroGen's president, Barry Glickman. "During the time they're testing equipment, KeySpan and GE MicroGen will continue discussing KeySpan's role in distributing fuel cell systems. It is similar to the agreement contemplated with LIPA."
Two things are at stake: local control of a technology that may replace central power plants and move the source of electricity directly into the home, and the profits that could come from such control.
While KeySpan pipelines would still be needed to feed household cells with natural gas or some other fuel, the cells themselves are much more reliable than power lines. The efficiency of the cells is also much higher than the turbine-powered plants that supply power now.
"Our initial unit produces electricity only, so we're not capturing the excess heat, so it operates at only 40 percent efficiency," said Plug Power's president and chief executive, Gary Mittleman. "When combined with a furnace and water heater, we're looking at 80 to 90 percent efficiency. Nowadays, power plants operate at 30 to 50 percent efficiency, but the heat escapes. We can capture that waste heat and put it to use."
There is wide agreement that the biggest obstacle to the cells is economic rather than technical. The cost of one seven-kilowatt cell is $7,000 to $10,000, a considerable amount even when weighed against increased efficiency and higher reliability. Mr. Mittleman said that in the next few years, Plug Power expects to bring the cost under $5,000. The key, he added, is mass production, a goal that has not yet been reached.
Still, the increased demand for power and the recently highlighted dependency on foreign oil have created an urgency for alternative fuel sources. The reliability of a cell installed directly in the home is also appealing.
Last winter, a power failure in New York City exposed the fallibility of backup generators in hospitals and other institutions. At Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, for example, AIDS research experiments were lost when the hospital lost power.
Environmental groups like Standing for Truth About Radiation, which has rallied to shut down nuclear research reactors at Brookhaven, are pleased with the fuel cell trials, which explains the presence of Ms. Brinkley and Mr. Cook at Mr. Richardson's ceremony: They are members of STAR.
"The future is now," Ms. Brinkley said from her folding chair. "It's here. This is a cure for energy needs and for a clean environment for future generations."

HEADLINE: Turnaround Specialist At Helm of Guild Hall

BYLINE: By BARBARA DELATINER 

DATELINE: EAST HAMPTON

 BODY:
IN her career as a curator and museum director in Alabama, Virginia, Minnesota and Connectictut, Ruth Stevens Appelhof, the new executive director of Guild Hall, earned a reputation as a turnaround specialist.
She took a limited local museum in Roanoke, Va., and transformed it into a cultural and educational center for the western part of the state. 
 At the Minnesota Museum of American Art in St. Paul, she sold its unused Art Deco building, deaccessioned the half of its collection that had nothing to do with "American art" to buy "American art," and turned its scattered galleries in an old courthouse into a permanent exhibition space. In Farmington, Conn., under her guidance, the little-known Theodore Hope Riddle Hill-Stead Museum, a moribund historic home-museum with what she called "an outstanding collection of French Impressionist paintings," became a regional cultural force.
Although Guild Hall, the arts center here, was not in dire straits when she took over in September, it did need "to look for fresh directions to amplify what we have achieved and help us be better hooked into our changing audience," said William Dryer, who headed the search committee that chose Ms. Appelhof.
After seven months on the job, Ms. Appelhof's presence is being felt as she sets about bringing "some serious revitalization" to the organization, which has an annual budget of $1.8 million. For the first time in about 20 years, Guild Hall is launching a formal capital campaign to renovate -- "I prefer 'restore,' " she said -- the building, which dates to 1931. The architect Robert A. M. Stern has been hired to spruce up the theater and figure out how the premises can be better used.
In an initial step, the original fireplaces in the two major galleries were rescued from behind plasterboard and period wainscotting was returned to the walls.
"The idea of expansion is debatable," Ms. Appelhof said. "I don't think we can enlarge our footprint, but perhaps we can move our collection storage off site and reconfigure the use of what space we have."
The mother of two adult children, Ms. Appelhof, in her "mid-50's," said that her "passion is education." She said she believes that "education eventually will be the umbrella or glue that holds it all together," and the position of education director has been made full time. There's a new director of development on board and the part-time public relations coordinator has become the full-time director of marketing.
Her input for the summer season has been minimal because most of it was set before the arrival of Ms. Appelhof, who says she is "committed to contemporary art and artists." The major shows, "American Impressionism: Treasures From the Smithsonian American Museum," June 17 through July 30, and "Willem de Kooning: In Process," Aug. 12 through Oct. 8, are both traveling.
In the future, said Ms. Appelhof, a native of Washington, D.C., who earned her undergraduate and graduate degress at Syracuse University and taught at Syracuse and the State University of New York at Auburn, she wants to "make exhibitions more scholarly and more accessible to all people with perhaps, talks in the galleries. Another thing we have to explore is the possibility of mounting exhibits that will then travel."
Similarly, while she was peripherally involved with the summer plans for the theater, she did not want to "turn it upside down." The same format in place last summer with days identified for specific programs is again being used. So Sundays will be devoted to the "American Musical Theater," Tuesdays to films about art and Thursdays to independent films provided by the Lincoln Center Film Society. There will be play readings by the Blue Heron Theater Company and the Abingdon Theater Company, and in the season's major departure, "Cabaret by the Sea," there will be a Friday and Saturday series of cabaret performances by such artists as Michael Feinstein, Betty Buckley and Patti LuPone.
The idea is "to build the vessel that holds this programming," she said. "And if the vessels aren't working you have to redefine the programs."
Her biggest challenge in trying to infuse Guild Hall with "new life, a renaissance after years and years of doing things the same way," she said is to find out "who Guild Hall serves." With that in mind she spent the month of March researching the community; talking to local organizations and running focus groups.
The East End community, Ms. Appelhof said, has changed since the 1970's when as a college student she spent the summer in the Springs with Lee Krasner, compiling a bibliography about the artist. Ms. Appelhof and her second husband, Gary Adamek, an executive with Ralston Purina, are building a house in the Springs. In the short time she has lived in rented quarters she has begun to realize just how different the area is. These days, retirees make up a sizeable, vocal segment of the population; year-round residents have increased, there is more ethnic, economic and racial diversity.
"We have to generate a new vision, reinvent ourselves around the people we serve," she said.
"I'd been on the job just a few weeks when I had a particularly bad day and one of the trustees noticed and told me not to get so upset. 'No matter what you do, Guild Hall will still be here,' he told me. I know that, but just the same I'd like to make a difference while I'm here."

HEADLINE: Early Planning for a Final Resting Place

BYLINE: By ROBBIE WOLIVER 

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON STATION

 BODY:
IT'S Saturday morning and Route 110 is becoming congested with drivers window-shopping from their cars. DVD's from the Wiz? A printer from Office Max? A coffin from Direct Casket?
There it is, in a small strip mall, sandwiched between a check-cashing business and a one-hour photo shop: a store boasting "Caskets at wholesale prices." 
 Inside, an elderly woman speaks with the owner, Kevin Gray. She is coffin-shopping for her terminally ill brother-in-law. "The casket is not that important," Mr. Gray tells her. "It's just the vehicle to place the deceased in."
"My sister is under terrible stress now," the woman explained later in the parking lot. "There are so many different prices and styles. After being married 60 years, she'll be in no shape to figure these things out when he dies."
The woman had already spoken with McCourt & Trudden, a family-owned funeral home in Farmingdale operated by a longtime friend of her brother-in-law. Direct Casket was half the price, she said, hoping the home would match it.
"She came back to us and we showed her our prices were identical," said Joseph Trudden, the funeral home's owner and spokesman for the Nassau-Suffolk Funeral Directors Association. "They're planning the funeral with us."
The lucrative business of death has become highly competitive.
In the Direct Casket store, Diana Krall's soft jazz vocals stream through the bright, airy showroom as customers scrutinize the 20 different styles of coffins. In an open office in the rear, Mr. Gray, 41, from Dix Hills, patiently speaks with customers who are, for the most part, pragmatic and calm.
Mr. Gray's typical customers are 50-year-olds making arrangements for their parents. The older customers are the curiosity seekers.
There seems to be plenty of money around, as baby boomers in the United States prepare to inherit an estimated $10 trillion from their parents, and people in the business say it is time to think about planning for -- and prepaying for -- the parents' funerals.
Kelly Smith, spokesman for the National Funeral Directors Association, said: "Prepayment and preplanning is the big trend. There's about $23 billion in 'pre-need policies' now." Mr. Trudden has 300 such arrangements on file.
There are 108 funeral homes on Long Island. An average traditional Roman Catholic funeral costs about $7,500, including coffin, wake, Mass and service but not burial charges, Mr. Smith said. Traditional Jewish funerals have few extras -- no flowers, for example -- and according to Gutterman's Funeral Home in Huntington, a Jewish funeral averages around $5,000.
Mr. Gray, who has also started a funeral business, Direct Family Funerals Inc., said his average funeral was around $3,500, including coffin.
Funerals in the United States, including burial charges, make up a $25 billion-a-year business, covering about 2.5 million deaths, and price mark-ups at some funeral parlors can run as high as 350 percent, according to the Funeral Consumers Alliance.
The Department of Commerce says mortuaries have had the lowest bankruptcy rate of any type of business. That may be changing; the Loewen Group Inc., a large consolidator of funeral homes, filed for bankruptcy last June.
The economics of funerals produces much back and forth between funeral parlors and retail coffin dealers like Mr. Gray, who said, "Wholesale prices of coffins is often quadrupled and tax is added in to determine the pretax funeral-home price."
Mr. Trudden disagreed: "Maybe the ones he dealt with, but that's simply not true."
Consumer advocates say that at many mortuaries, renting a hearse for two hours, which costs as little as $25 to provide, is billed to the bereaved at $300 to $400 or more; flowers, grave vaults, monuments and thank-you cards are all marked up three times the amount of cost. With a cemetery plot, which can cost between $2,000 to $3,000, and all the associated fees, a funeral can be one of the largest family purchases.
The rise in burial costs is a big factor in the increase in cremations, which run from $500 to $1,500. Cremations account for more than 25 percent of funerals, and are rising 10 percent a year, the Funeral Consumers Alliance estimates.
Real estate prices also attract diverse views.
Although prepaying for a cemetery plot is generally regarded as wise, Bonnie Tippy, executive director of the New York State Funeral Directors Association, said Long Islanders need not fear a shortage. "There's plenty of space," she said.
Not so, according to Helen Sutter, manager of the 10-acre Plain Lawn Cemetery in Hicksville. "New graves will be closed out within a year," she said. "Mausoleum space will run out in five or six years." If families already have plots at Plain Lawn, she said, "we can bury three deep."
Many funeral directors inherited family businesses, and Mr. Gray's father, Larry, a former Borscht Belt comedian, introduced him to the world of coffins. As a teenager, Mr. Gray stocked shelves with embalming fluid, restorative wax and plastic goods ("to wrap the deceased so there is no leakage") at his father's warehouse.
But, as he soon realized, "The big money was in caskets."
In the mid-1980's, the younger Mr. Gray started his own business selling "kosher caskets" -- those that complied with strict Jewish regulations, for example, that they be wood. "I had a very nice run for a while," he said.
But then funeral-home consolidation took hold. Publicly owned companies like Service Corporation International began buying up family-owned businesses like the I. J. Morris and O. B. Davis homes. (The company now owns 4,000 funeral homes in 18 countries.) Many were Mr. Gray's customers. Data gathered by New York City indicated that funeral costs rose by 25 percent at homes that were taken over by such consolidators.
In 1994 the Federal Trade Commission amended the Funeral-Rule Law, prohibiting handling fees for coffins bought from retailers and thus opening a path for entrepreneurs.
Mr. Gray opened his first coffin store in California and by 1997 he had two others in Southern California and one in Long Island City. He now has stores in New Hyde Park, Brooklyn and Huntington Station. "I've spawned all the stores popping up now," he said.
Eighty percent of his customers are in immediate need, he said; the other 20 percent are planning ahead. Mr. Gray, who advertises a 24-hour emergency number and has a Web site (www.directcasket.com), said he received "about three to five customers a day."
He has no love for funeral homes. "I know all their tricks," he said, adding that he is "despised" by the funeral-home business for undercutting their prices.
"Funeral homes alter your frame of reference," Mr. Gray said. "They arrange their showrooms to manipulate customers, who are often in shock, into spending more than they want. They show you the cheapest casket in the most hideous manner, directing customers to higher-priced caskets."
To which Mr. Trudden responded: "That's complete hogwash. We know all our customers. Everyone's treated first class. Those retail stores can't provide our personal service."
Ms. Tippy, of the funeral directors' group, said that although "the competition is healthy for the consumer," the full service offered by funeral homes can not be matched by retail stores.
In Mr. Gray's 1,300-square-foot showroom, the Hamilton, a silver-colored steel casket, stands at the entrance, priced at $645. An I. J. Morris spokesman said that that home sold a comparable one for $1,495, but Mr. Trudden said his price was only about $5 more than Mr. Gray's.
Direct Casket's most expensive coffin, the solid bronze Dartmouth, sells for $3,695, and although Mr. Gray said it would sell for $7,000 at a funeral home, Mr. Trudden said he sold it for the same price as Direct Casket.
A 30-something woman, her father and aunt entered Caskets Direct recently to make arrangements for the imminent death of the young woman's mother. A curious Huntington couple in their 60's soon followed; they wanted to plan ahead so their "children wouldn't be burdened."
State law requires that prepayments be placed in interest-bearing trusts that are fully refundable at any time. When the party dies and the coffin is used, the coffin store or funeral parlor can keep the interest.
Whatever the financial arrangements, the competition will only grow. In a recent poll by the National Funeral Directors Association, 14 percent of those surveyed used the services of a retail coffin store, and because of high-profile stores like the one on Route 110, the trend seems to be growing.
It is not a very friendly competition.
"Retail stores are not there for you in a full-service way," said Mr. Trudden, who is also mayor of Farmingdale. "We're part of the community. We're there 24 hours a day, every day. Just don't die on a Sunday if you buy from a retail casket store."
Mr. Gray laughed off the criticism. "I see people on their worst day," he said. "I'm here to make this emotionally and financially easy for them."

HEADLINE: The View From/New Haven;
Open to Suggestions On Vision for the Parks

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to visions of what New Haven parks might look like 10 years from now, there are plenty of visionaries.
Dozens of them attended the four meetings that were held in January and February to find out what residents wanted in their parks. The answers were many: paths connecting all the parks so people could in-line skate around the city; litter bags at park entrances so people could clean up after their pets, and after other, less thoughtful, humans; parks open after sunset during the summer. There were also socioeconomic themes: equal access to parks in all neighborhoods, and more youth programs. 
 Those at the meetings generally gave the department high marks, but said there was room for improvement. The city has hired a consultant, Leon Younger & PROS, to create a 10-year plan for the city's Department of Parks, Recreation and Trees.
Bob Schmalz, a New Haven alderman and president of the Board of Park Commissioners, said a master plan for the parks was done 40 years ago and updated about 20 years ago.
"We agreed that the parks had gone way down during the budget cutting of the early 90's," Mr. Schmalz said, adding that they have become a top priority for Mayor John DeStefano Jr. "Now we want to look at facilities, services and manpower. Should we do any privatizing? Should we acquire more land, as some areas are being cleared of buildings, to build tot lots and pocket parks?"
The plan has been ordered by the mayor and is being implemented by the director of the parks department, Robert D. Levine.
The city has 91 parks and playgrounds on more than 2,200 acres. Over the past few years, the city has restored all 25 percent of parks department jobs that were cut in the recession of the early 1990's, Mr. Levine said, bringing the current total to 104. The operating budget went from $3.5 million in 1993 to more than $5.7 million this year, while capital expenditures went from zero in 1993 to $2.6 million this year.
Hundreds of residents have participated in meetings, focus groups and a survey to determine what people want from their parks.
The focus groups revealed that New Haven residents value their parks, but that greater public awareness would enhance that value. Other suggestions from the focus groups included upgrading existing buildings before building new ones; gearing new programs toward families; addressing the city's waterfront, the most underdeveloped resource in the parks system; giving more attention to greenways and small parks in the inner city, and purchasing land whenever possible.
Chris and Rosemary Ozyck live with their young daughter in the Fair Haven neighborhood, on a street that parallels the Quinnipiac River. Ms. Ozyck said the two parks near her house, Quarry and Fairmont, are not well maintained and are often deserted. "I don't feel comfortable going there," she said. "Maybe the city doesn't think people care about the parks, but if it maintained them, then maybe people would care."
Mr. Ozyck has for years been a proponent of creating greenways to connect parks around the city, on the model of Frederick Law Olmsted's work in New York City and Boston.
He and his neighbors are focusing on the waterways as well. "The rivers have been underutilized throughout the city," he said, despite the recent success of the city's Riverkeeper program, which has enabled hundreds of people to go canoeing on the city's three rivers.
Mr. Ozyck and other Quinnipiac Avenue residents are urging the parks department to build and staff a boathouse on the Quinnipiac River. They said the area is underserved because it has no park ranger. They have even identified a potential site -- a parcel of land across the river from a small park that fronts the river on the other side. "You would have one park mirroring the other," he said.
Of the four meetings held around the city, the last one, at Wilbur Cross High School in the East Rock section, drew the largest, but also the least diverse, group of residents. That highlighted a problem the long-term plan hopes to address: how to get those who do not use the parks involved.
Peter Noble arrived near the end of the meeting, having just finished volleyball practice with the Latino youngsters he works with from the nearby Fair Haven neighborhood.
"You don't see these kids' parents at this meeting," said Mr. Noble, but he assured those in attendance that working-class Hispanic families want access to parks and recreational facilities for their children. He then described specific improvements to equalize access, with an emphasis on building a variety of playing fields.
A phone and mail survey of 950 residents is being conducted as part of the process, incorporating the issues identified in earlier phases.
"People who came to the meetings tended to be those who already are familiar with the parks, but the survey will look at both users and non-users," said Leon Younger, head of Leon Younger & PROS, the consultant. He said it was just as important to know why people are not using the parks as why they are.
"If the park system is only touching a small number of people, why is that? Is it that people don't feel safe? Don't they know about the programs, or do the programs not meet their needs?
"The park system needs to have amenities that are attractive to diverse groups," Mr. Younger continued. "Programs drive design. When you know what the program is, you design facilities to meet the needs of the community. But you have to ask them."
The consultants want a plan that incorporates the city's history and values, but also one that generates income.
"The consultants identified 45 possible revenue sources for the parks department," said Mr. Levine, the parks director, "and we are using only three or four."
Mr. Schmalz of the Board of Park Commissioners said he was excited about the process, which will culminate this fall with proposals to execute the plan.
"We are going to come out of this with not just a volume of pretty pictures to put on a shelf," he said, "but with a land-use plan."

HEADLINE: Spano Urges Reducing Use of Pesticides in County

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
SAYING the first family's move to Chappaqua has brought unprecedented attention to Westchester, County Executive Andrew J. Spano declared last week that the county must now act to protect the quality of life that received worldwide exposure.
One way to do so, Mr. Spano said in his State of the County address Wednesday, is to reduce the use of toxic pesticides that threaten the county's drinking water. 
 "Westchester property owners use more pesticides on their lawns and gardens than residents from almost any other county," he said. "But our extreme pesticide use is, in fact, a health hazard, and we must take measures to reduce it."
He is drafting legislation to reduce or eliminate the use of toxic pesticides on county property and parkland, he said, adding, "We must get our homeowners to reduce their use of pesticides on their lawns, trees and shrubs."
This would be voluntary, and he said he would create a position of water master in the Planning Department to coordinate a public awareness effort and other measures to protect the quality of drinking water.
"When the President and Mrs. Clinton moved to Westchester, we were besieged by reporters from all over the world who only knew of our image," Mr. Spano said. "To some, we were a small bedroom community to the north of New York City. To others, we were the land of the rich and famous."
But that image is not the whole picture, he said, and Westchester should be a model for the rest of the country "in protecting our children, protecting our drinking water, protecting the health of our families and protecting our quality of life."
In his speech, Mr. Spano, a Democrat, sounded like a candidate for re-election as he outlined the accomplishments of his administration in its first two-plus years and set forth a blueprint for the rest of the four-year term. He renewed a pledge to reduce county taxes while continuing or beginning programs to fight tobacco and drug use and drunken driving and to protect children and the elderly.
"Our finances are excellent," Mr. Spano said. "Our economy is booming. Our environment is cleaner. Our cities are energized. And our quality of life is second to none."
Saying he had accomplished all this "by making government better, not bigger," Mr. Spano added: "Later this year, I will submit a budget that will for the first time in Westchester history reduce taxes for a third consecutive year. We are doing this while maintaining our triple-A credit rating."
The speech before an audience of about 150 in the legislative chambers at the County Office Building here lasted about 55 minutes and came after a 15-minute video presentation that dealt with what Mr. Spano saw as his accomplishments. The speech was also broadcast on cable television's News 12 and on the Internet.
When he ran in 1997, Mr. Spano promised to cut the county tax rate by 15 percent over four years, but so far he has only been able to cut it by 2.5 percent. A complex plan enacted last December to borrow money that the county has been awarded from lawsuits against the tobacco industry is expected to help Mr. Spano come closer to fulfilling his promise.
In his speech, Mr. Spano voiced many traditional Democratic themes. Here are some of the highlights:
*Personal safety. Mr. Spano said he would continue efforts to prevent gun violence, observing that he recently drafted legislation making it a crime to take a gun within 1,500 feet of a school. He described various outreach programs to persuade young people not to smoke and to prevent drunken driving and said the county has acquired narcotics-sniffing dogs to help the local police.
*Children. The county will establish a countywide child abuse investigative team, which will include police officers trained to recognize abuse. The county, he said, is also beginning a program to help unemployed fathers find jobs so they can pay child support.
*Seniors. Reporting that one in five Westchester residents is over 65, Mr. Spano said the county is in the midst of a two-year survey of the needs of the elderly. In the meantime, he vowed that the county would fight for reform of health maintenance organization procedures and lower costs for prescription drugs.
Democrats on the Democratic-controlled Board of Legislators praised the speech, seeing in it proof of their own accomplishments as well as that of Mr. Spano. Republicans said it was big on rhetoric and short on substance.
"He effectively summarized the administration and legislature's accomplishments," said Michael B. Kaplowitz, a Democrat from Somers. Vito J. Pinto, a Democrat from Tuckahoe, said he was pleased with what he heard about helping the elderly and protecting the environment.
But James Maisano, a Republican of New Rochelle, said it was a typical "state of" kind of speech in that it sounded like a campaign speech but lacked substance. Paul J. Noto, a Republican of Mamaroneck, the minority leader, said, "All these programs have a price tag, and there may come a day we don't have the money for them."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
10 Projects Will Produce 2,900 New Hotel Rooms

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
AS the economic boom keeps rolling across New Jersey, so does the march of hotels, despite a modest dip in occupancy rates and a supply that is growing faster than the demand for rooms.
Over the 12 months ended in February the occupancy rate in the state's hotels was 67.2 percent, down 2 percent from the previous one-year period. At the same time, while the supply of rooms grew by 2.8 percent, overall demand rose by only 0.6 percent, according to Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn. The national occupancy rate for the same period was 63.1 percent, down 0.8 percent from the prior year. 
 Joseph A. Simonetta, the executive vice president of the New Jersey Hotel and Motel Association in Trenton, said the "huge spikes" of the past were not sustainable. Even so, the occupancy rate is high when compared with other states, he said, adding, "These are still good times for the industry."
And with the average daily room rate at $94.44, an increase of 3.9 percent from last year, developers continue to build, evidenced by 10 projects that are just opening, that are now under way or that will be by fall. Together, they will have a total of about 2,900 rooms.
Although more projects are planned, in New Jersey, as in the nation, "there are fewer projects entering in the pipeline," said Patrick Ford Sr., the president of Lodging Econometrics, a division of National Hotel Realty in Portsmouth, N.H. He said the slowdown started with the tightening of credit in the fall of 1998.
At first, there was a "significant drop-off," Mr. Ford said, and since then there has been a modest decline. "Money is getting more expensive," he said. "Projects that looked great 18 months ago may not pencil out today."
Other factors that will keep the industry in balance, analysts said, are the influx of companies expanding within New Jersey or relocating to the state, to take advantage of the number of new office buildings that are going up. Tourism in the state also has increased, generating $27.7 billion in revenue last year, up 6 percent from 1998. The number of overnight trips rose 10 percent to 43.8 million, according to state figures.
As might be expected, many of the new hotels are sprouting or being planned along highways, close to commercial centers or in resorts like Atlantic City, where the Boyd Gaming Corporation of Las Vegas expects to begin construction late this summer on a new casino with about 1,200 hotel rooms. Called the Borgata, it will be in the style of a Tuscan village.
The new hotels will also be near transportation hubs like Newark International Airport, where 10 hotels are planned. The largest project, being advanced by Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus, calls for a full-service hotel with as many as 550 rooms, a limited-service hotel with 250 rooms, a 50,000-square-foot conference center and a 150,000-square-foot office building. They will rise on a 55-acre site, 1,000 feet from the airport and accessible to Route 1 and 9.
Following the trend of the last few years, much of the new construction will be extended-stay and limited-service hotels. Typically, they do not have the large restaurants, shops and the abundance of meeting rooms found in full-service hotels. Ronald C. Witt, the president of Sweetwater Construction Corporation of Cranbury, put the cost of such limited-service hotels at $40,000 to $45,000 a room, which is 20 to 30 percent lower than the cost of building full-service hotels. "There's a rush to put up limited-service hotels," said Mr. Witt, whose company is involved in four such projects in the state, including a 146-room Hampton Inn on Route 9 in Woodbridge.
John A. Fox, a senior vice president at PKF, a hotel and real estate consulting concern in New York, said the proliferation of limited-service hotels caused supply to outpace demand. But, he said, since "markets are localized and site-specific," there are areas where such hotels are still warranted.
That is the thinking of Ocean Properties, of Portsmouth N.H., which is developing a 144-room Courtyard by Marriott in South Brunswick. "We look at the statistics, but don't live and breathe them," said Julie Jacques, the company's construction coordinator. "The Courtyard brand caters to business travelers, and this area is an opportune place for it."
THE hotel, to open in September on Route 32 near Exit 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike, is surrounded by millions of square feet of office and warehouse space, which Ms. Jacques expects to supply the hotel's weekday business. Because the hotel is also near the Forsgate Country Club, she said it should also be busy on weekends, with weddings and other social events.
In Edison, a growing office market in the center of the state, plans are advancing for a 146-room Courtyard by Marriott. "The bottom line is that New Jersey has some 156 million square feet of office space, so we go where the ducks are," said Buddy Watson, the president of Watson Hospitality Associates of Charlotte, N.C., the hotel's developer. "There are opportunities, but not all brands, or locations, will work."
The hotel will be part of a larger project on Woodbridge Avenue, near Exit 10 of the turnpike and Interstate 287, that will also include a 167,500-square-foot office building. "We see the hotel as a great amenity," said Robert Paulus, the president of Wick Companies of Woodbridge, which is developing the office building. Construction is to start this summer.
Markets close to Manhattan with large pools of corporate tenants are also attracting development, including full-service hotels. One is in Rutherford, where work is nearing completion on a 164-room Marriott Renaissance Hotel on Rutherford Avenue, near Routes 3 and 17. "The demand may be ebbing for limited-service hotels, but it's still strong for full-service lodgings," said Richard Branca, the president of Branca Properties of East Rutherford, which is developing the hotel.
At Veterans Boulevard and Highland Cross, also in Rutherford, plans are advancing for a 200-room full-service hotel as part of a two-building, 900,000-square-foot office complex to be developed by Lincoln Equities Group of Rutherford. The complex will rise across Veterans Boulevard from two occupied office buildings, with 565,000 square feet, that Lincoln already owns.
The Hudson River Waterfront in Jersey City is also attracting its share of activity. One hotel will open later this month and at least two full-service hotels are planned. Here, as elsewhere, the attraction is the millions of square feet of occupied offices.
The opening of the 189-room Courtyard by Marriott will bring the first hotel to the huge Newport mixed-used center at the northern end of the Jersey City waterfront. Now, the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park Queens, Newport's developer, is also planning a 415-room full-service hotel.
It is not alone. The Mack-Cali Realty Corporation of Cranford will begin development this summer on a 350-room Hyatt Hotel at its Harborside office complex at the southern end of the Jersey City riverfront. Reinforcing the hotel will be Mack-Cali's construction of a 185,000-square-foot office building for TD Waterhouse.
Mr. Ford of Lodging Econometrics said more attention is being given these days to downtown hotels, some of which are being built with public funds.
That is the case for two New Jersey projects. One is a $100 million mixed-used project, including a 200-room Benchmark hotel, that the nonprofit New Brunswick Development Authority will build with public and private financing in partnership with the Advance Group of Bedminster. The 15-story building will also include retail space, 198 rental apartments and the John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development, part of Rutgers University. It will rise on a triangular site, occupied by an old hotel that will be razed, bounded by Livingston Avenue and George and New Streets. Construction is to start this fall.
In Trenton, the city plans to build a 197-room hotel and conference center at Lafayette and Warren Streets. It will be linked to the Trenton War Memorial auditorium.
The $46 million hotel will be financed mostly from the sale of bonds, said Robert Powell, the managing director at Nassau Capital Advisors of Princeton, a consultant to the city. He said construction of the hotel, to be operated by Marriott, will start by the end of April. When it is completed in 22 months, Trenton will no longer have the distinction of being the only state capital without a hotel.

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

Lost at Sea
The strange story of Donald Crow hurst, an English businessman who took part in a 1969 sailboat race around the world in spite of being poorly equipped and wihout experience, has been has been told in an opera for solo voice called "Ravenshead."
It will be performed in Palmer Auditorium of Connecticut College in New London this evening at 7:30, and in Hartford at the Austin Arts Center of Trinity College on Friday and Saturday at 8. 
 Crowhurst recorded his voyage in two log books -- one containing the actual problems and mechanical failures he experienced, the other an idealized version of what he had hoped the journey would be. Six months after his departure, his empty boat was found adrift in the Atlantic.
Rinde Eckert wrote the piece as an exploration of the psyche of a man who could not reconcile his real and imagined selves. He will sing the role of Crowhurst, accompanied by the Paul Drescher Ensemble's Electro-Acoustic Band. The score was composed by Steven Mackey, professor of music at Princeton University, and the production was directed by Tony Taccone, artistic director of the Berkeley Repertory Theater in California.
Tickets at $15 to $25 may be reserved by calling Connecticut College, (860) 439-2787, or Trinity College, (860) 297-2199.
 
Dolphin Talk
Dr. Kathleen Dudzinski swims with dolphins and records their communications with each other on an audio-video device that she invented. Her research is featured in the new IMAX movie "Dolphins," at the Norwalk Aquarium through Sept. 28.
She will give a slide-talk at the aquarium on Wednesday at 7:30.
The 33-year-old Meriden native has been the recipient of awards from the National Science Foundation and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science. She is vice-president of the Ocean Conservation Society and director of its Dolphin Communication Project, and she has written a children's book called "Meeting Dolphins: My Adventures in the Sea," published by National Geographic Books.
Tickets to the lecture are $10 for adults, $9 for seniors, and $8 for children 2 through 12. The aquarium is at 10 North Water Street in South Norwalk, and the phone number for tickets or more information is (203) 852-0700, extension 206.

Emancipated Spirit
"Birth Rite: Sex, Drugs and a Restless Soul," an autobiographical one-woman show, was written and will be performed by Elizabeth Hess at Real Art Ways in Hartford from Thursday through April 30. It follows her painful transition from a rigid Mennonite childhood in Canada through a series of self-destructive episodes as a teenager and a college student, in London and New York, eventually leading to her emancipation as a free spirit.
The play was directed by Richard Caliban, and Ms. Hess's unusual costuming is by Marc R. Aubin. It consists of a skirt, blouse, jacket and shawl that transmogrify in step with the various stages of her emergence from repressed little girl to sexually and spirtually reborn woman.
Performances are on Thursday through Saturday at 8, Sunday at 3. Tickets are $18. Real Art Ways is at 56 Arbor Street, and the phone number for reservations or more information is (860) 232-1006.

Mediterranean Jews
The little- known history of Mediterranean merchant Jews of the Middle Ages will be revealed in a talk by Dr. Mark Cohen, professor of Near Eastern studies at Princeton University, next Sunday at 10 a.m. at Temple Israel in Westport.
Contracts and letters detailing a sophisticated international trade that formed the bedrock of middle-class Jewish life in the Mediterranean countries from the 9th to the 16th century were found in an old Cairo synagogue in the late 1800's but never translated and analyzed until now. Dr. Cohen will talk about the background of the so-called Geniza documents and their historical significance.
Admission will be $5 and include a light breakfast of Sephardic snacks and bagels and lox. Temple Israel's address is 24 Coleytown Road and the phone number for more information is (203) 227-1293.

Chinese Puppet Play
UConn's Repertory Theater is presenting the premiere of "The Bell," by Hua Hua Zhang, as its spring production. The puppet play, suitable for children from the age of 12 and adults of all ages, is drawn from Chinese mythology in which a bell is built by three people as a symbol of joy and unity in their community. But misunderstandings eventually destroy their utopian little world.
Ms. Zhang, a Master of Fine Arts candidate at UConn's unique Puppet Arts Program, trained in China and was one of the leading performers in the China Puppet Arts Troupe of Beijing.
She took part in the troupe's 33-city tour of the United States and Canada, and also additional tours of Thailand and Brazil in the 1990's.
The 13-member cast of "The Bell" was directed by Bart P. Roccoberton Jr., a professional puppeteer for 25 years, and successor to Frank Ballard as head of UConn's Puppet Arts Program.
Original music was composed by Liang Liang.
Performances are scheduled in the Studio Theater of the Drama-Music Building on Tuesday through Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m., and next Sunday at 2 p.m.
Tickets are $14 and $15, with a $3 discount for seniors and a $5 discount for students. Call (860) 486-4226 for reservations or information.

Jazz in Ridgefield
Artt Frank has drummed with the best: Dizzy Gillespie, Miles Davis and, for 20 years, Chet Baker. Mr. Frank will be onstage at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield on Friday from 7 to 9 P.M., joined by Pat Morrisey on trumpet, Ken Barry on tenor sax, Chris Clarke on piano and Phil Bowler on bass. Earla Porch will attend to the vocals.
Mr. Frank removed himself from the jazz scene for four years after Chet Baker's death in 1988, but snapped back with the recording of "Looking for the Light," a tribute to Baker that his widow persuaded Mr. Frank to organize.
Tickets are $15, including wine. The museum is at 258 Main Street. Call (203) 438-4519 for reservations.

'Poorest of Poor'
"The Poorest of the Poor: The Unmet Challenge of Global Development" is the theme of three lectures to be delivered this week from 4 to 5:30 p.m. in Davies Auditorium, 15 Prospect Street, on the Yale University campus in New Haven.
The speakers will be Jeffrey D. Sachs, director of the Center for International Development at Harvard University, and Galen L. Stone, professor of international trade at Harvard's Department of Economics.
The first talk, " Globalization and the Poorest of the Poor: The Limits of Convergence," will be presented on Monday; "Health-Nutrition-Population Nexus: The Scope for Public Action" is scheduled on Tuesday; and the final program, "The Role of International Assistance: A Redesign of International Strageies," will be held on Wednesday.
The series is free. For more information, call (203) 432-3726.

Artistic Complex Simplicity
Alan Magee, an artist whom critics have described as one of America's finest representational painters and a craftsman whose drawings reveal the complex simplicity of everyday things, will lecture on "Skeletons, Stone, Kafka's House and a Paintbox" on Wednesday in New London.
His work is in several major museum across the country. He holds awards from the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters and from the National Academy of Design.
The program is to be held in the Cummings Arts Center of Connecticut College, 270 Mohegan Avenue, at 5:30 p.m. Admission is free.
 ELEANOR CHARLES
