HEADLINE: Fidelity: A Major Investor in Real Estate, Too

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
THE Financial District headquarters of Fidelity Investments, the mutual-fund giant that manages $1 trillion, couldn't be more modest. With no views, low ceilings and a rabbit warren of corridors, the nine-story building where the company was founded 54 years ago gives no hint of the real estate empire that is rising from Fidelity's financial success.
The family-owned and -run company, long downtown Boston's biggest office tenant, is now also poised to become one of its largest commercial property investors and developers. In all, the FMR Corporation, Fidelity's parent, occupies almost 10 million square feet in the United States and abroad, and it owns about seven million square feet. 
 In Boston, FMR owns 3.4 million square feet of downtown office space. Of that, Fidelity Investments occupies 1.25 million square feet, much of it in separate buildings surrounding its headquarters at 82 Devonshire Street. And it leases an additional 1.4 million square feet.
"Now, Fidelity is probably Boston's only major office tenant that is also a major investor and developer," said Thomas J. Hynes, the chief executive of Meredith & Grew Inc./Oncor International, a Boston real estate company.
Fidelity's boldest investment here is the Seaport Center, part of the real estate market emerging along the downtown waterfront. The 2.5-million-square-foot complex includes a convention center with office space that it redeveloped on an old fish pier in the 1980's, a two-year-old hotel and two office towers now under construction. The east tower will open this fall, and the west this summer.
The Seaport Center hotel and towers are the first new buildings that Fidelity has ever put up in Boston, and like most of its real estate investments, is self-financed with company profits. It obtained a 99-year lease on the 8.5-acre site from Massport, the state port authority, and an option on a site for an adjacent third tower.
Unlike its Devonshire Street headquarters, these three new buildings have spectacular views of the harbor and downtown Boston. In July, when the $140 million 16-story east tower opens, it will be the first new office building in downtown Boston since the early 1990's. All told, there are nine projects valued at about $3 billion being built or planned in the hot new Seaport District.
Seventy-eight percent of Fidelity's east tower has already been leased, said Peter E. Masden, the managing director of Pembroke Real Estate, the real estate investment unit of FMR. Given the strength of the office market -- the vacancy rate is 2.9 percent and rents are reaching into the $60-a-square-foot range -- Fidelity will not itself occupy space there. "The leasing is too good," Mr. Masden said.
Mr. Hynes of Meredith & Grew said: "Fidelity focuses on what's cost-effective in deciding between leasing, owning and occupying. And it has the in-house talent to do it all well."
Besides the lure of substantial returns -- downtown Boston real estate values went up about 70 percent in the last six years, city assessors say -- Fidelity's rapid growth has made the accumulation of real estate expertise imperative. It now has 30,162 employees, about third of them working in Boston. In 1990, it had 7,000 employees, two-thirds of them in Boston.
"Our real estate activity is driven by our jobs growth," said David C. Weinstein, Fidelity's chief of administration. "By the mid-1990's, we were bursting at the seams."
SINCE 1990, the company has bought, leased or built space in Manhattan -- 230,000 square feet in the World Financial Center -- and in Rhode Island, New Hampshire, Ohio, Kentucky, Texas, Utah and California, and abroad, in Canada, Bermuda, Britain, Germany, France, Japan and Hong Kong.
Addressing fears that Fidelity might someday abandon Boston, Mr. Weinstein said, "In an economy based on brainpower, we're in the catbird seat here with all the colleges and universities."
The economic slowdown in the late 80's and early 90's presented Fidelity some opportunities for cost-effective expansion.
For instance, during the mid-1990's, it bought 1.6 million square feet of space in Massachusetts and New Hampshire from the Digital Equipment Corporation. And it bought 350 acres to develop a campus in Smithfield, R.I., where it built a 250,000-square-foot office building and is now constructing another slightly larger building, both for its own use.
It's also building in office parks near Dallas and Cincinnati and in Walnut Creek, Calif. In London, it will soon complete construction of a $100 million six-story office building near St. Paul's Cathedral. Mr. Masden said that about half of it is already leased at rents that reach $140 a square foot.
In downtown Boston, where Fidelity still rents the same amount of space it did in 1990, it recently bought two buildings with a total of about 1.1 million square feet for its own use. Last year, it paid $187 million for 245 Summer Street, an 850,000-square-foot building where it now occupies some space and will soon have another 350,000 square feet for expansion. It renovated the second 220,000-square-foot building, 255 State Street, on the waterfront.
Fidelity was a pioneer in the Seaport District. With lenders and tenants still wary from the 1990's real estate crash, Fidelity's ability to self-finance gave it an advantage.
"We're independent of the business cycle," Mr. Masden said, explaining that Fidelity could move ahead with its own projects when other office developers could not find financing.
The company's heft is also helping the entire Seaport District to emerge as a new downtown neighborhood, said William F. McCall Jr., the chief executive of McCall & Almy Inc., a real estate advisory company in Boston. "Everyone knew that once they started building they'd finish without going bankrupt," he said. "Their investment gave the area a huge boost in credibility."
Also helpful is $20 billion in publicly funded infrastructure improvements now under way that have made the waterfront a prime investment opportunity. The Seaport Center sits at what will be a crossroads for a new transportation network. At its front door will be a new tunnel under the harbor, to Logan International Airport; an extension of the Massachusetts Turnpike; a rebuilt downtown expressway; a truck road; and new rapid transit line.
In 1985, after Fidelity was stymied in building a new tower on Devonshire Street, it teamed up with the John Drew Management Company on the Commonwealth Pier project. Together, they redeveloped the fish pier into 700,000 square feet of offices that Fidelity occupies and a 150,000-square-foot exhibition hall for trade shows. At the same time, Fidelity started negotiating with Massport to lease more adjacent land.
In the early 90's, as financially shaky developers were forced to shelve plans, Fidelity continued its site planning and ground-lease negotiations. By 1994, it started to focus on the design of the 247-room Seaport Hotel and broke ground a year later. In 1998, the hotel opened, and Fidelity started building the 505,000-square-foot east tower designed by Shepley Bulfinch Richardson Abbott Architects of Boston.
But for all its real estate activity, the company is still modest about its holdings. The only public acknowledgment of its impressive real estate portfolio is a demure 12-inch bronze plaque with a grayish patina that fades into the masonry around the entrance to its headquarters at 82 Devonshire Street. The plaque is simply engraved: Fidelity Building.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 6; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1283 words

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES;
A Battle Over New Housing In Paterson's Historic District

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: PATERSON

 BODY:
The seven-acre tract of land along the Passaic River, with the ruins of an old brick factory and weather-worn timbers lying amid the knots of scrubby vegetation, does not look much like hallowed ground.
But it is in one of the state's most significant historic districts, and it is at the center of a dispute between the city and a group of preservationists that recently brought a suit against the planning board and a developer over how best to develop the land. 
 The site, stretching along a half-mile of riverfront here in the state's third-largest city, has been in disrepair for more than a decade, the target of vandals. For five years the city has been negotiating with the state and federal government to build 114 units of moderately priced housing.
But the preservation group, Paterson Friends of the Great Falls Inc. -- contending that the city has improperly approved a project that deviates from its redevelopment plan in terms of size and density -- insists something more befitting the cradle of American industry should be erected.
As legend has it, Alexander Hamilton saw the nearby Great Falls of the Passaic and envisioned a national manufactury. With that, Paterson was born as the oldest planned industrial city, and industries sprouted along the river, powered by the falls. Among them was Allied Textile Printing Corp. which gives the seven-acre tract its name, the A.T.P. site.
"Nobody disputes the fact that it's in a ruinous state, and nobody disputes the fact that it needs to be revitalized," said David Soo, a member of Paterson Friends and one of those who brought the suit.
"We believe that this project could be anywhere in Paterson," Mr. Soo said one recent morning as he toured the site, bounded by the Passaic River and Van Houten Street in the Great Falls Historic District. "And this singular, unique place offers an opportunity for economic development unlike anyplace else in the city or the state."
But Mayor Martin G. Barnes, who inherited the project from his predecessor, disagreed with Mr. Soo. "Is it the best possible development for that site?" Mayor Barnes said. "Probably not. But it's the best that we have."
Interviewed at City Hall, Mayor Barnes described the housing situation in Paterson as "bleak." Much of the housing stock is more than 100 years old, he said, while immigrants from Central and South America and Middle Eastern countries continue to flood into the city.
Indeed, officials here say the current Census will show Paterson's population has grown to more than 170,000, up from 140,900 in 1990. There are more than 3,000 vacant lots available for housing construction, but they are mostly small and scattered, planning and development officials say.
"This gives me some much-needed affordable housing," Mayor Barnes said of the ATP plan. "It gives me some ratables. It's the only seven-acre site I've got in the city. And it gets us to build up the downtown area because what we're trying to do is bring a community into downtown. Our downtown closes at 6 o'clock at night."
Under the first phase of the project, which will cost about $14 million, the developer, Regan Development Corporation of Yonkers, plans to put up 57 two-family houses of three and four stories as well as a cafe and public river walk, according to the developer and redevelopment officials.
The second phase, which will cost about $8 million, involves rehabilitating three old mills on Van Houten Street behind the first site to create 15,000 square feet of commercial space and 51 apartments. Part of second phase would also involve rehabilitation of the former Colt gun works -- also in disrepair on the A.T.P. site -- where Samuel Colt perfected his revolver.
The first phase was approved by the planning board here last July after it directed the developer to cut back on the number of two-family houses to 57 from 64 to provide some open space. It formalized the approval in February.
But Mr. Soo and others said there was nothing binding Regan Development to complete the second phase, a concern that the city disputed.
The Paterson Friends of the Great Falls, a group of about 50 residents and preservationists that was formed with the help of the Sierra Club, brought suit last month in state Superior Court in Paterson seeking to revoke the planning board's approval.
"Nothing in the city's redevelopment plan allows what is proposed to be built here," said Bruce D. Greenberg, a Newark lawyer who brought the suit. "The most significant deviations were the density of this development, the number of homes, the height of the buildings and what they call the floor area ratio -- the amount of the site that's covered by construction."
The suit contends that the planning board did not have the authority to approve these exceptions.
"None of that is true," Mayor Barnes said of these arguments. "You know, this is a real frivolous claim."
The suit also claims a deputy mayor who sits on the board should have abstained from voting because Mayor Barnes was an outspoken supporter of the plan.
But underlying the specifics of the complaints is the feeling it is not compatible with the historic character of the site.
Jeffery Jones, a councilman who represents the historic district, said the city had wrongly settled for what was convenient. "If any project comes before me, it's got to have more than just 'it's better than what was there,' " Mr. Jones said. "Anything's better than what's there, provided it gives you a lot more than what you have."
Jeff Tittell, executive director of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club, said because of the new state development plan and "urban revitalization that's sweeping the country," the A.T.P. tract is "probably the most historically important site in New Jersey."
Mr. Tittell said, "It has a great opportunity to be the catalyst for revitalizing this whole historic district and bringing the types of facilities that are going to enhance the city and really make it a better place for all types of other redevelopment.
"And instead of that," he added, "they're just going to be putting in vinyl-sided modular housing."
Larry Regan, the president of Regan Development, took exception to that characterization.
"There is no vinyl on this project," Mr. Regan said. In a telephone interview, he said the buildings will be three and four stories. "The fronts and the sides will be 100 percent brick and the rear will be wood clapboard."
Mr. Regan, who said the project would bring the city $500,000 in ratables the first year, added that his company had been committed to Paterson for more than 20 years, having built 145 units of artists' housing in the rehabilitation of two historic factories in the 1980's.
"This is our business," Mr. Regan said. "We do historic redevelopment and we're in it for the long haul."
What especially troubles critics like Mr. Soo, who lives in one of the artists' houses closest to the A.T.P. site, is that the city never sought requests for proposals from other developers for other uses like a museum, conference center and other cultural or commercial activities.
Francis Blesso, a former redevelopment director for the city, said that there seemed to be no interest when the city took the site over for taxes in the early 1990's.
Allied Textile Printing had closed up shop in the 1970's; a developer had failed to get financing for a mixed-use project at the site in the mid-1980's, and the site fell into further disrepair.
"We were going to do a market analysis and go out and solicit proposals," Mr. Blesso said. "In the meantime, we had been talking to people about different ideas, but nobody stepped forward."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 28; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1216 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Investing in Your Own Backyard: No Sure Bet for Growing Winners

BYLINE: By KATE BERRY 

 BODY:
THINKING about investing in a hometown mutual fund, one that focuses on shares of local companies?
If you live in San Jose or Seattle, you can find something. But if you're in Chattanooga or Buffalo or just about anyplace else in the country, don't even bother looking. 
 In the history of great mutual fund ideas, the regional mutual fund possibly won't rate more than a footnote. Parochialism, it turns out, is a selling point that cuts little ice with many investors, because arbitrarily restricting investments to companies in just one area can hamper returns -- or magnify trouble, as investors in Pacific Northwest-centered funds found out when Microsoft melted down last week.
Of the thousands of mutual fund portfolios tracked by Morningstar Inc., just 34 are United States regional funds, and only 13 of those had enough combined assets -- more than $30 million -- to qualify for The New York Times's mutual funds tables as of last week.
Most of the 34 invest in small and midsize companies, generally growth stocks not widely followed on Wall Street. Assets have grown from $1.15 billion at the end of 1995 to $4.57 billion on March 31.
As for returns, just 6 out of 34 outperformed the 25.73 percent average annual gain of the Standard & Poor's 500 index over the last three calendar years.
The regional funds take a geographical approach to following Peter Lynch's advice about investing in what you know. Their managers believe they know companies in their own backyards better than out-of-town analysts do.
"Being a consumer of the products and knowing people that work at local companies is important," said Bill Whitlow, manager of the $163.8 million Safeco Northwest fund in Seattle, whose largest holding should be easy to guess: Microsoft. The fund gained 54.2 percent last year, and 13.54 percent in the first quarter of 2000, but gave back more than half that gain last week.
Mr. Whitlow said he was a regular at Starbucks and a frequent flier on Alaska Airlines, and boasted that he could see the headquarters of Amazon.com from his office window. His fund has positions in all three stocks in a portfolio limited to companies based in five states: Alaska, Idaho, Montana, Oregon and Washington.
INVESTORS who believe that a regional fund gives them a pure basket of home-baked goods may be surprised to learn that many regional fund managers eye companies outside their borders. Securities and Exchange Commission rules allow funds calling themselves regional to invest as much as 35 percent of assets outside their geographic area.
That wiggle room allows Safeco Northwest to branch into stocks like Intel. Though Intel's semiconductor operations in Hillsborough, Ore., near Portland, make the company the state's largest private employer, its headquarters are in Santa Clara, Calif. Another stake outside the region is Kroger, the supermarket chain based in Cincinnati, which the fund found itself owning after Kroger acquired the Oregon-based Fred Meyer chain last year.
"It's nice to have that flexibility," Mr. Whitlow said. "The whole point of it is so I can maintain a diversified portfolio."
The local heroes that turned in the strongest performances of the last five years were driven, naturally enough, by strong regional economies. But regional economic performance can swing sharply down as well as up: Safeco Northwest had an anemic 3.5 percent return in 1998 because its home turf was hit harder than other areas by Asian economic turmoil. And recent weeks have made clear the risk inherent in the best performers' heavy reliance on technology stocks.
Conrad B. Herrmann, lead manager of the $2.93 billion Franklin California Growth fund, which has its pick of 1,400 publicly traded companies in California, believes strongly in the home-court advantage. "We're a drive down the road to Silicon Valley, so we do have a leg up," said Mr. Herrmann. "It has an appeal to the pride of people who live and work in the state of California."
Mr. Herrmann points out that, standing alone, California would rank as the world's eighth-largest economy and its fourth-largest stock market. But though state spirit might be the motive to invest in many regional funds, Franklin California Growth, the top-performing regional fund over the last three years with an annualized return of 46.3 percent, attracts fewer than half of its shareholders from California. That offers proof that a regional fund can attract out-of-territory investors, but is also a sign that few investors consider supporting their local economy a top priority, at least when it comes to choosing mutual funds.
Edward S. Rosenbaum, director of research at Lipper Inc., said funds like Franklin California Growth wind up being sector funds in disguise, overweighted in technology stocks; by contrast, the region around Minneapolis yields a much more varied portfolio for the four funds that concentrate on that area.
"Like any specialized fund, whether by geography or sector, it's a step away from diversification," he said. "That makes it less appropriate for a substantial portion of your financial nest egg. But it can be a way to engage in the economic life of that region." (Of course, many investors already get all the exposure they need to their home region's economic vicissitudes simply by living and working there, and might be better served by a fund that invests anywhere but their region, just as many financial planners advise against putting retirement savings in the stock of one's employer, to avoid an overconcentration of risk.)
BEGUN in 1991, the California Growth fund roughly tracks an index of the state's 250 largest companies ranked by market capitalization, and is rebalanced each quarter. Two-thirds of its assets are in networking and semiconductor companies, digital hardware makers and biotechnology stocks.
"We look at where market flows might be going, so we can acknowledge where money is shifting," Mr. Herrmann said by telephone from the headquarters of Franklin Templeton in San Mateo, Calif.
California Growth was an early investor in Netscape and Yahoo but trimmed its stakes in quarterly rebalancings after they soared to high valuations. As of last week, Internet service companies made up about 12.5 percent of the fund's 150 stocks, up from 6.5 percent in early 1999.
These days Mr. Herrmann likes JDS Uniphase, the optical-networking products maker based in San Jose; Versata, a software and service provider in Oakland; and Vitria Technology, an e-business concern in Sunnyvale. Other holdings include Applied Micro Circuits, a San Diego maker of integrated circuits for telecommunications applications, and Applied Materials of Santa Clara, a supplier of chip-making equipment.
Whether or not the regional funds make sense from an investment perspective, they are certainly suited to one purpose: They give the sales forces at regional brokerage firms and investment banks a product to pitch to local customers that fund giants like Fidelity and Vanguard do not offer. Critics say that makes them pure marketing gimmicks.
"They're kind of silly," said Russel Kinnel, director of fund analysis at Morningstar. "Generally, it doesn't really make sense to limit an investment to an artificial border. Why settle?"

SECTION: Section 3; Page 20; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 957 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Avoiding the Land of the Giants, Five Managers Harvested Gains

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
MOST mutual fund investors opened the new century with smart gains, though well below the double-digit returns posted in the final quarter of 1999. Those who generally steered clear of the giants in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index often outperformed in a stock market led by technology and smaller issues.
That was the winning approach for the five professional money managers who built hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times. All five beat the S.& P. 500, which gained 2 percent during the first quarter, and one beat the average of 6.5 percent for diversified domestic equity funds tracked by Lipper Inc. 
 A common theme among the five managers was unease about the market's recent violent swings. In response to that uncertainty, all looked to diversified portfolios and long-term perspectives.
Technology stocks were a boon to Jack A. Brill, vice president of Natural Investment Services in San Diego. His portfolio of "socially responsible" funds was the leader for the quarter, with a gain of 6.6 percent, aided by stakes in Citizens Emerging Growth, up 23.07 percent, and Calvert New Visions, up 18.54 percent.
For the second quarter, Mr. Brill is dropping Ariel Appreciation, a small- to mid-cap value fund. A sliver of the freed assets will be added to Citizens Emerging Growth; the remainder, representing 4 percent of the overall portfolio, will go to Calvert New Visions, a small growth fund he added in the first quarter.
"During these turbulent times, it is more important for investors to be well diversified," he said. "Market timing becomes much more difficult. Taking a long-term perspective is crucial."
The next-strongest portfolio last quarter was the one chosen by Eric M. Kobren, president of Kobren Insight Group and editor of Fidelity Insight in Wellesley, Mass. Mr. Kobren said his company was staying "cautiously optimistic" about the stock market.
"Valuations remain at historically high levels for certain areas of the market," he said. "However, the economy remains in very good shape, and corporate profits are growing. And when you eliminate the technology sector, stocks are much more reasonably priced."
ALTHOUGH the short-term volatility in the market "is unnerving," he added "investors are well-advised to maintain a diversified portfolio and not get unduly concerned about the wide daily swings we've been experiencing."
Mr. Kobren's portfolio, which contains only funds from Fidelity Investments, gained 5.95 percent for the quarter. He rode the hot technology sector with stakes in Fidelity Aggressive Growth, up 14.42 percent, and Fidelity Small Cap Stock, up 12.59 percent. For the second quarter, he is shifting 5 percent of the portfolio out of Aggressive Growth, reducing it to 15 percent, and into Fidelity Value, raising that fund's weighting to 25 percent.
With a cumulative portfolio gain of 217.47 percent since the contest began in July 1993, Mr. Kobren has almost caught up with the longtime leader, Sheldon Jacobs, who edits the No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y., and whose cumulative return is 226.75 percent. Since the start, the five portfolios have returned an average of 189.65 percent, compared with 281.49 percent for the Vanguard 500 Index fund, which tracks the S.& P.
The performance of the hypothetical portfolios is tracked each quarter by Lipper Inc., the research firm in Summit, N.J. The figures exclude sales charges and transaction costs -- as well as taxes, because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts.
The five managers may choose from among all funds open to new investors, and may shift money each quarter. The portfolios are meant to grow until July 2013, some 20 years after the competition began.
RUSSEL KINNEL, director of fund analysis at Morningstar Inc. in Chicago, posted the third-best return for the quarter -- 4.86 percent, buoyed by a large stake in MAS Mid Cap Growth, which was up 13.34 percent.
Mr. Kinnel, who took Susan Dziubinski's place in the contest in January and has overhauled the portfolio, is making no changes for the coming quarter. "I should at least be able to stick with them for three months," he said.
Mr. Kinnel is sanguine about the market: "We've watched a big rally in the Dow, and Nasdaq stocks are getting barbecued, but so what? The average value fund is still in the red for the year, and the average growth fund has double-digit gains."
Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., also plans no changes to his broadly diversified portfolio, despite placing fourth during the first quarter with a gain of 4.98 percent.
"The flip-flop in leaders and laggards continues, just as one would expect with a diversified portfolio in a turbulent market," Mr. Evensky said. "Because no one can predict what market to be in, the game plan continues to be managing risk as well as return."
Mr. Jacobs's portfolio trailed the pack for the quarter, gaining just 4.62 percent. Despite an impressive showing by T. Rowe Price Science and Technology, up 11.57 percent, his return was pulled down by stakes in Marisco Focus, up just 0.21 percent, and Strong Asia-Pacific, up 0.67 percent.
Looking ahead, Mr. Jacobs is cautious.
"It's time to take something off the table," he said. "Speculation is rampant, investors are complacent and many valuations in the new economy are far too high. The risk-reward relationship for equities isn't nearly as favorable as it was in the 90's."
As a result, he is redirecting 15 percent of his portfolio out of three stock funds, Vanguard Total Stock Market Index, Marsico Focus and Janus Olympus, and into a new position in Vanguard Money Market Prime. But he is standing pat with his Europe and Asia funds.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY;
Bargaining With Banks

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY JR. 

 BODY:
Tired of settling for whatever interest rate your local bank pays on certificates of deposit but hesitant to send your money thousands of miles away to get a better one? The creators of Shoprate.com, in Winchester, Ky., propose to resolve your problem.
Shoprate.com has started a free online auction site that lets consumers anonymously list how much they have to invest, for how long and at what desired rate. Banks then respond with bids for the business, and Shoprate sends e-mail messages listing their proposed terms. The investor chooses the best bid and completes the transaction directly with the bank. 
 Unlike other name-your-own-price businesses, including those for airline tickets, there is no obligation to accept any deal, even if it is exactly what you asked for. "This new method of negotiating C.D. rates brings down the curtain of uncertainty and intimidation many consumers experience when dealing directly with financial institutions," said Tracy Trimble, 32, a former banker who is president of Shoprate.com.
Still, the process may seem clumsy to consumers accustomed to the immediacy and excitement of an auction site like eBay. One person, for example, seeking a 7 percent rate on $5,000 for 12 months, waited for several hours on Thursday without getting a bid; another, seeking a 5.75 percent rate on $5,000 for nine months, received one matching bid.
The start-up makes its money by charging banks participation fees of $145 to $295 a year. So far, only 15 banks have signed up, and only $6 million has been offered by consumers. Even so, the idea seems compelling, said Warren G. Heller of Veribanc, a Wakefield, Mass., company that rates banks for soundness. "Look where Priceline.com's gotten to." ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 1271 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Solid, but Short-Lived, Gains for U.S. Funds

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
FIRST the good news.
The average United States diversified mutual fund performed strongly during the first quarter of 2000, posting a return of 6.5 percent. Technology funds were especially strong, up 18.54 percent, as were growth funds specializing in companies of all sizes. 
 Next the bad news. Unless an investor sold those funds the day the quarter ended, their gains have slipped away, thanks to the stunning sell-off in technology stocks over the last week. In a dizzyingly fast move, investors fled new-economy technology and Internet companies, with their big dreams and scant profits, for the safety of solid old-economy titans like Ford and Procter & Gamble. That left technology-heavy mutual funds, which had big gains last quarter, suddenly staggering.
So while the scenery in the rearview mirror is looking great, many an investment vehicle was found last week wrapped around a roadside maple tree.
Now mutual fund shareholders are trying to decide what lies ahead: Will the market continue to turn away from technology stocks, many of which are still hideously expensive by any traditional valuation measures, until their price-to-earnings and price-to-sales ratios are more in line with historical averages? Or will it quickly forget the brutality of this correction and focus again on the huge sales growth posted by many technology and Internet companies?
Unfortunately, those questions do not have easy answers. The shocking decline in the Nasdaq composite last Tuesday, when the index fell more than 13 percent in just a few hours, demonstrated that when expensive stocks fall, they can fall far and fast. If you own, or wish you owned, the top-performing funds of the last quarter, you need to accept that very real risk.
On the other hand, investing in the companies that are world leaders in technology, communications and the Internet has been hugely profitable for the last decade. And as growth fund managers like to remind their shareholders, the best time to buy those stocks has been when they are "on sale," which is a polite way of saying "down." With many technology and Internet companies expected to report strong growth in first-quarter earnings, now is exactly the wrong time to get out of technology, growth managers argue.
"Relative to old-economy stocks, these are still expensive, but I think these are the stocks people are going to want to own, and they will come back to them," said Bill Keithler, manager of the $10 billion Invesco Technology fund. Mr. Keithler's fund rose 26.15 percent in the first three months of the year, making it one of the quarter's better-performing technology funds. But it fell 10.09 percent on Monday, the first day of the second quarter, and an additional 1.21 percent on Tuesday.
"You have ups and downs, and it's going to be a volatile asset class," said Quint Slattery, manager of the $300 million PBHG New Opportunities fund, an ultra-aggressive growth fund that buys mainly technology companies. Just how volatile? Mr. Slattery's fund gained 533 percent in the 12 months ended March 31, including 42.37 percent in the first quarter. But it fell 16.41 percent on Monday and an additional 4.4 percent on Tuesday.
Invesco Technology and PBHG New Opportunities were hardly alone in their volatility. In general, the more a fund gained in the first quarter, the more it suffered as April began, according to statistics from Morningstar Inc.
The average large-capitalization growth fund, for example, rose 8.81 percent in the first quarter, then fell 1.78 percent last week through Thursday. Mid-cap growth funds were the quarter's best performers among diversified United States stock funds, rising 17.33 percent, according to Morningstar; they were down 4.11 percent in the first four days last week. For pure technology funds, the reversal was even sharper. Technology funds rose 18.54 percent for the quarter, then fell 4.89 percent last week through Thursday.
ON the other hand, funds that performed poorly during the first quarter rebounded with a vengeance last week. Funds that buy large-cap value stocks were the weakest performers for the quarter among diversified United States stock funds, gaining just 0.08 percent, on average, according to Morningstar. That changed last week, as the average gain was 1.3 percent through Thursday.
For mid-cap value funds, the story was similar. They rose 1.93 percent in the first quarter, second-worst among all diversified fund groups tracked by Morningstar, but emerged unscathed from last week's gyrations with a four-day gainof 0.08 percent.
Kent Simons, manager of the $2 billion Neuberger Berman Focus fund, a value-oriented offering that nonetheless rose 12.48 percent in the first quarter, said the recent turn toward more reasonably priced stocks was inevitable, given how expensive many technology companies had become. Although he is a value investor, Mr. Simons does not count himself as a technophobe. His fund owns shares of several technology companies, including Oracle and Texas Instruments, which have proved to be very good long-term investments.
Even so, Mr. Simons, who said he bought Oracle and other software companies in early 1999, watched in dismay in the first quarter as they soared to valuations he did not think their fundamentals could justify. Some new, fast-growing technology companies, meanwhile, were rising even faster, despite big losses and tiny sales.
"Wall Street, in my opinion, has always gone to extremes," Mr. Simons said. "But I think you're seeing greater extremes than in the past. A lot of the buying that was going on was pretty uninformed, and what's happened in the last couple of weeks is that the markets said, 'Oops -- I don't think the emperor has any clothes.' "
Technology funds, of course, were not the only strong performers in the first quarter. Health and biotechnology funds also surged, gaining 15.92 percent, on average, although many biotechnology funds fell sharply during the last two weeks of March as investors realized that many companies in the industry are, at best, years from profitability. Energy and natural-resources funds were the third-best sector, up 13.45 percent as oil prices rose sharply, with oil-company profits expected to follow.
On the other hand, financial sector funds had a weak return of 0.17 percent, on average, as investors worried that rising interest rates would hurt profits at banks and securities firms. Rate fears also crimped real estate funds, which gained an average of 1.78 percent. And gold continued its two-decade history of poor returns, with the average precious-metals fund down 15.23 percent.
COMPARED with the thrill ride that United States funds offered in the first quarter, the path of international stock funds was relatively sedate. On average, European stock funds offered the best runs of international funds, up 8.1 percent, as economies improved across the Continent. Many other international funds also finished in the black. Funds that invest worldwide gained an average of 5.14 percent, while Latin American funds were up 4.25 percent and funds investing in Asia outside Japan rose 3.56 percent.
But Japanese stock funds fell 3.26 percent as Japan's economy was stuck in neutral. The country's Nikkei index of 225 issues finished the quarter at 20,337.32, still down nearly 50 percent from its peak of a decade ago and a sobering reminder that bear markets sometimes need more than a week or two to run their course. As the Nasdaq swings ever more crazily, mutual fund investors in the United States might do well to keep that lesson in mind.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 3; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 567 words

HEADLINE: CITY LORE;
When the City Sits for Its Portrait

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
NO one would call New York, with its grit and clamor, "pretty as a picture." But the city has always been a subject for art, and that's the idea behind "Painting the Town: Cityscapes From the Museum of the City of New York," which opens Thursday at the PaineWebber Art Gallery in Midtown Manhattan.
All 70 paintings are drawn from the deep and eclectic holdings of an Upper East Side museum founded in 1923 to "preserve a city's remembrances." And the show, with images of the five boroughs ranging over almost two centuries, pretty much covers the local waterfront. 
 It does so literally in the case of a mid-19th-century painting titled "View of Hudson River," which offers a panoramic sweep of a now-vanished Manhattan beachfront. The picture is the work of Victor Gifford Audubon, son of the naturalist. And a tiny dark figure perched on a rock in the foreground may be the great John James himself, checking out gulls near his home, which once overlooked the river at what is now West 155th Street and Broadway.
Manhattan still offers its share of bucolic vistas, Central Park being the grandest, and Bryant Park -- its airiness neatly caught in a sweet 1914 painting by Theresa Bernstein -- one of the most exquisite. But a cityscape, to be strictly true to its name, has to be about more than nature doing its thing. It must include man-made structures, and many of these paintings do.
Structure is really the whole story in the jaunty cubistic "Escalator" (1943-44) by Mari-Louise Van Esselstyn. But elsewhere nature and culture balance out, in life and in art, as they do in that arching poem of cable and stone called the Brooklyn Bridge, and in Warren Shepherd's eyewitness painting of the bridge's fireworks-dazzled opening in May 1883.
What Shepherd didn't paint was the disaster that occurred the next day: a dozen people were crushed to death by a stampeding crowd of sightseers when a cry went up that the bridge was collapsing. Other artists, however, have relished their role as street-level reporters, even as they invoked artistic license to embroider the nitty-gritty a bit.
Two Manhattan painters, James Cafferty and Charles G. Rosenberg, for example, captured the drama of the worst financial panic of the 19th century in a work with the you-are-there title "Wall Street, Half Past 2 O'Clock, October 13, 1857." (They even bring Cornelius Vanderbilt, reputedly the richest man in the world at the time, into the fray.)
Closer to our day, Peter Hopkins depicted a violent clash between unemployed workers and city police that took place in Union Square in 1930. The event, which he watched from his studio window above the square, made an unforgettable impression on him. He painted it from memory 17 years later.
Memory of the past is the theme of "Painting the Town." But the show, which can be seen at the gallery, at 1285 Avenue of the Americas (between 51st and 52nd Streets), through June 23, is also about the present. The river and the parks are, after all, still here. So are the fireworks and tensions. So is the art. At the moment there's a big exhibition of dozens of the city's bright young artists at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens. Its title: "Greater New York." And in "Painting the Town" we get to see what was hot and what was at least warm yesterday. It turns out, on the whole, to be a pretty picture after all.

Rosenberg.; TAKING THEIR EASE -- "Bryant Park," 1914, by Theresa Bernstein. (Paintings From the Collection of the Museum of the City of New York)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 17; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT: STRATEGIES;
Monitoring Trades for the Good of a Fund

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
BIG BROTHER is watching. But don't worry, it's all for the good of your foreign stock fund.
In this case, the person doing the watching is one David Jones, a vice president at the FMR Corporation, parent of Fidelity Investments. His job includes tracking down investors who use a particular day-trading strategy that can damage the returns of funds that invest in foreign markets. 
 He's serious, too. "We will find investors who try this kind of strategy and they will be asked to leave," Mr. Jones said in a telephone interview.
Many investors, no doubt, will be surprised to learn that anyone cares about their mutual fund trades, much less wants to watch them. But most fund companies -- not just Fidelity -- spend a lot to monitor the trading patterns of their investors. And, like Fidelity's Mr. Jones, they'll ask you to take your business elsewhere if they decide you're a day trader taking advantage of their funds.
A day trader can exploit many mutual funds because of how they calculate their net asset values -- the prices at which they can be bought or sold. With just a few exceptions, funds calculate their net asset values once a day, at 4 p.m. Eastern time, based on the closing trades of the securities they own. That method gives day traders a couple of unfair advantages -- and one that pertains particularly to foreign funds.
When foreign stock and bond funds based in the United States price themselves at 4 p.m., they are using prices that are hours out of date. Funds that invest in Japan, for example, are using prices that are fully 14 hours out of date. That's because the Japanese markets close at 2 a.m. Eastern time.
The stale pricing gives shrewd traders a chance at easy profit. All they have to do is find news in the 14-hour window that can be expected to move the Japanese stocks up or down, then buy or sell just before the close of the United States markets.
Imagine, say, that after the close of the Tokyo market on a particular day, OPEC announces that it will increase production sharply; as a result, the price of Dubai crude plunges. The news, of course, is bullish for the Japanese economy, because the nation depends completely on imported oil -- and it's almost a sure bet that the Nikkei 225 index will rise sharply when the next session opens. By buying, say, the Warburg Pincus Japan Growth fund in the United States at the net asset value at 4 p.m., a day trader can, in effect, buy Japanese stocks at the prices that existed before the OPEC announcement.
It is the closest that investors will probably ever come to being able to act on Will Rogers's famous advice: "Buy some good stock and hold it till it goes up. If it don't go up, don't buy it."
Of course, not every event is as sure a bet as an OPEC announcement when it comes to moving the Japanese market. But day traders have discovered that daily fluctuations in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index work almost as well as an indicator. Much of what moves the S. & P. moves Japanese stocks, too. Movement in the S. & P. 500 on one day is often mimicked the next in the Nikkei 225.
Exploiting the correlation is simple. Buy a Japanese stock fund on days when the S. & P. 500 rises, and move to cash on days when the S. & P. drops.
How profitable can the strategy be? Plenty, according to research by two finance professors from the Yale School of Management, William Goetzmann and K. Geert Rouwenhorst, and one of their graduate students, Zoran Ivkovich.
They applied this simple strategy to 17 Japanese stock funds based in the United States from the beginning of 1990 through July 1998. Ignoring the effects of loads, or sales charges, for those funds that charge them, they found that the approach beat a buy-and-hold strategy by an average of nearly 27 percentage points a year, albeit without taking into account taxes or trading costs. Even better, risk was reduced sharply, because the strategy meant being in the market only about half the time.
But Professor Goetzmann and his colleagues didn't confine their research to Japanese funds. They applied the idea to nearly 400 foreign stock funds of various stripes based in the United States. Not surprisingly, the strategy was most profitable for funds whose stocks trade principally in markets, like Japan's, whose market hours don't overlap with those in New York. The strategy was only marginally profitable when applied to Latin America, whose market hours largely coincide with New York's.
The easy day-trading profits aren't free, however. The foreign funds' long-term shareholders pay for them -- to the tune of around $50 million a year, according to Professor Goetzmann's estimate.
The cost would no doubt have been greater, but the strategy has been relatively unknown -- at least until recently. Another mitigating factor has been fund company "security officers" like Fidelity's Mr. Jones.
But there is evidence that more day traders are slipping through the fund companies' defenses. Mr. Jones concedes that Fidelity has "seen an increase in short-term trading of our international funds recently." And the Securities and Exchange Commission reports similar complaints from other fund families.
One way that day traders can escape detection is by investing through a mutual fund marketplace like Charles Schwab's OneSource, which gives them anonymity because Schwab pools all its customers' investments in a particular fund into one account. A bigger potential problem for the funds comes from corporate retirement plans, which not only aggregate all plan members into one account but also provide a tax-free vehicle for the day traders, removing a key drag on the strategy's profitability.
OneSource and other fund marketplaces charge a fee for short-term trading. But Professor Goetzmann has found that such fees do not cut profits enough to dissuade the day traders' moves. He says fees for round-trip transactions, buying and selling a fund, would have to total 30 to 45 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to make the day-trading strategy unprofitable.
But on an investment of $100,000 or so through OneSource, for example, a round-trip transaction can cost as little as 3 basis points.
On March 1, Fidelity announced that in order to curtail short-term trading, it would begin imposing a redemption fee of 100 basis points on investments in its international stock funds that are held for less than 30 days. A number of other fund companies have announced their intentions to levy such fees, which are paid back into the funds themselves, compensating long-term shareholders for the costs of the day trading.
AN alternative solution for funds would be to calculate net asset values differently. Professor Goetzmann and his colleagues propose a complex solution that in effect "freshens" the stale prices of foreign stocks after trading has stopped in their home markets. They say funds already have the authority to use such a system, since the S.E.C. allows funds to use what is known as "fair value pricing," in effect, determining the value of their holdings on a basis other than a stock's closing trades. The funds have used this method, although rarely, to price securities during times of foreign market turmoil.
Until funds adopt a procedure like Professor Goetzmann's, it may make sense for long-term investors to steer clear of any foreign stock fund that doesn't discourage short-term trading. Of course, front- or back-end loads, or sales charges, are one way to discourage such short-term trading, but they constitute another kind of price tag. No-load funds that charge redemption fees on short-term trades are far preferable.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
For the City, Love Means Nothing At the South St. Seaport Courts

BYLINE: By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
The tennis courts near the South Street Seaport are approaching final game, set and match.
During its three-decade run, the private indoor courts on Piers 13 and 14 have witnessed countless matches, featuring novices as well as Wimbledon champions. The courts were also the setting for Woody Allen's fateful encounter with Diane Keaton in the 1977 movie "Annie Hall." 
 But the lease on the city-owned piers expires at the end of May and will not be renewed, said Janel Patterson, a spokeswoman for the Economic Development Corporation.
The city is looking to redevelop those piers for other uses, she said.
"This is going to be disastrous," said Samuel P. Sporn, 69, who has played at the courts, which are run by the New York Health & Racquet Club, about three times a week for the last 15 years. "There will be nowhere to play downtown."
The nearest private indoor court, also run by the club, is at University Place and 12th Street, about two and a half miles away. According to the Parks Department, Manhattan has 98 public courts, with only two indoors: one on 60th Street and York Avenue and one on Randalls Island.
"It's a huge loss for kids in Manhattan," said Bill Wiese, executive director of the New York Junior Tennis League, which gives free lessons to inner-city children at the courts near the piers. High schools also use the courts during colder months, said Martha Singer, the athletic director at nearby Stuyvesant High School.
In 1998, the city solicited proposals for that site and two adjacent piers. The ideas range from a floating hotel to an aquarium to a youth hostel. One proposal is for a branch of the Guggenheim Museum, a curvilinear building that would rise as high as 45 stories. It was designed by Frank Gehry, the architect of the acclaimed Guggenheim branch in Bilbao, Spain.
The New York Health and Racquet Club, which took over the two "bubble tents" housing the courts in 1988, also submitted an application.
Ms. Patterson said that the city is still reviewing proposals, but some observers, such as Paul Goldstein, chairman of Community Board 1, say that it will be years before a decision is reached.
George Kondos, a consultant for the health club, said his company had asked the city to keep the courts open until a decision is made. "At this point," Mr. Kondos said, "the city does not want to do anything for us."
Meanwhile, Mr. Sporn has collected about 300 signatures calling on local officials "to do everything in their power to save" the courts.
The petitions were sent out last month, but Mr. Sporn said he has not received any formal responses. "The ball," he said, "is in the city's court." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Three Who Thrived on Technology

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THE spring dive in the Nasdaq composite index left investors in aggressive, technology-oriented mutual funds gasping. Yet when the books on the first quarter closed, it was clear that Internet-related stocks had maintained enough altitude to ensure that virtually all the best-performing funds were filled to the gills with such shares.
Over all, domestic diversified stock funds posted returns of 6.5 percent for the quarter, on average, handily beating the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which returned 2.29 percent. All eyes, though, remain on technology shares and the funds that hold them. After all, technology's outsized gains have supplied much of the high-octane fuel for the bull market. 
 Managers of three top-performing funds -- portfolios generally full of silicon and bandwidth -- talked about what drove their performance and what to make of the market's volatile technology sector for the rest of the year.
 
The Market Came to Them
An 80 percent stake in technology stocks, with a sprinkling of biotechnology issues, pushed the $1.22 billion Kopp Emerging Growth fund into the No. 3 place for the quarter, with a return of 42.3 percent. The fund closed its doors to new investors on Feb. 7, when assets eclipsed $1 billion.
"The market's been going after our space," said the fund's lead manager, Lee Kopp, 65, referring to companies that make the equipment and software for e-commerce.
The fund holds 65 companies, and its turnover is relatively low, averaging 25 to 35 percent a year.
One big winner for the portfolio was Digital Microwave, which is based in San Jose, Calif., and makes and markets microwave radio equipment for fixed and mobile networks. "We're getting more attention devoted to wireless," Mr. Koop said, adding that the company was benefiting from its heavy past spending on research and development.
The stock rose 44.5 percent in the quarter; Wall Street is predicting earnings of 49 cents a share in the fiscal year ending in March 2001, compared with an estimated 15 cents for the fiscal year just completed.
Another favorite is Rational Software of Cupertino, Calif., which makes software used by companies to develop Internet and e-business sites and services. Investors, Mr. Koop said, increasingly came to view its business as a "hot button" play on the Web, as the stock gained 55.7 percent last quarter. Analysts estimate earnings of $1.19 a share in the fiscal year ending in March 2001, compared with an estimated 94 cents for the 2000 year.
The fund also made money in the Zygo Corporation, which is based in Middlefield, Conn., and makes systems to improve the quality and reduce the cost of automated manufacturing processes for high-technology businesses. The stock jumped 139.8 percent in the quarter, as the company reported increased orders. Wall Street sees earnings of $1.17 a share for the year ending in June 2001, up from an estimated 61 cents this year.
Looking ahead, Mr. Koop is cautiously optimistic. He expects market returns of 15 to 20 percent a year, annualized, over the next three to five years. But despite describing the recent sell-off in Nasdaq as "healthy," he warns new clients to avoid the stock market for now if they cannot stomach pullbacks of the kind seen over the past two weeks.
 
A Momentum Speedster
In his Grand Prix fund, which took 12th place for the quarter with a gain of 32.7 percent, Robert Zuccaro, 56, uses a computer model that ranks all 10,000 publicly traded stocks in the United States by earnings and price momentum.
The fund has $692.5 million in assets and is relatively concentrated, holding just 25 companies, with a tilt toward stocks with big market capitalizations. All are technology issues.
One is PMC-Sierra, a British Columbia maker of semiconductors used in high-speed telecommunications lines. The stock jumped 154.1 percent in the quarter. Mr. Zuccaro cited its positive price momentum, as well as the 17 percent margin by which it exceeded consensus earnings estimates for the fourth quarter of 1999. "The market wants these kind of stocks," he said. He expects the company's earnings to grow 31 percent a year, on average, over three years.
Another winner is Applied Micro Circuits of San Diego, another maker of semiconductors used in telecommunications equipment. The stock rose 135.9 percent in the first quarter because of an unexpectedly high 23 percent gain in fourth-quarter 1999 earnings, Mr. Zuccaro said.
He also succeeded with Veritas Software, a Mountain View, Calif., designer and manufacturer of computer networking software. The company exceeded analysts' earnings estimates by 10 percent in the fourth quarter, prompting the stock's 37.3 percent gain in the first quarter this year, he said. He expects earnings to grow 96 percent, annualized, over the next three years.
He is unfazed by the recent sell-off in technology. "Nothing is fundamentally wrong," Mr. Zuccaro said. He expects the S. & P. 500 and Dow industrials to gain 15 percent for the year and the Nasdaq composite to climb 40 to 50 percent. "The U.S. is in a record economic expansion that will help the stock market," he said, "because the two are inextricably interlinked."
 
Beyond the Sell-Off
Jim D. Oelschlager, manager of the $557.7 million Pin Oak Aggressive Stock fund, which ranked No. 1 for the quarter with a gain of 42.5 percent, seemed almost relieved about the recent sell-off. "I don't think anyone should be upset, " he said. "We had to have this correction because of the heavy run-up in the stocks and the disappointment when Microsoft and government couldn't negotiate a settlement."
The fund is concentrated in 28 stocks, with 85 percent of total assets in technology. One of his biggest winners last quarter was Applied Materials, the big maker of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, which rose 48.8 percent; the fund has owned the stock since 1996. "The chip market has been very strong," Mr. Oelschlager said, adding that he believes chip manufacturing equipment makers have a long way to go before they reach the peak of their highly cyclical business. Earnings for Applied Materials, based in Santa Clara, Calif., should grow 30 percent over the next 12 months, he said.
Another holding, Juniper Networks, a Mountain View, Calif., maker of networking hardware for large corporations, rose 132.6 percent in the quarter. It benefited from "demand for networking products in conjunction with the rapid growth of the Internet, which will likely continue in the foreseeable future," Mr. Oelschlager said. He foresees earnings growth of 50 percent over the next 12 months.
Ciena, a Linthicum, Md., a maker of optical networking systems, rose 119.3 percent in the quarter. "The stock was severely beaten in 1998, came back sharply in 1999 and continued to rally," said Mr. Oelschlager, who bought shares in April 1998. "It was overdone on the downside and the market has been focusing on fiber optics stocks lately."
He foresees earnings growth of 40 to 50 percent a year over the next two years.
As for the future, Mr. Oelschlager warned, fasten your seat belt. "I'm optimistic over the long term, " he said. "but there will be periods when returns might be sharply lower than they have been over the last few quarters."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STATEN ISLAND UP CLOSE;
An Arts Council Fights for Its Place in the Sun

BYLINE: By JIM O'GRADY 

 BODY:
Advocates for the city-designated arts council on Staten Island say that, compared with similar councils in the other boroughs, it is not getting its fair share of city money. So the group is lobbying to increase its cut of the forthcoming city budget, from $22,388 to $125,000.
Vincent Montalbano, a lobbyist for the group, the Coalition on the Arts and Humanities, said it needed more city money to do its job of promoting resident artists. (All the councils seek private donations, too.) 
 "If the city is giving money to arts councils and you've got a vibrant one," he said, "you should get more than $22,000 a year." Among other programs, the group runs a kiosk at Whitehall Terminal in Lower Manhattan where tourists taking the ferry to Staten Island can get information on cultural events.
But how does the group's share compare to that of other councils? It depends on the numbers used.
The $22,388 that the coalition received last year is called base-line financing: the amount of money that is written into the city budget at the beginning of the negotiating process each year. But Susan Rothschild, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, said that when extra funds disbursed by the City Council are included the group received $37,388. That comes to 9 cents per Staten Island resident: less than the 14 cents in the Bronx and the 11 cents in Queens but more than the 7 cents per resident in Brooklyn. Manhattan does not have a comparable boroughwide arts council.
But the coalition's executive director, Laura Jean Watters, said that base-line figures were the truest gauge of the support an arts council receives from the city. She said organizations like hers used base-line figures when making long-range plans because those funds were more reliable than extra money from the Council, which can rise or fall from year to year. And using base-line figures, she said, the per-resident financing for her group drops to 5 cents, while that for the other arts councils remains at the figures Ms. Rothschild cited. Tom LaManna, a spokesman for City Councilman Jerome X. O'Donovan of Staten Island agreed with Ms. Watters.
"The Council's ability to enhance an arts council's budget is subject to the economy," he said. "Right now it's good. Next year it might not be."
Nevertheless, Mr. O'Donovan is working with Staten Island's other two Council members to increase the extra financing the coalition will get in the coming budget. Mr. Montalbano said the coalition would then work to get some or all of that money converted to base-line financing in the next budget. JIM O'GRADY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ELMHURST;
Where Food Shops Are a Declining Species

BYLINE: By JIM O'GRADY 

 BODY:
Lee Epps, 69, said last week that she had changed her supermarket five times in the last eight years as, one by one, the stores have moved out of Elmhurst.
The last store was a Key Food at Broadway and Whitney Avenue. But it closed on March 31, and now Ms. Epps, and her 90,000 Elmhurst neighbors, have no supermarkets left. 
 The company that owns the Key Food building says it has signed another supermarket to move into the space. But in the near term there are none. And while Ms. Epps said she is well enough to push her wheeled shopping cart 10 blocks to the Met Market on 37th Avenue in Jackson Heights, not all of her elderly neighbors can do the same.
"Some of the ladies I know have medical problems that interfere with their walking," Ms. Epps said. "They're in their 70's, they're widowed, and they have no one to help them."
Councilman John D. Sabini, whose district includes Elmhurst, said that he started getting calls from worried residents two weeks ago, when word got out that Key Food was closing. As a temporary measure, he said, he had met with the owners of a supermarket in a nearby Queens neighborhood and urged them to run a shuttle bus from their store to downtown Elmhurst. Although he has high hopes for that arrangement, he said that a long-term solution would mean luring more supermarkets to the area.
"It's hard because it's prosperous there," he said. "Large pieces of property get snapped up."
Richard Grobman, the president of Dan's Supreme, the company that owned the shuttered Key Food store, said he wanted to keep doing business in Elmhurst. "But the landlord was more interested in leasing to someone else," he said.
The supermarket closings touch on tensions connected to the changing population in the neighborhood. As Asian immigrants have moved in, Asian food stores have sprung up. But Ms. Epps and other non-Asian residents say they cannot switch to these stores because they do not sell the foods that they are accustomed to eating.
Ms. Epps recalled that a manager at Key Food recently told her that the closing of the supermarkets meant it was time for her to leave her old neighborhood. "But I can't," she said.
Jim Wang is the president of 82-90 Broadway Realty Corporation, which owns the store that Key Food had been renting. He said, "We have already signed a lease with a new tenant, another supermarket company." He would neither name the company nor say whether it would sell Asian food items only, but he did say he expected the new store to move in next month.
The executive director of the Elmhurst Economic Development Corporation, Steven R. Trimble, said he spoke to Mr. Wang about having Key Food stay in the neighborhood.
"He quoted the Constitution," Mr. Trimble said. "He said, 'I can do whatever I want with my property.' And he's right." JIM O'GRADY

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Getting Reacquainted With Risk

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
NOW that the stock market's death-defying act of last Tuesday is receding into memory, can investors return to their tried-and-true bull market ways? Or was the sickening plunge and remarkable rebound in both the Nasdaq and the Dow industrials a sign that something basic about the stock market had changed?
Those are the questions that many investors are pondering even as Tuesday's tumult looks more and more like a one-day wonder. For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 1.7 percent, while the Nasdaq composite lost 2.7 percent. The Dow is down 3.35 percent so far this year, well below the Nasdaq's return of 9.27 percent. 
 Though things have quieted down, the wild action early last week was indeed a watershed, according to many market veterans. These people think that the 1,074-point round-trip move in the Nasdaq composite on Tuesday indicates that the markets have entered a new period and that investors who want to prosper in the future must retool their strategies to adapt to it.
"What was readily workable in 1999 and early 2000 is up for review," said James Moltz, vice chairman of International Strategy and Investment, an investment advisory firm in New York. "It seems clear the investor perception that nothing can go wrong in the new economy seems to be meeting with greater suspicion. The element of risk has been introduced into the equation."
Investors' heightened awareness of risk is evident in their flight to the stocks of profitable companies with solid stories. General Electric, Intel and Oracle all rose through last week's turmoil, while Internet indexes crowded with untested, unprofitable e-commerce companies struggled to find a floor.
The resilience of the giants led the recovery of the major stock indexes by week's end. But an astonishingly large number of stocks are in bear-market territory: as of Wednesday's close, 67.8 percent of stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 were down 20 percent or more from their 52-week peaks, according to Salomon Smith Barney, and 84.9 percent of stocks in the Nasdaq composite.
There is clearly stress in the stock market. And nowhere is it more evident than in the maniacal moves besetting prices today.
The greatest gyrations are in the Nasdaq composite. Leuthold Weeden, an investment advisory firm in Minneapolis, says the index has moved 3 percent or more from the previous close on less than one-half of 1 percent of all the trading days in the Nasdaq's 29-year history. This year, there have been such moves on 27 percent of trading days.
Or consider this measure of Nasdaq volatility: In less than four hours on Tuesday, it fell 634.31 points. In all of 1998, the index moved 622.27 points from the beginning of the year to the end. (Of course, that was a bigger move in percentage terms.)
But volatility is not limited to the Nasdaq. Extreme swings are increasingly common in the S.& P., as well. So far this year, Leuthold Weeden said, the S.& P. has moved 1 percent or more from its previous close on 47.6 percent of trading days. To exceed that level of volatility requires a trip back to 1938, a time of global turmoil. Even in the bear market year of 1974, volatility was lower than it is today: 45.1 percent.
Veteran investors say these wild swings in prices are the market's way of signaling that all is not well with the world. Professional traders like volatility, because it gives them opportunities to duck in and out of stocks. But for individuals, it is a sign of a market in transition -- one that poses significant risk.
The free fall on Tuesday "revealed a real fragility in this market," said Steven Leuthold, who calculated the volatility figures. "Investors, whether institutions or individuals, have really overwhelmed the market mechanism."
The mechanism that Mr. Leuthold refers to -- investors' ability to find others willing to trade with them -- has been overwhelmed for some time now. But investors have not recognized it as a problem as stock prices have risen. Buyers overwhelmed sellers, pushing stocks into the stratosphere. Investing was fun.
But an overwhelmed market mechanism can get ugly on the downside. "Market participants never perceive volatility when prices go up substantially," said Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist. "They only believe that markets are volatile when prices go down. That is the bias in investor behavior."
Many factors contribute to the surging volatility. Dirt-cheap commissions to trade stocks have lured many new investors into the market. They trade more often, and many move in and out of stocks en masse, reacting to information on the Internet or cable television.
INDEED, trying to profit from these waves of buying and selling has become popular -- not just among day traders, but among part-time investors, too. And individuals and institutions alike have embraced momentum investing, a strategy of buying stocks as they rise because they are rising -- and hence another contributor to market frenzy.
As more and more investors have entered the market, traders whose job it is to help them execute their orders have retreated from the arena.
Profits for market makers in Nasdaq stocks have fallen significantly, a result of regulators' scrutiny. And so the ranks of market makers have dwindled, leaving fewer buyers on hand to provide a floor for stock prices when they start to slide.
"There is very little cushion provided by intermediaries today," Mr. Leuthold said. "There is an illusion of liquidity given with the number of shares trading today. But the true liquidity of the market is revealed in a situation like we saw Tuesday."
Mr. Kaufman identified another important force propelling market volatility: Wall Street's obsession with making tradeable securities out of investments that previously would have sat on investors' or bankers' books until they came due. Home mortgages, for example, are now bought and sold furiously.
"With these new obligations, you can leverage them more, because the market price allows you to borrow against them," Mr. Kaufman said. "This allows a more intensive management of those assets, which also creates a more near-term orientation by portfolio managers. So stocks are bought more for their next price turn than for the likely value of them 10 to 20 years from now."
Some economists and market strategists think Tuesday's turmoil also confirmed what had been a stealthy but important shift in the broad economic picture.
"We had some very definite trends in the economy from late last summer to January or February of this year," said James Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. "Interest rates were rising consistently around the world, oil prices were going up and technology totally dominated the stock market. Now, all these trends have changed definitively."
Mr. Paulsen says these changes may portend a slowdown in the economy later this year. "The markets have been suggesting that profit momentum and economic momentum are starting to slow," he said. The key factor, he said, is that most corporations' pricing power is weakening even as the economy grows.
The bond market may have sniffed out a coming slowdown; that, Mr. Paulsen said, is why yields have fallen so fast, despite strong economic data. The perception also may explain the bond market's odd behavior, in which long-term yields are lower than short-term ones. An inverted yield curve has historically been a signal of imminent economic slowdown.
What all this means for technology stocks is, naturally, of supreme interest to investors. After all, these are the stocks in which investors have made the most money recently.
Christine A. Callies, chief equity strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, says the love affair is waning. As of Wednesday, she noted, roughly a third of technology shares were down at least 50 percent from highs hit in the first three months of 2000.
"Once traders have lost money faster than they made it, speculative fervor dies quickly," Ms. Callies said. She does not expect technology stocks to recover their market leadership role for several quarters.
NOT everyone agrees. Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist for Lehman Brothers, who has been extremely bullish -- and correct -- on technology in recent years, says Tuesday's plunge and pop in the Nasdaq was the bottom for technology. "Both for the market and for tech, typically when you get that kind of volume, that has almost invariably meant you have a climactic bottom," he said.
He acknowledges that investors must be more selective about technology stocks today. E-tailers look particularly vulnerable, he said, but companies building the Internet's infrastructure should remain leaders.
"Old-economy stocks will participate to a degree," he said. "But at end of day, does Ford Motor Company have the top-line growth of Oracle? No. This will be yet another year when growth outperforms value."
In coming weeks, first-quarter earnings figures will start to seep into the market, and most analysts think they will be impressive. But some economists worry that profits later in the year may disappoint.
"Profit expectations are too high," Mr. Kaufman said. "And the profit expectations that are embedded in prices today are way beyond anything that is achievable in any reasonable period of time."

Graphs/Charts: "How the World Has Changed"
Analysts say four fundamental changes in markets and the economy were factors in the manic trading last week.
 
UNRELENTING VOLATILITY
Low trading costs, new trading technology and instantly available financial data all are fomenting wide swings in stock prices.
 
DWINDLING LIQUIDITY
Markets have grown so huge that the brokerage industry is less able to put the brakes on fast-moving prices by buying when stocks are falling.
 
TECHNOLOGY DETHRONED
Old-economy stocks have taken technology shares' place as prime movers in the market.
 
FEARS OF A SLOWDOWN
When long-term bond yields fall below shorter-term rates, a decline in economic growth typically follows.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk
