HEADLINE: Organic Farming, Seeking the Mainstream

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: KUTZTOWN, Pa.

 BODY:
THE Rodale Institute's 330-acre research farm here got something it prefers to a bumper crop when a record drought struck eastern Pennsylvania last year.
Rodale plants crops with the goal of harvesting evidence that organic farming should be the wave of the future in agriculture. After the drought last summer, Rodale's parched organic plots yielded 24 to 30 bushels of soybeans an acre, well below the 40-bushel average of previous years for the research site, but Rodale could not have been happier. That was because yields on comparison plots just next to them that had been doused year after year with synthetic fertilizers and conventional farm chemicals had plummeted to 16 bushels. 
 "These are very significant findings for farmers around the world," exulted Jeff Moyer, Rodale's farm manager. "Our trials show that improving the quality of the soil through organic processes can mean the difference between a harvest or hardship in times of drought."
The results last year also reinforced long-term comparisons, begun by Rodale in 1981, that document how organic farming can be more profitable for small farmers -- even if yields are not always as high and, by some calculations, even without the premium prices that organic crops generally receive.
Good research news from bad weather. Sales growing faster than any other segment of the food industry. Consumer fears about biotechnology spurring interest. Low prices for commodity crops encouraging conventional farmers to take the organic plunge. Add it all up and there has never been a more receptive moment for organic farming.
So is the organic movement finally on track to becoming the mainstream enterprise that Rodale and other advocates have long envisioned? Hardly. Organics are starting from such a small base in the United States -- an estimated one-fifth of 1 percent of farmland and 1 percent of retail sales -- that it would take years of mind-boggling growth to gain a truly substantial share of the retail food sector, which the Department of Agriculture put at $756 billion in 1998.
Such growth is almost inconceivable, say agricultural economists and even many people in the organic movement. One reason is the many challenges of farming organically; another is the heavy investment in current farming methods. Perhaps most important, though, is the deep-seated suspicion of many organic farmers and consumers about anything that smacks of big business.
"Getting to 5 percent of food sales in 10 years would be miraculous," said Katherine DiMatteo, director of the Organic Trade Association in Greenfield, Mass. Many farmers, she and others said, will advertise organic practices, like not using pesticides, and siphon off potential organic customers without making the commitment to having their products comply with the certification requirements of monitoring groups.
If the industry is not on track to achieving market power, it is winning respect -- and that alone is something of a revolution in agriculture. From the 1950's to the early 1990's, farming without chemicals was widely derided in the United States as the province of hobbyists, the health-obsessed and misty-eyed urban and suburban refugees pursuing romantic dreams of rural life.
"It's not a niche market anymore in terms of consumer interest," said Harvey Hartman, a market researcher and retail industry consultant in Seattle. Surveys by his company, the Hartman Group, found last fall that 90 percent of American consumers were either buying organic products or considering doing so, up from 60 percent two years earlier.
Interest is stronger still in Europe and Japan, where fears are running high about the use of growth hormones, antibiotics, pesticides and genetic engineering in conventional agriculture. Sweden, one of several European countries that subsidize farmers in switching to organic methods, has set a goal of converting 20 percent of its farm acreage to organic farming by 2005.
In the United States, back-to-the-earth neophytes continue to set up organic farms, making organics the only sector of agriculture that is attracting new blood. But thousands of conventional farmers are also weighing the risks and benefits of heading down the organic path, lured by premium prices that are averaging 20 percent above those for conventional crops and sometimes many times more.
"Farmers have been losing money in conventional agriculture, and organic is looking profitable," said Mark Ritchie, director of the Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy in Minneapolis. But the farmers who are making the switch are more of a trickle than a flood.
ONE barrier may be the new national standards that the Agriculture Department is proposing for the industry. The aim is to overcome the consumer confusion caused by having more than 40 different private and state groups, often with conflicting rules, certifying which products are organic. But the proposed national standard is so restrictive -- at the industry's own insistence -- that Ms. DiMatteo and other experts contend that some farmers now selling "organic" products may no longer qualify.
Other hurdles are deeply rooted. "Everything in agriculture has been built around a simplified rotation of one or two crops," said Rich Welsh, an agriculture economist and rural sociologist at the Henry A. Wallace Institute in Beltsville, Md. To grow more crops in rotation -- a requirement for organic certification -- farmers would need to develop an array of new markets and systems for storing and distributing their products.
Labor could also be a barrier to growth, at least in the United States. Rapid expansion could leave the industry short of qualified inspectors to certify organic products. And many organic crops require periodic weeding by hand or other labor-intensive care.
"When we got started, we thought it was a good thing that it needs more people," said Thomas Beddard, of Chambersburg, Pa., who started Lady Moon Farm with his wife 14 years ago. Now, having become the East Coast's biggest organic vegetable grower, with 400 acres split between Florida and Pennsylvania, he frets about the consequences of his success.
"It's clear we are reliant on poor immigrants and that the work is brutal," Mr. Beddard said.
Perhaps the biggest barrier is the difficult transition from conventional to organic production. When they stop using chemicals on their land, farmers initially get sharply reduced yields. Research by Rodale and others shows that it takes three to five years for organic soil to be built up to high fertility levels and perhaps longer for farmers to learn how to deal with the weed, pest and disease problems they have to confront without chemical help. During the first three years, under nearly universal certification rules, the crop cannot be labeled as organic unless it is grown on previously unfarmed land, meaning that the farmer cannot sell it for a premium price. Some farmers also struggle to figure out how to market their crops.
"One of the hardest things about the organic industry is getting the information you need to get into it," said Gary Reding, a fifth-generation Indiana farmer who is converting 250 of his farm's 600 acres to organics.
For all the hurdles, experts say, organics could easily achieve an influential share of 10 percent or more in some parts of the industry. In fact, they already account for nearly one-third of all herb production, according to the Agriculture Department, and high percentages of specialty grains and vegetables.
More important, although once dismissed as clownish, negligent farming, the organic movement is now seen as an innovative standard setter that is pulling all of conventional agriculture toward higher environmental standards and more sustainable practices. This year, for the first time, the Agriculture Department has budgeted $5.5 million specifically for organics research; state universities are scrambling to get their extension agents, who advise farmers, up to speed.
"The trend is to adopt a lot of organic practices in conventional agriculture," said John Diener, who has put 20 percent of his diversified farm in Fresno County, Calif., into Greenway Organic Farms, a 2,000-acre partnership with two neighboring farms. "We've cut the use of commercial phosphate fertilizers on the conventional farm by two-thirds since we started with organic."
And organic farming could be essential to maintaining small farms in the developed world. The premium prices that organic products command can help small farmers earn enough to stay afloat as agriculture in general moves toward the industrial model of ever-larger farms producing food as cheaply as possible, often under contract to a meatpacker or food processor.
FINDING ways to make small organic farmers efficient has been a focus for Rodale and most other organics researchers.
"We're coming from the premise that it's bad for 10 percent of the farmers to produce 80 percent of the food," Mr. Moyer said recently, as Rodale planned to plant this year's crops.
Organic farmers might never have a better chance to gain public support. Their market centers on a growing demographic group -- wealthy baby boomers drawn to what Mr. Hartman calls "healthy lifestyles." These people are willing to pay more for products that they believe are healthier or fresher, better for the environment and more humane for livestock. Many people also see supporting small, local farms as a social good.
Some big companies are also throwing money into raising organics' profile. General Mills acquired Small Planet Foods, the producer of Cascadian Farms and other organic brands, and H. J. Heinz recently bought 19 percent of the Hain Food Group, which makes a variety of organic and "natural" products.
"Visibility with consumers has been a limiting factor," said David Neuman, vice president of sales and marketing for Nature's Path, which distributes organic breakfast cereals and other foods, primarily to natural-food stores. "General Mills put $15 million into marketing Sunrise, their new organic cereal, last year and they did $40 million in sales," Mr. Neuman said -- an amount more than his company brought in for all 30 brands it sells. "They can force-feed the distribution system."
Lately, supermarket chains that once had no interest in stocking organic products have been scrambling to line up reliable suppliers in the highly fragmented industry, especially for the produce aisles. They are competing with upstart retail chains like Whole Foods and Wild Oats Inc., which heavily promote their broad selections of organic goods.
In addition to that generally supportive climate, organic farmers are getting a boost from having what appears to be the perfect public enemy: genetic engineering. Critics of biotechnology, with the support of many organic farmers, have popularized a David-versus-Goliath image of small organic farms threatened with extinction by the products of giant agribusinesses like Monsanto, Novartis and DuPont. Drifting bioengineered pollen will pollute organic crops, they say, and insects will destroy what is left after feeding on transgenic corn and developing resistance to natural pesticides.
The Agriculture Department -- the public-sector face of the agricultural establishment -- helped spotlight the confrontation. Ignoring advice from the organics sector, it issued proposed national organic food standards two years ago that would have allowed ingredients from genetically altered plants and animals. After being inundated with 275,000 negative comments, the agency issued a new proposal this year that would ban transgenic ingredients.
THE controversy lured many biotechnology supporters into denigrating organic farming. They have argued that the public should accept biotechnology because farming without it -- especially organic farming -- is too inefficient to feed the world.
The arguments assume that feeding the world is a priority for everyone in agriculture. That may not be the case for organic farmers. In contrast to the Internet world, where it seems as if every small enterprise would be thrilled to be bought out by a large, wealthy competitor, organic farming circles are engaged in constant, bitter debates over whether big farmers, giant food processors and supermarket chains should be welcomed into the business. Many fear that such a development -- which could accelerate growth rapidly -- will erode the price premiums upon which they rely for survival.
"There's a fundamental conflict because, to a lot of people, this is supposed to be the alternative to the industrial agriculture system," said Charles Benbrook, a consultant in Sand Point, Idaho, who has been a prominent proponent of organic farming. "Is this about getting better food grown in an environmental way to the most people possible, or is it about creating an alternative food system that is small, local and sensitive to issues like social justice?"
If feeding the world organically becomes the main objective, many people in the organic sector say that the blanket opposition to genetic engineering might soften before long. Some organic farmers say genetic engineering has already created some products that they should be allowed to use, like Ecogen Inc.'s pesticides extracted from genetically-altered bacteria grown in fermenters. Such products, the proponents say, are simply more efficiently produced forms of sprays that organic farmers already use.
Others say genetic engineering should be considered where breakthrough gains for sustainable farming might be achieved, such as inventing a perennial form of wheat that could be mowed rather than harvested and replanted each year.
"Among organic farmers the views about transgenics range from 'no, never' to 'not yet,' " said Brian Baker, policy director of the Organic Material Review Institute, a nonprofit group in Eugene, Ore., that rates the acceptability of materials for organic farming.
The partisans of the small and local have the high ground when it comes to poetic thinking; some of them talk, for instance, of developing a society based on "foodsheds," just as the ecology of rivers is based on watersheds -- but the marketplace seems to be moving away from them. Many organic farmers on the East Coast say they are under heavy pressure from larger operations in California and imports from Mexico.
"All the same patterns that affect conventional agriculture are happening in organic," said Jim Crawford, whose New Morning Farm in Hustontown, Pa., is the headquarters for the Tuscarora Organic Growers Cooperative, which represents 20 farms in the area. "We're not even selling that we are organic at this point. We are selling freshness, quality and nearness to our markets."
Mr. Crawford added that sales to restaurants in the mid-Atlantic corridor had jumped from zero to 60 percent of the co-op's total revenue in the last four years.
Even the nation's biggest organic farmers, like the Lundberg family in California's Central Valley, have no intention of betting the entire farm on the organic business.
"About 55 to 60 percent of our sales are organic," said Bryce Lundberg, whose family currently grows organic rice on about 6,000 acres near Richvale, Calif. Although organic sales are way up from the 1970's, their share of the total farm revenue is down from 75 percent because major weed problems forced the Lundbergs to sharply reduce organic production for several years.
"It's a little more profitable, but much higher risk," said Tim O'Donnell, the Lundbergs' vice president of sales and marketing. "There's years when you could lose everything."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS: Open Windows;
The New Math Of Monopoly

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
THE scorecard in the Microsoft case, according to Attorney General Janet Reno, is simple: Microsoft lost and America's consumers won.
After a federal judge ruled on Monday that Microsoft was a monopolistic predator that had repeatedly violated the nation's antitrust laws, Ms. Reno declared, "Thanks to this ruling, consumers who have been harmed can now look forward to benefits." 
 Next, the Justice Department and 19 states who sued Microsoft will propose to the court what sanctions should be taken against the company. Before that happens, however, consider how consumers and the computing world have fared since 1995, when the government case against Microsoft began.
The average price of a personal computer has dropped sharply, while PC's have grown more powerful and versatile. The industry has generated growth, jobs and wealth -- even created, some say, a New Economy that is the envy of other nations.
So why was this costly and sweeping antitrust suit filed against Microsoft nearly two years ago? The answer, according to the government and many antitrust experts, is twofold: to enforce the law and to support innovation.
That is a new rationale for antitrust action, one adapted to the New Economy. In the Standard Oil era, monopoly-busting was about price-fixing. Now, the government claims, monopolies constrain technological change. So the Microsoft case marks what may be an important step in how government and the courts deal with the Internet economy in the future.
The traditional half of the government case was simply a litany of anti-competitive practices: that Microsoft illegally tied its Internet browser to its industry-standard Windows operating system, and then used exclusionary contracts and threats to force computer makers and Internet service providers to shun the products of rivals like Netscape Communications, the pioneer in Internet browsing software.
It was the economic theory underpinning the government's case that was novel. That theory leaned heavily on new thinking about how modern high-technology markets work. In traditional antitrust cases, high prices typically signal a gouging monopolist. There was, in fact, evidence presented that the price of Windows, which runs the basic operations of nearly 90 percent of PC's, would be lower if the company had competition. And industry analysts estimate that the pretax profit on Microsoft's Windows business is an astronomical 90 percent.
Still, Windows accounts for only about 5 percent of the total price of most PC's sold today. So even if Windows prices are slightly higher than they should be, it is not something that consumers would notice. (Microsoft said it raised prices on Windows because it has added all kinds of features in recent years.)
But price seems a less reliable signal of monopolistic abuse than it would be with, say, an oil producer or steel maker, because the cost of producing copies of a software program is virtually zero. Microsoft merely licenses its computer code to PC makers, who then install it. Whether Microsoft sells 100 million or 200 million copies, its costs are all in developing the code to begin with.
"The ground rules have changed economically in cases like this and we realized that in bringing the Microsoft case," said Daniel Rubinfeld, the chief economist of the Justice Department's antitrust division until the end of 1998. "And innovation, much more than price, is what the Microsoft case is about."
The new economics of software, according to the government, mean a dominant company like Microsoft can shape innovation and curb competition with a new weapon -- its technology standard. Windows is the gateway through which all the hardware and software used in the vast majority of personal computers must pass. Microsoft, the government charged, denied rivals early access to its technology, while rewarding its industry friends with cooperation. That raised the barrier to entry, in cost and difficulty, to challengers.
The Microsoft case, according to Mr. Rubinfeld, now a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, marks the beginning of a growing debate over government policy in markets that rely on innovation, software and the Internet. These markets, he says, tend to naturally evolve toward one or two dominant companies (think Cisco in routers for Internet data or eBay in online auctions). They control the technology standards in their markets. What balance should be struck between protecting their intellectual property and insuring that newcomers get a fair chance to compete?
"The goal of policy," said Robert E. Hall, an economist at Stanford University, "is to make sure you hold the door open to the next Netscape, to new entrants who bring innovation to the market."
After hearing the evidence in the antitrust case, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson found last week that "Microsoft mounted a deliberate assault on entrepreneurial efforts that, left to rise or fall on their own merits, could well have enabled the introduction of competition" to Microsoft's markets.
In his fact-finding document last November, Judge Jackson concluded with an impassioned embrace of the innovation theory of consumer harm. At the end of more than 200 pages examining Microsoft and its conduct, he wrote, "The ultimate result is that some innovations that would truly benefit consumers never occur for the sole reason that they do not coincide with Microsoft's self-interest."
Microsoft plans to appeal Judge Jackson's ruling, and the company's chairman, William H. Gates, bridles at its damning depiction of his company. "This ruling turns on its head the reality that consumers know: that our software has helped make PC's accessible and more affordable to millions of Americans," he said.
Microsoft insists that the very acts the government claimed were anticompetitive, like folding browsing software into Windows, resulted in bringing the Internet to the PC-using masses. That was real innovation, Microsoft believes, which deserves praise, not prosecution.
It is interesting to speculate how things might have turned out had Microsoft not, in Judge Jackson's phrase, placed "its oppressive thumb on the scale of competitive fortune."
The most rapid innovation and most venture-capital investment in recent years, experts note, have been in Internet computing, outside Microsoft's stronghold in the personal computer business. Innovation in Internet software, they note, might have gone even faster had Microsoft's actions not hobbled Netscape.
In the PC industry, they add, the most innovative company recently has been the reinvigorated Apple Computer since its cofounder Steven P. Jobs returned and took over in 1997. Again, Apple is largely outside Microsoft's control because it uses its own Macintosh operating system, instead of Windows.
"It's hypothetical, but the argument is that sure things are great in the high-tech economy, but they might have been even better," observed David Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard Business School. "All these things on the Internet would have happened anyway, but they would have happened faster and the quality would have been better without Microsoft's anti-competitive acts."

SECTION: Section 8; Page 11; Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 837 words

HEADLINE: Backtalk;
When E-Mail And Opinions Are Welcome

BYLINE: By Robert Lipsyte

 BODY:
Now that our forum is off and running at the mouth, just a click away on your e-mail dial (TheLipsite@aol.com), your only excuse for not participating is the continuing confusion over college sports: is it professional, semiprofessional, amateur? Are these labels without meaning? Why should we care?
As more colleges go online with their courses, the ultimate Final Four may be played among great cyberuniversities, several of which will probably be spun out of the Microsoft breakup. When a kid from Gates Tech who grew up in a home without a laptop wins most valuable player, we'll know that the old-school values held. 
 Marcia Fogel Yeager, who was one of TheLipsite's first respondents, is definitely old school. By e-mail, she says: "In my dreamworld students would go to college and then try out for the team. Many high school students I know don't even know that Duke or Georgetown are colleges -- they think that's just a team name."
Yeager identifies herself as "an avid sports fan (except when Dick Vitale is broadcasting)," who thinks "greedy players, coaches, TV, sporting goods manufacturers, etc., are dominating the system" and the "N.C.A.A., N.F.L., N.B.A., N.H.L., etc., need to take back the game."
You're right, Ms. Y, but aren't those groups the ones who gave (at least part of) the game away during their greedy snarfle at the trough?
A mailer called Pagresti writes: "All the stories I read over the past four weeks mentioned how good the basketball players were and how exciting the games were, but I never read about how the student-athletes keep up with their studies when they are on the road playing basketball for several weeks at a time. Do they get tutoring? When do they go to school to keep up with the other students? Or do they even go to classes? What do the college presidents say about going to school, or is schooling just another annoyance that the basketball players have to tolerate when they are playing these games?"
This should encourage the Drake Group, that band of tenured desperadoes who met in Des Moines last October in a remarkable conference organized by Prof. Jon Ericson of Drake University. Among the many notable academics in attendance were William C. Dowling, a founder of the Rutgers 1000, which is devoted to de-emphasizing sports at the university; Andrew Zimbalist of Smith College, the noted demystifier of sports economics; and Murray Sperber, Indiana University's antidote to Coach Bob Knight.
In its latest manifesto from the prairie, the Drake Group calls for the end of athletic scholarships and the term "student-athlete" (it's one or the other). The group wants sports controlled by the faculty senate rather than the athletic department. It is demanding full disclosure of all academic aspects -- tutors, course load, choice of major, graduation rates -- of a team and of athletes, except for individual grades.
The importance of the Drakes (they are mostly males, after all) is in their bold challenge to a corrupt system run by their bosses, the college presidents. Coaches may make the headlines and the shoe-contract money, but they are ultimately dependent on the talents of teenagers; meanwhile, the presidents perk on, whether or not the athletes win, whether or not the students learn. The Drakes are also bucking the sad complicity of their colleagues. Too many teachers roll over for coaches. Some are intimidated, others are fans, many just love to rub around in the testosterone pools of the jock culture.
Speaking of testosterone, the social, cultural, political and physical powers of that manly hormone were celebrated in an absorbing article in The New York Times Magazine last Sunday by Andrew Sullivan, who also poses questions for sports. How can women consider competing in most games with men when that most profound distinction, testosterone production, can never be equalized without making women into men? Sullivan adds, "Even more unsettling is the racial gap in testosterone." He cites scientific studies that show black men have 3 to 19 percent more testosterone than white men. He wonders if that could be the reason black men dominate certain sports.
If white men can't jump, they can do androstenedione, a legal supplement that boosts the hormone pumpers. Mark McGwire set the home run record on andro in 1998, although he says he has stopped. Lately, feeling righteous, McGwire criticized Major League Baseball for opening the season in Japan. He said it was a money-grubbing tactic not in the best interests of the pastime.
A reader, Jothar, comments to TheLipsite: "For Mark McGwire to turn down a trip to Japan because it was just about money is absurd. Since its inception, professional baseball was all about money. This Japan trip is merely a new twist in the sport's relentless pursuit of Mammon. Fifty years from now, we'll be waxing nostalgic about the very first advertising patches to be featured on major league uniforms, and it will involve our very own Mets."
What do you think?

HEADLINE: Angolan Paradox: Oil Wealth Only Adds to Misery

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola

 BODY:
Measured by the abundance of its oil and the paucity of its population, this is potentially the richest country in Africa.
Not that Antonio Dodge Domingo would know. 
 On the balcony of his second-floor apartment, human excrement splatters day and night. His neighbors toss it by the bucketful from above.
In Angola's capital, Mr. Domingo, his wife, his seven children and his hundreds of upstairs neighbors fill a 17-story building that has no electricity, no telephones, no elevators, no windows, no garbage pickup and no plumbing. A contractor abandoned the concrete shell 25 years ago, fleeing to Lisbon upon Angola's independence from Portugal.
Mr. Domingo's children often have dysentery, probably from playing on the balcony or from the brown water oozing down walls in the kitchen. They also get malaria, from mosquitoes in a lagoon next to the building. Garbage tossed from the building has carpeted the lagoon. Three neighborhood children have wandered into the garbage in the last two years and drowned.
"I am not happy at all, but there is no way out," said Mr. Domingo, 48, who has a doctorate in political science from the University of Bombay, runs a private English language school and has been living in the building for eight years. "I have to live according to the reality of my country now."
For decades, reality in Angola has been ruled by the paradox of plenty: oil wealth has helped to pay for an endless war between President Eduardo dos Santos, who heads the government, and his bitter foe, Jonas Savimbi, leader of the Unita rebels. That, in turn, has increased poverty and ill health for almost all Angolans. This country has the world's highest rate of citizens maimed by land mines (1 out of every 133). One third of children die before age 5; life expectancy is just 42 years.
If the paradox holds, Angola is ripe for even more misery. Recent offshore discoveries have made it one of the hottest oil-producing countries in the world. Production will probably double in the next five years.
For the United States and other gasoline-hungry Western countries, oil makes Angola more than merely another troubled country in Africa. It already accounts for 7 percent of America's annual petroleum consumption, and probably at least 10 percent by 2005.
Mr. Domingo's stinking apartment tower in downtown Luanda is anything but exceptional. The capital has four million residents but only about 20,000 of them have running water or modern toilets. At low tide along the Marginale, the walkway that curves along Luanda's bay on the Atlantic, the smell of sewage is so overpowering it is hard to walk without becoming nauseated.
Experts say the government could easily afford to build a sewage treatment plant and pipe drinking water into the city. There are two rivers nearby and the war is far from the capital. By default, millions of poor people in Luanda pay up to 10,000 times more for drinking water than the elite, who can turn on the tap.
Every night, the police and soldiers seal off the center of the capital, home to the ruling elite of about 30 families. The government does not want angry people invading the better neighborhoods after dark.
Across this Texas-sized, mineral-rich and immensely fertile country, the government offers its 12 million citizens social inequity and repression. More than two-thirds of Angolan children reach adulthood with four years of schooling or less. Illiteracy rates -- 50 percent for men, 70 percent for women -- are high by African standards and rising. The children of elite families in the government, meanwhile, study abroad on state scholarships, which in recent years have consumed up to 36 percent of all government spending on education.
Last year, according to American government officials, Angola's rulers spent about half of a $900 million windfall in oil earnings on weapons, many of which were purchased purely for kickback potential. These officials say that Angola's leaders apparently stole a substantial part of what they did not spend on weapons. International banking officials say the $900 million was not recorded in the country's published budget.
American oil company executives joke bitterly that they pay for Angola's main community development program: the transfer of money to banks in Zurich and Geneva.
BP Amoco, Chevron, Exxon Mobil and 24 other oil companies are planning to invest about $19 billion here over the next decade in deep-water offshore drilling rigs. There is widespread nervousness among publicly held multinational companies that bad publicity about corruption, social injustice and human rights abuse in Angola could threaten these investments.
Oil executives remember the consumer boycott that stung Shell when it was linked in the early 1990's to the human rights abuses of Nigeria's military rulers and the hanging of a prominent dissident.
"We know we are going to be under huge scrutiny," said David Rice, a senior political adviser in London for BP Amoco, which last year joined three other oil companies in paying a $350 million "signing bonus" for rights to an offshore field. "This is a wonderful cocktail for global public attention: oil, diamonds, civil war and land mines. If we are seen to be part of the problem, we have lost it. We have to be seen as part of the solution."
The State Department and the International Monetary Fund are pushing Angola to carry out reforms that would open up the economy and spend far more oil money on social services.
"There is a decision that they are going to have to make," an administration official said. "If they are serious about wanting to reconstruct their country, they are going to have play by a different set of rules than they have in the past."
For decades, the Angolan government pointed to the civil war as an excuse for all failings. The war with Unita, which began before Angola's independence in 1975, soaked up most of the oil money while ruining the country's infrastructure.
The government, though, finally seems to be winning. Unita has been pushed out of the diamond-rich Cuango River valley. Military analysts say rebels no longer have the diamond revenue necessary to pay for major ground operations.
As oil production ramps up and fighting ramps down, war is no longer an all-purpose excuse for bad government, as President dos Santos himself acknowledged in a recent speech.
The government has announced $250 million in new programs to rebuild infrastructure and grant loans to small businesses. For the first time, it has promised the I.M.F. that it will allow outside auditors to examine the way it spends oil money.
The I.M.F. and the United States government are prepared to accept a deal that would ignore past corruption and insist only on openness in the future.
The United States needs Angola's oil, and American officials concede that this need dampens their willingness to criticize the government or demand too much, too fast. "That is realism," a State Department official said.
In other respects, Angola seems impervious to the greater openness now seen across much of Africa. When a few people assembled in the streets of Luanda in February to protest a government-ordered, 1,600-percent increase in gas prices, the police beat them with clubs. An Angolan journalist and human rights campaigner, Rafael Marques, was sentenced the end of March to six months in jail for writing an article accusing Angola's president of corruption.
The change in oil accounting, if it happens, will reduce corruption, but will not affect arms deals and other business, said Gerald J. Bender, an associate professor of international relations at the University of Southern California and an expert on Angola. "I don't think there is ever going to be transparency in that," he said.
A number of companies, including Chevron, Exxon Mobil and BP Amoco, have built schools, orphanages and health clinics in Angola. But they are scarcely in a position to demand social reforms from the government as a condition for expanding oil production.
In the end, consumers are more interested in gasoline than Angola's social problems, said an American oil executive who has worked in Luanda for years.
"You cannot expect oil to hit our shores at a reasonable cost with conditions placed on what the equity holders must do to extract that oil," he said. "Angola will say 'forget it,' and take their oil elsewhere."
In his high-rise slum in downtown Luanda, Mr. Domingo, too, is reluctant to say anything remotely critical about the government. As a squatter, he could be ordered out of his building at any time. "Now," he said, "is the time to keep quiet."

HEADLINE: Kofi Annan's Millennial Vision

 BODY:
Part of Kofi Annan's job as secretary general of the United Nations is to think big thoughts about the future of the planet. Last week he made the most of that responsibility by outlining an audacious vision for the world organization in the 21st century. It would be easy to dismiss Mr. Annan's comprehensive vision as, in his own words, "absurdly ambitious." But it deserves a wide audience.
In a report setting the agenda for a millennium assembly in New York in September to which all the world's leaders are invited, Mr. Annan reiterated his advocacy of environmental protection, military interventions to stop genocide and mass murder, and curbs on weapons proliferation. But his most intriguing appeals focused on imaginative efforts among states, nongovernmental organizations and the private sector to fight poverty and disease. 
 Mr. Annan is right to suggest that the U.N. take the lead in bringing the Internet and other information technologies to poor nations. Throughout the developing world the Internet can greatly enhance access to markets, government efficiency and education at all levels. He announced plans to create an innovative volunteer corps, the United Nations Information Technology Service, to train groups in developing countries to use the Internet. He proposed an Internet health-care network for 10,000 on-line terminals in hospitals and clinics to provide access to medical information.
Mr. Annan stakes out worthy goals for the next 15 years: to halve the proportion of the world's people -- currently one in five -- whose income is less than a dollar a day, and to halve the proportion of people -- also one in five -- without access to safe drinking water. He endorses a World Bank plan to improve the lives of 100 million slum dwellers by 2020. He proposes that the U.N. work with the pharmaceutical industry and other partners to develop an affordable vaccine against AIDS, and sets a goal of reducing H.I.V. infection rates among young adults by 25 percent in 10 years.
No doubt the world will fall far short of these targets. Only a day after Mr. Annan's report was released, the U.N. Development Program concluded that there has been little progress in combatting poverty in the last five years. The main impediments, it found, were corrupt and authoritarian governments. The Clinton administration should heed Mr. Annan's call to drop trade barriers against exports from the least developed countries, a view the White House now opposes. America and other industrialized countries should also lift the debt of poor nations.

HEADLINE: Germans Seek Foreign Labor For New Era Of Computers

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: BERLIN, April 8

 BODY:
Vinod Kymar, the political counselor at the Indian Embassy here, is a puzzled man. Never in his many years in Germany has he read so much about his country in the press, nor found so much of it to be nonsense.
"High technology seems to have suddenly become synonymous with India here," Mr. Kymar said. "But the Germans are waking up about a decade late. The United States has already taken the cream of our talented computer people. All that remains for the Germans are leftovers." 
 India's occupation of center-stage in Germany's political debates began a few weeks ago with an apparently offhand remark at a trade fair from Chancellor Gerhard Schroder. He said his country urgently needed new talent in its high-technology sector and should be prepared to give residency documents, or green cards, to brilliant Indians.
The remark reflected a serious issue: underfunded, state-run German universities have been very slow to adapt their traditional curricula to reflect the explosive growth of Internet-related industries. In all of Germany, there is just one newly created chair in e-commerce, at the Goethe University in Frankfurt.
As a result, in a country with more than four million unemployed, there are an estimated 75,000 to 100,000 jobs vacant in the booming Internet sector, with few Germans apparently qualified to fill them. Hence the Social Democratic chancellor's sudden infatuation with Indian software engineers.
"We urgently need new programmers and developers for our projects, but we generally find the German education with its focus on heavy philosophical concepts does not turn out the people we want," said Amelie Heinrichsdorff of Acotec, a start-up software company based in Berlin. "We think globally and would like to hire talent wherever we can."
The dot-com view of the world is still far from that of Germany's opposition Christian Democratic Party. When the government began drafting a law to allow up to 20,000 foreign computer specialists into Germany with green cards, an outcry erupted.
Jurgen Ruttgers, a leading Christian Democrat, produced a campaign slogan in Germany's largest state, North Rhine-Westphalia, saying, "Children instead of Indians." Chancellor Schroder described the posters as "indecent and economically damaging."
Later, Mr. Ruttgers refined his message slightly, urging, "More education instead of more immigration." He was supported by the substantial wing of his party that remains deeply opposed to the idea of Germany as a "land of immigration," despite the fact that more than seven million foreigners live here.
But the difficulties of the Christian Democrats' anti-foreigner message became evident when Dieter Hundt, the head of the powerful employers' federation, lambasted Mr. Ruttgers' campaign as "poorly thought out and miserably populistic."
The sight of big business and conservative Christian Democracy tearing each other to shreds is novel in Germany. But then this is a time of substantial political and cultural shift, with the Social Democrats adopting many pro-business measures and many Germans developing a sudden infatuation with the Internet. Yet even the government's methods appear marked by bureaucratic hesitations of old.
Walter Riester, the Social Democratic labor minister, has proposed limiting the stays of the new green-card immigrants to an initial period of three and a maximum of five years. He also wants to shape the proposed law so that jobs would be offered to foreigners only after an extensive search has been made for a qualified German.
But Antje Radcke, a leader of the Green Party, which is the junior partner in the coalition government, said such proposals were far too cumbersome. "If we should have learned one thing from the experience of the 'gastarbeiters' who started coming here in the 1960's, it is that attempts to try to limit the stays of people are doomed to failure."

HEADLINE: Port Aransas Journal;
Residents Reassessing Spring Rite Of Students

BYLINE: By ROSS E. MILLOY

DATELINE: PORT ARANSAS, Tex., April 3

 BODY:
Out on the back porch of Woody's bait stand, in a salt-thick breeze off the Gulf of Mexico, Johnny Mathews, a fishing guide, flicks the foam from a cold beer and weighs in on the topic of students on spring break: "It's not that they're bad people. They just don't know how to act like normal people."
By normal, he means like native Texans. 
 An estimated 300,000 college students or families celebrating spring vacations have come and gone from the sandy Gulf beaches that stretch 100 miles from here to South Padre Island.
And left behind are mounds of trash, some alcohol casualties recovering in emergency rooms, and a debate rekindled every year by residents of the Texas coast: Is the annual raucous, crowded rite of spring really worth the money, and the aggravation?
Because towns like Port Aransas and South Padre thrive primarily on the tourist trade, one would think that any visitor with a credit card would be highly prized.
But with the economy in full blossom and with the residents increasingly restless about rapid growth in their once-small communities, the value of crowds is being debated.
"Cities that once fought over the spring break crowd are now becoming a lot more selective, particularly when it comes to the college kids," said Ann Vaughan, a Chamber of Commerce executive in this weather-beaten fishing village of 2,100 people, which had 100,000 visitors last month.
Problems with traffic, lewdness and general rowdiness, particularly among college students, have prompted Port Aransas to change the focus of its marketing away from students, she said.
"They can come if they want to, but they have to play by our rules," Ms. Vaughan said.
"Give us the families and let the students go to South Padre," says Larry Stimson, captain of a bay fishing vessel called the Island Queen, who has lived in both cities.
"The families will come with a set amount of money and spend every bit on beer, hotels, restaurants, fishing trips, and other tourist stuff," Mr. Stimson said.
"But the students bring their own beer, sleep on the beach, and just might buy a loaf of bread and some bologna. They don't have any money, so you can't get any out of them," he said.
Other cities have come to this conclusion. Fort Lauderdale, Fla., once attracted as many as 350,000 students on spring break. But Nicki Grossman, president of the Convention and Visitor's Bureau, says, "Now, we don't even like to see Fort Lauderdale and the 's' word used in the same sentence."
This year, Fort Lauderdale attracted only 15,000 students out of 550,000 visitors in March, she said. "We got rid of MTV and got rid of the wet T-shirt volleyball games," she added. "When MTV went, the lemmings went with it. We felt that if the kids could graduate, so could we."
Ms. Grossman said open container laws, police visibility, and a half-billion dollars in beach clean-up programs and community investments made it possible to discourage the student crowd and attract the more lucrative family vacation business.
"The college student business was worth about $110 million a year at its peak, but the current family market we cater to brings in between $450 and $500 million," Ms. Grossman said. "If the weather stays good and the kids stay away, everything's fine for us."
South Padre Island has become known as a vacation destination among students, and the resident population of 2,000 swells to nearly 200,000 during spring break, says Jennifer Beck of the Convention and Visitors Bureau.
Dr. Vern Vincent of the University of Texas Pan American at Edinburg says last year's crowd resulted in $700,000 in sales and hotel tax revenues to South Padre.
"Spring break comes during the off-season and it really helps the local businesses," he said.Everyone benefits from having the spring breakers there."
But there are problems.
Charles Morrison of the South Padre Police Department said his office arrested 530 people during this year's spring break, up from the normal 15 to 20 monthly arrests. "Most of those are driving while intoxicated arrests, and virtually all of those are students," he said.
Back on the porch at Woody's, Mr. Mathews, who has lived his entire life in Port Aransas, said that even though he finds the spring visitors' habits peculiar, particularly their driving, the economic benefit of their presence is worth the inconvenience.
And that includes the college students. "You just have to learn to go where they're not," he said.
But for some residents, any visitors are too many. A popular bumper sticker asks: "If it's called tourist season, why can't we just shoot them?"

HEADLINE: Good Times Could Burden An Incumbent In Greek Vote

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

DATELINE: ATHENS, April 8

 BODY:
For Greeks, their economy, their standing in Europe and even their tense relationship with Turkey are better now than at any time since World War II.
And it is this new confidence that could be the biggest liability for Costas Simitis, the Socialist prime minister, in what has shaped up to be an extremely close race for re-election on Sunday against his challenger, Costas Karamanlis, leader of the center-right New Democracy Party. 
 While Greek voters may be more or less satisfied with Mr. Simitis and his party, Pasok, those who are weary of the Socialists' long lock on power and secure enough now to look for change, may be tempted to take a risk and select a fresh, if untested, face, analysts say.
"Voters are making up their minds on something that is not discussed in public and cannot actually be done at the polls," said Thanos Veremis, a political analyst who heads a foreign policy research group in Athens. "How to change the government without getting rid of Simitis? Greeks are happy with him, but they are tired of the Pasok party's rule and the corruption that comes with longevity."
The choice is made more tempting still by the closeness of the candidates economic and foreign policy platforms. Both espouse the same fundamental choices for Greece -- cooperation with the United States and other NATO allies, and cautious rapprochement with Turkey and fiscal restraint to meet prerequisites for membership in the European Union's joint currency, the euro.
The campaign itself has focused on unemployment, health care, schools and the feverishly volatile Greek stock market, which boomed last year but has since plummeted, enraging small-time investors.
Pasok has held power since 1981, interrupted only between 1990 and 1993. Elected in 1996, Mr. Simitis, 64, quickly shed the welfare state policies and passionately anti-American rhetoric of his flamboyant predecessor, Andreas Papandreou.
Like Prime Minister Tony Blair in Britain, he moved his party toward the center. Two years ago, the Greek economy fell embarrassingly short of the minimum standards for the euro. Greece has since caught up, cutting inflation, public debt and interest rates and stabilizing the drachma, and it is almost certain to be included to use the euro next January.
That success could work against Mr. Simitis, since he called early elections on the grounds that Greece needed a stable, experienced government to lead it to the euro. Greeks already believe that has been done.
Mr. Karamanlis, 43, a lawyer who studied foreign policy in the United States and is fluent in English, does not suggest he would do differently, just better. "We are the authentic expression of a European orientation," he said at a campaign rally at the Olympic Stadium in Athens on Thursday.
He complained when Greece supported Turkey's effort to be considered for membership in the European Union, saying the government had failed to wring enough concessions from Turkey. But those nationalist sentiments seem mainly aimed at garnering votes. He assured American academics at a private lunch last year at his alma mater, the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy in Boston, that Turkey belonged in Europe, using the same pragmatic language as the Greek foreign minister, George Papandreou.
During the NATO bombing campaign in Kosovo, which was fiercely opposed by almost all Greeks, New Democracy again sought to tap into popular sentiment by fiercely denouncing the United States and its allies, at times echoing the rhetoric of Greece's small, hard-line Communist Party. But few in Greece believe that if Mr. Karamanlis were elected, he would reverse the current government's foreign policy.
Mr. Karamanlis, who has spent his career in New Democracy Party politics, is mostly counting on voters' thirst for change. But his chief credential is his lineage as the nephew and namesake of Konstantinos Karamanlis, the founder of New Democracy and a legendary former president and prime minister who coaxed the European Union to accept Greek membership in 1981, six years ahead of Spain or Portugal.
The absence of polarizing policy disputes has forced a curious reversal of roles -- Mr. Simitis campaigned as a capitalist while Mr. Karamanlis moved left, portraying himself as the champion of labor unions, farmers and other constituencies usually claimed by Socialist parties. But his chances mainly rest on whether voters will trust him to competently execute policies Mr. Simitis pushed through.
Many have not yet made up their minds. "I will decide at the last minute," Maria Christodulakou, 36, a schoolteacher in Sparta, said today. "They do not really differ," she explained. "I don't think there is a big risk if either man is elected."

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Teen Startup: 18 and Wired For Business

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.

 BODY:
THE executives of the company running the school district's computer system don't need to be told a thing about the network or fiber-optic cables or even which teacher is all thumbs on a mouse. All they need is a call every morning about 8 from the district secretary, Pat Raynor, to make sure they're awake.
That's what the district gets for hiring a couple of teenagers. 
 Kris Sims and Sean Myrden, both 18 and 1999 Riverhead High School graduates, are president and treasurer of Eastern Digital Intranet Services. Last week the school board accepted their $73,940 proposal to oversee the Long Island district's 600-computer network for a year. And why not?
They helped build the system as 16-year-old interns and maintained it as technicians after graduating. When the school board terminated the contract of its technology director earlier this year, they bid against five companies, some boasting long experience and millions in annual sales.
But it's hard to bid lower than two guys living with their parents.
"I don't know if either of them has a mortgage," said Bryon Duffy, the adult president of Tech2Logic, which bid $170,000. "They don't need the big bucks other people need."
Need is not in Kris and Sean's vocabulary. Boys in the wonderland of technology, they followed a youthful fascination to big prizes. They've forgone college and other trappings of an old economy that, for them, might as well be an exhibit at the Museum of Natural History.
"I would like the college experience," said Kris, who tried a few months at Suffolk County Community College. "But at 18, I feel like I'm beyond that. Maybe I'll go to college when I'm 30, when I'm retired."
They met in high school, both drawn to rock 'n' roll and computers. Sean, whose father is a computer consultant, helped wire computers as a child. Kris fell hard for them at 14. In their working-class town, they were always scouting odd jobs. After pestering school officials, they were hired as interns between their sophomore and junior years and helped install hundreds of computers. They became indispensable. Between classes they were pulled away to solve computer problems. After graduating, they became $50-an-hour technicians. Now, Kris said, "we're situated."
Young and wired, the teenagers' world view is all giddy exuberance and serious money.
They considered Silicon Valley after hearing of a school employee's relative whose salary and stock options there made him rich on paper. "Thirteen million or $1.3 million," Kris said. "Some big number."
When Kris mentioned a building they saw as a possible headquarters one day, Sean interjected, "Someone bought that."
"Really?" Kris said, briefly disappointed. "Oh well, everything's always for sale."
Kris, the exuberant partner, said: "I would be personally happy if I made $100,000. Well, probably $80,000 I'd be happy with." This year.
BRASH, perhaps, but in six months last year they made about $80,000. Their contract allows for extra pay for additional school projects. Opportunities elsewhere seem plentiful. Their competitors for the contract hardly wrote them off. Some offered them jobs.
Robert J. Holmes, the Riverhead Central School District superintendent, is thrilled that local boys made good, but said they pose a challenge to educators: "How do we accommodate the kids who are very bright but say, 'Sorry, I don't have time for the traditional stuff.' "
The boys are not fretting. Kris has a Corvette. Sean has a Lexus. They're in a rock 'n' roll band. They're the hottest startup in Riverhead. "I wear khakis every day and eat at McDonalds," Kris said. "It's a field like no other. It's run by young people. It's not an institution yet. It's not run by suits."
Sean's father, John, said he told his son: "Remember these events. Remember these times. They don't happen that often."
Sean, working at his computer, "looked at me like I was crazy," Mr. Myrden said. "I could see the 18-year-old in him saying: 'This is going to happen all the time. We're going to make this happen.' "

HEADLINE: On an Upstate Road Trip, Mrs. Clinton Says She Has Found Evidence of Crossover Support

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

DATELINE: OWEGO, N.Y., April 8

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton, apparently bolstered by an uptick in support from upstate voters, said today at two small-town campaign stops that she saw evidence that many Republicans would cross party lines to back her Senate bid.
"I've had more and more Republicans coming up to me," Mrs. Clinton told 50 Democrats who had gathered for a brief stopover at an Italian restaurant in this Tioga County village. "They came, both men and women, and said they would support my campaign both because they really want to continue the policies of the president, and because they want somebody in the Senate who will work with everyone in New York." 
 Earlier in the day, Mrs. Clinton made almost identical remarks at the annual Broome County Democratic Party Breakfast in Endwell, a suburb of Binghamton. Responding to reporters here, she said her evidence of growing Republican support was "just anecdotal." She said supporters she had met on this two-day road trip from Rochester to the Binghamton area "identified themselves as Republicans, and that is gratifying to me."
Mrs. Clinton also focused briefly on the upstate Republican vote in her final campaign appearance today in Corning, where she addressed 500 people at a meeting of the New York State Democratic Rural Caucus. She attended the event with H. Carl McCall, the Democratic State Comptroller, who is widely expected to run for governer in 2002.
Repeating an earlier pledge to campaign in all of the state's 62 counties before the November election, and saying she had already visited 51, Mrs. Clinton told the Corning group, "I want to convert a lot of those rural Republicans."
In other remarks, Mrs. Clinton sought to ally herself with moderates and fiscal conservatives within her own party. At one point in her Binghamton speech, in which she pointed to the success of the White House in reducing the federal deficit and invoked Franklin D. Roosevelt's phrase "rendezvous with destiny," saying she advocated a "rendezvous with responsibility" in fiscal policy.
Mrs. Clinton also took several occasions during her campaign stops today and on Friday to portray herself as someone with long experience in upstate New York. In describing her advocacy of more stringent gun control, she said she had spent "every summer" of her youth at a cottage on a lake near Scranton, Pa., and had frequently visited Binghamton. "I was taught how to shoot, not well I admit," she said, adding that she had "nothing against gun ownership, and nothing against hunting or sport shooting."

HEADLINE: Cloud on Fujimori's Future Shadows Voting in Peru

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 8

 BODY:
For a decade, President Alberto K. Fujimori has been Latin America's master of crisis management, defeating terrorist insurrections, hyperinflation and drug traffickers, as well as settling a 150-year border dispute with neighboring Ecuador.
But as 14 million voters decide on Sunday whether these successes should translate into five more years in office, Mr. Fujimori faces his most serious political crisis since he shut down the Congress and Supreme Court at the height of the guerrilla war in 1992. 
 Even if he ekes out a first-round election victory, diplomats and experts say, the campaign has been so marred by dirty tricks and legal irregularities that Mr. Fujimori will emerge a weakened leader. Several leading pollsters say a first-round win is unlikely unless the president resorts to fraud, and election observers have already received reports of preparations to steal the vote.
"The accumulation of irregularities has meant that even if the vote goes without fraud, President Fujimori's third term will be seen as illegitimate here and abroad," said Eduardo Stein, a former Guatemalan foreign minister, who is leading an 80-member Organization of American States observation team.
"This was not a fair competition," he added, "and if the landscape of campaign irregularities is replicated on the day of the vote, it will be a disaster."
The outcome is important not only to Peru, where the little real debate and independent media coverage the campaign has generated has been infused by discussion of the legitimacy of the electoral process itself.
It is also likely to reverberate throughout a region where many countries are still struggling to define the quality of their democracies. This is particularly so in Venezuela, where another elected strongman who has bent his country's democratic rules, President Hugo Chavez, is facing a growing challenge in an election set for May.
A stolen victory would also place the United States in the awkward position of having to decide whether to censure an important ally in the effort to wipe out the drug trafficking and insurgency that threaten the government in nearby Colombia.
The challenge to Mr. Fujimori is being led by Alejandro Toledo, a 54-year-old business school professor whose rise from humble roots has helped spur his popularity. He has also capitalized on the growing concerns about the campaign as well as grumbling over three years of particularly bad economic hardship.
Press and television smear campaigns believed to be directed by Mr. Fujimori's intelligence service destroyed the candidacies of two leading opponents.
The campaign has been dominated over the last three months by a scandal over the forgery of a million signatures to put Mr. Fujimori on the ballot, egg-throwing mobs at opposition rallies and microphones that went dead in the middle of opponents' speeches. There have also been persistent reports from around the country that recipients of government milk and cereal handouts have been threatened with a cutoff if they do not vote for the president.
As Mr. Fujimori tried feverishly to stop Mr. Toledo, television networks owned by allies of the president began broadcasting a comedian impersonating the challenger sitting next to a whiskey bottle. Nude dancers appeared at a Toledo campaign rally this week with television cameras in tow for live broadcasts, inspiring speculation by many Peruvians and senior foreign election observers that the dancers were planted by the Fujimori campaign.
At the same time, an active duty army officer was assigned to fetch a young girl from the provinces said to be the illegitimate daughter of Mr. Toledo for a television talk show. And the government began an investigation into the residency visa of Mr. Toledo's wife, Eliane Karp, a Belgian-born American citizen.
Mr. Toledo has denied the charges leveled against him, and pollsters say he has surged in recent days in Lima, a Fujimori stronghold with more than a third of the nation's votes. Mr. Toledo has vowed that he will cry fraud should he lose.
The campaign irregularities have been severely criticized by the Clinton administration, the Organization of American States and several public interest groups like the Atlanta-based Carter Center.
Senior diplomats here are already discussing calls for a new election and for withdrawing recognition of the government by the Organization of American States. Peru's mounting political problems will confront the organization with one of its biggest tests in years, its officials said privately. They said they expected Canada and the United States to try to mediate any conflict.
"It's a moment of great crisis for the regime," said Enrique Zileri, editor of Caretas, Peru's leading political magazine. "If Fujimori wins in the first round, a government that is totally isolated and lacking legitimacy would result."
Questions about the election process began emerging in May 1997, when Congress dismissed three members of the Constitutional Tribunal who had ruled that the law forbade Mr. Fujimori from running for a third term. The opposition assembled enough signatures to force a referendum on a third term in 1998, when Congress, tightly controlled by Mr. Fujimori, ruled that two-thirds of the legislators would also have to approve of a referendum, sinking the vote.
By the time Mr. Fujimori announced his candidacy last December, the opposition had no way of challenging the legality of his campaign. There has been sporadic violence over the issue, , but no leader has emerged to channel the discontent.
Now Mr. Toledo, who has said the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. is his hero, says he is ready to lead a vast civil disobedience movement to protest the results should he lose.
He has made a special plea to the army and police to guard the elections. And to make his candidacy more attractive to them, he has promised to raise police salaries and allow military personnel to vote in the future. His pleas have been backed by senior retired military officers who oppose Mr. Fujimori, and there are reports of discontent about the electoral process among middle-rank army officers.
International observers have already expressed fears of an organized effort by Mr. Fujimori's allies to steal the election.
The Organization of American States observer team has received numerous reports indicating that backers of Mr. Fujimori are training hand-picked poll watchers in how to mangle vote tally sheets that have large Toledo vote counts so that they will be disqualified. In 1995, 8 percent of tally sheets were disqualified in the presidential vote and 40 percent in the vote for Congress, enough to guarantee Mr. Fujimori's control, according to election observers.
Other international observers have received reports that voters dependent on government food and social programs have been given ballots already marked for Mr. Fujimori and his congressional slate. The voters -- observers say they are not sure how many may be involved -- have been instructed to return the blank ballots they receive at the voting places for payments ranging from about $1.50 to $3.
Observers say that fewer than half of the 88,000 voting tables will be monitored by independent election inspectors. They also note that, after being counted, ballots are immediately destroyed on election day, depriving observers crucial evidence of potential fraud. Tally sheets, however, will be preserved.
In an effort to detect fraud, a local group, Transparencia, financed by the Clinton administration and several other foreign governments, will announce its own estimate of the vote count Sunday night from thousands of sample voting tables.
"They have problems," Carlos Tapia, formerly a lecturer at the Army Superior Intelligence School, said of the Fujimori campaign. "They can fudge 4 or 5 percent of the vote, but no more."

HEADLINE: Pressure Is Raised on Cuban Boy's Kin

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
The Clinton administration is inexorably increasing the pressure on the Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez to reunite him with his father -- and hoping it happens without resistance.
President Clinton, who has reason to be chary of the lingering cold war passions that divide the United States and Cuba, has tried to moderate the tensions set off by the case of the Cuban boy. But the Justice Department, with the White House's concurrence, has nonetheless made ever more clear that the government's patience is nearing its end. 
 The major question facing administration officials at this point is whether persuasion alone will bring about a peaceful transfer of the boy next week, or whether it will take the force of law to overcome defiance among the Miami relatives and their crowds of supporters.
A White House official said today that a number of plans had been prepared for the handover of Elian to his father, including his removal from the home of Miami relatives by armed federal marshals. The official added that it was the hope of everyone in the government that the return of Elian to his father's custody would be accomplished voluntarily and peacefully.
The official said: "Are we capable of enforcing this action by force? Yes. Does anybody want to see that happen? No."
The Justice Department said today that the father would meet on Sunday with three three psychiatric experts who are to visit with the Miami relatives the next day, all part of the preparations to transfer custody of Elian.
For Mr. Clinton, the Cuban issue has been a problem for two decades. Mr. Clinton links his 1980 re-election defeat as governor of Arkansas in part to rioting among 20,000 Cuban refugees temporarily resettled at Fort Chaffee, Ark., by the Carter administration.
As president, Mr. Clinton has walked a careful line on relations with Cuba, at once offering modest steps to increase cooperation and travel between the two countries while maintaining the strict 38-year-old economic embargo on the island.
Acting on cue from the president, officials from the White House, State Department and Justice Department all expressed hope in public and private this week that the boy's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, who arrived here on Thursday from Cuba, could work out an amicable custody deal with his Miami relatives, who have kept Elian since he was rescued at sea last Thanksgiving.
Elian's mother, Elizabet Brotons, died when their boat sank as they fled Cuba.
The administration does not relish the idea of Cuban-American Miami rebelling over the repatriation of Elian. But neither does it want to jeopardize a slow and delicate diplomatic opening to Havana begun last year.
Even as other agencies are handling the emotional issue of the shipwrecked boy, the State Department is trying to manage an incremental opening to Havana. Last year, the administration announced that it would permit additional charter flights to Cuba from the United States and would approve significantly more visas for researchers, athletes, journalists, artists and students to travel to Cuba.
The Baltimore Orioles played an exhibition game against the Cuban national team last spring and other sports events are planned.
The United States is also quietly seeking broader cooperation with Cuba on immigration, drug smuggling, the environment and human rights matters.
Mr. Clinton has repeatedly said that the case will be handled under existing immigration law, most likely resulting in Elian's return to Cuba with his father and his stepmother, Nercy Carmenate Castillo.
A senior White House official said that administration officials were of one mind on the matter -- with the exception of Vice President Al Gore, who last week broke with the president and announced that he wanted the case moved into Florida family court, where Elian's relatives in Miami might have a better chance of winning permanent custody.
"There's no split in the administration over what we hope happens," the official said. "There is great concern if the family in Miami seeks a confrontation, there's no telling what direction this could go in."
Robert Pastor, who handled Latin American policy at the National Security Council under President Jimmy Carter, said that Mr. Clinton should harbor little hope of separating the Gonzalez case from 40 years of pained history between the United States and Cuba.
Mr. Pastor also noted that Cuban-American tensions always seemed to rise in election years and that this case offered no exception.
"There is no U.S.-Cuban issue that is not politicized," said Mr. Pastor, now a professor of political science at Emory University in Atlanta. "The United States and Cuba have been contesting a divorce for 41 years, so it's not surprising that this would be the mother of all custody fights."
Mr. Pastor said the riots at Fort Chaffee in June 1980, which left more than 40 Cubans and Arkansas law-enforcement officers injured, had caused a strain in relations between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Carter that took years to heal.
Mr. Clinton blamed Mr. Carter for sending thousands of Cubans to Arkansas without adequate provision for their security.
Mr. Clinton's defeat in 1980 remains to this day his biggest electoral disappointment.
A diplomat monitoring the case at the State Department said that officials there were "happily out of the picture." He expressed hope that Justice Department and immigration officers could persuade the families to agree to a peaceful transfer of Elian to his father's care.
Justice Department officials have said that while they believe the department has authority to order the boy's immediate handover to his father, officials were trying to handle the case in a "sensitive" manner and would be willing to accept a few days' delay to accommodate the wishes of Miami family members.
But they have now set a schedule for meetings on Monday to discuss the methods of the handover, with the boy's return to his father coming shortly after that.
"The administration has to handle this very delicately because of the intensity of feelings, and it's not going to be easy," Mr. Pastor said. "It's not going to be easy."
