HEADLINE: '70 Abortion Law: New York Said Yes, Stunning the Nation

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 8

 BODY:
To one side, it was an epochal breakthrough for women's rights. To the other, it felt like the end of civilization. A defining political and cultural event, it stunned nearly everyone, and its tiniest details remain etched in the players' memories.
Thirty years ago this week, New York State legalized abortion, adopting the country's most liberal law, three years before the Supreme Court legalized abortion nationwide. 
 The state's decision turned on hard-to-predict legislative votes and tactical errors by abortion opponents. The drama, which several participants recalled in interviews this week, was decided by the last-minute change of a single vote.
New York had a Republican governor then, Nelson A. Rockefeller, and Republicans controlled both houses of the Legislature. Of the 207 legislators, just 4 were women.
Surviving supporters of that 1970 bill will celebrate the anniversary on Tuesday at the Yale Club in Manhattan, at a reception sponsored by the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League, known as Naral. Their adversaries plan no gathering, but are acutely aware of the date.
By 1970, a few states had carved limited exceptions out of what was essentially a nationwide ban on abortion. Hawaii had approved the nation's first broad legalization, but it applied only to Hawaii residents. New York was second, its law went further, and it had no residency requirement. In the first two years, 60 percent of women having abortions in New York were from out of state.
In the early 1960's, Assemblyman Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan introduced New York's first bill to loosen the prohibition. In 1967, 1968 and 1969, the Assembly defeated bills to permit abortion under very limited circumstances. But before 1970, the Senate majority leader, Earl W. Brydges of Niagara Falls, a staunch abortion opponent, would not allow a vote in his house.
In separate interviews, some of the surviving participants shared their memories of the legalization debate:
 
John J. Marchi
Republican senator from Staten Island
"Abortion had barely entered into the public dialogue. I remember attending the New York State Constitutional Convention of 1967, and there wasn't a single bill on the subject, nor was there any advocacy."
 
Manfred Ohrenstein
Former Democratic senator from Manhattan
"We were living in a time of enormous change. There was the war. There was the women's movement, which was really bringing the abortion issue to a crescendo. It was the end of the civil rights era, and we viewed this as a civil right. In '65, we had repealed the death penalty, which people thought was impossible. There was a sense that extraordinary things were possible."
 
Lawrence Lader
Then chairman of what was called the National Association for Repeal of Abortion Laws
"We had just formed Naral, in February 1969 at a meeting in Chicago. We decided at that first meeting to concentrate on New York State as our breakthrough state. We felt that New York represented our best opportunity, and we knew that other states often looked to New York as setting an example. So we set up tables and gathered petitions in key districts in New York."
 
Barbara Shack
Then an organizer with the New York Civil Liberties Union, now president of the board of Naral
"The campaign to change the law was largely run by men, which really tells you about that time. And people forget that back then, a big part of the argument was about economics. Women with money could get abortions. They could pay doctors to do them, or they could go to Puerto Rico or to another country. Poor women, on the other hand, were dying in droves from unsafe abortions."
 
Michael R. Long
Chairman of the New York State Conservative Party
"Abortion was a nonissue up until then. The party wasn't even united on it then, because nobody had given it much thought. We first put a pro-life plank in the party platform in 1968, and we had a big internal fight about it. Nobody -- and I mean nobody -- expected this to become a reality."
 
Constance Cook
Former Republican assemblywoman from Ithaca
"I followed Al Blumenthal's bills with great interest, but a Democrat really couldn't get a bill passed in those days, with the Republicans in control. So in '69, Franz Leichter and I sponsored a bill for a full-fledged repeal, and we did it again in 1970."
 
D. Clinton Dominick III
Former Republican senator from Newburgh
"Al Blumenthal and Fred Ohrenstein came up with the strategy of doing it first in the Senate. The Senate was perceived to be the more conservative house, and they thought if the Senate passed it, that would improve the chances in the Assembly. So Fred Ohrenstein came to me and said, 'Would you be a sponsor?' I told Fred, 'Only if you get a bunch of other Republicans to be co-sponsors.' A couple of days later, he came back to me and said the only other Republican who would be a sponsor was Roy Goodman. But I said O.K., anyway. And then Fred said they decided that it would be best to have a Republican as the prime sponsor. So without my doing much of anything, I became the prime sponsor."
 
Warren M. Anderson
Former Republican senator from Binghamton, later the majority leader
"There wasn't all that much lobbying on it, and especially not against it. The big groups that have formed around this issue over the last 30 years barely even existed then."
 
LONG
 "We didn't really gear up over it because we didn't think it would pass. It came rather fast, and it even took the church by surprise, because their main concern was the aid for schools. I remember a lot of us being kind of angry at the Cardinal Terence Cooke and the bishops for not doing more, that if they had all gone to Albany, it would have changed the outcome."
 
LADER
 "The Catholic Church was caught off guard. They didn't think we had a chance, so they were really not that loud on the subject until the end. The church was really focused on a bill for state aid to parochial schools. The other strategic error was by Earl Brydges, in letting it come to a vote. There were bills to create limited allowances for abortion, but Brydges made sure that what came to a vote was a bill for out-and-out pure repeal, full legalization, no restrictions. A lot of his colleagues said it was a ploy on his part, because he thought the more liberal the bill, the more likely it would be defeated, and that would put an end to it. He just miscalculated."
 
ANDERSON
 "To this day, I don't know why Earl allowed a vote. Generally, he was pretty forthright about what he was up to, but this was one he kept to himself. I was as close to him as anyone in the Legislature, and I don't know what he was thinking."
 
Roy M. Goodman
Republican senator from Manhattan
"It was the most fascinating debate we've ever had in the Senate, because the outcome was really unclear, and furthermore it struck me as likely that some minds might change. It was a very tense thing. I remember I studied for literally days, looking into the embryology of the fetus, preparing for the debate. I was looking at diagrams and books on biology and anatomy."
 
MARCHI
 "It was a cliffhanger, and a number of people unexpectedly voted in favor of it. I wasn't persuaded that we had lost until we had the roll-call vote. I was in disbelief."
On March 18, 1970, the Senate was packed. The debate took more than five hours.
"From those of us opposing this bill I hear a buoyancy and a luminous debate," Mr. Marchi said in the floor debate. "But from those on the other side I hear plaintiveness and anguish. And it must be this way, for we are for life and they are against it."
Mr. Goodman said: "The present abortion law encourages butchery. We torture the fetus and we allow them to be born in stunted and twisted form. This law presses down unmercifully on the poor. Is this equality under God?"
Several senators had refused to say in advance how they would vote, and even as the roll call began, the result was unclear. Mr. Brydges spoke last, his voice gravelly and slow. "I have a deep, real, abiding conviction that this is the wrong way for the state to go," he said, "because we are a bellwether state, and many other states will follow our lead."
The tally was 31 for, 26 against. Thirteen Republicans and 18 Democrats voted for the bill; 20 Republicans and 6 Democrats voted against.
 
OHRENSTEIN
 "Here was the majority leader of the Senate, a very powerful man, a respected man, Earl Brydges, a very orthodox Catholic, and he got up and made a speech, practically in tears, and he was heartsick. He could have stopped it, but he said that he wasn't going to stand in the way of the majority."
 
GOODMAN
 "It hurt him tremendously that the vote worked out the way it did. When it was over he slumped into his chair and just dissolved in tears."
 
LADER
 "The Senate vote set the Catholic Church off, and then they really started to put pressure on the Assembly members. They had children at parochial schools write letters to Assembly members. Cardinal Cooke had a pastoral letter read in every church. When it came to a vote, there were nuns and priests walking the floor of the Assembly."
 
COOK
 "After the Senate vote, we amended the bill in the Assembly because it had no restrictions at all, and we didn't think that had a very good chance of passing. So we made it unrestricted abortion up to 24 weeks, and after that only for the life of the mother."
 
Franz S. Leichter
Former senator who was then a Democratic Assemblyman from Manhattan
"We had the first vote on March 30 and it was 73 for to 70 against. But we needed 76 votes, an absolute majority of the house, for it to pass. That certainly cast a pall and made us very apprehensive, but we agreed to table it and try to bring it up a second time on April 9 . . . . People were really torn, as a matter of conscience and as a matter of politics. People who had voted yes the first time voted no, and people who had voted no the first time voted yes. I spent 30 years in the Legislature, and it was one of maybe 20 times that I saw a bill come to floor where you really just didn't know what was going to happen."
Midway through an agonizing roll call, Assemblyman George M. Michaels, a Democrat from a heavily Catholic, central New York district, quietly voted no.
The count ended at 74 to 74. One Assembly member was absent. Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr., a Montauk Republican, did not vote, in keeping with the tradition that the speaker votes only if it affects the outcome.
Before the clerk could bring the vote to a close, Mr. Michaels stood and asked to be recognized. At first he rambled, his voice thick and trembling, and it was unclear where he was headed. But heads turned when he said his constituents would "condemn me for what I am about to do."
"One of my sons just called me a whore for the vote I cast against this," Mr. Michaels said. Another son had told him, "Dad, for God's sake, don't let your vote be the vote that defeats this bill."
"I fully appreciate that this is the termination of my political career," he said. "But Mr. Speaker, I must have some peace in my family. And I therefore request you, Mr. Speaker, to change my negative vote to an affirmative vote."
He crumpled into his seat and buried his face in his hands as bedlam swallowed the chamber. Someone screamed epithets at him. Mr. Blumenthal kissed his forehead.
Mr. Duryea cast the final "aye" vote, making it 76 to 73. Voting yes were 46 Democrats and 30 Republicans. Voting no were 24 Democrats and 49 Republicans.
The next day, the Senate passed the Assembly version of the bill. The day after that, April 11, Mr. Rockefeller signed it into law. "The wives of the Senate and the Assembly put this bill through," he said.
In that year's elections, Assemblyman Michaels, Senator Dominick and a handful of others who supported the bill lost to anti-abortion challengers. Mr. Brydges, who retired in 1972, died in 1975. Mr. Michaels died in 1992 at age 80.
In 1972, the Legislature voted to repeal the 1970 law, but Mr. Rockefeller vetoed it. In January 1973, the Supreme Court made its landmark ruling in Roe v. Wade, patterned in part on the New York law.
 
COOK
 "I didn't really have a sense at that time that we had done something momentous, though it was long overdue. Looking back now, it seems like a bigger deal."
 
LONG
 "It's interesting to look back and see how the New York Republicans have tended to remain a moderate party, while the national Republicans have moved to the right on abortion and other issues. Look at George Pataki and Rudy Giuliani, who are both on the opposite side from us on this issue. The Republicans in New York actually have a pro-choice plank in their platform."
 
MARCHI
 "Abortion has become fairly automatic. It's a tragedy. I don't think you're going to have total elimination of it, but I think you will see a gradual evolution of measures against it. I would say this and capital punishment are the worst things the Legislature has done in my time here."
 
SHACK
 "This was absolutely the most important thing I ever did. We knew that nothing would ever be the same again. We knew that we were changing the world."

HEADLINE: A Test Is Born

BYLINE: By Jim Yardley; Jim Yardley is a correspondent for The Times based in Houston.

 BODY:
"Okaaay,"
Beverly Nedrow begins gingerly, holding up three pieces of paper. "Everybody has read this breathtaking piece. I don't think it's one of our stellar pieces, but I think it will do." 
 Shannon Henry-Robinson and Charles Fuhrken smile faintly, withholding judgment on a story titled "Water Hole Rescue." They are sitting inside a conference room stuffed with textbooks, three-ring binders and other classroom materials, though they work for a multimillion-dollar corporation, not a school.
Outside, a chain-link fence surrounds the building. Visitors pass by a guardhouse and register with a security officer in the reception area. The company's name, the Psychological Corporation, lends a touch of mystery to the work carried out behind the building's dark reflective glass facade.
What does go on here?
The Psychological Corporation of San Antonio makes the standardized tests that evoke fear and dread in millions of students across the country, the same tests that can determine whether students graduate from high school or win placement in advanced classes or simply get to the next grade.
So sitting around a conference table, Ms. Nedrow, the leader of the company's reading and language arts group, is debating with two members of her staff about whether "Water Hole Rescue" can be included in one of those tests. The story, submitted by a freelance writer in rural Texas, tells how an elderly farmer and his two sons, Emilio and Carlos, rescue a cow stuck in a water hole. The plot, designed for eighth graders, is fairly simple: the family uses a block-and-tackle device to pull the cow out and save its life.
Ms. Henry-Robinson, a teacher until six months ago, is skeptical. She questions whether teenagers can identify with such a tale. "I still want to know," she exclaims, "will these eighth graders be interested?" Will they be able, she asks, to identify a block-and-tackle? Will urban and suburban children get it?
What about the title? Mr. Fuhrken asks. Will it confuse students? The characters are obviously Hispanic. Is this inclusive or is it prejudicial? And does the story provide enough grist for a reading section? One of the key words is "laborious." Students will be tested on its meaning within the story. But everyone agrees that the writer's use of the word is awkward. The story will need to be rewritten.
As it turns out, the story is rejected, and not because of the concerns stated around the table. Stories, after all, are frequently edited and rewritten. Instead, the problem is that a reporter has listened to the conversation.
So "Water Hole Rescue" cannot be saved, which is fine. There are hundreds of other stories to choose from, thousands more questions to write.
How is a standardized test made? In a politically charged environment in which several tests have been challenged in court, the quick answer is: Very carefully. And, it must be added, with much secrecy -- not only to prevent questions from reaching students before test time, but because the companies that dominate the testing market are intensely leery of surrendering any competitive advantage, real or perceived.
Among the biggest testing players are three of the major textbook publishers. CTB/McGraw-Hill publishes the TerraNova, which in modified form is used to help determine grade promotion in New York City. Riverside Publishing, owned by Houghton Mifflin, makes the popular Iowa Test of Basic Skills. And Harcourt Brace, the parent company of the Psychological Corporation, makes the Stanford Achievement Test, which has existed in different forms for nearly 80 years and is widely used throughout the country, including, in an augmented version, as California's state test.
None of these privately held companies will divulge the size of the testing market or what share they control. Without question, testing has become an enormous business, and a very profitable one. Harcourt's 2000 catalog is nearly an inch thick. In addition to the Stanford, Harcourt creates, publishes or administers customized tests for about two dozen states, including Texas, Florida and Connecticut.
For two days in late February, Harcourt officials allowed a reporter to visit the San Antonio offices of the Psychological Corporation to learn how a test like the Stanford is made. Because the company regards this as a secure test, access was limited; secrecy is considered so important that a photographer was not allowed to shoot even the cover of one test book. And some employees seemed a bit nervous talking with a reporter.
Eugene T. Paslov, the president of the Psychological Corporation, acknowledges that the timing was delicate. Harcourt's credibility suffered last summer after it erroneously reported that English as a Second Language students in California had fared better than they actually did. The mistake angered education officials in California. The error came as a rival company, CTB/MacGraw-Hill, made scoring errors that caused almost 9,000 New York City students to be unnecessarily ordered to mandatory summer school.
Together, the foul-ups underscore the consequences of testing in an era in which a failing score can prevent a student from graduating.
"We've been beaten up pretty soundly," says Mr. Paslov, who became president after a shakeup precipitated by the scoring mistake. "Once you get into high-stakes scoring, even minor mistakes can really blow up. So people are gun-shy."
Mr. Paslov, an affable former state schools superintendent in Nevada and Michigan, attributes the California mix-up to a communications breakdown between the company and the state, and notes that it has been corrected. He believes that tests, and how they are made, are widely misunderstood by parents, teachers and students, especially with their increasing use by the standards movement as a way to create accountability. Mr. Paslov sees tests not as the enemy but as part of a larger effort to improve education.
"We believe we hold a critical position in that reform movement," he says.
Undoubtedly, this is the era of the standardized test.
Once, generic tests like the Stanford or Iowa Test of Basic Skills were the industry's stock in trade. These tests are available by catalog and remain popular with cities, schools districts and even individual schools.
But accountability is a hot educational and political buzzword. Politicians like Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, have made testing students a priority. As politics has changed, so has the testing business. Mr. Paslov estimates that 70 percent of his company's testing business comes from creating custom tests for states. States want to control the test and what it covers, rather than order one from a catalog.
By the year 2003, according to the United States Department of Education, 26 states will require that students pass a test to graduate from high school; currently, 18 states require such a test.
This shift to high-stakes testing has not happened without controversy. Critics complain that a single test should not determine graduation, particularly since they believe the tests are unfair to minorities and low-income students. Dr. Monte Neal, executive director of Fairtest, a testing reform advocacy organization in Cambridge, Mass., argues that standardized tests are an inexact tool to measure what a student knows, especially since most questions are multiple choice. They might, he contends, test whether a student knows the name of a certain concept but not whether that student can actually use that concept. "The test may not tap into thinking skills," he says.
In the testing world, there are no such things as questions. Instead, there are "items." And every month, thousands of items pour into the Psychological Corporation from freelance writers, teachers, military retirees and others who are paid every time an item, or question, is accepted. "Water Hole Rescue" is one example.
The process of creating a test actually begins long before the writing and editing of items. In the case of the Stanford, company officials say three to five years are needed to make a new edition. (Stanford 9 is in current use; 10 is in preparation.) By contrast, a customized state test requires 18 months to three years, partly because state officials, not the testing company, usually determine the curriculum and standards.
"When we sit down and we say, 'Let's put out a new edition of Stanford,' we literally say, 'O.K., we need to start at ground zero,' "says Patricia Pederson, 46, who has worked for the Psychological Corporation for just under two years. Ms. Pederson, a former teacher who has a doctorate in curriculum and instruction, oversees the social science items.
In the case of the Stanford, she spends 18 months reviewing professional journals, textbooks, national and state standards, curriculum guides and other publications. This review allows her to develop a "blueprint" detailing when a student -- say, in the third grade as opposed to the fourth, or vice versa -- can be tested on a certain concept.
The blueprint itself is scrutinized by outside experts -- men and women of all races, many of them education professors from different regions of the country. "We'll send them out some questions they should address, and then we say, 'Rip this apart!' "Ms. Pederson says. It will serve as the framework on which the test is built.
It is at this point that items are written and edited. With companies like Harcourt developing dozens of tests every year (the Stanford series alone has a different test for grades 2 through 11), the demand is huge. Last September, the company received 12,000 questions from freelance item writers.
Marilyn Rindfuss, a public school teacher for 25 years before she joined the Psychological Corporation 11 years ago, is the company's national mathematics consultant, in charge of developing math questions. She recalls how, as a teacher, she often grimaced on test days because of frustration that the tests seemed so disconnected and irrelevant to what she did in the classroom. Then she joined the enemy.
"It's like being a politician who complains about the government, and all of a sudden you're speaker of the House," Ms. Rindfuss says.
Now, she proselytizes about testing with a missionary's zeal. Once, while driving in Mississippi after a snowstorm, she jumped out of her car to measure a circular bale of hay to create a test question.
She knows that teachers still complain about how test questions are written. (Because the term "multiple choice" evokes negative images in the minds of many teachers and students, the company prefers the euphemism "selected response.")
She says she strives to make the questions not only precise but also interesting and written to provoke higher cognitive skills. As an example, she offers a sheet of paper showing an "old-style" multiple-choice question: it includes a picture of a rectangle that is 6 inches tall and 8 inches wide. The question asks, "What is the perimeter of the rectangle shown below?" The answers are (a) 48 inches, (b) 28 inches, (c) 24 inches, (d) 14 inches.
The answer is "b." But, as Ms. Rindfuss notes, the simplistic architecture of the question fails to test a full range of cognitive skills.
She pulls out another sheet of paper with a similar question asked differently. First, there is no picture of a rectangle. Second, there are no answers to choose from. Instead, there is only this:
"A rectangular piece of cardboard is 8 inches long and 6 inches wide. As the first step in making a paper box, Lisa cut a one-inch square from each corner of the cardboard and threw the squares away. What was the perimeter of the polygon that remained? Show or explain how you got your answer?"
The answer remains 28 inches. But Ms. Rindfuss says that this format offers a window into how a student thinks. Increasingly, standardized tests include more of these open-response questions.
Writing questions is one thing. Choosing which ones are included on the test is another. It is a complicated process freighted with potential controversy, particularly in reading and social studies, where interpretation can be wide ranging.
"This is our dilemma," says Ms. Nedrow, the reading supervisor. "We want things that students are going to be interested in reading. But we want to be certain we don't offend people."
For example, Ms. Nedrow discourages stories about grandparents dying. What if a student taking a test had just lost a grandparent? It could hamper the student's performance. Will rural or suburban students understand a question about landlords and tenants? Can test makers include words like "got" or "like" without infuriating teachers? (No.)
Ultimately, national tests must have a universality that finds common ground among students with different backgrounds. And this is often one of the biggest complaints: that shelf, or catalog, tests are too generic. The Education Trust, a national nonprofit group concerned with achievement levels of low-income students, recently published a report calling for more rigorous tests that measure students against established state standards.
Amy Wilkins, a principal partner at Education Trust, complains that tests like the Stanford are norm-referenced -- designed to rank students against a national norm and fit them into a bell curve. These tests were intended to help teachers place students in appropriate academic settings like gifted or remedial classes. But many school districts and some states use them for high-stakes purposes. Miss Wilkins argues that this defeats the purpose of the standards movement: tests graded on a curve, even if customized, measure how students compare against one another, not whether they have mastered the standards.
The rigor of customized tests also varies. The Education Trust report, for example, commends the New York State Regents exams, which are created without the help of a testing company, as a true measure of the state's standards. Test-making companies say they must cater to each state's requirements in levels of difficulty, as well as any distinctive culture and mores. Ms. Rindfuss recalls how one state rejected a math question involving an AIDS quilt, while another state was "thrilled" to use the question.
Perhaps no question looms as heavily over any test as whether or not it is fair to minority students. Earlier this year, a Federal judge in San Antonio upheld the constitutionality of the Texas Assessment of Academic Skills, which is made by the Psychological Corporation. The Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund had asserted that the TAAS discriminated against minorities; in particular, that the test itself is biased, and that low-income students suffer because their schools often do not cover all the curriculum included in the test. The judge agreed that many poor, minority students suffered from attending inadequate schools. But, noting rising minority scores and that students could take the test seven times, the judge upheld the state's right to administer the test and establish standards.
For test-making companies, the issue of bias resonates throughout the process. Test writers now consult baby-naming books for a variety of ethnic names. An in-house committee reviews questions for discrimination or insensitivity, then ships the questions to a bias review committee of consultants for assessment.
Yet tricky situations are common: in one state test, the reading cluster included a story about a Latino youth struggling with the computer. Another Latino youth tutored him and, ultimately, the original boy mastered the computer. Ms. Nedrow and the rest of the reading staff approved the story. But state officials vetoed the story because it initially depicted the Latino youth in a negative light.
"It was painful for us when we put in all that effort and then we see it go," Ms. Nedrow says. "With all the lawsuits that are out there, they'd rather be safe than sorry."
One of the most critical stages of the testing process comes when the test itself is tested. Inside the Psychological Corporation, this is known as the tryout. A few thousand students across the country take the test, providing the raw materials for a statistical analysis conducted by people like Ed Slawski, who is known as a psychometrician. He crunches the results of the tryout and evaluates every question. This information is boiled down to hard numbers for internal analysis.
Sitting in an upstairs conference room, Ms. Pederson, the social science leader, holds out a spreadsheet taken from Mr. Slawski's numbers: each of the 28 social studies questions on a first-grade test is assessed. First, Ms. Pederson notes, every question is assigned a P value, which roughly represents the percentage of students who got it right. If, for example, Question 5 has a P value of .62, Ms. Pederson is happy.
She wants questions to fall between .52 and .79, a middle range that suggests the questions are hard but not too hard. (A .24, on the other hand, indicates that most students are missing the question.)
Of course, the P value cannot truly determine whether a question is hard.
Ms. Pederson notes that students will struggle with a question that is poorly written or ambiguous. So she may tinker to make it more precise. She also ensures that patterns do not emerge; for example, that every third question has answer "b."
In choosing her questions, Ms. Pederson is essentially choosing ingredients for a soup. Her goal is to create a test with a range of difficulty and subjects.
Each question is then analyzed for discrimination. Minority students who took the tryout will be lumped together by achievement. If high-achieving minority students did poorly on Question Five, even though high-achieving white students did well on that question, Ms. Pederson must decide whether to keep the question. In some cases, she will throw it out, in others she will not.
Critics are particularly concerned about this part of the process, which is known as banding. While Dr. Neal credits testing companies for improving the fairness of tests, a change he says has coincided with rising minority scores, the method of including or excluding questions is inexact, he asserts. How many questions, for example, are thrown out? Harcourt does not say. Others, like Al Kaufman, a lawyer who represented the Mexican American education fund, says that companies would never include a question that minorities got right and whites overwhelmingly got wrong.
he scoring season beGins in March and continues into the summer, when more than seven million tests pour into a drab yellow building on a commercial strip in San Antonio. There is no sign in front of the building. Trucks arrive night and day, delivering thousands of brown boxes filled with completed tests.
Walking through the 200,000-square-foot building, Mr. Paslov and Clark Miller, who runs the scoring operation, describe the scope of the task: tests are placed on blue library carts, then cut along the binder by machines and scanned into a computer. The computer automatically grades the multiple-choice questions and electronically feeds the open-response questions to rows of computers in large grading rooms.
Grading these questions is more subjective, and states often dictate how the company should do it. Often, a monitor conducts daily reviews to ensure grading is being done fairly and accurately.
From beginning to end, the process of grading a batch of tests is completed within 28 days. During the high season, as many as 1,000 full-time and part-time employees handle the huge crush, everyone packed into a building about as charming as a textile mill.
"It's not really glamorous, is it?" says Mr. Miller.
No, glamorous would be incorrect.
Competitive. Secretive. Disciplined. Evolving. Controversial. Educational. Any of those answers would be correct on a multiple-choice test.
Outside the scoring center, the temperatures are unusually mild as Mr. Paslov climbs into his car to return to the main office. The next week he will fly to California for a conference, and on to other states to talk tests. He is well aware of the criticisms of the tests made by his and other companies. Like others on his staff, he takes it seriously but tries to keep a sense of humor. Employees joke that it is not safe to disclose their professions at cocktail parties. But they can also sound evangelical -- some describe test days as "days of celebration" for the students.
Try telling that to a classroom of 11th graders.
 
Standards: A Primer
THE MOVEMENT: Today's clamor for measurable performance standards started with "A Nation at Risk," the 1983 federal report that questioned students' ability to compete in a global economy. By the 90's, with business leaders complaining that high-school graduates lacked basic math and reading skills, many politicians answered with a single mantra: standards.
STANDARDS: Professional associations representing various fields of study responded by establishing voluntary national standards. Today, every state but Iowa has written its own standards, describing what children should be able to do at given grade levels. Some standards are vague. Delaware kindergarteners through third graders "will use calendars, clocks, schedules and written records to record or locate events in time." Others, like New York State's, are more specific. The state publishes learning standards in seven fields, defining reasoning skills (say, applying mathematical and scientific analysis to problem solving) and presenting specific benchmarks (say, recognizing the order of whole numbers and commonly used fractions in the first and second grade).
HIGH STAKES: A critical component of the movement is assessing student progress. Increasingly, rewards and penalties directed at schools, administrators and children are tied wholly or in part to test scores. In 18 states, high- school students must pass tests to graduate, and many school districts base grade-level promo- tions on test scores. New York City students take a citywide test at third, fifth, sixth and seventh grade. The scores help officials determine whether to promote the students, said Bill Weichun, director of assessment for the Board of Education. Scores on state fourth- and eighth-grade tests are also used in promotion decisions.
OFF-THE-SHELF TESTS: National tests, like the Iowa Test of Basic Skills, Stanford Achievement Test and TerraNova, base questions on the national standards, regional curriculums and testing research. States, districts or schools purchase these to give outright or they are augmented with additional questions.
NORM-REFERENCED TESTING: Most national tests are scored by comparing student results to a national norm; results are expressed as a percentile. To determine norms, which are typically configured every seven years, test makers give exams to a representative sampling of students. Progress toward standards cannot be assessed with norm-referenced exams because they test how students compare with others, not how much of them they know. New York City uses a modified TerraNova, a norm-referenced test published by CTB/McGraw-Hill, and is working to match its questions to state standards to create a criterion-based exam.
CRITERION-BASED TESTING: This system measures student performance based on standards. Scores are reported as levels -- not proficient, basic, proficient, advanced. Without a curve, everyone theoretically can be proficient. More and more states, including Kentucky, Maryland, Texas, Michigan and Ohio, are creating exams based on standards.
PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENT: Educators are moving away from multiple-choice questions toward open-ended questions requiring longer answers. In math, for instance, students must show how they got their answers. New York City is developing a test that will combine the multiple-choice TerraNova with its PAM and PAL tests (performance assessment in math and in language arts). This year, sixth graders take the combined test in language arts and fifth and seventh graders take it in mathematics. PAULA L. PARK

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Education Life section last Sunday about problems with high-stakes testing referred incorrectly to a test used by the Philadelphia school district. It is a customized Stanford Achievement Test, not an unmodified Iowa Test of Basic Skills.
A picture caption with an article about learning disabilities misstated the status of Ashley C. Rondini at Landmark College. She is a faculty member, not a student.

Bottom, the secrets of test making are taught.; Piling up the tests in a warehouse for shipment to anxious children throughout the nation. Chart: "TEST MAKING: Questionable Questions"
Test companies strive to avoid vague or misleading questions. Here are some questions used for training at the Psychological Corporation, which makes the Stanford Achievement Test.
1. Knowing all the different kinds of land forms is important to the study of geography, and there are many kinds, including islands and peninsulas. This land form is best described as:
A. Land surrounded by water
on three sides.
B. A narrow neck of land connecting
two larger land masses.
C. Land surrounded on all
sides by water.
D. A beach surrounded by cliffs on three sides.
Critique: The item is not clear, as two land forms are mentioned. The antecedent for "this land form" is ambiguous. The item is also not concise, since the question could simply be, "What is a peninsula?"
2. According to the graph, what percent of the city's residents use the public library regularly?
A. Less than 20 percent
B. Less than 30 percent
C. Less than 50 percent
D. Less than 75 percent
Critique: Option A is subsumed by Option B; thus, if A is correct, so is B. Option C is subsumed by Option D; thus, if C is correct, so is D.
3. Who was the author of "Hamlet"?
A. William Howard Taft
B. William Wordsworth
C. William Shakespeare
D. William Jennings Bryan
Critique: For the options to be viable, all should be authors. The two politicians would be viewed as throwaway options.
4. In the story, Melissa decided to go to college after all because . . .
A. She didn't know what else to do.
B. Marco talked her into it.
C. She was afraid she would lose RJ.
D. Her uncle offered to pay her
tuition and give her a monthly allowance for four years.
Critique: The fourth item stands out, so students might select or avoid it strictly on the basis of its length.
5. Which of these has the largest diameter?
A. A baseball
B. A jai alai ball
C. A tennis ball
D. A golf ball
Critique: Unless students have had experience with all of these balls, the question is unfair. The jai alai ball clearly represents bias, as relatively few students would know anything about its size.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: They Threaten, Seethe and Unhinge, Then Kill in Quantity

SERIES: RAMPAGE KILLERS -- First of four articles: A Statistical Portrait

BYLINE: By FORD FESSENDEN; Reporting for this series was by Fox Butterfield, Ford Fessenden, William Glaberson and Laurie Goodstein, with research assistance from Anthony Zirilli and other members of the news research staff of The New York Times.

 BODY:
They are not drunk or high on drugs. They are not racists or Satanists, or addicted to violent video games, movies or music.
Most are white men, but a surprising number are women, Asians and blacks. Many have college degrees, but most are unemployed. Many are military veterans. 
 They give lots of warning and even tell people explicitly what they plan to do. They carry semiautomatic weapons they have obtained easily and, in most cases, legally.
They do not try to get away. In the end, half turn their guns on themselves or are shot dead by others. They not only want to kill, they also want to die.
That is the profile of the 102 killers in 100 rampage attacks examined by The New York Times in a computer-assisted study looking back more than 50 years and including the shootings in 1999 at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., and one by a World War II veteran on a residential street in Camden, N.J., in 1949. Four hundred twenty-five people were killed and 510 people were injured in the attacks. The database, which primarily focused on cases in the last decade, is believed to be the largest ever compiled on this phenomenon in the United States.
Though the attacks are rare when compared with other American murders, they have provoked an intense national discussion about crime, education and American culture. The Times found, however, that the debate may have largely overlooked a critical issue: At least half of the killers showed signs of serious mental health problems.
The debate was most intense last year, which began with echoes of gunfire in a Salt Lake City television station in January and ended with seven Honolulu office workers dead in November. In between there was a berserk rampage by an Atlanta day trader that left 12 dead and 13 injured. A self-styled fascist attacked a Los Angeles day care center. Seven people died as a hymn ended in a Fort Worth church.
Probably the most shocking were the shootings by two students at Columbine High School who burst into suburban classrooms and killed 13 and wounded 23. The teenage killers were much like the adults The Times studied, but with important distinctions that may bring a better understanding to the problem. Page 29. As the anniversary of that crime, April 20, approaches, the questions about crime and culture will inevitably reverberate again.
The Times set out to examine as many of these killings as possible in an effort to learn what factors they and the people who carried them out shared. For while many possible causes have been cited, including violent video games, a decline in moral values and the easy availability of guns, there has been little serious study of this explosive violence.
The Times included only rampage homicides -- multiple-victim killings that were not primarily domestic or connected to a robbery or gang. Serial killers were not included, nor were those whose primary motives were political.
These are among the findings:
*While the killings have caused many people to point to the violent aspects of the culture, a closer look shows little evidence that video games, movies or television encouraged many of the attacks. In only 6 of the 100 cases did the killers have a known interest in violent video games. Seven other killers showed an interest in violent movies.
*In a decade that had a sharp decrease in almost all kinds of homicides, the incidence of these rampage killings appears to have increased, according to a separate computer analysis by The Times of nearly 25 years of homicide data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Still, these killings remain extremely rare, much less than 1 percent of all homicides.
*Society has turned to law enforcement to resolve the rampage killings that have become almost a staple of the nightly news. There has been an increasing call for greater security in schools and in the workplace. But a closer look shows that these cases may have more to do with society's lack of knowledge of mental health issues, rather than a lack of security. In case after case, family members, teachers and mental health professionals missed or dismissed signs of deterioration.
Whether they happen in a school, in a mall, in a crowded train or in a workplace, these crimes have been characterized in a language of incomprehension -- "senseless," "random," "sudden," "crazy."
By contrast, murder in the heat of domestic passion or a tavern argument, in the desperation of armed robbery or in the cold calculation of gang competition, seems to make "sense."
But in reviewing court records and interviewing the police, victims and sometimes the killers themselves, The Times found that these killings, too, have their own logic, and are anything but random or sudden.
The rage that boiled over into homicide was clearly building in many. Of the 100 cases reviewed by The Times, 63 involved people who made threats of violence before the event, including 54 who threatened specific violence to specific people.
Richard Farley, for example, who was fired in 1987 for harassing a female co-worker, told acquaintances he was going to kill the people who had come between him and her before storming into his former workplace, killing seven. James Calvin Brady told psychiatrists he wanted to kill people, just days before he went on a rampage in an Atlanta shopping mall in 1990.
"These are not impulsive acts," said J. Reid Meloy, a forensic psychologist at the University of California at San Diego. "They are not acts of affective violence, where they drink a lot and go kill someone. There's a planning and purpose, and an emotional detachment that's very long-term."
Yet there was often a precipitating event in addition to histories of failure and mental illness -- a spark that set off the tinder, and gave the crime the appearance of being at the same time deliberate and impulsive.
"You can see someone who is morbidly depressed for a long time, and they have a suicide plan in place, but the timing is determined by impulse," said Kay Redfield Jamison, a professor of psychiatry at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine and author of "Night Falls Fast: Understanding Suicide" (Knopf, 1999).
By far the most common precipitator was the loss of a job, which was mentioned as a potential precipitator in 47 cases. A romantic issue -- a divorce or breakup -- was present in 22 cases.
"Some men see the loss of a job, or the loss of a mate, as irrevocable and catastrophic, something they can't get back or attain again," said David Buss, author of "The Dangerous Passion: Why Jealousy Is as Necessary as Love and Sex" (Free Press, 2000) and a professor of psychology at the University of Texas at Austin. "They set out on a course to inflict the maximum cost on their rivals, even sometimes killing the woman."
An analysis of the database found several recurring elements in rampage killings, including some that surprised the experts.
Perhaps the aspect that most set these crimes apart, aside from their spectacular nature, was this: Regular criminals try to get away with their crimes. More than a third of regular homicides went unsolved in 1997. But among the 102 killers in the Times database, not one got away. Eighty-nine never even left the scene of the crime.
In 1995, for example, after he killed three people at the Ohio trucking company where he had worked, Gerald Lee Clemons walked to the parking lot and leaned against his car calmly until the police arrived.
In 1997, Michael Carneal, a 14-year-old, killed three and wounded five at a school in Louisville, Ky. Then he laid down his gun and said, "I'm sorry."
More tellingly, 33 of the offenders killed themselves after their crimes. Nine tried or wanted to commit suicide, and four killed themselves later. Nine were killed by the police or others, perhaps committing what some refer to as "suicide by cop."
"The number of people knowingly getting killed is striking," Prof. Alfred Blumstein of the Heinz School of Public Policy and Management at Carnegie Mellon University said after examining the review. Professor Blumstein is the director of the National Consortium on Violence Research.
Dr. Jamison said: "The link between suicide and homicide is a very real one, and it hasn't been studied nearly enough. It has always struck me about Columbine, people forget they committed suicide. And that's understandable -- it was the least important thing from the public point of view."
Anthony Barbaro, a 17-year-old Regents scholar in upstate Olean, N.Y., offered a glimpse into this suicidal impulse in the note he left before he hanged himself with a knotted bedsheet in the county jail. He was awaiting trial after firing random shots out the window from the third floor of his high school, killing two passers-by and a school custodian, and wounding nine others.
"I guess I just wanted to kill the person I hate most -- myself," he wrote. "I just didn't have the courage. I wanted to die, but I couldn't do it, so I had to get someone to do it for me. It didn't work out."
One of the most remarkable insights to emerge from the survey is how much these killers differ from the typical American murderer.
Half of all murderers in this country are black. Eighty percent went to high school, and no further. Most of them killed someone they knew, or while committing another crime, like a robbery.
The rampage killers, on the other hand, were white, by far, though 18 of the 102 were black, and 7 Asian. The racial profile of the rampage killers is close to that of the entire population.
The rampage killers were overwhelmingly male -- but not entirely. Six were female, and they exhibited many of the same disturbed, aggressive characteristics of the males. Here again, however, was a distinction from regular murderers, who are about twice as likely as rampage killers to be women.
The rampage killers were far more likely to have a military background, and to kill strangers. There are intriguing age differences as well. The rampage killers were older than regular murderers, with more in their 40's and 50's and fewer in their 20's, compared with the typical killer.
Of the rampage killers who were over 25, a third had college degrees. Another third had some college education. Only nine had less than a high school diploma.
And there seemed to be no urban bias for these crimes, as there is for other violent crimes; 31 were in suburban areas, 25 were in small towns or rural areas. Forty two of those surveyed committed their crimes in urban areas.
That profile -- a group that is largely suicidal, and shows few of the demographic patterns of poverty and race associated with regular crime -- suggests that mental illness plays a huge role, psychiatrists say.
"Mental illness does not vary in different races, but socioeconomics do," said Dr. Lothar Adler, director of a psychiatric hospital in Muhlhausen, Germany, and author of "Amok," a book on multiple murder.
The Times found much evidence of mental illness in its subjects. More than half had histories of serious mental health problems -- either a hospitalization, a prescription for psychiatric drugs, a suicide attempt or evidence of psychosis.
Of the 24 who had been prescribed psychiatric drugs, 14 had stopped taking them when they committed their crimes. Mr. Clemons, for instance, ran out of drugs a week before his crime, according to relatives.
Recent studies have shown that the mentally ill are no more violent than other people, except when they are off their medications, or have been abusing drugs or alcohol.
Indications of mental illness were far more common among the 100 cases than was evidence supporting popular explanations that emerged in the days after some of these spectacular events. Violent video games or television were mentioned in only a handful of cases. Three killers showed an interest in the occult. Racist ideas were apparent in the backgrounds of 16.
But 48 killers had some kind of formal diagnosis, often schizophrenia. Some of the diagnoses came after examinations by psychiatrists in trial preparations -- which did not usually help in their defense, as only eight avoided conviction on grounds of insanity. Twenty-five killers received diagnoses before their crimes, which illustrates another recurring issue: They do not just suddenly snap. Many have long histories not only of mental illness but of failure and dislocation.
In spite of their education levels, for instance, a striking number -- more than half -- were unemployed.
"The high education level is one thing I hadn't anticipated, and the link to unemployment is another thing I didn't realize," Professor Blumstein said. "One of the things that education does is raise expectations, and raised ones are more readily frustrated."
For people without the emotional resources to accommodate it, frustration "can lead to rage, can lead to suicide," Professor Blumstein said.
These crimes are not new. Public rampage killings first entered the national consciousness with Charles Whitman, who stood on the University of Texas's tower in 1966, firing his rifle at students, killing 14 people.
Nor are they peculiarly American. The best scientific thinking, in a field that is admittedly understudied, now holds that multiple, public murder occurs at a fairly constant level across time and cultures. What some people call "running amok," a term first used in Malaysia to describe frenzied, indiscriminate killing, has been observed in many cultures, with weapons as varied as grenades and tanks in addition to high-powered handguns.
"Even though homicide rates and suicide rates are very different from country to country," said Peter M. Marzuk, a professor in the department of psychiatry at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University, "the rates of murder-suicide are really the same throughout the world."
Yet there is a strong impression that they have become more common. In an effort to confirm the trend, The Times analyzed F.B.I. reports of all homicides since 1976. Each year there were 15,000 to 22,000 homicides, but very few involved three or more victims.
That universe shrank even more, to just a few dozen, when The Times weeded out those involving robbery or gang violence, and those in which the primary victim was a family member.
What is left is the closest thing there is to a census of rampage killings -- about one-tenth of one percent of all killings.
And it shows that in the 1990's, they increased.
Their number remained fairly consistent from 1976 to 1989, averaging about 23 a year, only once going above 30. But between 1990 and 1997, the last year for which data was available, the number averaged over 34, dipping below 30 only once, in 1994.
"In the early 90's, for some reason, it increased, and seems to have a different level since," said Steven Messner, a criminologist at the State University of New York at Albany, who reviewed the numbers at the request of The Times.
There are many possible explanations. But the shift coincides, roughly at least, with a trend of increasing availability of more lethal weapons. In the late 1980's, the production of semiautomatic pistols in the United States overtook the production of revolvers, and with their larger ammunition magazines and faster reloading, semiautomatics have added to the potential for mayhem.
The effect may be apparent in the number of deaths per murderous incident, which suddenly increased in 1993 and has remained high since, according to the analysis of F.B.I. data by The Times.
"You have drastically increased the ability to inflict death and injury," said Tom Diaz, author of "Making a Killing: The Business of Guns in America" (New Press, 1999) and a senior policy analyst at the Violence Policy Center. "That means you can shoot more rounds faster and easier, what they call spray and pray."
In the Times study, wielders of semiautomatics inflicted more injuries. The ratio of maimed to killed victims was 50 percent higher than for those who used other weapons. Yet, the increased availability of high-powered weapons may not explain everything. Some kinds of multiple murder have declined or remained static. Killings of three or more people to cover up another felony, like robbery, have not increased, for example. Neither have multiple killings of relatives. The number of incidents in which three or more died and the principal victim was a family member has remained fairly steady, around 30 cases a year.
"It used to be the most common type of this violence was in the family," said James Alan Fox, author of "Overkill: Mass Murder and Serial Killing Exposed" (Dell, 1996) and one of the nation's foremost experts on mass murder. "Now it's no longer true. It's in the workplace and in the schools."
Experts believe the crimes may be feeding on each other, particularly in an era of saturation coverage by cable television. Fourteen of the killers expressed knowledge about their predecessors.
For example, Ladislav Antalik, a Czech immigrant who killed two former co-workers and then himself after being fired from his job in Research Triangle Park, N.C., in 1994, had a newspaper article in his car describing a previous massacre.
The Columbine killers talked of doing it bigger and better than it had been done before. William Kreutzer, known as Crazy Kreutzer, as he set out to mow down a company of soldiers at Fort Bragg with an assault rifle and a semiautomatic pistol, told a friend he knew what the record number of multiple killings was.
But beyond the question of whether one event triggered the next, experts say the recent increases in these crimes strongly suggest a social contagion.
"Why do you get a lot of people doing the same thing?" said Joseph Westermeyer, a psychiatrist at the University of Minnesota who has studied epidemics of explosive murder in other cultures. "I think there is this copycat element."
Dr. Adler, in his book, documented two cases of soldiers running amok with a tank in Germany in the 1980's after a widely publicized tank attack there. Army security was increased, and "tank amok never happened in Germany again," Dr. Adler said.
An angry, depressed, unstable, perhaps mentally ill person picks up a gun because it has become a known alternative. "Something that was inconceivable to many people suddenly becomes conceivable," Dr. Messner said.
"The transmission mechanism seems to be nothing more or less than that it's an idea that's in the air," said Philip Cook, a professor of public policy at Duke University, who has studied social contagions. "So you have these kind of catastrophic consequences from what seems a minor change in the environment."
 
How the Study Was Conducted
The New York Times set out to study rampage killings by assembling a detailed database of as many such crimes as could be discovered by searching news clippings in all 50 states, scientific papers and other sources.
Times researchers and reporters found 100 cases that met strictly defined criteria aimed at encompassing the kind of crimes that seem to have become more common recently. The crimes had to have had multiple victims, at least one of whom died, and to have occurred substantially at one time and in a place where people gather -- a workplace, a school, a mall, a restaurant, a train. Multiple killings that were a result of domestic strife, robbery or political terrorism were excluded, as were serial killings.
Reporters and researchers reviewed newspaper articles and court transcripts, and interviewed prosecutors, victims, families and, when possible, the killers. Reporters recorded into a database more than 90 separate pieces of information on each crime, including age, mental health histories, victim relationships, weapons used, warning signs, location, time of day and criminal records.
Ford Fessenden, a database reporter at The Times, coordinated the research.
The 100 cases include 20 shootings at schools, 11 at restaurants or shopping malls and 32 at the killer's workplace. There were 102 killers. Four hundred twenty five people were killed and 510 injured.
In some cases, it was difficult to get precise information, as news accounts and even police reports varied. And while extensive efforts were made to be as complete as possible, there is no central list of multiple murders, and the database does not include every attack of this type over the last 50 years.
Still, the experts acknowledged it to be the largest and most detailed database devoted exclusively to such murders in the United States, and suggested it should be considered an initial step in a systematic study of a largely unexamined field.
"This should be seen as a way of starting the conversation and getting good social science going," said Franklin Zimring, director of the Earl Warren Legal Institute at the University of California at Berkeley.
"It's not science and shouldn't be addressed as science," said Alfred Blumstein, director of the National Consortium on Violence Research, who was shown The Times's findings. "But I think it's aggressive and careful."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 98; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2200 words

HEADLINE: Hanging On In The Burbs;
Too Rich For Their Blood

BYLINE: By James Kaplan; James Kaplan is the author of "The Airport" and "Two Guys From Verona: A Novel of Suburbia," which he is currently adapting for the screen.

 BODY:
Pete Cross bought the big white house on Ridgewood Terrace in Maplewood, N.J., in 1972. It was a good time. He had just made the jump from teaching phys ed at Maplewood's Columbia High School to being a guidance counselor, his lifelong dream. He and his wife, Jeanmarie, his high school sweetheart (they both graduated from Columbia High in 1954) had four healthy children, three boys and a girl, ages 5 to 12. They'd been bursting the seams of their old house, a small three-bedroom near the high school. So, in the midst of a brewing energy crisis and a down housing market, they pulled off a bit of real estate prestidigitation, selling the old place for $35,500 and buying the white 1910 Colonial with two-story pillars on the front porch, a stained-glass window on the stair landing and a big backyard, in an equally good neighborhood, for $33,000. Taxes were $4,000 a year -- a stretch, but Pete and Jean figured they could just make it.
Twenty-eight years later, Pete and Jean Cross still live in the big white house. "We were lucky," Jean Cross says. "We raised a family." These days, though, taxes are $9,000 per annum -- a bigger stretch than ever, now that Pete is retired. Three of their children have moved away -- Peter Jr. is a postal clerk in Florida, Cathy is a stay-at-home mom near Boston and Andrew, who lives in Cedar Knolls, N.J., works for Johnson & Johnson. Only the youngest, David, 34, still lives in Maplewood. He's the town's K-9 police officer. He still lives in his old bedroom upstairs, just across the hall from a room occupied by Maplewood's police dog, a 110-pound German shepherd named Britz. 
 Ridgewood Terrace is a long, wide street gently ascending the low crest known somewhat grandiosely as the first of the Orange Mountains, and flanked by wide lawns and big, solid houses of the same vintage as the Crosses': Victorians and Queen Annes and Dutch Colonials. It is a beautiful street in a picture-perfect suburb, and the houses are the kind that every upwardly mobile young couple moving out from Brooklyn Heights or Hoboken desperately wants to own. People stick handwritten notes in the Crosses' storm door, offering them cash for their place. Lots of cash -- a similar house around the corner just sold for $610,000. And Pete Cross is puzzled and amused by his situation: he can no longer afford not to move from this house. "I'd like to give it to David, but I can't," he says. "And even if I could, he couldn't afford the taxes."
On the surface, Maplewood, population 21,000, looks much as it did 30 years ago, when Pete Cross was my gym teacher at Columbia High, and a pot-loving classmate of mine referred to the town with affectionate scorn as "Mapleville." Neighboring South Orange, where I grew up (the two communities shared a school system), was the first stop for Jewish Americans migrating west from Newark -- there was plenty of new money, and even a fancy neighborhood for it (piquantly named Newstead) at the top of the hill. Maplewood had no such enclaves. The town center, with its crooked streets and mock-Tudor overhangs, has always had a stage-set quality, and the visual message it conveys is Cozy American Suburb. Nothing moving too fast. Self-contained and self-possessed.
But there is a certain amount of artful illusion to this impression. Maplewood is bordered on three sides by Newark, Irvington and Union, which are heavily black and largely poor. And those borders are becoming ever more porous. "Maplewood is an example of the pastoral and mountainous in charming combination, having just enough of the urban character to enhance creature comforts and social attractiveness," reads a booklet issued by the Maplewood Improvement Association in 1902. "It is the children of the village who complete the picture. Their shining faces are the best index of the homes to which they belong and the wholesomeness of their surroundings, moral and material."
Maplewood may look much the same today, but these days, when school lets out, many of those shining faces are faces of color. Columbia High's most famous recent alumna is the hip-hop genius Lauryn Hill, and the school is more than 50 percent black. Most of this shift happened over the last decade, as upward-aspiring African-Americans from Newark, Irvington, East Orange and Orange moved in, drawn by the beautiful houses but even more by the community's renowned school system. Maplewood's black population, less than 5 percent in the 1970 census, had grown to 13 percent by 1990. (The higher proportion of minorities in the schools stems from the replacement of white empty nesters by blacks with school-age children.)
Initially, the influx of students transferring from poorer schools sent test scores into a downward spike, and the influx of minority families triggered a certain degree of real estate panic. Blacks and whites alike charged real estate agents with racial steering, and white flight rather than natural turnover has contributed to much of the mutation in the community's ethnic makeup.
Columbia High is trying hard to regroup, and there has been some success. A diversity coordinator was hired (though she has since left and hasn't been replaced); test scores are creeping up. The school is peaceful and clean, and while a security guard is stationed in the lobby, anyone looking for gangs, graffiti or metal detectors will have to look elsewhere.
A complex equilibrium reigns. The real estate market is booming, largely thanks to Midtown Direct, a revamping of New Jersey Transit train lines that eliminated the antiquated train-to-Hudson-tubes transfer at Hoboken and shaved the commute from Maplewood to Penn Station, some 20 miles, to just over 30 minutes. Median household income in 1990 was a solid $59,306 for blacks and $57,947 for whites. Overall crime has dropped substantially -- 39 percent -- since a peak in 1980, and car theft, which reached a fever pitch in Newark a few years ago and spread across the border into Maplewood, stands at its lowest level in 15 years. The town hasn't had a murder since 1995 (when there was one) and had fewer burglaries in 1999 than in any other year since 1973. Residents proudly cite Maplewood as a model of ethnic and economic integration.
There are blips. The frequently redistricting public school system often seems to be its own worst enemy. The Board of Education's recent decision to bus students with severe disciplinary and academic problems from Columbia High to a special facility in a former South Orange elementary school provoked outrage from the largely white residents in the school's neighborhood. And the basketball courts in Memorial Park, a stone's throw from Maplewood center, remain a focus of controversy every spring and summer, as the (mostly white) neighbors complain about noise, garbage and vulgarity from the (mostly black) players.
Downtown Maplewood feels as poky as it did in the 60's, but most of its stores have turned over several times since then. Food businesses, both restaurants and takeout shops, are everywhere -- a subtle sign that the reign of the single-commuter household is over. This is the age of the commuting couple, both incomes necessary to afford the mortgage and taxes, both husband and wife too busy to do much cooking.
Pete Cross and I are sitting in one of the town's less chichi eating establishments, the Maple Leaf diner, where the waitress and a good deal of the clientele, not to mention many of the people we passed on the street on our way to lunch, know him by first name. Cross has lived in Maplewood all his life. His grandfather, Charles Cross, built one of the first houses on Prospect Street -- then largely farmland -- shortly before the turn of the last century. In 1906, Charles Cross wrote Maplewood's first Police Act, formalizing the existence of a volunteer department, which he briefly headed. "I like the idea of my son David being on the police force, and my grandfather wrote the act," Pete Cross says.
The hard-eyed glare I remember from gym class has given way to a certain twinkle. Cross is a handsome and youthful 63 -- he swims laps and lifts weights almost every morning -- and still walks with an athlete's slim-hipped swagger. "You didn't smoke, you didn't drink, or you got kicked off the team," he says, of his glory days as an all-state third baseman for the Columbia High School baseball team. "Team rules, I followed."
He takes out a sheaf of pictures. One of them is of the brown fish-scale-shingled Victorian his grandfather built on Prospect Street. "My parents had their wedding reception in that house," he says. "I lived there my whole childhood. Maplewood feels very similar to when I was young."
I tell him I've visited Columbia High a couple of times in the last few years. A very different place, I say.
Cross nods. "The minority presence was only 3 or 4 percent when you went there; now that it's 50-50. . . . " His voice trails off.
"Is it working?" I ask.
He gives me a look. "You get more kids now at both academic extremes," he says. "Where's the middle? Where's Pete Cross? But it's still a great school. We average 50 to 60 kids admitted early-decision at some of your top colleges. Enrollment's going up -- we're at around 1,800 now; we got as low as 1,200."
Is white flight still a problem?
"We talk about it a lot," he admits. "You still see a lot of kids transferring to private schools. But you know what? I think it's working at Columbia. We've had our problems. But the kids, they walk side by side in the hall, white and black. If there's any problem, it's not white against black, it's black against black, the Haitians and the local-born kids."
"Hey," Cross says, "want to see the house on Prospect Street?" Lunch is done. We've walked to town -- Pete doesn't like to drive anywhere if he can help it. So we amble back toward Ridgewood Terrace, past the video store and yuppie caterers, past the pizza parlor where Pietz Hardware used to be, past a clutch of old gaffers standing around, one of them, florid-faced, wearing a U.S.S. New Jersey baseball cap. "Hi, Pete; hi, Pete," everyone says.
The houses get bigger as we cross Ridgewood Road. Cross's place is just two up from the corner. We climb into his gold Chrysler minivan and head back through town, past the grand municipal building, with stars-and-stripes bunting on its sandstone pillars. And there, at the corner of Prospect and Oakland, is the fish-scale-shingled brown Victorian, perfectly preserved and unbearably sweet in its proportions, a snapshot of a softer time.
"There it is," Pete says.
It's beautiful, I tell him. But it's beautiful, I realize, because someone a lot newer to town than the Crosses has put a lot of money into restoring it.
David Cross repeats his father's senti-ments about Maplewood. "It truly hasn't changed that much since I was young," he insists. "Kids still gather in town every weekend the way they always have. There's never really any trouble."
Would this tend to make his police work -- boring?
"Nah," he says, grinning lopsidedly. He's sitting at his parents' dining-room table, a solid young man with a weight lifter's torso, a brush cut and warm brown eyes. "There's always something going on." What he means, he elaborates, is not crime but planned events like the Fourth of July. He mentions the dropping car-theft and burglary statistics.
Why, then, does Maplewood need a police dog?
"He's a deterrent," Cross says, smiling. The town's K-9 program, he tells me, was modeled after that of Irvington, which has -- and needs -- eight dogs. The fact that Maplewood has only one says something about both its smallness and its relatively low crime rate. Yet there's an ambiguity about the presence here of such a menacing creature. David Cross tells a story of apprehending eight kids in a stolen car who were about to scatter on foot when he gave the required verbal warning: "Stop or I'll release the canine!"
He adds dryly, "They chose to give up."
On the other hand, Pete Cross told me that Britz once cornered him in an upstairs bedroom, where, not knowing the release command, he remained until his son came home.
Asked about the racial changes in Maplewood, David Cross gives a no-big-deal shrug. Where does the nearest black family live? He points a thumb over his shoulder. "Next door," he says. There are a lot more black families, though, near the Newark/Irvington/Union borders, on the other side of town, far from Ridgewood Terrace.
David Cross has traveled around a bit -- he's driven half the Pacific Coast Highway. Has he ever seen anyplace like Maplewood? He shakes his head. "Some people might take it as a knock, but it's Mayberry," he says. "Everybody knows everybody. A lot of the places I go are resorts -- nobody knows nobody. You're just a tab. The goodness is gone. Not here."
Still, a town's goodness is rarely simple -- or cheap. "I'm thinking about condos," Pete Cross tells me. "Maybe South Jersey. I want to get thinner on the taxes." David Cross is looking at small houses out along the Route 78 corridor in Morris County. The future is irresistible. But how much will Maplewood and the Crosses miss each other?
