SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 908 words

HEADLINE: NEW ECONOMY;
Tuning in the new way: The Internet scene may just have a lot in common with the 1960's.

BYLINE: By Leslie Kaufman 

 BODY:
FOR Joshua White, the vibe at Pseudo.com, the dot-com enterprise where he is employed these days, is amusingly reminiscent of a different era: the 1960's.
Mr. White is a senior vice president in charge of production at Pseudo, a company that creates original off-beat shows on everything from the space program to hip-hop music to broadcast over the Web. The struggle of the young staff to use the developing medium in ways uniquely suited to the Internet strikes him as a perfect parallel to his own life in 1968. 
 That year, Mr. White was a 25-year-old lighting artist who went to work for the rock promoter Bill Graham at the Fillmore East theater in Manhattan's East Village. Mr. White's job and his passion were to create light shows to match the kinetic new rock music emerging from artists like the Grateful Dead and Jimi Hendrix. He was at the center of cultural change, and it felt good.
"I wasn't chasing after anything traditional," he recalls. His job, after all, was something no one had done before.
"There was this feeling among those that were in it," he added, "that we were involved in something that older people would not get. And then, like now, everyone over 30 is an outsider. They come by and want to be part of it, but they just don't get it."
What is it about the zeitgeist of the Internet of today that keeps calling to mind the radical 1960's? Let's have no illusions: the two decades are decidedly at odds in terms of ideology.
The earlier era was defined by a rejection of prevailing social norms, from segregation to sexual modesty to name a few. Today's dot-com babies think about transforming commerce not values and mores. And they are working happily within establishment parameters to do it, fighting not in the streets but on the Street.
In the 1960's, dropping out meant dodging the draft and moving to Canada to join a farming collective. Today, it means skipping out of college before graduation to join a technology start-up and cash in on millions of options.
"The sense of empowerment is the same," Vern Keenan, who runs a San Francisco Internet consulting firm, observes dryly, "but the politics is very different. Then the group party was socialism; now it is libertarianism."
Yet, for their obvious differences, the two eras are linked in the psyches of many. Part of the connection is that many of the Net's founding fathers came from the crucible of rebellion culture in California -- Steve Wozniak of Apple Computer and Bill Joy of Sun Microsystems to drop two prominent names. But the similarities run deeper than that.
Most obviously, the Internet is a radically youth-centric culture, convinced that dewy college graduates can better see the future than those already tainted by their role in the old economy. Surely, the hippie slogan, "Don't trust anyone over 30," is as apt for this emerging generation as it was for the 20-something protesters who coined it.
"In the university there is an inverse correlation between age and experience," said Clay Shirky, a professor of new media at Hunter College. "The younger they are, the better they are at speaking the new language. So undergraduates know more than graduates, and freshmen know more than seniors -- all of which really upsets the traditional order."
There is also an aura of vitality and era-defining importance around the activities of those who are plugged into the new economy -- only some of which was lost in the recent stock market slide. It is a common refrain for reporters to hear people talk about not wanting to be bystanders to the digital revolution, as if working for a dot-com is on par with going to Haight-Ashbury to drop acid during the Summer of Love.
Richard Skeen is one of those mid-30-somethings drawn to the new economy, in part, for the scene. Last month, Mr. Skeen left a comfortable job at the publishing side of GQ, the men's magazine published by Conde Nast to join Powerful Media Inc., whose soon-to-be-introduced Web site Inside.com, aims to be a must-read news service for media professionals. He is thrilled to have left the polished Times Square offices of the the big publishing company for an enormous warehouse building on 11th Avenue, where numerous new media enterprises make their home and the elevators are packed with gadget-porting post-pubescents. "It is an incredible counterculture going on here," he says.
Mr. Skeen also sees the 1960's in his adventures. He equates, for example, the lure of money in the 1990's to the lure of drugs in the 1960's.
Chris Locke, co-author of "The Cluetrain Manifesto," (Perseus Books, 2000), a polemic that is rising quickly on the best-seller lists, argues that the Internet revolution is the logical heir to the 1960's on another front: communications.
The 1960's saw giant strides toward the democratization of information, Mr. Locke argues, pointing to alternative publications like Rolling Stone and journalists like the great Gonzo himself. "Hunter Thompson was writing about what he was engaged in," Mr. Locke said. "He was not pretending to be objective or out of context."
The Web, in Mr. Locke's view, brings the revolution against the sonorous all-knowing corporate voice to its inevitable climax and resolution in favor of the plebeians. "The Internet enables people to talk directly to each other and to corporations," he said. "It is something businesses ignore at their own peril."
Heavy, man, heavy.

HEADLINE: Hope on the Transit Horizon

 BODY:
Not since the 1970's, when the Second Avenue subway project in Manhattan was killed because of city and state fiscal crises, have planners dared think about big new transportation schemes for New York City. Now, with hard times behind them, planners at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have proposed the first major expansion of subway and commuter rail in decades. In a separate step toward realizing that goal, Gov. George Pataki and state lawmakers last week agreed to try to work out a possible $3.8 billion state bond issue for the ballot in November, which would help finance both highway and mass-transit projects. The accord has serious flaws that will need to be addressed, especially a shaky financing scheme and questionable priorities. But the very fact that political leaders are seriously discussing bold new transit projects is a welcome development.
The Albany agreement calls for work to be speeded on three major projects. They are a plan to bring the Long Island Rail Road through the East Side to Grand Central Terminal, favored by Governor Pataki as a gesture to his suburban constituency; a full-length Second Avenue subway from 125th Street to Lower Manhattan, pushed by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, who represents the Lower East Side; and a rail link to La Guardia Airport, demanded by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, reportedly as a favor to his political supporters in Queens. Though each of these priorities has merit, their selection was driven as much by politics as anything else. They will need to be evaluated more thoroughly to determine if all three deserve to be at the very top of the list. 
 Both Governor Pataki and the M.T.A. want to put primary emphasis on the Long Island Rail Road extension and the upper portion of the Second Avenue subway, from 125th Street to 63rd Street. But Speaker Silver wants to start the lower part of the Second Avenue subway now as well, to ease crowding on the Lexington Avenue line, especially if thousands of new Long Island commuters are to come in to Grand Central each day. This page has supported building the full Second Avenue line, but some critics fear it would gobble up scarce funds best used elsewhere. Meanwhile, the La Guardia link needs better justification than it has so far been given.
A project that has been given secondary priority but may need greater emphasis is the proposed extension of the No. 7 subway on the West Side, from Times Square down to Penn Station and over to the river, where it could help spur economic development in a vastly underused area of warehouses, parking lots and wasted space. The factors that are now pushing this area to the fore include the need to expand the Midtown business district and enlarge the Javits Convention Center. There would also need to be improved access to a possible stadium to serve local teams or the Olympics, should New York compete for and win the right to host the 2012 Games.
A separate flaw of all these plans relates to the shakiness of the financing, which many elected officials, business and transit advocacy groups fear could lead to drastic fare increases. The plan calls for the M.T.A., a state agency, to undertake its most ambitious five-year construction plan in a generation, at a cost of more than $16 billion. Some $1.6 billion of the money would come from the proposed state bond issue, which would have to be approved by voters. An additional $5 billion would be sought from Washington, where Congress has been only a bit more willing to finance mass transit in recent years. But the biggest problem is that about $11 billion would come from new M.T.A. bonds and refinancing of old bonds, creating a mountain of new debt that might have to be paid off by higher fares for subway riders and commuters.
The M.T.A. disputes some of the figures used by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce. But there is no question that fare increases can be mitigated only by tapping other sources of financing. Mayor Giuliani and Governor Pataki need to find more resources for the system, and they have to work together -- something they do not do very well -- to pressure Congress and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to provide more money. The New York City Partnership also proposes raising tolls on motorists coming into Manhattan, a politically difficult idea that could win widespread support only if voters see the money being put to good use.
Despite these problems, Mr. Pataki, Mr. Silver and the M.T.A. have taken a major step forward in reaching their agreement last week. For the first time in a generation, New Yorkers can actually hope for major changes in a transportation system that are vital to the future of the city and the region.

HEADLINE: Strategies for Safer Blood

 BODY:
Blood safety is becoming an important factor in combating the global spread of AIDS. The World Health Organization estimates that between 5 and 10 percent of transmissions of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, occur through the transfusion of infected blood or blood products.
A new survey by the agency found that more than two-thirds of the world's nations do not have adequate policies to insure a safe blood supply. Of the 75 million units of blood donated each year throughout the world, nearly 20 percent are not screened for either H.I.V. or other agents that cause hepatitis B and C, syphilis and malaria. The poorest developing nations are the hardest hit by infectious disease, and have been least able to test or monitor blood safety. They are also least able to bear the long-term economic and human costs of AIDS or other diseases spread by unsafe blood. 
 Recognizing this crisis, the W.H.O. has begun a new campaign to improve blood safety worldwide. Blood screening is essential, but for poorer nations, the costs can be prohibitive. The Clinton administration is seeking a $100 million increase in next year's budget to combat AIDS abroad, with part of that increase to be used for blood testing programs. But testing must be supplemented by good laboratory practices, standards for safe storage and transportation of blood, and reliance on voluntary, unpaid blood donors. In poorer countries, most of the blood supply still comes from paid donors or family donors, who pose a risk because they may conceal behaviors that make them unsuitable as donors.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A magazine intends to grow along with the Internet economy.

BYLINE: By Courtney Kane 

 BODY:
AT a time when swings in technology stocks are feeding a debate about the Internet economy, The Industry Standard, a magazine devoted to e-commerce, is starting a campaign to attract a broader range of readers.
When the magazine began in April 1998, it was aimed at the people who were responsible for developing and putting into effect their companies' Internet strategy. As e-commerce has exploded, so too has that pool of potential readers. 
 "There are more people now who need the kind of information we've been providing," said Kerry G. Zeida, vice president for marketing and brand development for Standard Media in San Francisco, which publishes The Industry Standard.
The $10 million television and outdoor campaign -- the magazine's first -- comes at a time when circulation growth is already strong. The Industry Standard's circulation has risen to 150,000 from 60,000 when it began. The number of advertising pages, marketing everything from alcohol to cars to technology, has grown even faster: to 1,678.12 pages in the fourth quarter of last year from 251.17 pages in the fourth quarter of 1998, an increase of 568 percent, according to the tracking service Adscope Inc. in Eugene, Ore.
Mr. Zeida said the magazine, in researching an angle to speak to its expanded audience, found that its readers appreciate a competitive advantage they get from reading the publication. Three 30-second commercials, which start today, take that notion to a humorous extreme by showing Internet business leaders making an effort to keep confidential the information they get from The Industry Standard.
In one spot, two men are seated at tables in a nondescript cafe, with their backs to one another. In a spoof of spy movies, the two exchange a series of quirky code phrases to assure each other that they have the right contact: "Does your wife sleep in the nude?" "Actually she prefers flannel." "Little Bo Peep has lost her sheep." "Leave them alone, and they'll come home."
Then the two exchange their top-secret information. One man quickly passes the magazine, which is concealed in a folder, to the other and says, "See you next week."
A second commercial features a man hustling to enter an empty elevator. As he starts to open The Industry Standard, he feels the presence of a security camera and backs up out of its range. He then takes out a can of spray paint and blackens the lens.
Both spots close with an announcer saying: "Read it. Learn from it. Don't let it fall into the wrong hands," followed by the company's tag line, "The Industry Standard. Your weekly intelligence report on the Internet economy."
The commercials will begin running today in 10 markets -- Atlanta, Dallas, Miami, New York and San Francisco, among others -- during cable business programs that include those of Bloomberg News, CNBC, CNN and MSNBC. The work is the first from TBWA/Chiat/Day in Playa del Rey, Calif., part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, since that agency was awarded the account in January.
In the spots, "we're saying this magazine is just chock-full of information all geared toward the Internet economy," said Jerry Gentile, managing partner and creative director at TBWA/Chiat/Day. "I think what we've tried to do is to personify it."
"The idea of don't let it fall into the wrong hands," he added, is one of "making this your edge to e-commerce, trying to make everybody feel they have their own little personal source to understand e-commerce."
The outdoor portion of the campaign will feature billboards in New York and San Francisco. One ad is a spectacular, a gigantic electronic display situated just off the Bay Bridge en route to San Francisco. That billboard features an enlarged masthead of The Industry Standard, accompanied by a live feed of Internet-business-related news headlines for commuters.
Other billboards show a copy of the magazine accompanied by headlines including, "We never met a bubble we couldn't burst" and "Sugar coating is for cereal."
The campaign for the magazine is the first component of what will become a branding campaign to promote the entire company, Standard Media. Subsequent ads for the other ventures and services will be introduced later this summer.
Standard Media, which is referred to simply as, "The Standard," is majority-owned by the International Data Group. The company also produces a Web site (www.TheStandard .com) and 18 online newsletters including Media Grok, in addition to conducting national and international conferences and events.

HEADLINE: PEN Is to Honor Two Poets Imprisoned in Kosovo and China

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
At the PEN American Center's annual literary gala this evening at Lincoln Center, there will be a pause as two imprisoned poets, Dr. Flora Brovina, an ethnic Albanian in Kosovo, and Xue Deyun, who is Chinese, are honored in absentia. Dr. Brovina and Mr. Xue will receive PEN/Barbara Goldsmith Freedom-to-Write Awards. Each award carries a stipend of $3,000, but the honor's primary purpose is to call attention to writers who are imprisoned or in danger.
"These awards put a human face on the high price that writers continue to pay for expressing themselves freely," Michael Roberts, the executive director of the PEN American Center, said in an interview. 
 "Since the awards were established in 1987, 14 of the 20 writers in prison at the time of the award have been released within a short time. In some cases it has been immediately, and in other cases it has been weeks or months."
PEN, an organization of authors, editors and translators founded in 1921 to promote free expression, sends out appeals by prominent members, coordinates missions to countries where writers are in jeopardy and promotes awareness of the dangers of censorship. The Freedom-to-Write Awards are underwritten by the author Barbara Goldsmith.
One of tonight's honorees, Dr. Brovina, 53, is not only a poet but a pediatrician and founder and president of the League of Albanian Women in Kosovo. After war broke out in Kosovo, she remained in Pristina, running a shelter for women and children. On April 22, 1999, eight masked Serbian paramilitaries abducted her from an apartment and held her incommunicado for two weeks. Eventually she was accused of "terrorist acts," and in December a Serbian court sentenced her to 12 years in prison.
Dr. Brovina's supporters say that she was forced to sign a confession that said she had participated in the Kosovo Liberation Army. In January her lawyer filed an appeal with the Serbian Supreme Court asserting that her rights to due process had been violated.
In prison Dr. Brovina has only been able to shout to visitors from a distance, and in front of guards. Her 18-year-old son, Ylli Begu, an exchange student at Richland College in Dallas, is scheduled to attend the ceremony tonight. In an interview from Texas, Mr. Begu said that his father, Agri Begu, an economist and banker, had visited his mother three weeks ago. Dr. Brovina has angina and needs to be hospitalized, her son said, adding, "She's being held in prison without medicine and proper doctors." Mr. Begu also said that Dr. Brovina's Albanian lawyer had been beaten by Serbian police officers, and had been hospitalized. Agri Begu, in Pristina, could not be reached.
In China, Mr. Xue was at the center of a cultural revival in the southwestern province of Guizhou. Mr. Xue, 40, was arrested on Jan. 26, 1998, with three other poets, Ma Quiang, Wu Ruohai and Xiong Jinren (also known as Xiong Xiang), in the provincial capital of Guiyang. They were about to publish a new literary journal, China Cultural Renaissance, which advocates freedom of literary expression. Chinese dissidents say that the men's homes were raided without a warrant and their writings and address books were confiscated.
Three of the poets were released, but Mr. Xue, who writes under the name Ma Zhe, was charged and convicted in the Guiyang Municipal Peoples Court of "engaging in subversive activities" and attempting to overthrow "the socialist system by rumor-mongering (or) slander." He was sentenced to seven years in prison. Mr. Xue had been imprisoned from 1987 to 1990 because of his involvement in the Beijing student protests of December 1986.
In an interview from Boston, the exiled Chinese writer Meng Lang, a close friend of Mr. Xue's, said that Chinese dissidents in the United States did not know which prison has Mr. Xue.
"At this moment there is no way to communicate with anybody who has seen Mr. Xue," said Mr. Meng, who is the executive editor of The Tendency, a Chinese-language literary journal in Boston. "Though the Chinese Constitution has stated that Chinese people have the freedom to organize, to publish, to speak, they have never carried it out."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Purchase of Robert Fleming By Chase Is Seen This Week
Robert Fleming Holdings, one of Britain's last independent banks, is expected to announce this week that it will be acquired by Chase Manhattan for close to 5 billion, or nearly $8 billion, executives close to the talks said.
That price is higher than most analysts expected when reports of the negotiations first emerged last month. Page C20. 

A Private Solution for Microsoft?
With a federal judge ruling last week that Microsoft repeatedly violated the law, the government has the easy part of the antitrust case behind it. The real policy challenge comes now: What are the right remedies? One respected economist suggests that the government could just walk away and leave remedies to private litigation. C7.
 
Turned On to the New Economy
Despite their obvious differences, the Internet era and the radical 1960's are linked in the psyches of many. For one, the Internet is a radically youth-centric culture, convinced that dewy college graduates can better see the future than those already tainted by their role in the old economy. There is also an aura of vitality and era-defining importance around the activities of those who are plugged into the new economy. New Economy. C4.
 
Malls Look to Compete Online, Too
Web merchants have had a lot of fun at the expense of shopping malls, contending that mall shopping was a waste of time and money. Now, with investors fleeing Web merchants en masse, malls are poised for a counteroffensive. They are vying to fill the gaps left by traditional and online retailers in areas like ordering and customer service. Efforts include Internet connections inside malls for merchants and hand-held scanners that allow shoppers to select items, either to put on a wish list or buy. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C16.
 
A Test Case for Press Freedom
In Canada, advocates for freedom of the press hope that a case involving the author of a best-selling crime book will set a precedent for the kind of reporters' shield legislation that spread in the United States in the 1970's. Stephen Williams's book, "Invisible Darkness," contains precise details of a gory sex murder scene. Mr. Williams has been charged with two counts of disobeying a judge's order to disclose the source of the details. C19.
 
Business Travel Web Sites Planned
British Airways and the online business-travel service GetThere.com plan to announce today that they will create customized Web sites to provide corporate travel services for small and midsize businesses in Europe. C7.
 
Ad Campaign for Industry Standard
At a time when swings in technology stocks are feeding a debate about the Internet economy, The Industry Standard, a magazine devoted to e-commerce, is starting a $10 million campaign to attract a broader range of readers. Advertising. C23.
 
'Sopranos' Consolidates Its Power
The mob family hit "The Sopranos," burdened this season with expectations heavier than cement shoes, finished its second burst of 13 episodes last night having added to the biggest programming phenomenon in HBO history. Ratings soared for "The Sopranos" in its second season, climbing more than 60 percent. Though the ratings are important, there is something broader at stake. HBO does not measure the success of its series in direct income. Because HBO is a subscription channel dependent on monthly fees, the prime consideration is selling people on the channel in an increasingly crowded marketplace. C19.
 
Children's All-Cotton Superhero
The tales of the children's book character Captain Underpants are stealthily gaining popularity against the more mainstream Harry Potter books. The two characters share the same children's publisher, Scholastic, which has now issued more than six million copies of books featuring Captain Underpants. C19.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1863 words

HEADLINE: A Leader in Cyberspace, It Seems, Is NoPolitician

BYLINE: By JERI CLAUSING 

 BODY:
Esther Dyson was presiding over the most recent meeting of Icann, the controversial international group trying to create the Internet's first democracy. While she sat on a stage facing an audience of several hundred, her frustration and impatience grew increasingly apparent, as people filed to a microphone in the aisle to voice their complaints.
Many opposed the interim board's proposal to elect permanent members through an indirect process. But Ms. Dyson, the interim chairwoman, defended using an electoral council instead of letting the world's Internet users vote directly for their board representatives. That was the best way, she told the group, to prevent the nomination of "people who are stupid." 
 The next day, after seeing her remark on The New York Times Web page, Ms. Dyson took exception. "Out of context," she said. "I might have said it, but it was out of context."
Whatever her intention, the remark put Ms. Dyson directly at odds with some of the same civil liberties groups that have long been among her staunchest supporters. And the incident, last month in Cairo, made clear that despite her unofficial titles of Doyenne of Cyberspace and Queen of the Digerati, a politician is one thing that Ms. Dyson is not.
It has been nearly two years since Ms. Dyson was chosen to be interim head of Icann -- the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers -- with the mandate of leading the Clinton administration's effort to move oversight of the network from federal contractors to the international Internet community.
But she has ruled Icann's fractious public meetings with a mix of impatience, frustration and condescension. And the paucity of diplomacy, some Internet executives say, has played a role in Icann's rocky start. Among the missteps, two of the group's earliest decisions -- to hold closed meetings and to levy a $1 tax on Internet addresses -- were later rescinded under pressure from the administration and Congress.
"I think that what you see sometimes is that she doesn't quite have the common touch," said Mike Godwin, a lawyer who worked with Ms. Dyson in the early 1990's at the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a public interest group devoted to the defense of free speech and civil rights on the Internet.
"I think that there is a dimension of being a political being that involves going out and getting hands on and dealing with individuals," said Mr. Godwin, who is now senior legal editor of E-Commerce Law Weekly, a print publication. "I don't think she is terribly comfortable with that. I think she is democratic in principal but not entirely democratic in practice."
In an interview last week at her cluttered office in midtown Manhattan, on a rare day that she was not traveling, Ms. Dyson defended her leadership style.
"I don't have a tolerance for having my time wasted; I'm straightforward," she said. "It's not a question of intelligence; it's a question of appropriateness."
Indeed, most who know Esther Dyson say she does not suffer fools gladly. But she was picked to head Icann not for her tact but because of her international reputation for independence, integrity and straightforward manner.
At 5-foot-3 and 47 years old, Ms. Dyson is a wiry, almost elfin figure, with seeming disregard for the trappings of makeup or fashion. She keeps her hair short and simply cut. She scurries around her office and official meetings wearing socks without shoes. And she often wears faded blue jeans, typically accompanied by an oversized T-shirt.
The daughter of the reknowned physicist Freeman Dyson, she is described by another Electronic Frontier Foundation colleague, John Gilmore, as having "formidable intelligence." But Ms. Dyson's fast mind can manifest itself in ways that may come across as dismissive and condescending.
"She is not a people person," said Jerry Michalski. For five years, Mr. Michalski wrote Release 1.0, the influential technology newsletter that Ms. Dyson's company, EDventure holdings, publishes monthly. Mr. Michalski left about two years ago to become a freelance consultant and speaker, a decision made in part, he explained, by the emotional wall he said she kept between them.
"She likes humans," he said. "She just doesn't do small talk. If you hang out with her, it feels awkward. If you start talking about feelings, she will turn around and leave."
Whatever her interpersonal skills, over the last 20 years Ms. Dyson has cultivated long-standing relationships with a wide circle of some of the most influential people in the computer and Internet industries.
A graduate of Harvard with a bachelor's in economics, Ms. Dyson began her career in the computer world in the 1970's, covering the budding industry as a reporter for Forbes magazine. From there she moved to Wall Street as an analyst. And in 1982 she formed her venture capital firm after buying a computer industry newsletter that she renamed Release 1.0. With that newsletter came a related annual conference, which she has parlayed into an invitation-only event, called PC Forum, that the industry's top executives and digerati are afraid to miss -- even at a registration fee of $4,500.
Ms. Dyson is also on the board of numerous companies and nonprofit groups around the world and has become a mainstay at Internet conferences and policy panels. And she has positioned herself as a well-paid, highly sought speaker.
As former chairman, and now vice chairman, of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, she espoused some of the earliest predictions about the complex challenges the Internet would pose for intellectual property and privacy. And she has served on special federal commissions on intellectual property, privacy and encryption.
In her role as a civil libertarian, however, Ms. Dyson is more of an observer, a thinker, than an activist, according to people who know her well, who say she seems more comfortable with identifying tough issues than taking on the hard fight to resolve them.
And certainly that limitation drew criticism to her 1997 book, "Release 2.0: A Design for Living in the Digital Age," which some critics derided as a naive collection of only sometimes interesting observations.
Patrick Lambert, reviewing the book for Business Week, said Ms. Dyson "glosses over the obstacles that lie in the way" of achieving the "electronic Utopia she foresees."
Still, when Ms. Dyson talks, people in the digital world listen.
"If Esther starts talking about something, and you don't know why, you better start paying attention," said Miljenko Horvak, a former Citibank executive who is involved in several Eastern European start-ups companies with Ms. Dyson. For instance, Mr. Horvak said, Ms. Dyson started talking about online privacy five years ago, well before it became a cause celebre.
"There is this thing that I call Esther's orbit," Ms. Horvak said. "She, by the gravitational pull of her personality and her person get all of these different kinds of people to be in orbit around her."
And that "pull", Mr. Horvak says, does not involve charisma or charm. But finding someone to say anything more critical for public attribution is nearly impossible. "Can we go off the record?" is the first thing many people said when asked to comment for this article.
As one acquaintance put it: "People are afraid to say bad things about Esther. Not because she is not a nice person, or out of fear of retribution from her, but because they think it will cast negatively on them."
The most recent Icann controversy is the issue of electing half of the 18-member board. Originally the voting was to be complete by the end of this September, but is now not expected to be finished until sometime next year.
Yet even as some blame Ms. Dyson for not being a better leader and problem solver, many give her credit for dedicating the time necessary to keep the very fragile Icann experiment from blowing up altogether.
Roger Cochetti, who as a policy executive with I.B.M. helped select Ms. Dyson as Icann's interim chairwoman, said the decision was not based on the assumption that she had any particularly unique insight into the Internet.
"There are probably about 1,000 people in the world who are as insightful about the Internet as Esther," Mr. Cochetti said. "People may disagree with Esther, and they may disagree with either her substance or her tactics, but it's rare -- if ever -- that anyone has ever questioned her integrity," he said. "She is a person who from my experience operates from her principle. You can rely on that."
Even before taking on the Icann duties, Ms. Dyson was spending 70 to 80 percent of her life on the road, attending her different board meetings and conferences and overseeing the personal investments she has in some 30 technology companies around the world -- many of them obscure ventures in Eastern Europe.
Her Icann work comes atop this heavy load. And the strain of the group's highly contentious process shows during Icann's public forums, which are purposely held in a different country each time -- and at which Ms. Dyson has become increasingly curt to the people who line up at the microphones to challenge proposed policies or question the group's procedures.
It is because Ms. Dyson has built a career as a seeming voice for the little guy, the individual user of digital technology, that some people in the electronic libertarian community say they feel a bit abandoned by Ms. Dyson in the Icann process.
They cite an episode last fall, when a coalition of nonprofit groups traveled to Chile for an Icann board meeting. The group asked the board to slow its policymaking until Icann had representation from non-commercial interests and individuals. As critics lined up to question how Icann, for example, had arrived at its business-backed policy for cracking down on so-called cybersquatters, Ms. Dyson's growing irritation became evident.
"With all due respect," she told the audience, "we are less interested in complaints about the process" and more interested in "doing real work and moving forward."
And in the case of last month's meeting in Cairo, Ms. Dyson and the rest of the board at first resisted demands from powerful groups like Common Cause and the Center for Democracy and Technology that they reconsider the election plan.
In the end, despite Ms. Dyson's "people who are stupid" remark, the interim board listened and agreed to allow direct election of the new members. But it remains unclear whether the hostilities will dissipate and the board will again attempt to work closely with the civil libertarians.
Ms. Dyson admits that Icann has made mistakes. But she said she was not sure how she might have made things work better. "Could I have been more forceful in raising some of things that I think were mistakes?" she said. "I don't know. It might have worked and it might have backfired."
And many of her critics and supporters alike agree that, whatever the shortcomings, she has credibly performed a thankless job.
"I don't think anyone could have done it any better than Esther has," Mr. Godwin said. "It's to Esther's credit that Icann hasn't been laughed out of existence."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1547 words

HEADLINE: Do Diplomas Make Jurors Any Better? Maybe Not

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
Their jury room pontifications do not necessarily mesmerize blue-collar New Yorkers. Some judges complain that they slow things down by talking about themselves so much. And court clerks say they do not come up with better excuses for getting out of jury duty: they are just more obnoxious about it.
Three years after New York State added nearly one million formerly exempt residents to its pool of potential jurors -- doctors, lawyers, nurses and other professionals -- the impact is becoming clear. And the results are not the ones that some people might have expected. 
 Better-educated jurors, it seems, are not necessarily proving to be better jurors. Doctors, lawyers and other professionals play leading roles in deliberations and ask sharper questions, judges say, but they do not sway the opinions of less-educated jurors and single-handedly decide cases. The arrival of the professional set, in fact, has resulted in no discernible change in the number of convictions or acquittals in criminal court, or damages awarded in civil court, according to court records.
But the change, the boldest of its kind in the nation, has drastically altered the makeup of juries in New York City. It has produced a sense that both the mighty and meek are being forced to endure a civic chore, prompted lawyers to change how they argue some cases, and created a vast social and legal experiment.
The city, particularly Manhattan, now boasts what are believed to be the nation's most diverse juries, legal experts say. City jury rooms have become the equivalent of sealed city subway cars, where a dozen people of different generations, classes, education levels, religions and races are expected to meet awkwardly, discuss anxiously and, it is hoped, agree amicably.
"You've got more professionals coming in and you've got a younger group of people that brings in a whole set of new attitudes," said Gregory P. Joseph, a lawyer who headed a special committee that studied the changes. "At the same time, you've got very Balkanized religious and ethnic groups in the mix."
Signs of tension exist. There are reports of lawyers who serve as jurors offering off-the-cuff jury-room legal opinions that improperly influence deliberations. But over all, New York's bold experiment appears to be working, according to judges, lawyers and legal experts.
Diverse juries are reaching verdicts in difficult cases, and celebrated professionals -- from the mayor to judges to the actor Harvey Keitel -- are serving as jurors without dominating deliberations. Even professionals presumed to be inherently biased are showing that they can be evenhanded, with police officers, for example, acquitting defendants in some cases.
Over all, New Yorkers are showing that a diverse jury can not just function but also function well and prevent jurors from stereotyping defendants, witnesses and each other. The change appears to be proving a long-running legal theory -- that 12 people of divergent backgrounds can bring more perspective, life experience and common sense to a case than 12 cookie-cutter jurors.
"You don't want 12 Ph.D.'s and you don't want 12 high school dropouts," said G. Thomas Munsterman, director of the Center for Jury Studies at the National Center for State Courts in Virginia. "You want a cross section. A lot of time you're not looking for the stuff a Ph.D. would know. You're looking for the down-home wisdom."
James Levine, dean of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, said he learned about New York's version of "down home wisdom" last fall while serving as a juror in an assault case. Professor Levine said his doctorate was useless as he struggled to decide whether a defendant had intended to pop a man's eye out during a subway brawl, or whether it had been accidental.
"I got educated by a guy who had an education in street fighting," Professor Levine said of a fellow juror. "He knew what blows you use to hurt and not hurt. He educated me, with all my degrees."
The impact of the changes could be seen in jury selection in the trial of the State of New York v. Jing Cheng in Manhattan Criminal Court on a recent Monday morning. Mr. Cheng, 23, a food deliveryman, was accused of getting into a dispute with a doorman in an Upper East Side apartment building last fall and breaking his nose.
The 20 people called for jury selection in the case included a surgeon, a lawyer, a nurse, three people with master's degrees, a former Broadway performer, a retired schoolteacher, a security guard, a messenger, a secretary and a doorman at another Upper East Side building. Even the judge presiding over the trial, Donna G. Recant, had been called for jury duty in the past.
In the end, a business executive with a master's degree, the nurse, the former Broadway performer, a woman who sold television shows, an editorial assistant at a publishing company and the doorman were chosen to decide Mr. Cheng's fate. Because he was charged with misdemeanor assault, a crime that carries a maximum sentence of one year in jail, the jury consisted of 6 people, not 12.
James Naughton, a 40-year-old business executive with a master's degree, said he believed Mr. Cheng's account that he was provoked by the doorman and found it suspicious that a surveillance camera videotape that could have captured the confrontation was missing.
But the woman who sold television programs did not believe Mr. Cheng and argued that there should be some type of conviction, according to Mr. Naughton. The doorman on the jury was open-minded, Mr. Naughton said, but also favored a lesser conviction. (The doorman and the television program saleswoman both declined to comment on the case.)
After five hours of deliberations that nearly ended in a hung jury, the panel unanimously voted to acquit Mr. Cheng of all charges. Mr. Naughton said the process had been difficult but worthwhile and said he supported the elimination of juror exemptions.
"I certainly would want a diverse jury," he said. "I think this guy would've been convicted if it were a less-educated jury."
The prime motivation for eliminating the exemptions was fairness, court officials said. No group, they said, should be exempt from a civic duty long considered the bane of New Yorkers. Along with professionals, people on unemployment and welfare also started being called for jury duty in 1996.
Of the two new groups, professionals were by far the larger one. Exemptions for some professionals, like doctors, lawyers and police officers, were originally created to thwart bias on juries and free up professions. But over the years, politically connected professions lobbied for and received exemptions from jury duty from the State Legislature.
By 1996, there were 21 exempt professions, including pharmacists, optometrists, podiatrists, embalmers, physical therapists, firefighters and people who fit artificial limbs. New York had more exempt professions than any other state.
With complaints from existing jurors rising and similar changes in other states proving successful, New York's chief judge, Judith S. Kaye, helped persuade the Legislature to eliminate all exemptions in 1996.
The changes sparked trepidation in some quarters. Judges worried that lawyers would improperly influence deliberation, and civil lawyers feared that professionals would be more tightfisted with jury awards.
Court officers, New York's version of bailiffs, joked that the arrival of more highly educated jurors would lead to paralysis. One court officer said he and his peers long ago dubbed summer juries in Manhattan "interplanetary juries" -- a reference to the high number of college professors who serve as jurors in the summer, when classes are in recess.
Highly educated jurors, according to their blue-collar critics, have a difficult time making their minds up and seem more neurotic. "They would have a tough time deciding what kind of sandwich they would have," one former court officer said. "Let alone how to decide a case."
But while some judges report an anecdotal increase in hung juries, court system statistics show no significant increase in deliberation times or mistrials. Russell F. Moran, publisher of The New York Jury Verdict Reporter, a newsletter that tracks verdict trends, said there had been a slight increase in plaintiffs losing cases, but jury awards remained unchanged.
Trial judges, who oversee trials and are in the best position to appraise the work of juries, generally praised the change. Justice John Cataldo of State Supreme Court in Manhattan said he recently began supervising jury trials after a three-year lapse and was struck by jurors' high education and professional levels. The majority of people on a recent jury had multiple degrees, he said.
"The questions from jurors during jury selection and during deliberations are good, on the point," he said. "I'm very happy with the jury pool."
Gail Winograd, a longtime Manhattan resident who has served on six juries since the mid-1970's, said she and her fellow jurors tended to make assumptions about each other while watching a trial, only to be disproved once they entered the jury room. "I've always been very impressed with the angles people come up with," she said. "You can't pigeonhole people."

HEADLINE: A Resurgent Michigan Leads Newly Flush States

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich., April 8

 BODY:
Lawmakers here and in many other states, now in the throes of writing their budgets for the 2001 fiscal year, are witnessing the biggest of six consecutive years of rising revenues, inspiring inventive new ways to spend money and wave upon wave of tax reductions.
States are collecting revenues from the taxes on surging industries, fully employed work forces, stock market gains and this year, for the first time, from a two-decade-long, $246 billion windfall from the settlement of their suit against the tobacco industry. 
 "The states are overflowing with money and spending a lot of money," said Stephen Moore, an economist at the conservative Cato Institute in Washington. "You are starting to see -- among Republican governors, by the way -- budget increases of 6, 7, 8 percent a year. States are continuing to cut taxes, too. But the money is coming in so fast they haven't kept pace."
Gary S. Olson, director of Michigan's nonpartisan Senate Fiscal Agency, which tracks the state's finances, said: "This is sort of an ideal situation. Michigan had never been able to reduce taxes and raise spending at the same time. I've worked in the Legislature since 1978, and clearly, these are the best times I've ever seen."
Because of the peculiarities of their taxation systems or their economies, a few states, like Wyoming, Iowa, Kansas, Tennessee and New Hampshire, are not reaping much of this harvest. But most are. New York, California, Texas, Maryland, Minnesota, Indiana, Washington, Pennsylvania and Michigan have been amassing annual surpluses exceeding $1 billion, typically representing hundreds of idle tax dollars collected from each of their citizens.
The surpluses have led to new spending plans and an array of tax cuts. In Maine, Gov. Angus King, an independent, would give a laptop computer to every seventh grader. Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland, a Democrat, would buy textbooks for students in the state's 500 private schools. In the fall, Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, a Republican, will send the state's 3.3 million homeowners a tax rebate check of $100.
Some states are cutting sales taxes on food and clothes and property taxes on automobiles. Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, an independent, has handed taxpayers $1.3 billion in sales tax rebates. In January, Gov. Bob Taft of Ohio, a Republican, put into effect tax breaks for adoptions and college tuition. In New York, Gov. George E. Pataki's top priority is lopping $1.25 billion from the state's debt, saving taxpayers the cost of carrying it but incurring the wrath of Democratic legislators and many Republicans who want more tax cuts and spending.
In his new budget, Gov. John Engler of Michigan is dipping into the state's tobacco settlement money for $83 million to give $2,500 college scholarships to students who pass a state achievement test. He proposes awarding $1,000 bonuses to the staff members of high-performing schools, from principals to janitors. He is creating a virtual high school for students to take advanced courses unavailable in rural areas through the Internet. And he plans to give all 80,000 public school teachers laptop computers.
Lawmakers are beginning to call their surpluses "structural," prosperity's antithesis to the structural deficits of much of the 1900's. By law, states, unlike the federal government, must erase one year's deficit the next year with spending cuts or tax increases. The serial surpluses of the 1990's and 2000 let them build reserves to tide them over in a moderate recession without touching programs and taxes.
But in choosing where to dispense prosperity's bounty, Democratic leaders in the states, most of which have Republican governors, say the big beneficiaries are businesses and the rich. "There is a percentage of our citizenry," said State Senator Alma Wheeler, Democrat of Ann Arbor, Mich., "that is not having its boat floated by this economy."
State Representative Hubert Price, a Democrat from Pontiac, Mich., calculates that a family of three with Michigan's median income of $40,000 will save $1.20 a week from a recent cut in the income tax rate to 4.2 percent from 4.4 percent. "I haven't had any constituents walk up to me in the grocery store and say, 'Thank you,' " Mr. Price said.
And public policy analysts say the prudence that states showed in the mid-1990's in setting aside rainy day funds to weather recessions has begun to wane. "Until now, it's been a series of happy surprises," said Iris Lav, an economist and expert on state finance at the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington. "Every year, revenues come in higher than forecast."
But she said three and four years of lowered tax rates and rising spending were consuming a larger part of the rising revenues, reducing the surpluses and resources set aside for recessions. The National Conference of State Legislatures in Denver reports that reserves have dropped to $30 billion this year from $37.5 billion last year.
Some of the tax cuts, especially the rebates, are one-time events, said Mandy Rafool, a senior policy analyst at the conference. "They're trying to give the money back but play it safe," she said. And to avoid the one-year jolt of sharp tax-rate reductions, many legislatures favor small, phased reductions like Michigan's 23-year elimination of a tax on business. In that way, she said, they avoid the political repercussions of raising taxes to cope with recessions.
No state has gained more from prosperity and surpluses than Michigan, where the cities of Flint, Pontiac, Benton Harbor and Detroit formed the downtrodden core of a region that economists called the rust belt. For decades, Michigan and West Virginia shared the nation's highest unemployment rates, often exceeding 10 percent.
In February, however, Michigan's unemployment rate was a mere 2.7 percent, one of the nation's lowest, the state's lowest in at least 30 years and well below the national rate of 4.1 percent. Automobile workers are working overtime and earning an average of $60,000 a year. On top of that, they are collecting $8,000 and $10,000 annual bonuses -- all taxable income that feeds the surplus.
Such unanticipated tides of revenue are pouring into the state treasury at a rate of $2 million more a day than the governor's economists predicted just a year ago and hundreds of thousands of dollars a day above their predictions as recently as January, when Governor Engler submitted his budget.
The governor was first elected 10 years ago as a tightfisted, tax-cutting crime-fighter, and has cracked down on parole and young offenders. Crime is down, as it is in the rest of the country, but prison terms have stretched, and the prison population has doubled during his tenure, to 40,000.
By the end of next year, Governor Engler and the Republican-controlled Legislature will have added 10,200 prison beds, with 3,700 opening this year. Prison spending has doubled during his tenure, reaching $1.5 billion last year, just $100 million less than spending for Michigan's colleges and universities. This year, Governor Engler is proposing to raise prison spending by nearly 9 percent, about the same as last year.
He has also chopped hundreds of millions of dollars in state and federal welfare spending by steering recipients into jobs and cutting the caseload from 238,000 in 1994 to 74,800 in January -- the lowest in 30 years. Last year for the first time, spending for day care, mostly for former welfare recipients who have gone to work, exceeded spending for cash assistance programs.
The rising revenues have let Governor Engler make 31 tax cuts since taking office, the last five in January, and accelerate spending from a 3 percent annual increase to more than 4 percent. He has begun letting the rainy day fund decline from 7 percent of state revenues to 5 percent, the minimum that economists say a state needs in a recession.
But 5 percent, representing $1.6 billion, is still well above the levels of the 1980's, when the fund never exceeded $500 million. "We could take a two-year hit and still be O.K.," said Robert J. Kleine, senior economist at Public Sector Consultants in Lansing, a private, nonpartisan research organization.
Industrially, the state is more diversified, giving lawmakers confidence that it can ride out recessions better than in the past. The old rust belt industries of automobiles, appliances and furniture have been driving the boom, but tax cuts may be reinforcing it.
All together, the governor's office says, the tax cuts have left taxpayers with $15 billion more to save or to spend to keep the economy rolling. "Michigan is a case study that tax cuts work," said State Representative Bill Schuette. "I think by cutting taxes, you're able to flex your economic muscle."
Michigan's new glut of money has also changed the tenor of budget debates. To spurn entreaties for aid in the days of tight budgets, said Mary A. Lannoye, Michigan's budget director, "You could say, 'There is no money. Just no.' " In this climate, more money shows up. So, she said, a legislator thinks, " 'Here's an opportunity to get a project I've been looking at for my community.' "
State Senator Harry Gast, a Republican who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, said that during the long recession of the mid-1980's, "we had to cut the budgets of 19 departments." But with year-after-year surpluses, he said, "we have programs coming out of the weeds -- groups with something warm and fuzzy, and some of them have merit."
Lately, as the revenues grow, Governor Engler's adversaries say they have begun to detect a softer view of the poor. "I think the governor is willing, in today's climate, to take itty-bitty steps," Representative Price said.
Soon after taking office, the governor eliminated the state's general assistance program, casting 83,000 single adults and couples without children from the welfare rolls.
"But we haven't had any more of those horrendous program cuts," said Sharon Parks, a director of the Michigan League for Human Services. And, she said that last year the governor approved a 2.5 percent increase in cash assistance for families remaining on welfare, the first increase in 12 years. Another increase, of 3 percent, will take effect in October.
Governor Engler has also given in to appeals for support of the arts, with grants to libraries and museums. "In the early 1990's, there was a significant cutback in arts and cultural spending in the state," said Mr. Olson of the Senate Fiscal Agency, which tracks state finances for the Senate. "Now we're probably spending more for the arts and culture than ever."
Yet in the face of Michigan's bonanza, smoldering issues remain. Surging health care costs are eliminating small businesses' gains from tax cuts, said the House Democratic leader, Michael Hanley. More spending for child care, he said, would slow the progression of young people to crime and prison.
"Clearly," said William Sederberg, president of Ferris State University in Big Rapids, Mich., "it would be better to spend more on higher education than on incarcerating people."

HEADLINE: Long History of Turmoil Entwines Incentive Pay Plans for Teachers

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
The mayor says it will help steer New York City's school system off the road to doom. His opponent in the Senate race, echoing the teachers' union, warns that it will divide the ranks of teachers and conquer their spirit. An impasse over the issue prompted the schools chancellor last week to cancel summer classes for 70,000 students. The topic is a hot one elsewhere, too: teachers in Los Angeles and England were threatening to strike over it 10 days ago.
But history, too, has something to say about merit pay for public school teachers, a concept that dozens of school districts across the country have embraced as a way to improve student achievement. 
 After almost three centuries of experiment, the merit pay closet is crammed with skeletons. There is the very dusty payment-for-results plan that was tried and then dropped in 18th-century England; a scandal-ridden scheme in Arkansas in 1969, which offered students transistor radios in return for higher test scores; and the incentive plans abandoned by scores of school districts around the country in the 1970's.
But the version of merit pay that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is proposing, one that would reward city teachers with bonuses based on their students' test scores, has spurred political turmoil in other school systems, and its impact on student achievement is largely untested, education experts say. Most incentive plans have used supervisor evaluations to judge individual teacher performance, relying on a school principal's review in doling out rewards.
Mr. Giuliani's opponent in the Senate race, Hillary Rodham Clinton, said last week that she would support merit pay plans that rewarded entire schools, rather than singling out individual teachers, an idea that some unions also support.
About six states and a dozen school districts are experimenting with schoolwide bonuses, but as is the case now in Colonial, Pa., near Philadelphia, incentive programs that also offer cash awards to individual teachers have typically touched off political firestorms or been derailed by critics.
Education scholars have watched public school merit pay plans come and go and come again since the first United States experiment, in Texarkana, Ark., the beginning of a national incentive program spearheaded by President Richard M. Nixon. Many experts say such plans have been dogged by fraud and rarely lead to real gains in student achievement.
"When you throw individual merit pay into the mix, controversy erupts," said Allan Odden, an education professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison who has spent a decade studying incentive programs. "The sad thing is, you could get much more acceptability with the school-based bonus programs." Professor Odden said such programs in Philadelphia, Boston and Memphis and in North Carolina were leading to better performance.
When incentive plans for teachers emerged in this country, about a decade after school desegregation, President Nixon, sounding a lot like Mr. Giuliani today, touted his program as a way to lift poor urban students out of academic failure and hold their schools accountable.
In 1969, Arkansas was the first to try the incentives, in the Texarkana public schools, one of the lowest-performing districts in a state with a major achievement gap between black and white students.
In a program run out of Washington, all Texarkana school employees were eligible for financial incentives if test scores improved, and students who did well on tests would receive free transistor radios, green stamps and rock music albums.
The program, known as "performance contracting" because private companies were hired to test the students and evaluate the performance of school employees, quickly expanded to other cities, according to several education scholars. The Texarkana incentive system was soon mired in scandal, with companies caught teaching to the test and cheating, and school districts gave up on President Nixon's plan.
Arkansas was only one of many places that have seen incentive plans fail amid cheating and scandal. In the British experiment with merit pay, in 1710, teachers were so determined to receive pay raises that they had their students memorize reading passages for English tests, according to Wellford W. Wilms and Richard R. Chapleau, education scholars who wrote an article in Education Week last November about the history of merit pay for teachers. In one account, a school inspector evaluating the program said a group of children read to him flawlessly from textbooks they were holding upside down.
More recently, a 1997 effort in Kentucky to award teachers cash bonuses for higher test scores, as part of an incentive program that also included schoolwide bonuses, was plagued by grade inflation on tests and other problems.
Many other incentive plans proposed by state education agencies and local school boards have died amid opposition from teachers' unions.
In Los Angeles earlier this month, the union threatened to strike, in part over a merit pay plan proposed by the acting school superintendent, Ramon C. Cortines, the former New York City schools chancellor.
Union leaders, who had enjoyed a cozy relationship with Mr. Cortines for the last several months, were so annoyed by his proposal that they called him "Go Away Ray" at a rally on April 2 that was held as contract negotiations opened.
British teachers, too, are locked in a ferocious battle with the government over a proposal that would tie annual pay raises of 2,000, or $3,159, to performance and possibly have teachers evaluate their colleagues and recommend them for bonuses. The teachers say the government's plan would fuel mistrust and lead to bribery and what a union leader called "snooping."
"If you get the 2,000, he'll want you to buy him a pint," Doug McAvoy, general secretary of England's National Union of Teachers told The Independent, a London newspaper, earlier this month. "But if you don't get it, whether he shares his chalk with you in the future would be debatable."
Most large urban school systems that experimented in the 1970's with incentive plans eventually dropped them, although merit pay plans survived and succeeded in some affluent districts, where pay scales are already higher than in the cities and where students tend to do well.
Denver is one of a few urban districts to revive merit pay in recent years, but it is too soon to tell whether that program will succeed, Professor Odden and other experts said.
"It's very difficult to do well," said Kathy Christie, who runs the information clearinghouse for the Education Commission of the States, a nonprofit policy group in Denver. "It's difficult to design. It's difficult to make sure it's fair, and it's difficult to fund over time."
In Denver, a two-year pilot plan approved last fall was to involve 450 teachers, who were to be paid $500 for signing up and $1,500 more annually for reaching certain goals, including improved scores.
The pilot plan was supposed to start in November, was delayed until January, extended to four years and has so far involved only 12 of the district's 104 schools and 350 teachers. Some Denver teachers said they were worried that the school district would run out of money if too many received bonuses, a problem many districts faced in the past before giving up on incentive plans.
Still, some participating teachers said the Denver program was encouraging them to pay more attention to student achievement. "I think you focus more now on what your objective is," said Sue Sterkel, a math teacher for disadvantaged students at Columbian Elementary School in northwest Denver.
The question of whether merit pay discourages teachers from working with low achievers is, along with the possibility of educators' cheating or using other tricks to raise test scores, at the root of the debate over financial incentive plans.
"Merit pay is ridiculous, and the reason it's ridiculous is that it discourages teachers from taking classes that are difficult," said Judith Gabey, a senior English teacher at Murray Bergtram High School for Business Careers, in Lower Manhattan, referring to a school considered one of the best in the nation. "If you work at Stuyvesant for merit pay, you're going to get your merit pay."

HEADLINE: PERU VOTERS GIVE PRESIDENT A SHOCK; A RUNOFF IS LIKELY

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 9

 BODY:
President Alberto K. Fujimori appeared to fall short of a first-round re-election victory today in a vote hotly contested by Alejandro Toledo, a business school professor from humble roots who immediately charged that the government was trying to steal the election.
Standing united with all six of the other opposition candidates who vowed to fight any attempt at fraud, Mr. Toledo said, "I can assure you, if someone tries to block the will of the people, I guarantee that I will be in the streets in two minutes." 
 Dressed in faded jeans and a green work shirt with a red bandana around his head, he added, "I'm an Indian rebel with a cause."
Mr. Toledo made his charges to tens of thousands of supporters, whom he then led to the presidential palace in a dramatic climax to a campaign riddled by smear tactics that crippled other challengers.
The President had been almost uniformly viewed as a sure winner, but a popular and international outcry over what appeared to be a growing and systematic attempt to steal the vote peeled away his support at an accelerating rate in the final 10 days of the race, pollsters said.
Mr. Fujimori is seeking an unprecedented third term after a tumultuous decade in which he defeated two terrorist insurrections and ended years of hyperinflation in this Andean country of 26 million people. But Mr. Toledo managed to capitalize on the disaffection the campaign had created, as well as unhappiness over the economy and the appeal of his own personal story as a one-time shoeshine boy who rose from poverty in a family of 16 children.
A complete count will not be announced for at least 48 hours. But a quick count based on vote tally sheets gave Mr. Fujimori 48.7 percent to Mr. Toledo's 41 percent, with a margin of error of less than half a point. Those figures came from a private group, Transparencia, partly financed by the United States and European governments.
A candidate needs to win more than 50 percent of the vote to avoid a runoff, which must be held by the first week of June. Earlier surveys of voters leaving the polls showed 45.2 percent for Mr. Toledo to 43.6 percent for Mr. Fujimori, with a margin of error of up to five percent.
There were reports of other demonstrations around the country in opposition to reports of fraud, and the crowds gathered in Lima tonight chanted, "Democracy yes, authoritarianism no!"
Mr. Fujimori had no immediate public comments. As the night progressed, several television networks whose owners are allied with the president switched off their election coverage and began airing movies and light entertainment shows.
The chance of a runoff was privately viewed by the Clinton administration and the Organization of American States as the best possible outcome to assure the political standing and economic stability of a country that has been a key American ally in combating the drug trade in Latin America.
Fears of a fraudulent victory by Mr. Fujimori, foreign diplomats here said this week, opened the possibility that the Organization of American States would rule that the election had not met international standards and would withdraw recognition of the Lima government.
"We are very concerned right now," said Eduardo Stein, a former Guatemalan foreign minister who is head of the Organization of American States observation team. "There is an unexplainable delay in the moving of the voting sheet tabulations to the computer centers," where they are counted.
Senior Clinton administration officials telephoned the chief of Mr. Fujimori's cabinet to seek assurances that the vote count would be clean. They also called Mr. Toledo requesting that he cool down his rhetoric.
There were reports of electoral computer glitches and at least sporadic vote fraud from across the country throughout the day, including instances of convicts voting, ballots filled in before they were given to voters and people voting with false documentation, presumably to cast their ballots more than once.
Most common were reports of ballots distributed with the name of Mr. Toledo, the leading opposition candidate, cut from voting sheets.
"There is outrageous fraud being committed," Mr. Toledo declared on a national radio network when he voted at midday. He said electoral authorities were confiscating and hiding evidence of fraudulent ballots after complaints had been filed, adding, "I plead that they stop dirtying this process."
A centrist, Mr. Toledo campaigned promising to strengthen local government, make the court system independent of presidential influence and use tax incentives to bolster agricultural industries as a way to increase exports and create jobs.
With his strong Indian facial features, Mr. Toledo was able to tap into the large urban population of mestizos, as people of mixed Indian-Spanish race are known, and offer himself as an example of what a poor son of a bricklayer and fishmonger can do with an education.
Several television networks broadcast the results, as well as exit polls showing that Mr. Fujimori had lost control of Congress. Mr. Fujimori's coalition, Peru 2000, won the largest block of congressional votes, but two-thirds of the seats will be divided among several opposition groups.
Polls indicated that President Fujimori was able to cling to most of his rural Indian voter base with a campaign that promised to continue tough policies that would prevent future terrorism and a broadening of milk and cereal handouts to ease hunger in Andean villages.
He had also promised to extend lunch programs and computer classes to schools across the country and build more roads connecting the provincial hinterlands, while he handed out hundreds of thousands of land titles to landless peasants.
Mr. Fujimori sometimes appeared to be a reluctant candidate who was pushed into the race by eager aides -- particularly his intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos -- who are concerned about losing their jobs or future prosecution for corruption.
Only in the last days of the race did Mr. Fujimori appear to campaign in earnest. He donned Indian costumes and danced on platforms across the country. The pace of his rallies -- held some days at desert cities along the coast and high altitude provincial capitals within hours -- amazed even his supporters.
He also began airing an effective barrage of television and radio commercials arguing that now that he had defeated terrorism and hyperinflation and made peace with neighboring Ecuador, he was ready to roll up his sleeves and attack the problem of unemployment.
But Mr. Fujimori was dogged by a scandal amply documented by the newspaper El Comercio involving campaign workers who forged one million signatures to get him on the ballot. The mounting evidence forced several election officials and congressional candidates allied with Mr. Fujimori to resign, and gave the impression that the president had lost control over what was once thought to be a well-oiled political machine.
He was also hurt by steady criticism that he had replaced judges and manipulated the Congress to run for an unprecedented third five-year term despite a constitutional ban.
In the final days of the campaign, the Organization of American States observer team released a report expressing concerns that systematic campaign irregularities had "impeded the citizenry from having the confidence that sufficient conditions exist for the exercise of effective democracy."
Mr. Toledo, a former World Bank official with a Stanford doctorate and a Belgian-born naturalized American wife, was the surprise of the election. After running a poor third in the 1995 presidential election, he was not expected to be a threat this year.
But Mr. Toledo surged dramatically in the last five weeks of the campaign after the candidacies of two other candidates were destroyed by a series of vicious personal attack campaigns appearing in the leading television networks and tabloid newspapers that were believed to be directed by Mr. Fujimori's intelligence service.
In the last two weeks of the campaign, the smears were directed at Mr. Toledo, but pollsters said they did not seem to have the same impact. "The demolition machine just ran out of steam," said Santiago Pedraglio, a political columnist for the daily Gestion.
