SECTION: Section E; Page 5; Column 5; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1133 words

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Yesterday's Orchard, Today's Dot-Com Target

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., April 5

 BODY:
Emily Mann's adaptation of "The Cherry Orchard" at the McCarter Theater here opens in somber fashion, with a violin solo in the discordant contemporary mode and the image of a young boy tossing a ball up and down behind a screen so he appears almost as a silhouette. The ball -- it must be a balloon -- rises and falls in watery slow motion; the boy is Grisha, the drowned son who lingers in the memory of his mother, Lyubov Ranevskaya, the haplessly sad-hearted landowner in the throes of heartbreak and disenfranchisment in Chekhov's last play.
The personification of the boy as the tiny specter of grief is one way that Ms. Mann's gently un-Russianized production remembers the individual, as opposed to the societal, traumas visited on the citizens of this melancholy comedy; it sends the play off with an undismissible thrum of defeat. 
 But this "Cherry Orchard" is otherwise a rather amiable one that emphasizes the fecklessness of its gentrified characters, and spills them, at the end, into a new world order that seems not emptier, just busier in background noise. Yes, of course, times have changed, but we can't concentrate on that; love is still impossible; death is still premature.
This is Ms. Mann's millennial idea, that the world is changing differently now, chaotically and bafflingly, rather than with an abrupt swivel. It feels right, though it also undercuts the disastrous, slow doom that the playwright sympathetically visited on his characters a century ago. This production (which runs through Sunday) is born of a world where it is as likely that the hacking down of an orchard could portend economic progress as it could corrupting development.
In the end the sound of chopping as the Ranevskaya household disperses -- that famously ominous herald of a vanished gentility -- isn't much more than static here. Instead the most resonant moment comes earlier; it is the revelation, by the socially risen businessman Lopakhin (Avery Brooks), that it is he who has bought Lyubov's orchard at auction. When he leaps in instinctively untoward delight at his coup, you can't help thinking of a dot.com millionaire.
Such is the sly spirit that makes this rendering of the play contemporary and American without being literally an update. The sparely selected furniture on Adrianne Lobel's set and Jennifer von Mayrhauser's costumes are authentic, but on the McCarter's vast stage they create a period doll-house feel. And the action is set among sliding screened panels, as though passing through shifting decades.
The text, adapted from a literal translation by Ellen Chances, is rendered in sophisticated modern vernacular, and the actors have been encouraged to speak without stilted formality; it's anachronism that works. And Ms. Mann has also made shrewd use of nontraditional casting, employing black actors in a fashion that fixes the eye of this production on the American century.
In addition to Mr. Brooks, there is Roger Robinson, as the shambling 87-year-old valet, Firs; in the touching speech about his arrest, decades earlier, for a killing he didn't commit, the American echoes are chilling. Indeed, you can't help but see the two actors together as bookends of a 100-year African-American journey.
A third black actor, Caroline Stefanie Clay, is cast as Varya, Lyubov's stepdaughter; her aching frustration at Lopakhin's inability to propose to her because he longs for her stepmother is given an added wrench by the racial implication. Lyubov is played by the excellent Jane Alexander, who is, of course, white. The effect of all this is oddly twofold; the casting stratagems add an interpretive tingle but also an air of hope, rather unexpected in the Chekhovian universe.
Led by Ms. Alexander's just-dizzy-enough, woe-is-me portrayal of Lyubov, the crowded Ranevskaya household is presented here as a circus of ineffectuality and pretend dignity. In particular, as Gayev, Lyubov's pompous and utterly useless brother, John Glover is flamboyant and lovable; his speech proposing a birthday celebration for a 100-year-old bookcase is a tour de force of foolishness.
Cupid's errant arrows are the preoccupation of this household; the people in it are much more able to confront one another's love problems than the imminent loss of the family home. And Ms. Mann presents the soap opera with the relish of hormonal riot; it tips, a little unfortunately, to slapstick in the dominant-submissive ballet between the servants Yasha (Jefferson Mays) and Dunyasha (Kate Goehring).
Amid the loopy courtship misfirings, Lopakhin's paralyzing indecision -- Lyubov or Varya? -- stands out as unsatiric. Lopakhin, more than any other character after all, feels the tug of both future and past. Lyubov is his fantasy of attainment, the privileged woman who was kind to him when he was a peasant boy. Varya would be the conventional match in the business-driven new world order that he himself defines.
Playing against physical type, in a performance at the hub of this production, Mr. Brooks is fascinating to watch. His size -- he towers over the other actors -- and his carriage, his erect bearing, don't normally compute in Lopakhin, whose upbringing taught him deference to caste superiors and whose adult affluence is a source of pride and confusion. Mr. Brooks exercises his stature elaborately, folding and unfolding like a collapsible cane as he moves among postures of slack repose, plaintive advice-giving and the joy born of a fat wallet.
When the family departs the homestead that now belongs to him, Lopakhin has won his sought place in the world, but no one is more bereft. In Mr. Brooks's crestfallen exit, with his weakly expressed hope for a reunion -- "So, until spring! Come on, friends" -- is the lingering sadness of victory. It's the inevitable leveling of people, not trees, that keeps Chekhov a playwright for our time.
 
THE CHERRY ORCHARD
By Anton Chekhov; adapted and directed by Emily Mann from a translation by Ellen Chances; sets by Adrianne Lobel; costumes by Jennifer von Mayrhauser; lighting by James F. Ingalls; composer, Mel Marvin; sound by David Budries; choreography by Peter Pucci; literature consultant, Ellen Chances; resident producer, Mara Isaacs; dramaturg, Janice Paran; production stage manager, Alison Cote. LENGTH: 141 words

HEADLINE: Social Security Gain

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Law Removes an Earnings Limit on Recipients of Social Security" (news article, April 8): The bill, passed by Congress without a single dissenting vote and signed by President Clinton, eliminates the earnings test for Social Security recipients age 65 to 69. This bill has symbolic meaning beyond the additional dollars it provides for some. It removes one of the "means test" rules that marked Social Security as a welfare program instead of the insurance it was meant to be. 
 At a time when people are retiring early, living longer and seeking ways to supplement their income over a longer life span, this law allows older people to take part more fully in the strong economy and promotes the idea of employing older men and women with special skills and experience.
 
ROBERT MENCHIN
Chicago, April 8, 2000

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1762 words

HEADLINE: A Little Light Reading, Anyone?;
WhenWeighty Issues Are the Magazines Themselves

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Mark Clements, a magazine consultant, has a new idea for a product: a special piece of luggage designed to carry big, fat magazines.
"Considering how much these things weigh these days, it will be indispensable," he said. "Who can carry this stuff home?" 
 Mr. Clements was joking, but just barely. After all, the magazines he was referring to -- In Style, Vogue, Vanity Fair and W -- have all in the last year blown past their records for size, heft and length. They are part of a growing breed: the obese magazine, publications so fat that if they were people, they might spend their time in a high school auditorium sweating to the oldies with Richard Simmons.
Toss them on a desk, and you'll hear what publishers like to refer to as "the thud factor." (The louder the thud! thunk! or boom! the better.) As the economy continues to thrive, some magazines have become so fat with advertising that the editorial content is sometimes relegated to the increasingly hard-to-find nether reaches of the publication.
These magazines are so packed with perfume-scented pages and dot-com ads -- ranging upward to 1,200 pages a magazine, in extreme cases -- that some are bigger than the Minneapolis/ St. Paul telephone book (988 pages). Because they are printed on heavy, glossy paper, they weigh almost as much as a newborn baby. In Modern Bride's February-March issue, the main editorial feature section does not begin until page 871; by that point in a 19th-century Russian novel, the heroine most likely would have already died her tragic death chapters ago.
Of course, not all magazines are so lucky. Just in the last month, Time Inc. announced that it would stop publishing Life magazine in May. Conde Nast, a subsidiary of Advance Publications, shut down Details in the guise of a four-month publishing hiatus. Both magazines had slimmed down to a foreboding, anemic flimsiness -- relative to their fat cousins -- in their final months.
And even the most successful magazines know that the good times will not last forever. No one expects advertising dollars to keep flowing so generously from Internet businesses intent on establishing their brand.
But for now the magazines that are doing well have never had it so good. This year, In Style broke its own record with 588 pages in its April issue, Vanity Fair had a record 472 pages, Vogue's March issue was 566 pages (not an all-time record, but a record for the month), and W's March issue was 520 pages (W broke its all-time record last March with 562 pages). And while Bride's might send affianced women across the country to the chiropractor -- this spring, the February-March issue made it into the Guinness Book of World Records as the largest magazine ever produced, at 1,271 pages -- so might Modern Bride, with 1,062 pages.
Internet business and technology magazines like Red Herring, Business 2.0 and The Industry Standard are also breaking records. Fortune broke its record with a 630-page issue that arrived on newsstands last week. At The Industry Standard, a weekly, advertising pages have grown more than 450 percent the last year, running 1,548 pages in 2000 through the middle of March. That outpaces every other weekly magazine in the country, including People, by a significant margin, according to Media Industry Newsletter, a trade publication.
Advertisers bought $1.2 billion in consumer magazine advertising for February, the last month for which complete figures are available, according to the Magazine Publishers of America, a trade association. That represents an increase of 15.4 percent over February 1999.
Circulation increases help magazines justify higher ad rates, but the number of readers is often less important than who the readers are and how badly the advertisers want to reach them. According to the Publishers Information Bureau, Vogue's advertising revenue is up 32 percent the first two months of 2000, compared with the same period in 1999, to $21.9 million. But the magazine's circulation was flat for the year ended Dec. 31, the last period for which figures are available, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
Samir Husni, a professor of media at the University of Mississippi and a close observer of the magazine industry, said that magazines have never been so physically huge. "We used to have fat issues in the early 1980's, but it was always just the September issue of Vogue or Elle," he said. "But now any issue of Fast Company or Business 2.0 or In Style is as big as those were."
But with every embarrassment of riches, there is worry. Publishers lie awake at night worrying that consumers might be annoyed at the advertising tonnage. Advertisers fret that their ad might be lost in the vast commercial soup. And with a five-pound beast of a magazine rolling off the printing presses, there can be problems at the printers, at the bindery, with the trucks, at the newsstand, and even with the consumer, who some publishers fear might not want to carry around a magazine that weighs as much as a cinder block.
Martin Walker, a consultant to the magazine industry, said that magazines have become fatter for two reasons: First, the economy is good and advertisers are eager to spread the wealth and, in the case of new Internet companies, develop brand recognition with consumers. Second, the most successful magazines are mostly niche publications, not general-interest magazines, and there has been an emphasis on aiming at specific audiences.
"Fashion and beauty magazines really are vertical, special-interest publications, as are the dot-com magazines and the bridal magazines," Mr. Walker said. "So there is a significant amount of endemic advertising. All the venture capital groups and all the dot-com groups feel it is a requirement that they be in The Industry Standard. Calvin Klein is required to be in Vogue and In Style. But who's required to be in Time? No one. And that's why you won't see a Time magazine this fat."
But even the general-interest weekly magazines are getting chubby these days. The Dec. 5, 1999, issue of The New York Times Magazine was 214 pages, a record for recent years. Time magazine's last issue of 1999 was 252 pages.
But does anyone really look at 1,180 pages of ads anyway? If magazine publishers are to be believed, the answer is yes.
"The real question is, does it turn off the reader?" Mr. Walker asked. "Absolutely not. To a woman reading a bridal magazine, an ad for a wedding gown is just as interesting as an editorial page featuring a wedding gown. What's the difference between a Calvin Klein ad in Vogue and a Calvin Klein editorial page? Absolutely nothing."
Richard D. Beckman, the publisher of Vogue, said the advertising in the March and September issues, when readers are thinking about new clothing purchases, "is the strength of the book -- readers shop the magazine."
"The ad, the edit, it's all the same," said John Balen, the associate marketing director of Modern Bride.
The notion that readers might be turned off by a magazine's weight and too many ads prompted Louis Cona, the publisher of In Style, to survey 5,000 readers of the magazine recently. "We were concerned because we thought too much weight might affect the pass-along readership," he said. (A high rate of pass-along readership -- how many people see each copy -- helps bolster advertising rates.)
Mr. Cona said that 66 percent of the respondents said that "a thick book makes the issue more valuable." And 87 percent said that the weight of the magazine did not deter them from carrying it to another place to read.
But Yogi Berra's observation -- it's too crowded; nobody goes there anymore -- holds true for advertisers: some shy away from the fat magazines. Gene DeWitt, the chief executive of Optimedia International (U.S.), an advertising services agency in New York, said that if advertisers could not get highly trafficked pages in a packed magazine, they might skip that issue.
"In the business category, we'll discuss Forbes, Fortune and Business Week and advertisers will say, 'Forget about Business Week, it's too cluttered,' " he said. (Business Week's ad pages have risen 28 percent over last year.) "And in some issues of Vogue, if you can't get a good spot, you may say to yourself, 'Why would I want to be in there?' They won't drop the magazine altogether, but a guaranteed position is required."
Does more advertising mean more articles? Not necessarily. Most of the obese magazines stray from the norm for the average ratio of advertising to editorial content, as measured by the Magazine Publishers of America. The trade group reported last year that the average ratio for American consumer magazines was 49.4 percent advertising to 50.6 editorial content.
Vanity Fair's March issue was 66 percent advertising; the February-March Bride's -- with a whopping 1,180 pages of ads, said Nina Lawrence, the publisher of Bride's -- was 93 percent advertising.
Mr. Cona of In Style said that he was careful to monitor the ratio of advertising to editorial pages, keeping it to an average of about 47 percent editorial to about 53 percent advertising. But the April issue of In Style had 337 pages of advertising and 235 pages of editorial content, or about 41 percent editorial to 59 percent advertising.
The March issue of Vogue had 177 pages of editorial and 389 pages of advertising, or about 31 percent to 69 percent.
All that advertising can complicate production. In Style has grown so big in recent months that there have been delays in getting the magazine to newsstands.
"You can only bind 7,500 copies of In Style per hour, as opposed to most magazines, where you can bind 11,000 copies per hour," Mr. Cona said. "As you slow down that process, you can have delivery problems to wholesalers, which gets them out late on the newsstand, which costs you sales."
The cost of trucking the magazines has also risen. When In Style was first published in 1995, 20 magazines fit into one bundle. Now, only five do. Mr. Cona has had to hire extra drivers and trucks and has also had to buy bigger, deeper newsstand racks -- but of course all the cost is offset by the surging advertising revenue.
"Look, there are worse problems to have in this world," Mr. Cona said. "As long as it thuds, it's good." And he said that he is always gratified when Don Logan, the chief executive of Time Inc., which publishes In Style, calls to see the early copies.
"He drops it on his desk and he listens," Mr. Cona said. "And the louder the thud, the happier he is."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Bonds Rise Smartly On Expectations of Buyback

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday on speculation that the Treasury Department may step up its purchases of government debt after the April 17 tax-filing deadline and as a decline in the Nasdaq composite index bolstered the allure of bonds.
"People feel bulletproof" owning bonds against the threat of rising interest rates, said Dana Johnson, research chief at Banc One Capital Markets. "Once April tax receipts start pouring in," the Treasury is going to accelerate the buyback. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 16/32 , to 108 13/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.66 percent from 5.70 percent on Friday.
Treasuries extended gains in late trading as the Nasdaq plunged 5 percent, sending some investors into the haven of fixed-income debt, analysts said. Notes also got a lift after the Federal Reserve bought Treasuries due between April 30, 2003, and Feb. 15, 2004, as part of its regular money market operations.
With two years of budget surpluses behind it, the government last month repurchased $2 billion in longer-term government debt, part of a planned $30 billion buyback this year. Those plans and reduced debt sales have helped push the 30-year yield down more than three-quarters of a percentage point since January. Bonds have returned 12.9 percent, including reinvested interest, erasing last year's losses, the worst since the Treasury began regular bond sales in 1977.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Philippines Set to Privatize Power Company

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, April 10

 BODY:
Legislators in the Philippines are set to vote this week on a bill that would privatize the heavily indebted national power company, a reform that the International Monetary Fund and other lenders have demanded before disbursing critical new loans.
The House of Representatives is scheduled to begin voting on Tuesday on the Power Reform Bill, which would overhaul the nation's power industry and put the unprofitable, state-run National Power Corporation into private hands. President Joseph Estrada and Manuel B. Villar, the House leader, have both pledged support for the bill, which the Philippine congress aims to make law by this summer. 
 The I.M.F. has given Manila until June 30 to pass the power bill, along with the privatization of the Philippines National Bank, before it releases $500 million in loans needed to help offset the country's 62.5 billion peso ($1.5 billion) budget deficit. The World Bank and the Asian Development Bank have also made further lending contingent on the reforms.
This week's vote has also become a test of the credibility of Mr. Estrada's administration. Action on the power reform bill has been delayed for years.
"Investors want to see some tangible evidence that the government can do something right," said Rebecca Patterson, an analyst at J. P. Morgan in Singapore. If legislators fail to push the power reform bill through this week, she said, "it suggests they can't get anything done."
Selling the company would also have several tangible benefits, economists say. These include easing electricity prices, which are second only to Japan's, promoting investment and reducing a sizable burden on public finances. Government outlays to Napocor, as the money-losing utility is known, are a major contributor to the Philippines budget deficit.
While there is some optimism the House can pass the bill before next week's Easter recess, there is less hope about its fate in the Senate.
The Philippines is not the only country in Southeast Asia where the I.M.F. is threatening to cut off aid to stimulate economic changes. In Indonesia last week, the I.M.F.'s move to withhold $400 million in loans spurred the government in Jakarta to expedite economic changes to keep the money flowing.
Philippine financial markets have been rocked this year by concerns about creeping cronyism and other forms of corruption. Fueling those concerns is a scandal over accusations of insider trading involving a friend of Mr. Estrada. The stock exchange's entire compliance department resigned late last month to protest what it called a cover-up of the insider trading.
The scandal is overshadowing what economists say is an otherwise positive economic picture. A trade surplus, low interest rates and strengthening domestic demand are underpinning an economy that analysts at Merrill Lynch predict will grow 3.4 percent this year.
Napocor's financial problems are partly the result of the country's chronic power shortages of the early 1990's. In response, the company signed contracts with roughly a dozen independent power producers, who now provide about a quarter of the nation's electricity. The contracts overestimated the country's power demand, however, meaning Napocor has to pay for the power the country does not need. Worse, most of the power plants use oil for fuel, leaving the Philippines dependent on petroleum imports for about half of its power needs.

SECTION: Section B; Page 11; Column 1; Style Desk; Fashion Page

LENGTH: 1265 words

HEADLINE: 'Cheap Chic' Draws Crowds on 5th Ave.

BYLINE: By RUTH LA FERLA 

 BODY:
On Friday, a crowd packed the sidewalk waiting for the 10 a.m. opening of H&M, a purveyor of cheap chic that is Manhattan's latest temple to consumerism. Held back by velvet ropes, as if at a nightclub, customers were squeezed shoulder to shoulder. The instant the portals swung open, they rushed the racks, snatching up $9 tank tops, $30 dresses and $19 drawstring pants -- the fashion equivalent of fast food, in both price and trendiness.
Many failed to notice that it was soon well past the hour when more conscientious New Yorkers are at their desks. "I'm supposed to be at an audition right now, and I have to catch a plane at 1," said Becky Bahling, 22, an actress. But the prospect of missed flights and squandered opportunities seemed not to faze her. "I want this and I want it now," she said, slipping on a caramel-colored leather coat that cost $170. 
 On another day last week, Diego Del Pino, 26, a Web site designer for Sothebys.com, was making his third visit to the store since its opening on March 31. He plucked out a pair of $39.99 trousers to match a $69.99 gray linen sport coat. "Before I came here, I used to shop at the Gap and Banana Republic," he said. "But lately those stores have been so boring. The design just isn't there." As for prices, he said, "Well, compared to almost anywhere, this place is heaven."
Judging by the throngs descending on H&M, on Fifth Avenue at 51st Street, many shoppers do regard it as a retail Nirvana. On Saturday there was a 25-minute wait for one of the unisex dressing rooms, and customers were changing in the aisles. A woman demanded a paisley skirt from a mannequin when the racks were emptied. At peak hours, the store restocks from garment racks on the sidewalks and trucks waiting in the street.
"People told us that New Yorkers didn't line up to come into stores," said Par Darj, director of United States operations for H&M, a Stockholm-based chain with 700 stores in 12 European countries. "How did this happen? We're very surprised."
So are retail experts. "They're able to translate forward fashion quickly at value prices, and at least in the first few days, they have been very successful," said Arnold Aronson, managing director of retail strategies for Kurt Salmon Associates, a retail consulting firm. "I've seen consumers walking out not with onesies and twosies, but with dozens of garments. If the store can make adequate margins to satisfy their profit needs, then they've got something very relevant."
The press of shoppers is all the more remarkable considering that only a month ago, few New Yorkers had heard of H&M, or Hennes & Mauritz, as it is formally known. But on the strength of a last-minute flurry of advertisements featuring the actress Chloe Sevigny and enthusiastic word of mouth, the store has succeeded, for the moment at least, in pumping consumers' adrenalin levels to dizzying heights. Mr. Darj said 2,000 shoppers rushed into the 35,000-square-foot store the first 13 minutes it was open.
H&M arrives at a time when consumer shopping patterns have changed markedly in the United States. Ever on the prowl for bargains, and made cynical by frequent store markdowns and promotions, even many affluent customers have deserted department stores. They shop instead at discounters like Target and outlet centers like Woodbury Common in Central Valley, N.Y.
"It's chic to pay less," said Howard L. Davidowitz, a New York retail analyst. "More now than it ever has been."
The success of chains like Old Navy has shown that even in an economic boom, customers will flock to retailers offering deep discounts. But while Old Navy sells basics like T-shirts and cargo shorts, H&M's formula is to offer much hipper fashion at rock-bottom prices. With most items priced well below $100, even the occasional cheap-feeling fabric or frayed hem isn't turning off shoppers intent on getting the latest Helmut Lang or Prada look-alike. The clothes are for the most part a synthesis of current runway fashion and street styles: fringed and embroidered hippie chic, lots of leather, uptown ladylike clothes.
Margareta van den Bosch, H&M's chief designer, maintained that her 70-member team, which designs under 23 labels for men, women and children, was not creating knockoffs. "Of course we follow fashion," she said. "We have invested quite a lot in that. But we want to do things our own way."
In the recent past, urban shoppers on the prowl for cutting-edge style at deep discounts had to wait for sales at midprice apparel chains like Zara, Club Monaco or Scoop, or ferret out deals amid the bedding and barbecue grills at Kmart and Target. H&M stores cater to young-minded patrons who prefer to shop guilt-free for fashion that can be discarded after only a season or so.
"They're coming in at a level between Target and the department stores," said Candace Corlett, a partner at WSL Retail Strategies, a retail consultant. "It certainly has the competition sitting up and taking notice."
Stores like Lerner New York, the Limited Express and Bloomingdale's, which might be most directly affected if H&M sets off a price war, seem to have a wary eye on the newcomer. Bloomingdale's ran ads last week linking style and value in what seemed an obvious attempt to compete.
A spokesman for Lerner New York, Philip Monaghan, said there were so few stores selling truly stylish clothes at ultralow prices that the arrival of H&M would not set off a price war. "I don't think we're going to feel the impact from H&M," he said. "They're not in the malls of America yet."
But H&M intends to be there. Days after opening on Fifth Avenue, the chain opened a second 35,000-square-foot store at the Palisades Mall in West Nyack, N.Y. And on Thursday, it will open a third at the Garden State Plaza in Paramus, N.J. There are also plans for a 40,000-square-foot store on West 34th Street, around the corner from Macy's, and a store on Lexington Avenue in the former Alexander's location. Retail analysts estimate that the chain plans 100 stores nationwide.
But some experts said they doubted H&M could sustain such aggressive expansion, speculating that profits would suffer. "H&M appears to be doing a large number of transactions," said Richard B. Hodos, the president of HGCD Retail Service, a retail consulting and brokerage firm. "But it would be interesting to see the average dollar amount that they are ringing up."
Mr. Darj declined to cite revenue figures for the store's first week, or to specify how much H&M must sell to be profitable. But he did say the numbers were "well beyond our expectations."
Other analysts questioned whether the notion of "disposable chic" would ultimately prove distasteful to customers. "It's the kind of merchandise we used to call flash and trash," said Richard Jaffee, a retail analyst at Paine Webber.
But Mr. Jaffe praised what he called the store's energy level: its mix of shoppers, young and old, hip and fashion-clueless, and the amount of socializing that goes on while customers shop. "The store is positioned to generate the same kind of excitement we used to see on the main floor of Bloomingdale's 20 years ago," he said.
On Friday, Mattie Ullrich, 26, a movie costume designer, was weighed down by her haul, which included a plaid skirt ($25) and a tiger-print tank top ($17). "This is fun," she said, teetering toward a register. Holding up a sleeveless bead-embroidered sweater, she said, "I love this top."
"The only bummer," she added, "is that by this time next week everyone else in New York will have it, too."

HEADLINE: Africa's Plague, and Everyone's

BYLINE: By Nadine Gordimer; Nadine Gordimer, who was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1991, is a goodwill ambassador for the Race Against Poverty project of the United Nations Development Program.

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
Sixty-nine percent of the world's victims of H.I.V. and AIDS are in sub-Saharan Africa. This figure is not easy to take in. AIDS seems to have come upon everyone while we were looking the other way: it happened to some sex or color other than our own; it was endemic to some other country.
In South Africa it was quite some time before the realization that the disease was not the unfortunate problem of our poorer neighboring countries, but was our own. Now, out of South Africa's 43 million people, about 4 million have been infected by H.I.V. and a further 1,700 are infected daily. Recently, in a Johannesburg home caring for orphaned or abandoned babies born with AIDS, there was a service in memory of 40 who had died there not long before. While South Africa is the most highly developed country on the African continent, we are faced with this kind of future for the generations to come. 
 But every community, every affected country, has to decide how to approach what is no longer a problem but a catastrophe. There is prevention, and there is cure. The ideal is to seek both at once, but this is beyond the capacity of most countries where the disease is rampant.
Cure, and prevention by inoculation, are not within the capacity of lay people; these are in the hands of medical science, which implies money to be provided to advance research. Immediate prevention is in the hands and initiative of each population itself.
I believe we cannot emphasize bluntly enough that the cure and vaccine development depend on money. And until recently, the country that has the money, the United States, perhaps inevitably has concentrated on a vaccine for a subtype of AIDS prevalent in the Northern Hemisphere. It was only at the World Economic Forum's meeting this year that President Clinton announced that large-scale aid for vaccine development would be forthcoming from the United States. Only now has the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative announced a third international development project, based on those subtypes of the virus most prevalent in the direly affected regions of Southern and East Africa, the subtypes C and A.
It is encouraging that the project is being pursued in wide collaboration among researchers of the United States, South Africa, Kenya and Oxford University, and that the philosophy of the initiative is that of "social venture capital," meaning that in return for financing, it has secured rights to ensure that a successful vaccine, when it is achieved, will be distributed in developing countries "at a reasonable price." The formation of an International Partnership Against HIV/AIDS in Africa is to be welcomed as extremely important in the same context.
The question of money -- price -- is vital in terms of the palliatives available to arrest the disease and alleviate symptoms. It is another piercing example of the gulf between the world's rich and the world's poor that the suffering from AIDS may be alleviated, and even the lives prolonged, of those victims who can afford expensive treatment. The same principle applies to prevention. Everywhere in Africa moral and humanitarian decisions are a common dilemma, with money the deciding factor.
At the level of international -- global -- responsibility, the total sum needed annually for AIDS prevention in Africa is on the order of $2.3 billion. Africa currently receives only $165 million a year in official assistance from the world community.
Other questions that rest with the world community become relevant: debt relief for developing countries, for example. The director-general of the World Health Organization said last year that debt relief should be reviewed in light of the resources that governments with large debts need to confront H.I.V.
The role of governments in financing is another example. Where does the defense budget not far exceed the public health budget to combat AIDS? Nevertheless, what H.I.V. and AIDS mean to the capability to govern, ultimately, was revealed in South Africa by the minister of public service and administration in February. The public service is the largest employer in the country and the fundamental government structure. In 1999, one in eight South Africans was H.I.V.-positive. It is estimated that 270,000 out of 1.1 million public servants could be infected by 2004. This looming crisis in governance exists almost everywhere on the African continent. If, in developing countries, defense budgets continue to leave H.I.V. budgets relegated to a footnote, all we shall have left to defend in the end is a graveyard.
AIDS is not only a health catastrophe, a challenge to medical science. It is socially enmeshed in the conditions of life that obtain while it spreads, just as the medieval plague was in its time. Although AIDS is no respecter of class or caste, slum conditions, ignorance and superstition (it is a white man's disease; it is a black man's disease) make the poor its greatest source of victims.
In working to prevent the spread of the virus, we must accept the idea that promiscuity is difficult to condemn when sex is the cheapest or only available satisfaction for people society leaves to live on the street. On another socioeconomic level, casual sex thrives among young people who are materially privileged yet whom society has failed to endow with the real values of human sexuality, the knowledge that fulfillment involves contact with the other's personality, that the sexual act is not some mere bodily function like evacuation -- which is what some campaigners seem to reduce it to.
There are subtleties, important ones, connected with any campaign against H.I.V. and AIDS, if it is to succeed in changing attitudes toward sexual mores. For there will be a cure discovered, there will be a vaccine -- and after that? How shall we restore the quality of human relations that have been debased, shamed, reduced to the source of a fatal disease? The free condom dispenser is not the panacea. Neither, alone, is sex education restricted to anatomical diagrams and dire warnings in schools. The entire meaningfulness of personal sexual relations will need to be restored. That is what social health means, along with inoculation and survival.
Self-interest cannot be discounted. So, to the developed world, a pragmatic word from the stricken African continent: Call not to ask for whom the stock exchange bell tolls and the figures on the computer sound the alarm -- the toll is for Europe, for the United States, even for those countries where H.I.V. and AIDS victims are few. For if the markets and vast potential markets for the developed world's goods fail -- if decimated populations mean there is no one left economically active with money to spend -- that bell tolls for thee, globally.
H.I.V./AIDS is everyone's disaster. It has, finally, something to do with our whole manner of existence. It confronts us with questions that must be answered historically: What have we done with the world, politically? What are we doing with the world? What do we mean by development? Some Ugandans who had been in the audience of an AIDS information play were asked what message it had brought them. One said, "Don't go out with bar girls." Another said, "Stick to one partner." Then an older woman said: "AIDS has come to haunt a world that thought it was incomplete. Some wanted children, some wanted money, some wanted property, and all we ended up with is AIDS."
Maybe she spoke for Africa.

HEADLINE: Putin, in Major Test, Wins Accord for Vote on Nuclear Arms

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 10

 BODY:
In the first major test of a new and more centrist parliamentary majority, President-elect Vladimir V. Putin reached agreement today with his legislative allies to bring a long-delayed nuclear arms reduction treaty to a ratification vote in Parliament as early as Friday.
Proponents of ratifying the treaty, known as Start II, predicted that they had the votes to win. The decision to move forward immediately with the vote in the wake of Mr. Putin's victory in the presidential election last month was hailed as a significant advance for arms control, an agenda that a Communist-led coalition that dominated the Parliament has blocked for five years. 
 But with the victory in December by liberal and centrist parties, who won a majority of the 450 Parliament seats, a strong ratification would also demonstrate the realignment that is taking shape as Mr. Putin prepares to undertake a new phase of economic reforms for which he will need strong backing.
"The presidential elections have given us a good chance to be guided by Russia's interests and not to look back at internal problems and engage in politicking," said Sergei Ivanov, director of the national security council under Mr. Putin, after a meeting of the advisory body this afternoon in the Kremlin.
A number of legislative leaders here, as well as senior members of the Clinton administration, have been urging Moscow to vote on the treaty before Mr. Putin is sworn in on May 7. On Friday in Washington, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott was quoted by Reuters as having said, "The Russians continue to assure us, including in the last 24 hours, that the process for ratifying Start II in the Duma is under way."
But with all the prodding, it appeared that Mr. Putin decided to test his strength in the Parliament only after it was clear from legislative leaders that a majority would support ratification.
The treaty is still quite likely to be opposed by Communist deputies. The Communist Party leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, in a televised interview tonight, reiterated his view that the treaty "in its current state is absolutely defective" and would destroy "Russia's most important nuclear missile umbrella" at a time when Russia lacks the budget resources to maintain a strategic missile force as large as that of the United States.
"They propose to destroy our missiles, while mass production of new ones has not started, and there is no money for it," Mr. Zyuganov said.
But another legislative leader, Vladimir Lukin, a member of the liberal Yabloko faction and a former ambassador to the United States, said he did not believe that the Communists would be able to muster more than 150 votes if they opposed ratification. "So it seems that a majority is being hammered together," Mr. Lukin said, adding that the chances for ratification were "rather high."
In one sense, the ratification of the seven-year-old treaty is the least contentious item on the arms control agenda. A more heated debate lies ahead in the Start III negotiations, where Moscow is seeking deeper cuts in strategic arsenals, in part because it can no longer afford a large array of strategic weapons, and where Washington is seeking Russian acceptance for American plans to build an antiballistic missile shield over the United States to protect it from "rogue states" and accidental launchings.
Those plans have incited deep concerns here and in China that the United States will ultimately destabilize the strategic balance by having both a shield against nuclear missiles and the most robust offensive nuclear forces.
Today, Moscow warned that it remains opposed to American plans to build a national missile defense system that would undermine the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972. Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov, meeting today with American executives and journalists, said, "The collapse of the 1972 ABM Treaty would cast the world into a new confrontation."
Adding that an American decision to scrap the treaty would undermine relations between Moscow and Washington, Mr. Ivanov said, "The climate in which our economic cooperation develops depends to a large extent on the long-term resolution of issues related to strategic stability."
The chairman of the Duma international affairs committee, Dimitri Rogozin, said ratifying Start II and its extensions that were agreed to in 1997 provided "an opportunity to keep the Americans from quitting the Antiballistic Missile Treaty."
Start II, negotiated in the last year of the Bush administration, commits the United States and Russia to reduce their nuclear arsenals, from 6,000 to 3,000 to 3,500 warheads each. One milestone of the accord is a ban on land-based missiles with multiple warheads. American negotiators have long sought to eliminate those systems, most notably the heavy SS-18 rockets with 10 warheads each. The missiles and warhead destruction was to have been carried out by 2003. But in the absence of ratification, the two sides agreed to deactivate the affected missiles by that date and destroy them by 2007.
President Boris N. Yeltsin failed to bring the treaty to a vote in 1996 and 1997. In late 1998, as the Communist-led Duma prepared to debate the accord, American and British air strikes on Iraq led to a delay. Washington's announcement last year that it would seek amendments to the ABM treaty also resulted in delay. In March 1999, Duma leaders said they would vote on the measure the next month. But that was delayed, too, when NATO moved against Serbia.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 501 words

HEADLINE: Breaking the Ice in Korea

 BODY:
The unexpected announcement yesterday that the leaders of North and South Korea plan to meet in June could lead to a lessening of tensions on the cold war's last military frontier. The talks between South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, and Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader, would be the first discussion between the leaders of the two Koreas since the peninsula was divided after World War II.
It is nearly 50 years since an armistice ended the Korean War. But a peace agreement has yet to be signed. Each side has stationed hundreds of thousands of troops on either side of a demilitarized zone filled with tank barriers and minefields. Some 37,000 American troops remain permanently based in South Korea to bolster Seoul's defenses should the North again attack. Meanwhile, North Korea's flirtation with nuclear weapons and long-range missiles compounds the dangers and the risk of renewed American military involvement. 
 Although the North's main motive in seeking this meeting seems to be its desire to take up Seoul's offers of humanitarian relief and economic assistance, the South is sure to bring up security issues as well. For years, North Korea tried to reach around South Korean leaders to strike a deal with the United States. Washington has wisely insisted that direct dialogue between North and South Korea must come first.
Since Kim Dae Jung was elected South Korea's president in 1997, he has courted new business, tourist and humanitarian ties with the North. His "sunshine policy" has tried to couple continued military vigilance with new openings aimed at encouraging more predictable, less dangerous relations across the 38th Parallel. The announcement of the June meetings, to take place in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, confirms the wisdom of Seoul's approach. It does so at a particularly helpful time for President Kim, just three days before important Congressional elections that will determine how much political authority he commands during the remaining three years of his term.
The North's agreement to these meetings seems to demonstrate that Kim Jong Il is now firmly in charge of North Korea and inclined to reach out diplomatically to the wider world. In recent weeks the once reclusive North has sought improved ties not just with Seoul but with various European countries, China, Japan and the United States. Though political developments inside North Korea remain largely opaque, this spurt of diplomatic activity must be considered encouraging.
North Korea is still dangerous and unpredictable. Its economy barely functions and there are fears that it could abruptly collapse, sending millions of refugees fleeing south and perhaps sparking clashes across the DMZ. Seoul should approach this meeting carefully. Previous efforts to bring together the top Northern and Southern leaders have fallen through. If the June meetings proceed as planned, however, they could start a belated but hopeful thaw in relations between the two Koreas.

HEADLINE: Starbucks Will Buy Beans at Premium

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, April 10

 BODY:
The Starbucks Corporation said today that it would buy more coffee beans from importers paying above-market prices to small farmers and would sell them in its more than 2,000 United States coffee shops and on its Web site.
The Seattle-based company will buy an unspecified amount of so-called fair trade beans from wholesale sellers that are certified by the nonprofit group TransFair USA to pay up to three times the 30 cents a pound farmers typically receive. 
 Starbucks will pay a minimum of $1.26 a pound, a price above the current world market rate but less than its average cost, to cooperatives that pay up to $1 a pound to farmers. The program will begin in Central America but may expand to other regions.
Global Exchange, a group that has repeatedly urged Starbucks to buy fair trade coffee and had planned protests at Starbucks coffee shops in 30 cities this week, praised the deal as a step toward ending exploitation of coffee growers.
"This is a gigantic first step toward establishing fair trade coffee as an economically viable alternative," said Jason Mark, a Global Exchange spokesman.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Internet Take overs Fuel a Big Surge in Acquisitions in Brazil

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 10

 BODY:
Fueled by a flurry of Internet takeovers, mergers and acquisitions in Brazil surged in the first quarter of this year.
Latin America's largest economy had 65 transactions involving the acquisition of controlling stakes in medium- to large-sized companies, or 23 percent more than in the first three months of last year, according to figures compiled by the Brazilian unit of KPMG, the consulting firm. 
 A healthier economy provided the backdrop to the increase in takeover activity, since Brazil was struggling to recover from a debilitating currency devaluation in the same period last year. But there is no doubt that a frenzy of deal making in the country's vibrant Internet industry contributed to the growth of mergers and takeovers.
Fourteen of the transactions involved Internet companies, up from three in the first quarter of 1999. Among the foreign firms involved in this buying spree were PSINet Corporation, which acquired two Internet service providers, and Portugal Telecom, which bought Zip.net, a portal company, for $365 million.
"There's still a nationalist tendency in Brazil to view transnational takeovers skeptically," said Marcos Moraes, the founder of Zip.net, who still sits on its board. "I hope this nearsightedness will not keep us from trying to bridge the gap between Brazil and developed countries through the Internet."
Brazil's Internet industry continues to undergo a rapid consolidation process, imitating, in a way, the Internet industries of the United States and other rich nations. Other Brazilian industries contributed to the increase in takeovers as well, driven in part by a perception that bigger companies are more powerful.
Analysts have pointed to Brazil's largest-ever corporate takeover, Companhia Cervejaria Brahma's $7 billion acquisition of Companhia Antarctica Paulista, recently approved by antitrust officials, as a signal of things to come.
"Scale matters, period," said Carlos Novis Guimaraes , the head of Latin American investment banking at Lehman Brothers. "The Brahma-Antarctica deal could be played out in sectors that are still quite fragmented, like banking and insurance."
One closely watched deal will be the privatization this year of Banco do Estado de Sao Paulo S.A., or Banespa, which has extensive consumer banking operations in southeastern Brazil. Among the candidates to buy Banespa is Citigroup, as well as Brazil's largest banks.
Another big transaction will be the federal government's privatization of its reinsurance monopoly, I.R.B.-Brasil Resseguros S.A.
Still, concern has emerged over the effect that wide swings in the Nasdaq and other United States markets may have on mergers and acquisitions in Brazil. Today, the Bovespa index for the Sao Paulo stock exchange fell 4.2 percent, led lower by technology issues.

HEADLINE: Mood-Dimming Question in Seoul

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, April 10

 BODY:
An unusual catalog of emotions shock, relief, wariness -- were on display today as South Koreans learned that their president would go to North Korea in June for their country's first summit meeting with the leader of the Communist North.
One reaction, nearly universal, was shock that a meeting that few had imagined possible had been successfully negotiated in secret. In almost every case, the surprise was followed with a happy sense of relief that the cold war might finally be ending in one of its final redoubts. 
 Then came the practical question, asked by almost all: What will it cost us?
Such a mood-dampening question, on an occasion seemingly fit for celebration, was an expression of the extraordinary circumstances of a diplomatic breakthrough whose basis has still not been publicly explained. Why, after years of snubbing South Korea as an insignificant puppet of the United States, has the North Korean government chosen the eve of crucial national elections in the south to offer that country its most precious diplomatic plum?
"We are all waiting for the details of what we must give them and what we can expect from North Korea," said Yeon Ha Cheong, an expert in relations with that country and dean of the school of marketing at Myongai University in Seoul. "North Korea will certainly demand lots of things."
After announcing the breakthrough today, the South Korean government compounded the mystery by retreating into a shell, providing almost no information about the secret negotiations that led to the agreement with the North. The government did say that the task of fixing an agenda for the talks would be left to diplomats.
That left many South Korean experts on North Korean diplomatic behavior wondering aloud who was playing whom. To hear them speak, either the South Korean government is cynically manipulating the issue of national unification for vote-getting purposes or the leadership is being had by a Pyongyang government that senses its desperatation for a pre-election breakthrough.
In practical terms the legislative vote here on Thursday will determine how much power the South Korean president, Kim Dae Jung, wields for his remaining three years in office. And in addition to finally rewarding Mr. Kim for the steep political risks he has taken in reaching out to the north, several analysts here said the North Koreans most likely calculated that the eve of the vote was the moment to strike a diplomatic deal at the best price.
"This kind of meeting cannot come all of the sudden, out of nowhere," said Cho Dong Ho, head of North Korean economic studies at the Korea Development Institute, a private nonprofit group. "No one knows in detail, but the basic agenda must be a longer-term framework of political contacts between us and, of course, economic cooperation."
Although North Korea is widely believed to be past the worst of its catastrophic economic difficulties of the last decade, during which 200,000 people or more died of starvation, the country is still afflicted with debilitating power shortages.
One potential reward widely mentioned today as a possible recompense for giving President Kim such a diplomatic vindication on the eve of elections was a reconnection of the power grids between the two countries, enabling the booming South to furnish desperately needed electricity.
Speculation about quid pro quos has been magnified by observation of North Korea's recent diplomatic behavior. For years, since the end of the cold war and the loss of most of its Communist allies, the country's government bore the title of the world's most isolated.
But North Korea has recently emerged as one of the most diplomatically active countries, as it has rushed to establish ties with a wide range of countries. In most instances formal ties, or even serious diplomatic contacts, have come with a steep price tag.
Persistent reports have circulated in recent weeks that Pyongyang, since agreeing to resume official talks with Japan, has sought $5 billion in "reparations" from that country for Tokyo's brutal colonial past in Korea.
The United States, too, has often been put in a position where it has had to commit itself to helping ease North Korea's economic catastrophe -- through major food or fuel deliveries -- in exchange for Pyongyang's cooperation in suspending its nuclear weapons development or in halting the testing of its long-range missiles.
Mr. Kim's political rivals, feeling threatened by a dramatic diplomatic turnabout after weeks of campaigning against his "sunshine policy" toward the North as a fruitless sellout, today clung to the line that the coming summit meeting, with its hidden and presumably high costs, was no victory.
"The government must have paid a huge price, or agreed to some secret conditions to reach this deal, but that side has not been revealed," said Jan Kwang Keun, a spokesman for the Grand National Party, the main opposition group. "We want to remind people that such compensations involve taxpayers' money."
The public's reaction was more positive, but often came laden with complex sentiments and anxieties that are the legacy of a shared history of awful wartime violence, yield-no-quarter ideological jousting and harshly contrasting economic fates.
"Do you really think these countries will unify anytime soon?" asked Han Kyoung Ok, a 51-year-old woman who was preparing to board a train to Pusan at midday. "For people of my generation this is good news. But younger people have grown soft in this country, and now I fear that the northerners, who have lived through so much will out-compete us."
In part, her comments reflected the fact that in the span of her life -- roughly the period since June 1950, when the Korean War broke out -- Ms. Han has witnessed an extraordinary turnabout in the fortunes of the two countries.
For the first half of their separate histories after World War II, the Communist North, although more sparsely peopled, was by far the more prosperous of the two countries. But since the 1970's, and accelerating each year, South Korea has outstripped its neighbor, becoming one of the world's most energetic and entrepreneurial societies, while the Stalinist North, though still heavily armed, has flirted with economic collapse.
"I don't support unification, because things are nice the way they are now," said Hwang Ji Hwa, a 21-year-old woman, who spoke in downtown Seoul. "There are just too many differences between our countries. If we try to unify, things might get out of hand."

HEADLINE: Detroit Sees Park as Star Player in Redevelopment

BYLINE: By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 10

 BODY:
Few major cities have talked more about or waited longer for a visible symbol of resurrection than this one, the nation's poorest.
Some of the patience will be rewarded on Tuesday with the inaugural game at Comerica Park, the new $300 million home of the Detroit Tigers baseball team and the showpiece of a burgeoning entertainment district in downtown Detroit. The stadium was built with city, county, state and private money, and was named for its corporate sponsor, Comerica Bank in Detroit. 
 City leaders are convinced that the ornate open-air stadium, with its synchronized fountains and 50-foot-high Ferris wheel, will pull investment, not to mention thousands of visitors, back downtown, just as Jacobs Field and Camden Yards transformed Cleveland and Baltimore.
Tigers officials are quietly picking out spots to display a World Series banner, should the Tigers bring home the championship, a feat this 99-year-old franchise has not accomplished since 1984. And the way the team is limping along, 1-5, fans will probably wait a while longer.
"We've endured a lot of rhetoric over the years," said Denise Illitch, daughter of the Tigers owner, Mike Illitch. "But this ballpark is real; it's proof things are changing."
Ms. Illitch is president of Olympia Development, which is handling projects surrounding Comerica Park. The Illitch family also owns the Detroit Red Wings hockey team, which plays at Joe Louis Arena on the city's waterfront.
Change is whirling all around the ballpark. Later this week, construction will begin on an $800 million office complex several blocks south that will become the headquarters of the Compuware Corporation, which makes software for managing corporate networks. The company is moving from Farmington Hills, Mich.
Just east of the stadium, construction crews are excavating the site of Ford Field, a brick-and-glass stadium with a dome, also costing about $300 million, that will sit alongside Comerica Park and bring the Detroit Lions football team back to the city for the first time in 26 years. The Lions, who now play in Pontiac, plan to open Ford Field in 2002.
Some of the three million people expected to visit Comerica Park this season will not be coming from the suburbs, as in the past. They'll walk. Forty-seven townhouses, with price tags of $140,000 to $250,000 are being built across the street, on land that for years had been used by prostitutes and drug users.
Signs advertising loft space pop up daily in the windows of deserted office buildings nearby.
But most surprising is the nightlife that has crept back, now that two of the three voter-approved casinos have opened temporary sites on the fringe of downtown. On most evenings the parking lots at the MGM Grand and the Motorcity Casino resemble those of suburban shopping malls. Eventually, the casinos will build near the waterfront.
Of course, no one here, not even the ever-jubilant Mayor Dennis Archer, is ready to proclaim Detroit completely reborn.
"We're still not where we want to be," Mr. Archer said recently.
Huge swaths of the city are dominated by weed-choked lots and abandoned houses. Some basic services like street lighting and bus service are still unreliable. That is why many Detroit residents say they are reluctant to believe that the city's renaissance will ever extend beyond downtown.
"It's absurd that we're spending hundreds of millions of dollars on a new ballpark when we can't keep our libraries open regular hours and our kids don't even have safe playgrounds," said Frank Rashid, a lifelong resident and founder of the Tiger Stadium Fan Club, which pleaded with city officials to revitalize Tiger Stadium. The famed ballpark sits empty about a mile from Comerica Park.
"This city is fixated on shortcuts to revitalization," Mr. Rashid said, relying on huge projects " that do nothing but deliver false promises."
Urban planning and economic experts agree.
"There really is no evidence that building a new sports stadium resurrects a downtown or a city," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College. "In cities that are investing in several downtown projects all at once, there is additional activity, but it's mostly from the transfer of income and employment from surrounding communities into the downtown area. You rarely see a great spread effect."
Still, the mayor contended that Comerica Park was crucial to Detroit's comeback, if for no other reason than as an morale boost.
"Comerica Park will help restore the excitement of urban living that has been missing far too long from downtown Detroit," Mr. Archer said.
To be sure, Comerica Park was designed to dazzle. Life-size stone tigers and baseball bats guard the entrances. Inside the ballpark, children can ride a Ferris wheel with seats shaped like baseballs or a carousel featuring 30 handpainted tigers. The low-rise outfield stands are expected to be another attraction, with their postcard view of the city's skyline. Along the wall in left-center field are huge stainless steel statues of Hall of Fame players like Hank Greenberg, Ty Cobb and Charlie Gehringer. And the 10-story-tall scoreboard is the largest in baseball, the Tiger organization said.
As it is with most things, Comerica Park's grandeur comes at a price. Now that the team offers luxury seats, the price of an average home game ticket has doubled to $24.83, the fourth highest in baseball, according to Team Marketing Report.
But even that has done little to spoil this city's excitement.
"Detroit has lost so much and had to wait so long for something to be proud of," said 63-year-old Bernard Battistelli, a longtime Tiger fan, who typically attends 10 to 15 home games a year. "I'd rather pay a little extra than sit around another 10 years waiting for a rebirth."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Microsoft Hires Lobbyist To Curry Favor With Bush
Microsoft has hired Ralph Reed, a senior consultant to Gov. George W. Bush's presidential campaign and a former head of the Christian Coalition, to lobby Mr. Bush in opposition to the government's antitrust case against the software giant.
 Microsoft's aim, the company says, is to curry favor with the apparent Republican presidential nominee, hoping he will speak out against the government's case -- and, perhaps, take a softer approach toward the company if he is elected president. Page A1. 

Motorola Posts Strong Earnings
Motorola, the telecommunications and semiconductor giant, reported another quarter of strong sales and profit growth, which could provide a lift to flagging technology stocks. Profit more than doubled, to $449 million, compared with $184 million in the quarter a year earlier. The results beat Wall Street forecasts by a penny a share. Before the results were announced, shares of Motorola fell $3, to $150, but climbed as high as $157 after hours. C2.
 
Wells Fargo to Buy First Security
Wells Fargo agreed to buy First Security for $2.9 billion in stock, less than two weeks after the collapse of First Security's planned merger with Zions Bancorporation. The deal will enable Wells Fargo to build its presence in Utah, where First Security is based. C7.
 
Mergers Increase 23% in Brazil
Fueled by a flurry of Internet takeovers, mergers and acquisitions in Brazil surged in the first quarter. The nation, Latin America's largest economy, had 65 transactions involving the acquisition of controlling stakes in medium to large companies, 23 percent more than in the first three months of last year. C4.
 
Fed Testing Alternatives to Checks
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said that the central bank was moving to modernize its check-processing system and was testing new technologies but acknowledged that many Americans are still clinging to paper checks. C7.
 
Tokyo Urged to Redraw Bank Laws
In Japan, Hideyuki Aizawa, who heads the ruling party's Financial Issues Research Committee, is urging financial regulators to reconsider plans to issue banking licenses to nonbank companies like Sony, saying the banking laws first need to be redrawn. C4.
 
Privatization of Power Company Set
Legislators in the Philippines are set to vote this week on a bill that would privatize the heavily indebted national power company, a reform that the International Monetary Fund and other lenders have demanded before disbursing critical new loans. The House of Representatives is scheduled to begin voting today on the Power Reform Bill. President Joseph Estrada, above, and Manuel B. Villar, the House leader, both support the measure. C4.
 
Web Site Removes Microsoft Report
The Wall Street Journal's Web site posted and then removed a report that Microsoft might be forced to make the programming code for its Internet Explorer Web browser available to customers and computer makers. C8.
 
OPEC May Cut Back on Production
Less than two weeks after OPEC agreed to increase production to bring down the cost of oil, prices have fallen abruptly and are near the level at which the cartel had agreed it would then cut back its output. C12.
 
Profit Increases 19% at Gannett
Gannett, the publisher of USA Today an 73 other daily papers, said that first-quarter profit rose 19 percent because of increased advertising sales and lower newsprint prices. C10.
 
Approval Urged for Rival of Viagra
Uprima, made by TAP Pharmaceuticals, may soon be cutting into Viagra's impotence-drug market after government advisers recommended that the tablet be approved for sale to the public despite some side effects. A20.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Doing Lunch to Reinforce His Support Among Women

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began a series of statewide "Women for Rudy" lunches yesterday to reinforce his support among Republican female voters, a group that has largely remained loyal as polls show that the mayor's reaction to the shooting of Patrick M. Dorismond has caused a drop in his support among men.
At the first lunch, at the Women's National Republican Club in Manhattan yesterday, Mr. Giuliani received a hero's welcome from 250 guests, many of whom said that Mr. Giuliani's fight against crime had made them feel safer and that his economic policies had made them prosper. 
 But as he has in the past before similar groups, the mayor did not specifically mention women's issues. Instead, he delivered his standard speech about what he considers the Giuliani renaissance of New York City, and only occasionally alluded to his Senate opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton.
"Everybody that used to run the city," Mr. Giuliani said to murmurs of approval, "and used to run the city with the high crime rates and the big welfare rates, and used to run the city when it was called ungovernable, all of those people support my opponent, right? Every single one of them! They used to run the city, they support my opponent. What does that tell you about ideas, ideologies, issues?
"Now, we've done something different. We've changed it. Lots of people don't like that. Lots of people are embarrassed by it. I'm proud of it."
At a news briefing afterward at City Hall, Mr. Giuliani said that he had deliberately avoided speaking specifically about women. "I don't consider women voters different than men voters," he said. "They're the same to me."
He added that "white voters and black voters are the same."
"Catholic, Jewish, Protestant, Russian Orthodox, outside of Russia, Muslim voters," he said, "they're all the same to me." His approach, he said, had helped move the city away from its emphasis on "vast and intricate subcultures."
In a clear reference to Mrs. Clinton, he added that women support him because "they don't feel that I have some kind of pandering group of views that say, 'Oh, gee, you know in front of a white audience I'm going to say one thing, in front of a black audience I'm going to say another thing, in front of a women's audience I'm going to say a third thing.' "
Mrs. Clinton, who leads the mayor 49 percent to 41 percent in a New York Times/CBS News poll of 1,573 respondents conducted this month, also leads among women over all, 52 percent to 38 percent. Her support among women is statistically unchanged from a similar Times/CBS News poll conducted in February, before the police shooting of Mr. Dorismond, when Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Giuliani among women voters, 50 percent to 38 percent.
But the poll showed that Mr. Giuliani's support among men had dropped in the same time period. In February, Mr. Giuliani led Mrs. Clinton among men over all, 54 percent to 37 percent. By April, it was Mrs. Clinton who was leading among men, 46 percent to 43 percent.
The poll showed that one of the mayor's biggest declines in support was among independent men, who supported him, 62 percent to 26 percent, over Mrs. Clinton in February. By April, they were supporting him by 47 percent to 32 percent, a net drop of 15 points.
At yesterday's lunch at the Women's National Republican Club, a number of guests characterized Mr. Giuliani's attacks on Mr. Dorismond as merely impolitic.
"Perhaps his choice of words wasn't clear," said Jennifer Duncan, 31, of Rocky Point, on Long Island, who works as a hotel catering manager in Manhattan. "Just listen to him. He's an intelligent man. He certainly wouldn't want an innocent gentleman killed."
Others said the mayor's record on crime was his most attractive attribute. "I was mugged when I first came to Manhattan, and it's a much safer city because of him," said Carol Nobbs, 53, a New York City real estate broker.
Mr. Giuliani's criticism of Mr. Dorismond, she said, did not bother her. "He was defending himself," she said of the mayor.
Tomorrow, Mr. Giuliani is to attend a "Women for Rudy" lunch in Rochester and then what his advisers are calling a "women's town hall meeting" in Buffalo. On Thursday, Mr. Giuliani is to attend a "Women for Rudy" lunch in Mineola.

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Pledge Funds For Projects Along Hudson

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: WEST POINT, N.Y., April 10

 BODY:
In an effort to revive ailing towns and preserve farms along the Hudson River, federal housing and agriculture officials said today that they would focus more than $50 million in loans and grants over the next two years on projects that spur the region's economy while improving its environment.
In contrast to most federal offers of money for development aimed at solving a local problem, the effort would give preference to projects whose impact spans several municipalities or counties, said Andrew M. Cuomo, the housing secretary, at a meeting of about 150 officials and business owners from the area. 
 The goal, he said, is to use the competition for aid to spur cooperative planning in a state where local governments usually act independently -- and often at cross purposes. "If you want to win, you must come up with a regional plan which gets outside of your boundaries," he said.
Mr. Cuomo said he hoped the valley would follow the path already taken by several other parts of the country that have shifted to a regional strategy for economic growth, including western Kentucky and the Research Triangle Park area of North Carolina.
The Hudson River project is modeled on a similar 1997 effort for communities along the Erie Canal that used federal money to encourage tourism and new businesses, Mr. Cuomo said.
He cited a 1999 Cornell University study that showed that the Canal Corridor Initiative, as the previous effort was called, had so far funneled $400 million in federal loans and grants to communities along the 524-mile waterway, while generating an equal amount of private investment and creating twice as many jobs as had been initially predicted.
As they outlined the Hudson Valley plan, Mr. Cuomo and Dan Glickman, agriculture secretary, were flanked by New York congressmen of both political parties, including Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, a Republican whose district stretches from the suburbs of Westchester to the Borscht Belt in the Catskills.
Mr. Gilman predicted that communities around the valley would find ways to take advantage of the program.
Mr. Cuomo cited recent surveys of New York's economy showing that most of the Hudson Valley has not shared in the protracted economic boom.
For example, he said, federal surveys of wages showed that from 1990 to 1997, while the average weekly wage in the state rose 9 percent to $467 from $424, the average weekly paycheck for the rest of the Hudson Valley fell 1 percent, to $355 from $361.
The project outlined today included a variety of grants and loans aimed at both urban renewal and rural preservation around the region.
Up to $20 million in grants from the housing agency will be doled out over the next two years for proposals that foster regional planning, Mr. Cuomo said. The deadline for proposals is May 24, he said.
Housing officials said recent examples of federally-supported local projects that have had a broadly beneficial impact were a park, museum and marinas along the Erie Canal, which created a network of stopping points for boaters, and an existing proposal for a ferry linking Ossining and Haverstraw, which sit on opposite sides of the lower Hudson River.
The grants can be sought by communities across the country, Mr. Cuomo said, but he added that the Hudson Valley was one of only a few areas where several municipalities could easily create a suitable project with shared benefits.
He cited a recent economic partnership between Kingston and Newburgh, two Hudson River cities that faced high unemployment and loss of industry, as an example of the kind of collaboration the agency was seeking to support.
In a separate but coordinated effort, the agriculture department is offering $30 million over the next two years to projects up and down the valley that help sustain the farming economy, Mr. Glickman said.
In addition, the housing agency is offering loans for business development that could bring the total targeted support for the region to $80 million, Mr. Cuomo said.
