HEADLINE: Harassment Suits Hit the Dot-Coms

BYLINE: By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
The dot-com workplace is a magnet for young Americans, with its promise of adventure, riches and a casual work environment.
Now, though, the environment may be getting too casual. Managers at some Internet companies are rethinking their corporate cultures as a smattering of sexual harassment lawsuits begins to roll into their high-technology world. Some legal experts think these cases might be the beginning of a wave. 
 "The Internet start-up community is going to be a major target for sexual harassment litigation," said Gregory I. Rasin, a senior partner at the Manhattan office of Jackson Lewis Schnitzler & Krupman, an employment law firm that has several dot-com clients.
By nature, these companies are at legal risk because the entrepreneurs who start them are often eager to create the ultimate anticorporate environment, says Corey Sprague, director of human resources at the RiskMetrics Group, an Internet start-up on Wall Street. "I get a lot of calls from people who are setting up dot-com companies and want to create a no-holds-barred, wild culture, free of rules and policies," said Ms. Sprague, whose company is one of the few start-ups that hired human-resources personnel from the beginning. As a result, she says, most are not eager to create policies and training programs that address traditional human resources concerns.
Even managers who are sensitive to issues like sexual harassment are so focused on raising capital and expanding their businesses that they neglect to create a human resources department to address them, says John Iorillo, co-founder of the Ambrose Employer Group, a provider of human resources services in New York that has more than 120 dot-com clients. "For the first few years, most start-ups are just in survival mode," he said.
That was the case at Pseudo Programs, a Manhattan-based Internet TV network that was sued in January by a former employee who says the company had a hostile work environment for women. In her complaint, the employee, Kelly Alfieri, said male employees at Pseudo frequently referred to female employees as "bimbos" and forced them to look at sexually explicit material on the Internet.
Pseudo's male employees "were allowed to do whatever they wanted," said David Jaroslawicz, Ms. Alfieri's lawyer. "It was like they were living in the Wild West, and the sheriff was out of town."
Jeanne Meyer, senior vice president for marketing at Pseudo, said Ms. Alfieri's accusations were "completely without merit." The company acknowledges that it created a human resources department only after Ms. Alfieri quit Pseudo two years ago. "As with most start-ups, our senior management did everything in the beginning, from putting toilet paper in the bathrooms to payroll," Ms. Meyer said. But now, she said, its new department "continually reinforces the company's sexual-harassment policies."
Compounding the lack of formal policies and training at many start-ups is a culture of long hours and close quarters. "People are working 80 or 100 hours per week, so the only social contact they're having is in the context of the workplace," said Daniel Weisberg, an employment-law specialist at Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison, a Manhattan-based law firm. As a result, he says, inner-office dating is rampant, and relationships that go sour have the potential to turn into sexual harassment complaints.
In one highly publicized example, Juno Online Services, a Internet company based in Midtown Manhattan, was sued last fall by two former female employees who said they had been told they would lose their jobs if they broke off their relationships with senior executives they were dating. Juno's lawyer, Terri Ross, says the company denies the accusations in both lawsuits. One lawsuit has since been referred to arbitration by a New York state court, and Juno has applied to send the second complaint to arbitration.
Another common theme in cases he handles, Mr. Weisberg said, is that "the one who was spurned gets terminated or doesn't get the promotion they thought they should get and decides to sue."
Because Internet start-ups are often small, with many staff members working in the same space, other employees are often unwitting witnesses to office liaisons, according to Garry G. Mathiason, a partner at Littler Mendelson, a San Francisco employment-law firm that represents more than 1,000 dot-coms throughout the country.
Mr. Mathiason offers the example of a company he represents where an employee recently complained that she had walked in on two co-workers having sex on the office floor. The woman was so offended, he says, that she immediately quit her job and is threatening to bring a claim against the company.
While such reports of sexual harassment seem fairly blatant, the majority of sexual harassment complaints at dot-coms are more subtle, according to Mr. Weisberg. "The most common problem we hear about are employees who are offended by all the sexually explicit e-mail jokes that bounce around these offices," he said.
Mr. Mathiason recently received a complaint from an employee who said she had received an e-mail, later traced to a co-worker, that read, "I see you're wearing black today. You're a very bad girl," and directed her to an X-rated Web site. At another dot-com, Mr. Mathiason said, female employees complained that their male colleagues were continuously logging onto a Web site featuring co-eds taking showers.
"These kinds of activities seem to predominate in the dot-com world," Mr. Mathiason said. "A lot of these guys haven't been out of school for very long, and they're still experimenting with this kind of juvenile stuff."
Not all managers turn a blind eye to such antics, of course. Mr. Weisberg said his office had fielded several calls from dot-coms looking to provide sexual harassment training to managers. His office recently assisted two larger Manhattan-based Internet companies, DoubleClick Inc. and About.com, in setting up anti-discrimination training programs. "We're definitely seeing more companies take a pro-active stance," Mr. Weisberg said.
Another start-up, Boutique Y3K, recently appointed a human-resources manager to oversee its 12 employees. "We intend to take issues of harassment and discrimination seriously," said Lisa Tisdale, the new manager.
Those that do not take such issues seriously are looking for trouble, Mr. Mathiason says. "Right now, you're not seeing as much litigation as you might expect" in the dot-com world, he said. That is partly because the economy is so robust that would-be plaintiffs are "getting six job offers on the way to their lawyers' offices," Mr. Mathiason said.
But the minute the economy slows, he warned, disgruntled employees will have fewer opportunities to move on and will be more likely to go after their deep-pocketed former employers. "It will be like an earthquake hit," he said.

HEADLINE: THE BOSS;
Call Him Lucky. Or Elvis.

BYLINE: By Neil M. Cornelius Jr.; Written with Deidre Leipziger 

 BODY:
It's important to get opportunities, to see them and to take them. It's also important to see that other people get opportunities, too.
I didn't grow up with a silver spoon by any stretch. My dad, an auto mechanic, was from the Oneida Indian Nation, and my mother, who was a teaching assistant in a local school, was from the Stockbridge-Munsee Band of Mohican Indians, and they kind of raised us in the middle, in Shawano, Wis. The town was predominantly white, with Native American all around. I've always felt comfortable in both worlds. 
 I have eight siblings. My older sister Carol and I are the only ones of the kids who went to college and graduate school. She's a college professor. I don't know why we accomplished what we did, but we somehow got the message that we needed to do something to get out of the environment unless we wanted to repeat the environment.
I got lucky when I was 14 or so -- I got invited to join Upward Bound, a government program for poor kids with some potential. I got to be with other kids like myself. I got to see some successful people, and I got some coaching. It got me to college. The Rev. Jerry Thompson, who headed the program, is one of the biggest influences in my life. He was a cheerleader and a spiritual leader and a father figure. He particularly liked beating us at racquetball.
After college, I went to work for I.B.M., where my sister Carol was working. She got me the job -- no, she got me the interview; I got me the job, stocking computer parts. The big thing for me was to work for I.B.M.; I didn't care what job. I soon got the opportunity to get a job as a computer repairman in Milwaukee. I didn't have any experience, but I somehow got tabbed as a guy who could succeed. Eventually, I got into management.
I.B.M. was great to me, and I was great to I.B.M. It was a great marriage. But in my 20th year there, I realized I wasn't going to be chairman. I decided to seek out more opportunity, and I wanted to come back and work with my people. The timing was right, too: I.B.M. was downsizing, and they offered a silver parachute, so to speak. I had a few dollars in my pocket and I was unemployed, so I went back to school and got my master's degree.
I was living in Boulder, Colo., and took a summer driving trip with my son, seeing baseball games along the way. In Wisconsin, we came to see family, too. One thing led to another, and soon I got a job with the Oneida tribe as director of the enterprise division.
Indian gaming came to town in the early 1980's, and things had changed dramatically. For the better? Yes and no. It has enabled many things for some tribes that didn't have anything -- schools, infrastructure, housing, jobs. But many smaller tribes now have a new kind of welfare: wealth without having to work. It's worse than poverty without work.
For my new job at the Treasure Island casino, which is owned by the Prairie Island Indian Community, I live at the casino hotel in Red Wing, Minn., during the week. I very much look forward to going home to Green Bay on Friday. My family saves all my chores, of course, but I'm a big Packers fan and if there's a game I get to go.
It's tough being away, but my job is extremely fulfilling. One of the most fun times I ever had was about two years ago, when I was the gaming general manager at Oneida. I did a sky dive with the Flying Elvi -- those entertainers in Elvis costumes. I didn't get a costume, but I did get pictures.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 4; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1706 words

HEADLINE: Need a Chef? Have Your People Call My People

BYLINE: By AMANDA HESSER 

 BODY:
IN five years in New York, Richard Farnabe built up a stellar resume. He started as a cook at Daniel, moved to Jean Georges and eventually was promoted to executive chef at Mercer Kitchen. Last year, he was hired away to cook at the Myriad Group's Berkeley Bar and Grill. Shortly afterward, Tommy Hilfiger's secretary came in to ask if he would like to cook for her boss.
At the same time, he was approached by David Rabin, who was opening a restaurant and needed a chef. Mr. Rabin also had a headhunter seeking prospects. 
 Mr. Farnabe came out on top. He took both jobs, cooking during the day at Mr. Hilfiger's offices and at night at Mr. Rabin's Lotus, opening next month. He had made himself marketable and played his cards right, just like any young lawyer or investment banker trying to get ahead.
Mr. Farnabe's path represents just what has happened in the restaurant world in recent years. Chefs have gone from being essentially blue-collar workers to true professionals, as much in demand as athletes. Top players, like Daniel Boulud, Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Alice Waters, have become brand names, and their proteges, like Mr. Farnabe, use those brands as springboards.
The vibrant economy has only accelerated the shift, with restaurants opening seemingly by the second -- more than 250 restaurants opened last year in New York City, according to the Zagat Survey -- and with an American public that has more money and the ambition to eat well. Cooks who have polished resumes are more in demand than ever.
As a result, they are being lured away from these brand name restaurants to cook in private homes, where the work is less grueling and they can command higher salaries. At the same time, competition among restaurants to find and keep good cooks is intensifying.
"This is probably the most difficult labor market in any restaurateur's memory," said Dennis Lombardi, an analyst at Technomic Inc., a Chicago-based food-service consulting company. "We used to have an ample supply of skilled and motivated employees. Now, we don't."
Getting chefs' jobs used to be an informal process, driven largely by word of mouth. But now it is like any other highly evolved profession: there are headhunters and agents to help.
"Some of them say I'm their secret weapon," said Alfred Ehrlich, the owner of the Kitchen Maestro, an executive-chef search and consulting concern in New York City, speaking of restaurants. "And they don't want others to know about me." Mr. Ehrlich recently helped Patricia Yeo, the former chef de cuisine at Hawthorne Lane in San Francisco, become the chef at AZ, a restaurant opening in Chelsea next month.
Mr. Ehrlich, who was once a cook at La Reserve and worked in the wholesale division of Gourmet Garage, is well connected in the restaurant business. About a year and a half ago, after helping a number of chefs and restaurateurs find cooks as a favor, he decided to make a business of it. Some restaurants hire him for a single deal, paying him a percentage of the chef's first-year salary. But others, who want protection in the transient restaurant world, put him on a retainer, so that if the chef he finds leaves, he can search for a replacement. For Jack's Fifth, for instance, he found Herb Wilson to fill the chef's position. But Mr. Wilson stayed for just a few months. Mr. Ehrlich may soon have to find someone new.
"There's obviously a need," he said. "Every day I get faxes from people -- wish lists -- from chefs." Both restaurants and chefs come to him.
He is the reason Sam Hazen became the chef at Rue 57. Mr. Ehrlich heard that Mr. Hazen had left Tavern on the Green, and he knew that Marc Packer, a restaurateur opening Rue 57, was looking for a chef. He made the match for Mr. Packer.
Often, headhunting means poaching cooks from restaurants and trading them like athletes. Phillip Alfus, an owner of the Alfus Group, a Manhattan-based search firm, has found chefs for Tavern on the Green and the Russian Tea Room. He won't steal from friends like Daniel Boulud and Charlie Trotter, but "outside of that group," he said, "everybody is fair game to me."
Sherry Yard, the pastry chef at Spago Beverly Hills, has had headhunters take pastry chefs away from her. One went to the Ritz-Carlton on Maui, another to Patina in Los Angeles. Laurent Manrique, the chef at Campton Place in San Francisco, recently had a cook lured away.
An oral agreement is the traditional way to retain staff. Restaurants like Union Square Cafe and Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., offer cooks benefits that are standard in other professions: medical insurance, for example, and paid vacations.
But they can't always offer what wealthy families hiring private chefs can. Gilbert Pilgram, the chef at Chez Panisse, had three of his line cooks leave last year, hired away by families.
"I can't say I wasn't frustrated when it happened," Mr. Pilgram said. "Chez has an appeal. And people with money wanted to hire senior cooks to be their private chefs."
Jennifer Sherman was one of them. She had cooked at Chez Panisse for seven years, working nine-hour days producing about 100 meals, when she left to work for a family. Now, she works about seven hours a day, cooking just dinner. The family she works for is well traveled and knowledgeable about food -- and is familiar with Chez Panisse and its bragging power. "They definitely get some mileage out of that, for sure," Ms. Sherman said.
Anne Dickey was another. She works for a family in the Bay Area. She gets to shop at the farmers' market, cooks just four days a week, makes twice as much money and, she said, finally has the energy to think about other things. "Restaurants can really suck the life out of you," she said.
Ms. Sherman and a third Chez Panisse cook found their jobs through Cindy Race and her partner, Susan Flynn, who three years ago started Four Star Private Chefs, a placement agency in San Francisco.
Ms. Race became a private chef herself five years ago, after 17 years in restaurants. It changed her life, she said. "I was finally able to drive a car from this decade."
Most private chefs interviewed for this article said they were earning at least twice what they made in restaurants and were working about a third fewer hours. In New York City, salaries for full-time private chefs hired through agencies start at about $55,000 a year, said Keith Greenhouse, an owner of the Pavillion Agency in Manhattan. They can go up to as much as $130,000. Salaries are comparable in Los Angeles, but lower in San Francisco, starting at around $45,000 for dinner only, Ms. Race said.
In 1998, the mean hourly wage for a restaurant cook in New York City, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, was $11 an hour, or $22,880 a year. And many cooks have hefty cooking school loans to repay.
The math is not difficult to do.
With the influx of new money in places like New York City and Silicon Valley, demand is booming. Steve Kelley, director of career services at Peter Kump's New York Cooking School, said he gets calls for private chefs all the time, most recently from young couples with children. He has placed about a dozen chefs in the last six months, including one with David Letterman.
Cindy Race also has a busy phone line. "And I have an unlisted phone number and I'm not in the Yellow Pages," she said. Many of her clients are couples in their 30's and 40's, looking for full- or part-time cooks.
"It's becoming a big status symbol," said Christian Paier, the owner of Private Chefs Inc., an agency in Beverly Hills. "It's like having a personal trainer. Now, anyone who can afford it wants to have their own chef."
Few of these families want just any chef. They want names -- brands, if you will -- that they can rely on. Ms. Race had a client who wanted a cook who had worked for Nobu. Mr. Greenhouse had one who wanted a cook from Bouley. Both found them.
Clients are getting younger and younger, said Jo Lynne Lockley, the owner of the Chefs' Professional Agency in San Francisco; many are in their early 30's. And they want young chefs. "These people hiring someone who had been an executive chef would seem like hiring their grandfather," she said. What they are getting is talent in the rough.
When Steve Kelley of Peter Kump's placed a cook with a family in Southampton, N.Y., the cook was offered jobs by two guests. Now, he cooks for the three families.
These part-time arrangements, agencies say, are becoming increasingly popular. Which is no surprise: it is much less expensive than eating in a restaurant, which in places like New York can easily cost $30 a person. For $200 to $250 a week, said Robin Kellner, the owner of the Robin Kellner Agency, a family can have three dinners prepared by an experienced cook.
James Rafferty left a position as the chef at Boughalem in Greenwich Village to become a private chef for a magazine publisher in New York City. Having Bouley on his resume, he thinks, helped him get the job.
He cooks lunch and dinner for the publisher five days a week and travels with him occasionally. When he goes skiing out west, Mr. Rafferty goes, too. And he snowboards in between meals. The stress at his new job, he said, is a fraction of what it was at Boughalem. He used to work 12-hour days, finishing at midnight, and was plagued with staff problems and tight costs. Now, he works seven-hour days, can experiment with different styles of cooking and has an unlimited food budget. He also gets to have dinner with his wife.
He got the job through Mr. Greenhouse at Pavillion. A few years ago, Mr. Greenhouse also arranged a job for Franklin Becker as a private chef for Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon. Mr. Becker went into it after working at a club, and catering, he said, simply to save money. In less than two years, he did that, but there was more to it.
"It helped shape me," Mr. Becker said, "as an individual and as a cook."
And it provided the perfect steppingstone, which is why many cooks do it.
Mr. Becker parlayed his stint with Mr. Perelman into a job as the executive chef at Local, an ambitious restaurant in Midtown Manhattan. If he had stayed in that little-known club, he might still be there.

HEADLINE: Betting the Farm On a New-Age Vision

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
SUNRISE at Sunnyside Farms is greeted by a ritual that startles the uninitiated. Workers advance upon windowless structures on wheels that are scattered around the 539 acres and lower the sides, releasing thousands of clucking chickens eager for a good day's work at what they do best: eating bugs.
David Cole, venture capitalist, philanthropist and organic farmer, uses these coops on wheels -- chicken mobile units, they're called -- to move his chickens where the pecking is needed most. The mobile units are just one of many labor-savers he employs on the organic farm he started in 1995 in the middle of Rappahannock County, home to the very rich who have made their money elsewhere and to farmers who barely make a living. Like the cattle, sheep and goats that keep the pasture trimmed, the chickens take care of fertilizing it. 
 Like every aspect of his $11.5 million farm, the mobile units are state-of-the-art equipment intended to ensure the success of his experimental farm. Money is no object, and money is not the only objective.
The farm is not a rich man's hobby. It is a rich man's business, and Mr. Cole, who made his name as president of Internet services at America Online (and his money in a variety of other computer technology businesses), predicts confidently that Sunnyside will turn a profit by 2004.
In addition to its wagonloads of chickens, the farm has 424 head of Wagyu cattle (close relatives of the famous Japanese Kobe beef); 60 to 70 varieties of vegetables, herbs and flowers; and 8 to 10 varieties of berries, as well as pear, apple and cherry trees. It is experimenting with more than 200 kinds of fruits and vegetables.
But even more important to Mr. Cole is Sunnyside's role in promoting organic farming as economic savior. By helping local growers profit in an era when independent farms are struggling, he hopes to create a model for reviving depressed agricultural areas around the country.
The idea of saving a region through organic farming might once have sounded outlandish. But the demand for organic food nationwide is greater than the supply, and sales have increased by at least 20 percent annually for several years. Buyers looking for such food -- independently certified to be free of chemical pesticides, genetically engineered ingredients and antibiotics -- willingly pay a premium for it.
Mr. Cole, 47, calls his system network farming: a large central farm is the hub, with smaller nearby farms the spokes, their production marketed through the hub. Sunnyside's system is designed to show that diversified organic farming, with a mix of vegetables, fruits and animals, can be profitable while protecting the environment, not only from tract housing but also from the damage done to it by traditional farming methods. Such a system would be particularly useful in helping small organic farmers compete.
The concept is not new. Walnut Acres Organic Farms in Pennsylvania, which Mr. Cole just bought, operates in the same fashion. But Sunnyside was set up to be an experimental demonstration farm.
"What he is doing is really rare," said Katherine DiMatteo, executive director of the Organic Trade Association. "That he has the ability to have this diversity on his farm makes it unique. It totally encompasses the breadth of on-farm innovation and research. He is really taking new and old ideas and combining all that information into a full farm approach."
So far three small farms have signed on with Sunnyside, and conversations with a dozen more farmers are under way. The farm pays to educate them in converting to organic techniques and gaining organic certification and gives them access to the expensive equipment needed to run an organic farm. It also pays them 20 to 30 percent more than they would get if they were selling conventional food and, more important, gets their products to consumers.
"A weakness of a lot of farmers is marketing," said Brian Cramer, the gardener and orchard production manager at Sunnyside. Selling at farmers' markets or farm stands, with no middlemen, "is always preferable," he said, "but some farmers don't want to do it."
"Some don't have time to do it," he said, "so they leave it to someone else, and they get taken advantage of."
In the summer Sunnyside is opening a market in an 1835 building Mr. Cole is restoring in the center of the tiny town of Washington, Va., less than a block from his most prestigious customer, the Inn at Little Washington. Its farmers' products will be sold there, at a farmers' market in Washington, D.C., and to restaurants, the Fresh Fields natural supermarket chain and an organic wholesaler who sells up and down the East Coast. There will be more than 30 varieties of tomatoes, 15 different peppers and three dozen kinds of greens.
"Eventually we could have 8 or 10 spoke farms, and that could have a tremendous economic impact on the community," said Mr. Cole, who has restored the 1720 house on the farm, one of several places he lives with his wife of 30 years and the youngest of their four children. (One son works for Sunnyside full time, another during the summer.)
The original 1,000-acre farm had been in the same family for 276 years. When Mr. Cole bought half of it, in 1995, the land had been worn out by conventional farming. It took two years of intensive working and enriching the soil for the first earthworms to return, and Sunnyside was certified organic in 1999.
Ms. DiMatteo, of the Organic Trade Association, said she doubts that anyone has ever started an organic farm from scratch on so grand a scale, and while she greatly admires what Mr. Cole is trying to do, she is not certain it will succeed.
"People either go into organic farming gradually or specialize in one crop while they figure out crop rotations," she said. "Wealthy people do organic farming, but profitability is not what it's about, and he's setting a goal of a working farm that is economically feasible.
"This is the food industry. It's not like the technology industry. You can't force nature to perform according to some bottom-line expectations."
John Burns, a consultant who was hired by Mr. Cole in 1995 but left after a falling-out two years later, agreed. "When there is such an excess amount of capital around," he said, "the solution seems to be spend more money, get more people and get more equipment, as opposed to scaling back and concentrating on fewer things. It's the mentality of his other enterprises: you get enough brain power and enough people and you can get it solved, and farming isn't that way. It's the cycle of life and nature; it's not microchip speed."
Mr. Cole, though, maintains that with enough money and his successful business experience he can help nature along. For instance, his recent purchase of Walnut Acres, the oldest organic food mail order company in the country, provides Sunnyside with built-in marketing advantages.
He has also scoured the country for the best people in organic production, like Wes Beall, a cow's version of the horse whisperer: cattle trust him. To assure a steady supply of loyal farmworkers, who are recruited from two villages in Mexico, Mr. Cole provides benefits including trips home for two or three months at a time and 401(k) plans, matching the workers' contributions.
Mr. Cole has also planted several varieties of dwarf fruit stock to see which grow best. These varieties, Mr. Cramer said, bear more fruit more quickly, and are easier to pick and to spray with organic pest controls. Many are heirloom varieties like Roxbury Russet and Grimes Golden apples and newer varieties like Liberty that are immune to a serious apple disease called scab.
Sunnyside has its own weather station. It alerts the orchardist when to expect an outbreak of pests and prepare for it. For example, it can pinpoint the moment when the Japanese beetle's larvae are about to emerge. While the commercial grower is bringing out the pesticides, Mr. Cole is sending out the chickens.
The farm uses animals in an intensive grazing rotation, a technique now being reintroduced into organic agriculture. "In order to save human labor we enlist animal labor," Mr. Cole said, "by having them do what they do naturally." For a day or two cattle graze on high grasses in a particular field; when they move on, the sheep and goats come in for a day to eat everything else. They are followed by the chickens, which scatter the manure left behind by the other animals as they eat the weed seeds out of it, at the same time depositing their own nitrogen-rich manure. (The chickens also provide eggs for the farm to sell.) Then the rotation begins again.
All of these approaches will be shared at the Sunnyside Institute, to be built on the farm. It will provide information not available from federal and state agriculture agencies, which have spent little time or money studying organic farming.
"No one has ever coordinated all this information," Ms. DiMatteo said.
Mr. Cole traces his interest in the environment to his childhood in Hawaii. His family has financed global conservation efforts for 15 years, most recently through the Cole Family Foundation. He chose Virginia for his experiment because of its climate and its proximity to one of his homes. He found the farm through a friend who is now a neighbor, John Sawhill, the president and chief executive of the environmental group the Nature Conservancy.
In an interview for "Dream Makers," by Michele Hunt (Davies-Black Publishing, 1998), Mr. Cole said entrepreneurs need to redefine capital to include not only money but the earth itself and stop treating it like an unlimited resource. "Instead of saying the world is going to hell in a handbasket, you have to say we can do something about this. We can change our relationship to the earth."
Like any rich mogul who comes to town and buys up all the available land, Mr. Cole has his detractors. But even those who have parted ways over differences of opinion admire what he is trying to do.
Mr. Burns, who quit as a consultant, said Mr. Cole is "brilliant." But he added: "He makes it hard for some people to deal with him, because you have to do it his way. He wants to do too much too fast. If I'd had my druthers, I would have managed the farm for three years without growing a thing, but he wanted to have crops in 18 months."
In early April, Mr. Cole was invited to lecture at the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London on organic food trends in the United States. In his speech he described his attempt to fuse two totally different cultures: the high-powered, fast-paced world of technology and marketing and a slow-paced place from the past where success is based on the production yields of organic farming.
Mr. Cole leaves no doubt of his certitude that he can apply the principles of the Internet, where rewards can come at warp speed and most problems can be remedied with brain power and capital, to farming, where even the best-laid plans are subject to the vagaries of nature.
"He wants to do good, and he really sees this as an important step," Mr. Burns said. "And being a leader in a previous industrial incarnation, he wants to do the same thing in the organic world. But organic mogul may be an oxymoron."
 
Same Idea, Different Scale
 FOR organic gardeners operating on a smaller scale, Brian Cramer, the gardener at Sunnyside, offers a few techniques. Some are old, some new.
Flaming newly emerging weeds with a propane torch is particularly useful with crops slow to germinate, giving them a chance to grow.
Planting crops in the carrot family -- dill, parsley, cilantro, Queen Anne's lace -- attracts beneficial insects for other crops nearby.
Turnips, broccoli, radishes, cabbage and brussels sprouts should be planted in the fall because the flea beetle, which attacks them, comes early in the spring but goes into decline by the end of August.
Certain crops can be covered with plastic to protect the plants from wind and insects, provide a few degrees of frost protection and hasten ripening. This is particularly useful for valuable crops and those especially susceptible to insects. At Sunnyside, for example, plastic is used to protect eggplant.
Pheromone lures, which contain substances secreted by animals, can be placed in the garden not only to lure pests into sticky traps but also to confuse males so they cannot find females and mate. They are as effective as many pesticides.
Certain crops affect the growth or germination of other plants around them. On a farm, residues of rye can stop certain weeds from germinating; in a garden, sunflowers can do the same. A byproduct of corn syrup, corn gluten meal, inhibits the germination of many common weeds. It is a promising herbicide, and it also fertilizes. MARIAN BURROS

HEADLINE: To Nurture a Teacher

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "A Few Words in Praise of Unexceptional Schools" (Lessons column, April 5), by Nicholas D. Kristof:
Mr. Kristof reminds us that there is a difference between education and training. In a society that measures success by how much money a recent college graduate earns, education should not be measured solely in short-term economic terms. 
 Education is a continuing process of growth and understanding of one's role in a complex world. Education at its best helps us develop our full potential as creative people prepared to contribute as parents, spouses and citizens.
The teacher who sparks the curiosity and instills a drive in a young person to learn must be appreciated and nurtured. Economic measures and test scores are only part of the educational process.
 
JOSEPH S. GOLDMAN
Woodland Hills, Calif., April 9, 2000

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
No Tipping, Please

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
More than 20 years ago I fell in love, as young social scientists will, with nonlinearity -- and in particular with the idea that large effects could have small causes. I was inspired by the economist Thomas Schelling's classic little 1978 book "Micro motives and macrobehavior," with its illustrative models of how seemingly trivial individual concerns (such as a mild desire to have some neighbors similar to yourself) could lead to extreme social outcomes (such as complete racial segregation). And I dreamed of a theory of everything -- of fashions and fads, booms and slumps, economic miracles and social catastrophes.
So when I read "The Tipping Point," the new best seller by Malcolm Gladwell, I sighed for my lost innocence. Mr. Gladwell is a very good writer, but he is also lucky: he has not yet been forced to confront the sad truth that it is far easier to tell nonlinear stories than to confirm them, let alone use them as a basis for action. 
 For those who haven't yet heard about it, "The Tipping Point" -- subtitled "How little things can make a big difference" -- has a pretty good chance of becoming one of those books that, arriving at just the right moment, reinforce a new public mood. After decades of disillusionment with social engineering, of backlash against the Great Society and all that, there is a new mood of social activism abroad in the land; and Mr. Gladwell offers hope that "tightly focused, targeted interventions" might work after all. So his book might be to the next decade what Michael Harrington's "The Other America" was to the 1960's.
Mr. Gladwell's main idea is an analogy between social movements and epidemics. With stories that range from the sudden resurgence of Hush Puppies as fashion footwear to the recent decline in New York's crime rate, he argues that behavior patterns, like viruses, can spread from a few individuals through a large population. (Oddly, he makes no mention of the biologist Richard Dawkins, whose analogy between "memes" -- infectious ideas -- and viruses had, I thought, itself spread widely even among the literati). And a small change in the environment, which makes a particular behavior pattern just a bit more likely to persist in one individual or be adopted by another, can sometimes cause sudden, large social change.
It's an idea that, in some broad and general sense, is certainly true. And if you have never thought about such things before, it can be mind-opening. But a word of caution: If you accept Mr. Gladwell's conclusion that the analogy between epidemics and social change offers "a reaffirmation of the potential for change and the power of intelligent action," you are likely to be bitterly disappointed.
Why do I say this? Because when it comes to the idea that big events can have small causes, economists -- who ought to have a simpler problem, because they deal with the cruder emotions -- have been there and done that, repeatedly, for 60 years or more. And by and large the theories haven't worked.
For example, surely the spread of the Great Depression from Wall Street to the world at large was a sort of epidemic; more recently, the 1997-98 crisis in Asia was almost invariably described with terms like "financial contagion." Everyone who thinks about it seriously realizes that such crises must involve some kind of self-reinforcing process. But the ingenious "nonlinear business cycle theory" that briefly flourished in the 1940's turned out to be no help in predicting or preventing future recessions. I have a personal stake in believing that the currency crisis models some of us devised in the midst of Asia's turmoil will have a better fate; but history is not on my side.
Another example: Economists once thought that a brief "big push," perhaps concentrated on a few key sectors, could jump-start a stagnant economy into rapid modernization. But none of the deliberate efforts to engineer an economic takeoff delivered on their promise; when economic miracles like Korea's sudden surge in the 1960's (or our own recent productivity revolution) occurred, they have always come as a surprise.
I'm not saying that "focused, targeted interventions" aren't worth trying. But don't count on much success. Little things can indeed make a big difference; but they're usually not the things you were watching, or the difference you expected.

HEADLINE: All Boats Rise. Now What?

BYLINE: By William Julius Wilson; William Julius Wilson, a Harvard University professor, is the author of "The Bridge Over the Racial Divide: Rising Inequality and Coalition Politics."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Thanks to the economic boom, and despite much hand-wringing to the contrary, there are signs that America's rising income inequality that began in the early 1970's is finally in remission.
Yet this good news gives rise to worrisome questions: Will this new economy eventually produce the sort of progress for most families that prevailed in the two and a half decades prior to 1970, a pattern in which a rising tide did indeed lift all boats? Or will the government's social and economic policies prevent us from duplicating this prolonged pattern of broadly equal family economic gains? 
 Between 1947 and 1970 all income groups in America experienced economic advancement. In fact, poor families recorded higher growth in annual real income than other families. However, in the early 1970's this pattern changed. The families in the higher income groups, especially the top 20 percent, continued to enjoy steady income gains, adjusted for inflation, while families in the lowest 40 percent experienced declining or stagnating incomes.
This growing disparity in income, which continued through the mid-1990's, was in large part connected to a slowdown in productivity growth. Profits and wages depend largely on how much we produce, and in those years productivity slowed and less revenue was produced, which put downward pressure on wages.
Then, beginning in late 1995, productivity began to surge, averaging 2.6 percent annual growth since then, and reaching an astonishing 6.4 percent annual rate in the last quarter of 1999. Given the current rate of productivity growth, a rising gross domestic product and our sustained low unemployment rates, the most optimistic scenario is that this new economy will eventually produce rates of family economic progress similar to those of the 50's and 60's.
The signs are encouraging. Real wage growth has been quite impressive since 1997, especially for low-wage workers. The ranks of the long-term jobless -- those in the labor market who have been out of work for more than six months -- plummeted from almost two million in 1993 to just 637,000 today. The unemployment rate of high-school dropouts declined from almost 12 percent in 1992 to less than 7 percent now. The unemployment rate among blacks is 7.3 percent, the lowest since the Bureau of Labor Statistics began compiling comparable unemployment data by race in 1972.
So, in the face of all these promising numbers, can those of us concerned about inequality finally relax? Not yet. Productivity growth is only part of the picture. The future of ordinary families, especially poor working families, depends a great deal on how the government decides to react to this new economy.
As the economist James K. Galbraith has pointed out, what is unique about the 1950's and 60's is that the government's policies -- social as well as economic -- were integral to the gains experienced by all families. Low-wage workers gained from a wide range of protections, including steady increases in the minimum wage, and the government made full employment a high priority. Throughout the 60's these policies were accompanied by federal wage-price guidelines that helped check inflation. There was also a strong union movement that ensured higher wages and more non-wage benefits for ordinary workers.
However, in the 1970's and 80's things moved in a different direction for lower-wage workers. The union movement began its downward spiral, wage-price guidelines were eventually dropped, and macroeconomic policy was no longer geared toward tight labor markets. Monetary policy became dominant, and it was focused on defeating inflation above all else.
As part of the "Reagan experiment," the tax structure became more regressive and Social Security taxes increased. Furthermore, congressional resistance to raising the minimum wage and expanding the earned income tax credit threatened the economic security of disadvantaged families.
More recently, the fate of the working poor has rarely been discussed when the Federal Reserve Board, worried about the possibility of rising inflation, has raised interest rates to slow down the economy. But now, with high productivity keeping inflation in check, at least there has been a healthy debate among economists and financial analysts over the Fed's dogged decision to continue raising interest rates.
History shows that trends of rising inequality are associated not only with economic changes, but also with the eroding strength of what the economist Frank Levy of M.I.T. calls "the nation's equalizing institutions." These include public education, unions, the welfare state broadly defined, international trade regulations and so on.
These equalizing institutions were much stronger from 1947 to 1970 than they are today. And they will have to be strengthened to ensure that the rising inequality remains in remission and a broadly equal pattern of family economic progress can be restored in the new economy.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Ethan Allen Going a Bit West for Its Flagship Store

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
For many furniture retailers, a comparatively low rent that permits a large display area is crucial to success. So Ethan Allen Interiors, the manufacturer and retailer of home furnishings and furniture products, has leased 20,000 square feet way west in Manhattan, far from the usual retail-chain haunts.
The new space is on the ground and first floors of 101 West End Avenue, a 504-apartment twin-tower rental building nearing completion between 64th and 65th Streets. 
 "Furniture retailers can't afford to pay a significant per-square-foot rent," said Joanne Podell, a vice president at New Spectrum Realty, who represented Ethan Allen in the deal. "So much floor space is taken up with the furniture, so the sales per square foot are not as great as with, say, a clothing store. And this site gives Ethan Allen an opportunity to display its entire line, rather than to have to selectively choose which items they can present in the showroom."
Ms. Podell said that the asking annual rent was $45 a square foot for the ground floor and $35 for the second-floor space, and that the actual rent, which she would not disclose, was lower.
"It would have probably been triple that or more in other parts of town," she said. "To be on Broadway on the Upper West Side, the asking rent could be $200 a square foot. And then you have to hope for a blended rent for the different floors, and it's a challenge finding the right amount of space. And you have to minimize your space and not put in the full furniture line. We looked at a number of places on Broadway, but the economics didn't work."
West End Avenue in the mid-60's has not been a hub for national retail chain stores. It is primarily a residential area, a couple of long blocks distant from the commercial strip of Broadway and Lincoln Center, though it also houses ABC television buildings, including a studio just west on 66th Street in which the soap opera "All My Children" is shot.
A Consolidated Edison control center is between 65th and 66th, with a neighborhood deli, a bicycle shop and the Ideal Tile and Stone Gallery just to the south, and a Western Beef supermarket by the West End Towers residential development at 62nd Street. North of 66th is Lincoln Towers, an 8-building, 4,000-unit co-op complex that stretches to 70th Street. And west of Lincoln Towers are the first completed buildings of the large Trump Place residential development.
Ms. Podell said Ethan Allen, which is based in Danbury, Conn., viewed the site as "destination driven," adding that "the company is a national chain with a large advertising base, and when you have that, the consumer can come to you."
"People travel to buy their furniture," she said. "It's a thought process. They spend time deciding where to visit and what products they like. They don't just walk down Broadway and decide to buy a sofa. It's a planned family activity."
The site on West End Avenue, she said, is "easily accessible -- it's a short walk from the West 66th Street subway." And, she said, "there's a tremendous amount of residential development on and near the avenue, with Trump Place, West End Towers and the long-established Lincoln Towers, all of which will add to the customer base."
The West End Avenue store, which Ms. Podell said was expected to open in the fall, will be Ethan Allen's third in Manhattan and will be its corporate flagship. A company-owned store is at Third Avenue and 65th Street, and a franchise store is at Lexington Avenue and 32nd Street. Kelly Maicon, a spokeswoman for Ethan Allen in Danbury, said the company would not comment on the new store.
Alan Victor, an executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation, a retail brokerage company, said he thought that the area had the "right ingredients for Ethan Allen."
"There's a lot of new construction to support the store," Mr. Victor said, "a lot of people in the area who will need furniture. The number of new residential units that have gone up there is extraordinary. The demographics are very strong."
The growing population on and near West End Avenue is also bringing a large new supermarket to the neighborhood. Barry Rosner, a senior managing director of GVA Williams Real Estate, the leasing agent for 80 West End Avenue, a commercial building between 63rd and 64th Streets that is home to Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, said a 25,000-square-foot Food Emporium would open later this year on the building's long-vacant ground floor.
Mr. Victor said he did not think Ethan Allen's arrival marked the start of a retail renaissance on the avenue. "I don't think it's an indicator that West End is going to develop into a retail corridor," he said. "I think it's still going to be local and destination driven. But there's a chance that some stores in the furnishings category, stores related to home use, might be interested."
Ms. Podell said she thought other home furnishing companies might join Ethan Allen in the neighborhood. "I don't think it's the kind of area where you put the Gap," she said. "But what happens with home furnishing companies is that they tend to cluster. So others may follow."

HEADLINE: Board Reports Record Income From Rent-Regulated Housing

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
The landlords of the one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City enjoyed record-high income coupled with the smallest increase in expenses in nearly a decade in 1998, according to the latest annual report issued yesterday at a meeting of the city's Rent Guidelines Board.
Tenant groups said that the figures showed little if any need to raise rents, while landlords said they were only rebounding from the recession and pointed to recent increases in fuel costs for heat and hot water. 
 The rent board's staff conducted the study in preparation for the annual decision in June on whatever rent increase it might authorize for the coming year. Besides that study, the board gives major consideration to its annual index of operating prices, a report due for release on April 25.
The income-and-expenses study covered 1998, the most recent year for which figures were available, and was based on a survey of more than 10,000 buildings by the city's tax assessors.
Net operating income -- the difference between income and operating expenses -- jumped 11.8 percent, slightly more than the previous record of 11.4 from 1997. Net operating income is used for mortgage payments, building improvements and profit.
The report called the findings "the highest rate of net operating income growth found in the nine years" that the agency has tracked the statistics. It added, "These figures suggest that New York's stabilized housing market has emerged from the deep recession of the early 1990's."
One tenant advocate in the audience, Kenneth D. Schaeffer of the Legal Aid Society, said: "I'm struck by the huge increase in net income, double digits two years running. Last year they did better than ever, and now they're doing 11 percent better than that." He said that past rent increases adopted by the board had "overcompensated" landlords.
But one landlord representative on the board, Harold A. Lubell, spoke in biblical terms, likening the turnaround to a belated feast "following seven years of famine." Another board member noted that despite the upturn, 7 percent of the buildings were still running deficits.
Citywide, the average monthly rent collected on rent-stabilized apartments in 1998 was $681, an increase of 5.5 percent over 1997. The study attributed the higher collections to fewer vacancies, fewer tenants in arrears, rent deregulation, general rent increases and increases for improvements. Among the boroughs, Manhattan had the highest average monthly rent collection, $892; followed by Queens, $609; Brooklyn, $536; and the Bronx, $508. A figure was not given for Staten Island because of the small number of stabilized apartments there.
Expenses on rent-stabilized apartments averaged $459 a month per apartment citywide, an increase of 1.5 percent, which the report said was the smallest in the nine years that it has recorded the figures. The trend was ascribed to a dip in insurance, utility and fuel bills in 1998. Manhattan had the highest costs, $586; followed by Queens, $406; the Bronx, $365; and Brooklyn, $364.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: A Tale of Muscle and Morale;
Why Home Depot Employs Olympic Athletes

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
When the Olympic Games open in Australia this summer, about 30 athletes will represent Egypt. Sixty will make up the contingent from Turkey. Eighty will run, jump, swim and play for Ireland.
And nearly 100 will make up the delegation from Home Depot. 
 The company's orange logo will not appear on the Olympic athletes' uniforms, of course, and television commentators probably won't even mention the giant retailer's name. But here in Home Depot's home base and elsewhere around North America, thousands of company employees will stay up late to root for the athletes on TV and get up the next morning to devour the accounts of the competitors' exploits in the sports pages.
That, it turns out, is the audience Home Depot executives are trying to reach. When a company employs 210,000 people in an industry with one of the highest turnover rates in the country -- in the midst of one of the tightest job markets in more than three decades -- it does what it has to do to hold onto every last one of them.
So, at a cost of several million dollars, Home Depot has hired 116 Olympic athletes from the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico -- more than all the other 50 or so companies in the official Olympic Games jobs program employ combined -- to pace its floors and advise customers on everything from screws to lawn mowers. It is using their presence not to increase sales in a national advertising campaign, but to pump up employee morale.
In this economy, in other words, the imperatives of management can trump the demands of marketing.
Home Depot has spread the 116 Olympic contenders among its 958 North American stores, where local managers enlist them to motivate employees and attract new ones. The athletes autograph their colleagues' aprons, and those who have won medals show them off at company parties. Company managers point to the athletes as real-life examples of corporate nostrums like "going for the gold" and "giving it your all."
Dick Hammill, Home Depot's senior vice president for marketing, who oversees the program from company headquarters, said of the athletes: "They're disciplined. They're on time. They work hard. It rubs off."
Some of the Home Depot athletes will fail to qualify for the Sydney Games. But because national Olympic committees require that athletes be highly ranked in order to participate in the jobs program, most should qualify, officials said. Ranging from unheralded rowers and wrestlers to stars like the runner Butch Reynolds, the athletes work about 20 hours a week for about $400 and spend the rest of their time training.
Other companies that have been in the jobs program, like United Parcel Service, have run TV ads promoting their athletes to the general public. In contrast, Home Depot is only now planning its first commercial starring one of its Olympians -- and the setting is expected to be a send-off party a store gives to wish good luck to an athlete on the way to an event.
So intent is Home Depot on finding qualified employees that it has even made some of its commercials the equivalent of help-wanted ads. Earlier this year, for example, it began broadcasting a spot that showed employees and ended with the words, "The Home Depot. Great Careers Built Here."
Other companies are pursuing a similar strategy. Last year, McDonald's ran a television ad, set to feel-good music, in which captions like "future software engineer" and "future elementary school teacher" appeared under its young burger flippers. At Hewlett-Packard, Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive, has said that a primary target of its current television campaign that describes the company as "the original start-up" is the company's work force, which could be easy pickings for dot-com firms.
A host of companies, including both Home Depot and Microsoft, are even starting to use outdoor billboards to seek job candidates. Around the country, spending on help-wanted billboards almost tripled last year, to $16 million, according to the Outdoor Advertising Association of America.
Home Depot, however, is in a category all its own. At a time when few skilled workers remain unemployed, it aims to more than double its current payroll, to nearly 500,000, within four years. That is a monumental task for a company in a traditional field that pays entry-level employes about $10 an hour to perform work that can be both exhausting and repetitive.
To maintain the gung-ho workplace culture that many experts say has helped fuel Home Depot's remarkable growth, the company has had to attack the great bane of retailers: high employee turnover. For years, executives have held pep rallies and allowed store managers to spend the company's charity money on local causes that are often dear to the hearts of employees. "It's the internal people that are the target" of many Home Depot initiatives, said Frederick F. Reichheld, a consultant at Bain & Company and author of "The Loyalty Effect" (Harvard Business School Press, 1996) who has studied the company.
That is the rationale behind the company's Olympic sponsorship. The retailer paid $40 million to sign up as a sponsor eight years ago, when Atlanta was getting ready to be host of the 1996 Summer Olympics and the company was expanding across the country, Mr. Hammill said. By the time the Atlanta Games opened, Home Depot had more than 90 American athletes on its payroll. Combining results from the Atlanta Games and the 1994 and 1998 Winter Olympics, its athletes have won 16 gold medals, 6 silvers and 9 bronzes -- more medals in the four-year span than Belgium, Denmark or Britain has brought home.
In the last two years, the company has created similar versions of the jobs program in Canada and Puerto Rico.
For all the glory that the Home Depot athletes aspire to, they follow a pretty ordinary workplace routine. On a recent Wednesday, 27-year-old Derek Mills, a runner, spent the morning and early afternoon stocking shelves and answering questions in the electrical department of the store in Alpharetta, Ga., an Atlanta suburb. Wearing an orange Home Depot apron with "Hi, I'm Derek" emblazoned on it, he paused at one point to tell a colleague using a forklift that he was about to bump against a ceiling lamp and send a stack of outdoor barbecue grills tumbling to the floor.
There was little to suggest that Mr. Mills was the owner of a gold medal for the 1996 400-meter relay -- until one of his colleagues walked by and said, "Hey, Speedy!"
The nickname is apt, in more ways than one. Within an hour, Mr. Mills was driving 25 miles to a training session on the campus of Georgia Tech, where he received an engineering degree in 1995. The next day, he was crossing the Atlantic, off to Glasgow for an indoor track and field competition.
Like other athletes in the Olympic jobs program, Mr. Mills continues to draw his pay when he is on the road. It is a perquisite that participants, injury-prone and financially strapped as many of them are, greatly treasure.
Mr. Mills, for example, has suffered nagging hamstring and Achilles' tendon injuries the last three years, making it more difficult for him to earn appearance fees at track meets. "It's not the early stages for my career anymore," he said ruefully.
For athletes in less lucrative sports, the wages can make an even bigger difference. "I would not be training if I didn't have this job; it's too much of a struggle," said Julia Chilicki, 28, a rower who was in the 1996 Olympics and recently transferred from a Home Depot in Massachusetts to one in South Carolina so she could train with her team.
Indeed, Home Depot is one of the few big successes that the Olympic jobs program can claim. J. C. Penney, part of the program since its founding in 1977, now has 16 athletes on its payroll. But all other companies in the program limit themselves to just a few athletes, given their unpredictable schedules and the prospect of paying them for hours they do not work.
As a result, many of the 600 American athletes who will be in Sydney -- as well as hundreds of others who are training but will fail to qualify -- cobble together part-time jobs and appearance fees to make ends meet.
In return for their pay, Home Depot's athletes take a public role as company cheerleaders. Mr. Mills, for example, went to his store's annual party last year dressed in his track uniform and with his gold medal hanging around his neck. "He let everybody touch it," said Craig Denton, a colleague who himself was a member of the Olympic jobs program as a kayaker. Mr. Mills also starred in a mock newscast that was broadcast to all 210,000 employees in advance of a recent videotaped speech by Arthur Blank, chief executive of Home Depot.
The company's generosity toward its Olympic athletes -- paying them a week's wages for half a week's work and keeping the checks coming when they are traveling -- clearly has the potential for creating resentment among the rank and file. But that has not happened, employees say, largely because the regular workers look up to the athletes and realize how hard they have to work at their training.
"Years from now, I may be able to tell my kids I knew someone who won an Olympic medal," said Richard Faber, who works alongside Colleen Rosensteel, a member of the women's judo team, in Palatine, Ill. "Everybody's living a little vicariously through Colleen."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
If you can't remember what kind of car you're driving, you may have been on the road too long.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. Joe Sharkey's e-mail is jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
FREQUENT business travelers, who tend to spend a lot of time alone on the road, increasingly are congregating at various Internet sites to share practical information and, given the inexorable relationship between humor and adversity, crack jokes. Here, culled from postings in various business-travel chat rooms, news groups and bulletin boards (primarily www.flyertalk .com, sponsored by the publisher of InsideFlyer Magazine), is a Top 10 list that could be titled: "You Know You're a Hard-Core Business Traveler If . . ."
1. You've noticed that despite America's reputation as a melting pot, some people in some cities bear a frightening resemblance to one another. 
 2. You walk out into the hotel parking lot and have no idea of the make, model or color of your rental car.
3. You are amazed by people who cannot pack a week's worth of clothing and needed work items into a single rollerboard and a carry-on bag.
4. You know the menu by heart at every TGI Friday's, Bennigan's, Applebee's, Ruby Tuesday's and Olive Garden.
5. You've driven more models of cars than Consumer Reports magazine.
6. You can tell at a glance which customs line has the time-wasting troublemakers queued up in it.
7. You aren't fazed by writing checks to American Express or Visa every month for $5,000 or more.
8. You actually know the names of all the meteorologists on the Weather Channel.
9. You can recite the safety-instruction spiel word-for-word along with the flight attendant.
10.You press "9" on your home phone before dialing a number.
 
Side Trips
The average daily room rates for hotels in major cities in the United States grew by 4.4 percent during the second half of 1999 from the comparable period in 1998, according to PKF Consulting's Hospitality Research Group. Among the reasons the research firm cited for this increase, which occurred despite a continuing oversupply of hotel rooms and slight declines in occupancy rates, was the "wealth effect" in a booming economy that has prompted "a loosening of tight corporate travel budgets and personal pocketbooks." Reflecting this, higher-priced hotels are faring best right now.
The annual airline quality rating study jointly conducted by the business school at Wichita State University and the Aviation Institute at the University of Nebraska always gets a lot of publicity with its customer-service performance rankings of the top 10 airlines in the United States in areas such as on-time arrival, boarding availability and mishandled baggage.
But the 2000 survey, which placed Southwest Airlines in first place and UAL's United Airlines last, has some footnotes and observations intended to put the overall industry on notice. Among them: "Continued declining industry performance quality in 1999 gives cause for Congress to again seriously consider the passage of an Airline Passengers' Bill of Rights" that would provide an enforceable alternative to existing in-house attempts by the airlines to define standards for handling customer complaints.
Furthermore, the study warns, the decline in comfort and reliability in air travel is leading to "consumer retaliation" that shows up in a doubling of informal complaints made to the Transportation Department.
The upshot, according to the study is that "soon, consumers will become driven by price and schedule only" without regard to loyalty for any particular airline.
The study also faults the industry for "targeting" regional and start-up airlines with practices like temporarily adding flights to block upstart competitors.
AirTran Airways is accusing Northwest Airlines of trying to do just that. AirTran recently filed a complaint with the government saying that Northwest "dumped" seats onto its Minneapolis-Atlanta routes to thwart AirTran's plan to introduce flights on that route in June, using 100-seat Boeing 717 aircraft.
"This over-aggressive capacity increase eliminates the possibility for AirTran to profitably enter the market," AirTran said in a statement. But Northwest denied acting unfairly toward AirTran, saying that it filed for expanded service on the Minneapolis-Atlanta routes in mid-February -- weeks before AirTran filed for its new routes.

HEADLINE: James Marston Fitch, 90, Architect and Preservationist

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
James Marston Fitch, an architect whose writings and teaching helped transform historic preservation from a dilettante's pastime into a vigorous, broadly based cultural movement, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.
Less interested in where Washington slept than in how ordinary people built their homes and workplaces -- and what lessons modern architects could draw from the most modest and common building types -- Mr. Fitch was the outspoken antithesis of a freeze-it-in-amber sentimentalist. 
 Instead he argued that a respect for older buildings made environmental and economic sense. And he broadened the notion of what constituted important historical resources to include "vernacular" buildings, structures like the 19th-century cast-iron industrial lofts of SoHo, which were not designed in high style yet spoke eloquently about the cultures that created them.
"The ultimate task of architecture is to act in favor of human beings," Mr. Fitch said in the newly revised and updated edition of his 1947 work, "American Building: The Environmental Forces That Shape It" (Oxford University Press, 1999), written with William Bobenhausen.
Jane Jacobs, a central figure in the movement that repudiated the clean-slate planning strategies of the 1950's and 60's, said yesterday of Mr. Fitch, "He was the principal character in making the preservation of historic buildings practical and feasible and popular."
"He opened people's eyes," Ms. Jacobs said by telephone from Toronto, where she now lives. "He didn't just relegate the need for preservation of the built environment to early examples, sacred styles and so forth. He was one of the first to see the value of Art Deco." But his enthusiasms were wide-ranging; he was also a founding member of the Victorian Society in America and was instrumental in saving the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan.
"He made people understand that whole districts -- even with undistinguished buildings in them -- were worthy of preservation and appreciation," Ms. Jacobs said.
Now taken for granted, such concepts were almost unheard of in 1964, when Mr. Fitch and the architect Charles Peterson founded a graduate program in restoration and preservation at Columbia University. Mr. Fitch headed the program until 1977, seeking as diverse a student body as he could find in the belief that preservation touched many lives and could profit from many different kinds of expertise and passion.
"The great forces in American preservation have always been the lay people," he said in a 1998 interview. "Professional designers have, time and time again, retreated from the scene of battle. Preservationists are the people who fought tooth and nail."
Among his former students are Frank Sanchis, the executive director of the Municipal Art Society; John H. Stubbs, the vice president of the World Monuments Fund; and Adele Chatfield-Taylor, the president of the American Academy in Rome.
As a man who led architectural tours with the cry "Andiamo!" ("Let's go!") -- in the cadences of Tennessee -- Mr. Fitch was scarcely the kind to retire at 68, when he stepped down from Columbia's Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation.
His next career was as the director of historic preservation at the Manhattan architectural firm Beyer Blinder Belle.
In the firm's recently completed renovation of Grand Central Terminal, Mr. Fitch advocated construction of a new staircase on the east end of the concourse to complement the existing staircase on the west.
A preservation purist might have disputed such an intervention. But Mr. Fitch said: "I tell you the logic of the plan suggested that there could have been a balancing stair there. That's the essence of the Beaux-Arts planning philosophy. We didn't violate the intentions of the builder."
That is not to say he was a pushover for alterations. When his own firm came up with a plan for Donald J. Trump to reclad the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South and the Avenue of the Americas, Mr. Fitch was opposed.
When the firm was restoring the Cathedral of the Madeleine in Salt Lake City, Mr. Fitch "got into incredible dialogues, telling the bishop how Catholic services should work," recalled Richard L. Blinder, a partner in Beyer Blinder Belle.
Mr. Fitch was born in Washington on May 8, 1909, and grew up in Chattanooga. He attended the University of Alabama and the school of architecture at Tulane University. The Depression prevented him from finishing school but he was granted five honorary doctorates later in life.
As an Air Force meteorologist in the second world war, he traced the effects of climate on people, information he later used to study how buildings relate to their environment.
"He was an environmentalist when we were doing glass buildings that had no relation to their environment," Mr. Blinder said.
Before and after the war, Mr. Fitch was an editor at Architectural Record, Architectural Forum and House Beautiful in New York; he was appointed an associate professor at Columbia in 1954.
Mr. Fitch's other books include "Walter Gropius" (1960), "Architecture and the Esthetics of Plenty" (1961) and "Historic Preservation: Curatorial Management of the Built World" (1982).
His first wife, Cleo Rickman Fitch, an archaeological researcher, died in 1995. He is survived by his second wife, Martica Sawin, a critic and art historian, and three stepdaughters, Martica Douglas of Portland, Me.; Maggy Wolf, of New Orleans; and Gina Sawin, of New Gloucester, Me.
Between spells together on the preservation battlefield in the 1960's, fighting the Lower Manhattan Expressway, which would have run along Broome Street, Ms. Jacobs recalled many evenings of conversation in their West Village homes.
"He was a great educator," she said, "even when he wasn't in the classroom."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Chase WillPay $7.7 Billion In Cash and Stock for Fleming

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 11

 BODY:
Chase Manhattan formally agreed today to acquire Robert Fleming Holdings for $7.7 billion, part of an effort by Chase to strengthen its presence in Europe and Asia.
The deal, which had been widely expected, means the end of independence for Fleming, one of the last privately held investment banks based in Britain. 
 It also illustrates the intensifying pressure on midsize firms like Fleming to merge with larger institutions on favorable terms or risk being swallowed up or driven out of an increasingly global business.
Chase said its motive in acquiring Fleming had little to do with saving money by trimming overlapping businesses. Rather, the American bank said, the purchase would help vault it into a position that would allow it to compete more effectively around the world.
The agreement will give Chase, the third-largest bank in the United States, a quick presence in Asia, where Fleming's asset management business has been flourishing, and in Europe. The addition of Fleming also gives Chase new revenue streams from asset management.
The acquisition is expected to be completed by July or August.
"This isn't about expense synergies," said William B. Harrison Jr., Chase Manhattan's chief executive. "If you like the growth prospects for Asia and Europe, then you will like this transaction."
Not all investors and analysts viewed the deal so favorably, with some saying Chase might have overpaid for Fleming. Under the terms of the agreement, Chase will pay about $4.1 billion in cash and $3.6 billion in its stock. In New York today, Chase Manhattan shares fell $2.125, to $86.
"It clearly took a bit for Chase to leverage it away from the family," said Julian Bird, an analyst with Credit Lyonnais Securities here.
Chase acknowledged that the acquisition would dilute earnings the first year, but maintained that the dilution was not significant.
Fleming, which is not a publicly traded company, is 29.4 percent-owned by the Fleming family -- which included Ian Fleming, the writer who created the character James Bond.
It was founded 127 years ago by Robert Fleming, a onetime bookkeeper who saw a future in investing in the cattle ranches and railroads of America, then the world's most promising emerging economy. Fleming formed the Scottish-American Investment Trust, which expanded into one of Britain's biggest asset managers by the time of his death in 1933 at age 88.
It has since grown to operate in 40 countries with a staff of 7,500, managing $140 billion in clients' funds. The company also owns Jardine Matheson Holdings, one of Asia's leading investment management and banking groups.
Some analysts said that the new company, which will be called Chase Flemings, would still operate in a second-tier league to larger and more powerful investment banks like Merrill Lynch and the Goldman Sachs Group.
Yet for Fleming, a loss of independence may have been inevitable if it is to ultimately survive in the face of aggressive global expansions by American firms.
"It's the same dilemma that Schroders faced," said John Tyce, a banking analyst at SG Securities here, referring to the acquisition by Citigroup of that British investment bank in January. "In case no one has noticed, the Yanks are here and they are making people squeal."
The only remaining independent British investment bank is now Cazenove & Company, which, interestingly, advised Fleming during the negotiations with Chase Manhattan. Chase's own mergers-and-acquisitions unit acted as its adviser.
As part of the deal, Fleming sold its half-stake in a joint venture with T. Rowe Price Associates for $780 million to Price, the Baltimore-based mutual fund company and money manager. Rowe Price Fleming manages about $43 billion.
Under the arrangement, Fleming's current chief executive, William Garrett, will continue to run the business. Chase said no layoffs are expected.
The acquisition of Fleming reflects Chase's strategy of building its business by making several smaller acquisitions rather than merging with one of the bigger banks. Last year, Chase bought Hambrecht & Quist for $1.35 billion, strengthening itself in technology-related investment banking.
