HEADLINE: PERU'S PRESIDENT, SHORT OF MAJORITY, NOW FACES RUNOFF

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 12

 BODY:
President Alberto K. Fujimori today fell just short of reaching a first-round victory in his re-election bid, meaning that a runoff will be held by early June, a surprise development that elated the opposition.
The government announcement set off euphoria in the streets, where news of a Fujimori victory was awaited and would probably have resulted in violence. 
 Such has been the criticism of the election's fairness at home and abroad that if Mr. Fujimori had won a third five-year term, his administration would most likely have become an international pariah and the source of constant instability.
With 97.7 percent of the vote counted, the authorities said tonight, Mr. Fujimori's total had risen a bit, to 49.8 percent, tantalizingly close to the needed 50 percent. But election officials said the complete result could not give the president outright victory because there were too few uncounted votes outstanding.
"The democratic forces have triumphed," Alejandro Toledo, Mr. Fujimori's leading opponent, shouted from a balcony overlooking tens of thousands of supporters in San Martin Plaza in downtown Lima. Waving a flag and flashing a victory sign, he added: "Our people have won despite all the games and tricks. On to the second round."
Election officials said that in the latest count, Mr. Toledo had won 40.3 percent of the vote. He will face Mr. Fujimori in the runoff.
The developments tonight stand to give Mr. Toledo a strong start in the second round. Little known only six weeks ago, he now can ride a wave of publicity, and he is strongly identified with democratic currents that are beginning to swirl powerfully through the country. His strong Indian features and rags-to-success personal story have made him appealing to many Peruvians, and the results of Sunday's election should add to his mystique as a man who surmounts enormous odds.
But Mr. Fujimori, 61, has come back against long odds, too, and he will have many advantages that come from controlling the government purse strings and an intelligence service with potent political tools.
Eduardo Stein, head of the Organization of American States' election observation team here, expressed relief at the government announcement tonight, saying, "It was the most sensible option open for the stability of Peru."
Mr. Stein said that "the O.A.S. could not condone what was going on" and was facing an eventuality in which "democratic order is broken."
The United States welcomed the result. "This is a good first step toward restoring credibility in the electoral process, and these results correspond" to early findings of election trends, James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said in Washington.
He added, "We urge the government of Peru and its electoral authorities to take every possible step to ensure that the next round of voting fully meets the standards of openness, transparency and fairness."
Mr. Stein's unremitting public criticism of unexplained delays in the handling and computing of vote tallies proved to be a decisive element in breaking Mr. Fujimori's international support. And the Organization of American States proved itself able to ease a domestic crisis among its member states, something it has rarely been able to do.
As the results trickled in this week, and election monitors raised many charges of improprieties, diplomats at the Organization of American States already had begun discussing economic and political sanctions to reverse the vote, and if necessary, to strip the government of its recognition.
Mr. Toledo, a 54-year-old business school professor, said this week that he would accept nothing short of a runoff, and promised to lead nonstop demonstrations culminating in a national strike on Friday if Mr. Fujimori were declared the winner.
But now there will be a runoff. Election officials said the uncounted votes could add five-hundredths of 1 percent at most to Mr. Fujimori's total, leaving him still shy of 50 percent.
Mr. Fujimori had no immediate comment tonight. Mr. Toledo boasted that demonstrations over the last three days had stopped Mr. Fujimori from stealing the election, and that the mostly peaceful marches across Peru had moved the international community to back democracy in Peru.
Jose Portillo, the head of the national election commission, dismissed that contention, telling the news media that reports of computer and vote fraud were proved false by the results.
"You can think what you like," Mr. Portillo said. "It was impossible to falsify or adulterate the results."
But in a news conference tonight, Mr. Toledo contended that he had obtained information from an insider in the election process that as of 7:30 p.m. on Sunday night, vote tallies gathered by the government showed him with 56.8 percent of the vote. He said the official count was falsified, and demanded that all senior election officials be replaced.
"The international community has played a critical role in defense of democracy," he said. "I expect them to continue monitoring the election."
Mr. Toledo repeated his demand tonight that all the networks open their airwaves to the opposition and that dirty campaign tricks be halted.
Such tactics, like microphones that went dead at opposition rallies, egg-throwing mobs meeting opposition candidates, and smear campaigns orchestrated in the press, came under intense criticism by the Organization of American States, the Atlanta-based Carter Center and several international teams of election observers.
"Now we will show the world that Peru can hold a clean process," Mr. Toledo told the throng in downtown Lima tonight, one of many that gathered expectantly in cities across Peru. "I want to be clear that I will be respectful of the institutions of democracy."
Throughout the day, international pressure mounted on President Fujimori to hold a second round of voting rather than declare an outright majority.
Thomas R. Pickering, the United States under secretary of state for political affairs, called Prime Minister Alberto Bustamante to say that United States relations with Peru would be seriously strained if a second round were not held.
"The conversations have been stark but decent," a State Department official said. "There is no doubt in our minds they know the way we feel."
The ambassadors of France, Britain and several other European nations also said there was enough evidence of fraud -- including pre-marked ballots and a series of unexplained counting delays -- to require a second round to ensure the credibility of the next government.
But senior Latin American diplomats here expressed concern about the tough language by Mr. Pickering and other American officials. Several cabinet officials complained openly of blatant interference in Peru's internal affairs.
The pressure, however, seemed to be effective.
The Lima government appeared to be testing a nationalist response to the international pressures when Mr. Fujimori's running mate, Francisco Tudela, scolded foreign governments and news media on Tuesday night for conspiring to ignore the will of the Peruvian people and push an election result to their liking.
"We've never had this kind of international intervention in our political process before," Mr. Tudela said in a television interview, which was repeatedly broadcast on a pro-government channel today. "We are not a banana republic. We Peruvians need to defend our national sovereignty."
Foreign diplomats said the government had at least an unofficial count of all votes by early this morning, when it completed tallying ballots from Peruvians living abroad and from distant jungles and Andean Indian villages. They said Mr. Fujimori's most senior aides spent the day reviewing the results.
The Japanese ambassador, Yoshizo Konishi, had a long meeting today with Mr. Stein, who has been criticizing what he sees as blatant irregularities in the vote count.
Mr. Fujimori, whose parents were Japanese immigrants and who speaks Japanese, has looked to Japan for economic and political aid in virtually all of the crises he has faced. During a 1993 coup attempt, he sought refuge in the Japanese Embassy, and he frequently travels to Tokyo seeking economic aid.
Facing off in this political crisis were two men with very different leadership styles. While Mr. Toledo appeared to be an improviser, Mr. Fujimori took his time, kept only his closest advisers informed of his thinking, and apparently made his decisions at the last possible moment.
Since the election Sunday, Mr. Fujimori had said little, while allowing the opposition to take to the streets in Lima and other cities.
He showed the same patient style in his handling of his last big crisis, when terrorists seized the Japanese ambassador's residence and hundreds of hostages in 1997. For days, even as Tupac Amaru rebels threatened to kill hostages and held his mother and half brother, Mr. Fujimori said nothing. He consistently resisted international pressure to negotiate seriously with the rebels and to allow them to find asylum in Cuba.
Finally, he ordered the storming of the building, wiping out all 14 rebels and saving all but 1 hostage, who died of a heart attack during the rescue.
For his part, Mr. Toledo appeared to be an unpredictable leader whose style and rhetoric could change from hour to hour. There were times, usually during the day, when he donned double-breasted suits and looked like the business school professor and former World Bank official that he is. It was then that he spoke like a statesman, saying he did not intend to "put fuel on the fire," warning against violence and declaring himself a follower of the tactics of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and Mohandas Gandhi.
Before tonight, when speaking before large crowds -- and the crowds grew with each day this week -- his oratory became far more heated. "There is no tank or missile," he told a throng Tuesday night, "that can silence the voice of the people."
Mr. Toledo was a midlevel economic adviser in the Peruvian government in the early 1980's, but he has never held a high leadership position. As the son of a bricklayer and a mother who sold fish in a street market, and as a former shoeshine boy himself, he can be fiery in support of the disadvantaged.
After winning a scholarship with the help of some Peace Corps volunteers, he studied at the University of San Francisco in the 1960's, when social revolution was brewing. He speaks of those days of protest with nostalgia.
But tonight, in victory, he remained cool and measured in his reactions, and uncharacteristically, he put back on his suit at his triumphant news conference, and promised he would reinstitute democracy and an independent justice system in Peru.

HEADLINE: Senate Chief May Consider Indian Casino For Catskills

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 12

 BODY:
The Republican leader of the State Senate said today that he might take up a measure that would allow an Indian casino to be opened in the Catskills, potentially moving the state closer to approving the disputed plan.
The comments by Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, come nearly a week after the United States Department of the Interior granted the St. Regis Mohawk tribe permission to open a $500 million casino in the Catskills, provided that the state also approves the plan. 
 Gov. George E. Pataki, a strong proponent of casino gambling, has maintained that he has the authority to approve such a plan on behalf of the state. But he has also proposed a bill seeking approval from the Legislature for casinos in resort areas like the Catskills.
Mr. Bruno's comments are significant because he has been extremely reluctant to consider such gambling measures in the past, given the intense opposition that such proposals face from antigambling groups like the Roman Catholic Church and the state's Conservative Party.
More than that, Mr. Bruno had been adamantly opposed to the governor's bill for constitutional reasons. He took exception to a provision that would permit slot machines in Indian casinos, saying that the State Constitution forbids slot machines.
In an interview this afternoon, he reiterated his opposition to the provision in the bill that would allow slot machines on Indian reservations. But he said he would consider taking up the measure as long as that provision was removed. "I'm looking at it because we may take some action," he said, adding that "the biggest question we have is the constitutionality" of allowing slot machines.
The Interior Department's decision helped clear the way for the Mohawks to eventually operate a $500 million casino in the Catskill community of Monticello, where officials and business leaders hope that gambling may bolster the economy of a fading resort area once known as the borscht belt.
The plan calls for the Mohawks to operate the casino on a 30-acre parcel that was put in trust for the tribe, whose reservation is on the Canadian border. The casino, which would be only 90 miles from New York City, is expected to employ 3,000 people and draw 9 million visitors a year.
Mr. Pataki has long said that Indian casinos could be a boon for struggling resort regions like the Catskills and Niagara Falls. But his actions have caused a great deal of confusion.
For example, only a few days after a judge threw out two lawsuits challenging the governor's right to approve gambling projects on Indian land, Mr. Pataki filed a bill to require approval from the Legislature for Indian gambling initiatives.
It is unclear what the Legislature's role will ultimately be. The governor may still push for his bill to be adopted by the Legislature. But there are those here who believe that he may ultimately approve the Monticello casino after the Legislature's members leave Albany for the summer.
The Democratic speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver, has repeatedly said he favors opening casinos in the Catskills and other resort areas, and he has pushed legislation through his chamber that would permit casino gambling in the state.

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety;
By Some Measures, Highway Deaths Fall

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE preliminary statistics for highway deaths in 1999 are out, and they show substantial safety progress, if you look at them the way the Department of Transportation does. Looking differently at the same numbers, though, some safety analysts see stagnation.
And buried in the numbers are some contradictory trends. 
 According to the report, released earlier this month by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the number of people killed in vehicle accidents last year was 41,345, down from 41,471 in 1998, a 0.3 percent reduction.
A drop of 126 people out of more than 40,000 may not sound like a success, but the Transportation Department called that an improvement when measured by vehicle miles traveled: The 1999 rate was 1.5 deaths per 100 million vehicle miles traveled; the rate in 1998 was 1.6 deaths per 100 million miles.
Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater said the drop in the death rate was historic. "This continued reduction in traffic fatalities is encouraging news," he said in a statement. "Safety is President Clinton's and Vice President Gore's highest transportation priority, and these statistics show that our commitment to safety is paying huge dividends."
Over time, the number of deaths per 100 million miles is down sharply; 20 years ago it was 3.4, or more than twice the current rate, and 30 years ago it was 4.7, or three times what it is now.
But the actual number of fatalities is shrinking far more slowly. For each year of the 1990's, it has varied from 39,250 to 44,599. The rate is dropping because vehicle miles traveled jumps by about 2 percent each year, now approaching 2.7 trillion miles, up from 2.6 trillion last year, and 1.8 trillion in 1970. "The number of deaths could be stable or rising and you divide by this huge number, and it looks like things are always getting better," said Dr. Robert A. Scopatz, a statistician and road safety expert at Data Nexus Inc., a public safety consulting firm in Kissimmee, Fla. "It's always going to look like an improvement, because vehicle miles traveled rises."
Mr. Scopatz said the statistical method used by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, called the Fatality Analysis Reporting System, produced the best data available. But he added that vehicle miles traveled -- an estimate based on states counting cars at various spots -- was not the ideal number on which to make safety calculations. A better method for measuring safety, he said, would use the number of people miles -- meaning the total number of miles that people travel, whether alone or with others -- although currently there is no way to measure that. (Mr. Scopatz said he was also curious about the number of deaths per million cell phone calls.)
The preliminary numbers, some reached on the basis of direct counting and others through sampling, show that the total number of crashes reported to the police, 6.3 million, is also down, by about 0.7 percent. But the number of injuries, for reasons that are not clear, rose to 3.2 million, an increase of about 8,000, or 0.3 percent.
New cars that include more safety features and the wider use of seat belts may be reducing fatalities, and thus increasing the number of people who are counted as injured, but that shift likely represents hundreds, not thousands, of people. Stephanie Faul, a spokeswoman for the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety, said better emergency medical care has also spared lives, if not injuries.
One category that experienced disappointing results was motorcycle fatalities, which reached 2,537 last year, up 11 percent from 1998. The 1998 number was about 8 percent higher than 1997.
Again, no one is sure why. Julie Rochman, a spokeswoman for the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, said, "In a good economy, more people may be purchasing motorcycles as a toy." And, she said, helmet laws were being relaxed. Further analysis may show whether the death rate is highest in states that have eased their helmet laws.
And continuing to fuel the debate over higher speed limits, the transportation department's preliminary 1999 data showed that the number of deaths on roads with posted speed limits of 55 and above rose by 2 percent, and the number on roads with speed limits below 55 fell by 3 percent.
On its face, that makes it sound like faster highway traffic is causing more deaths. But there are complicating factors. According to Dr. Steven A. Bloch, a researcher at the Automobile Club of Southern California, an AAA affiliate, higher freeway speed limits are inducing drivers to change their routes from back roads to the interstates, increasing traffic there, and, as a result, the number of accidents. And the federal data did not account for the miles of roadway where the speed limit was shifted from under 55 to 55 or over.
If a past pattern holds, the number of deaths in 2000 might be significantly lower: Deaths dropped sharply in 1974, 1980 and 1992 -- years when the price of gasoline spiked. But some people think the consumer reaction to the current increase in gas prices will not be so strong.
Shashi S. Nambisan, a professor of civil engineering at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, said the scarcity of fuel could make people drive less or slower. Still, she added, "I don't think a significant portion of the population is driving significantly less."
 
2 Views on Side-Impact Air Bags
In an echo of the crisis over air bags killing or injuring children in the front passenger seat, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said last October that side-impact air bags on the rear seats could also be a hazard to children. And since parents were being urged to put children in the back seat to keep them away from the front air bags, the carmakers who offer side-impact air bags in the rear seats should ship those cars with the bags disabled, the agency said, leaving it to the buyer and the dealer to decide if they should be activated.
The reaction has been mixed.
A spokesman for BMW, Karl-Heinz Ziwica, said his company had shipped cars that way even before the October letter from the safety agency. But at Mercedes-Benz USA, James M. Resnick, a spokesman, said, "It's our belief that the rear side air bags provide a very significant safety benefit, both for adults and children." Children should be in appropriate seats or booster seats, he said, and if they are properly positioned, there is no threat to them." Based on that position, Mercedes ships its cars with the side air bags activated.
Only "a very small handful" of buyers have asked to have the bags deactivated, Mr. Resnick said.

HEADLINE: Poor Nations Seek Sharing of Global Wealth

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HAVANA, April 13

 BODY:
Third world leaders met behind closed doors today to find ways to persuade the globe's economic powers to share the wealth.
Beyond trying to shame industrialized nations into action with sobering statistics, leaders at the Group of 77 summit meeting sought common ground among themselves. 
 Since its founding in 1964, the Group of 77 has grown to to include 133 developing countries.
Leaders are committed to "real results," said Venezuela's president, Hugo Chavez.
Forty foreign ministers in Havana urged the United Nations to take a more active role in economic development and technology transfers to poorer nations.
"The only way to improve our lot as developing countries is to ask for a fair share in the U.N.'s decision-making process," said the ministers, mostly from Africa, Latin America, the Middle East and Asia.
Within the United Nations, the Security Council -- the only body with the power to enforce its decisions, has 5 permanent members -- the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China -- and 10 whose terms rotate every two years.
The United States and France favor adding five permanent seats -- Japan, Germany and one each from Asia, Africa and Latin America selected by the regional groups. Many nations oppose expansion, saying permanent members' veto power would freeze decision-making.

HEADLINE: Wake Up and Smell the Profits;
A Singaporean Sees the World as His Coffee Cup

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, April 13

 BODY:
In the shadow of some dreary public housing developments, 16-year-old April Ong is whiling away another sweltering afternoon with friends at the Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf cafe, chatting about boys and nursing an icy coffee milkshake that cost the equivalent of $2.50.
Only a few years ago, the fanciest coffee around here cost 40 cents and looked like motor oil cut with a dollop of Elmer's glue. This syrupy concoction can still be had at old-fashioned kopi tiams all over Singapore. But just as in America, teenagers like Ms. Ong and older upwardly mobile workers nowadays flock to trendy cafes to ponder dating or dot-coms over pricey coffee concoctions. 
 "Here, it's very high class," said Ms. Ong, who was wearing a pair of blue-lensed sunglasses to match her mobile phone. "The kopi tiam is very low class. It's for those uncles and aunties."
A principal agent for the change is Victor Sassoon, 42. In 1996, Mr. Sassoon, a Singaporean entrepreneur and former rock concert promoter, bought the Asian franchise for Coffee Bean, a chain of gourmet coffee shops based in Los Angeles and then little-known outside southern California. The stores he opened were very successful and Mr. Sassoon thought the Coffee Bean brand and its signature ice-blended coffee milkshakes were very hot. So in late 1998 he turned around and bought the American parent company, International Coffee & Tea L.L.C., from its founders -- a move analysts say is highly unusual.
Mr. Sassoon now has 32 outlets here and 21 in Malaysia; the company expects to generate more than $100 million in worldwide sales this year. This month, it opened the first Coffee Bean in Taiwan. And with an eye on the success of Starbucks, Mr. Sassoon plans to expand across the United States and even take Coffee Bean public.
"In America, we're really going to roll," Mr. Sassoon said as he sipped a black coffee in an office filled with posters from pop tours he brought to Southeast Asia, autographed by stars including Alanis Morrisette, Phil Collins and Michael Jackson.
Fittingly, Mr. Sassoon's foray into coffee owes much to another pop singer, Paula Abdul. Mr. Sassoon and his wife, Michelle, promoted Ms. Abdul's tour to Southeast Asia in 1992. Three years later, while the Sassoons were in Los Angeles visiting Victor's brother Sunny, they met Ms. Abdul at the Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf in Beverly Hills. Coffee Bean had already earned a reputation in southern California for a celebrity clientele that included the actors Jennifer Aniston, Tom Cruise and Bruce Willis.
Mr. Sassoon mentioned he was considering bringing Coffee Bean to Singapore. "Guys," Ms. Abdul recalls telling them, "this is the greatest product in the world. You've got to get this company." Mr. Sassoon was sold.
It was a good time to bring a new brand to Singapore. Asia's economic boom was fueling a taste for anything imported. In Singapore, a handful of companies were already catering to the newfound taste for expensive blends among well-traveled urbanites. Within months of opening the first Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf, Singapore's first Starbucks opened, only 600 yards away. There are now 21 Starbucks outlets here -- and 226 throughout the Asia-Pacific, with plans for a total of 500 in the region by the end of 2003.
Coffee Bean was founded in 1963 by Herbert and Mona Hyman, and quickly became something of a Southern California institution. Its 1987 addition of the ice-blends multiplied its popularity, but Mr. Sassoon said it took months to persuade the Hymans, who had never taken their brand much beyond Los Angeles, that expanding abroad was a good idea.
Born in Singapore to an Iraqi-Jewish family and raised in Jakarta, Mr. Sassoon got his first taste for retailing when he inherited his father's business importing designer watches in 1984. He still runs the exclusive franchise for Cartier in Indonesia. Next was a chain of stores carrying a line of Disney baby merchandise, a franchise Mr. Sassoon and his wife ran until 1998.
In 1990, they began promoting big-name events, starting out with the illusionist David Copperfield. But Asia's financial crisis erased Singapore from the pop tour map. In 1998, Billy Joel, Elton John and U2 all canceled visits here, and Mr. Sassoon took it as a sign that it was time to get out of the concert business. "Boy bands have taken over from megastars anyway," he said. And the newcomers, he added, "don't even last long enough to get them here."
Mr. Sassoon also saw the writing on the wall for franchise operators.
"The world's getting so small," he said. "The licensing business is dead." So he approached the Hymans, then in their 70's, with a new offer: he and his brother would take the company off their hands. In December 1998, the Sassoons bought the company for an amount they declined to disclose.
The Sassoons are less shy about their plans to expand in the United States. From 60 outlets in Southern California, they plan to add 50 this year in California, Nevada and Arizona, according to Sunny Sassoon, and may even venture as far as Chicago or New York. The company has consulted investment bankers and may try to spin off the Asian operations of Coffee Bean this year; it may also later try to list the United States company.
("Well heck, I should get some credit for that," said the Sassoon's surprised original consultant, Ms. Abdul.)
Emulating the continental spread of Starbucks -- which has more than 2,800 outlets worldwide and which last year had $1.7 billion in sales -- will mean succeeding where other coffee chains have failed, analysts warn. "It is a very difficult thing to do," said Scott Waltmann of Merrill Lynch in New York. With labor markets so tight, adding new stores eventually means sacrificing service, he said.
Back in Singapore, Coffee Bean's rivalry with Starbucks seems more evenly matched, though neither will say much about the competition. The most pressure is on Singapore's own incumbents, the traditional kopi tiams. These noisy, open-air cafes, were once as central to Singapore's traditional neighborhood and village life as the small-town American diner or the English pub.
Among the godowns, or warehouses, and villages of Singapore 30 years ago, the kopi tiam was not only a place to get a hot drink or quick meal from the hawker stalls but also served as both neighborhood watch center and fire station. In a city where very few could afford a newspaper and even fewer could read, the kopi tiam was a place to share a newspaper or hear it read out loud.
Pang Eng Fong, 56, remembers growing up above his grandfather's busy kopi tiam among the rubber godowns along the Singapore River after World War II.
The kopi tiam burned down in the 1960's and, like Singapore, Mr. Pang has moved onward and upward. After earning his doctorate in economics from the University of Illinois in 1971, he is now Singapore's ambassador to Britain. Where the shop once stood, trendy clubs operate out of restored buildings. Abandoned godowns are being pulled down to make way for Mediterranean-style piazzas and bars with names like Tivoli and Bar Celona.
The old kopi tiam may not have had electricity or indoor plumbing, Mr. Pang said, but "there was a sense of community that I think is hard to define now."
There are still plenty of other kopi tiams in town even today. Not far from where Ambassador Pang grew up, his cousin Pang Peng Bee, 55, serves up as many as 700 cups of coffee a day at his Tanglin First Stop Coffee Shop. Coffee here is prepared not in a gleaming espresso machine but by pouring pitchers of scalding water mixed with powdered grounds through a sort of sock.
Most of Singapore's old kopi tiams moved into food courts in the 1960's and 1970's as old neighborhoods and villages were demolished to make way for bland public housing. Where Ms. Ong's favorite Coffee Bean stands, for example, was a village of pepper and pineapple farmers. As the city grew richer in the 1980's, food courts abandoned the tropical heat for air-conditioned shopping malls.
Now, per capita incomes are on par with many parts of Western Europe, and mass-market consumer goods are not enough for the status-conscious Singaporean. Wine bars, cigar bars (Cubans only, please), organic food shops and microbreweries have all begun to proliferate. Dining outdoors, once considered plebeian, is now called alfresco.
Starbucks, too, has upmarket hopes here. "Starbucks is a place where people want to meet," said Loh Jee Fang, a marketing executive at the company's franchise operator, BonStar Pte. Ltd. "It's a destination in itself."
When Mr. Sassoon opened the first Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf in Singapore in November 1996, the local newspaper ran a coffee glossary complete with pronunciation key. The chain's popularity was undiminished by Asia's financial crisis: sitting in cafes became a relatively cheap alternative to shopping and traveling. In late 1997, Mr. Sassoon expanded to Malaysia.
The beans are roasted in California and shipped out in vacuum-sealed packs. Coffee Bean's baristas, mostly teenagers, are taught strict quality control, relying on a timer to make sure they pull every shot of espresso with just the right amount of crema. They mix the coffee with milk in a glass, Mr. Sassoon said, so they can monitor the mixture by its color.
Of course, not everyone is won over. Holding a cup of Mr. Pang's muddy brew between inch-long fingernails, Stephen Chiok, a 37-year-old telephone technician, says he is one of the many ordinary folks uninterested in coffee served "where they have all the test tubes and whatnot." At this kopi tiam, the barista is a balding man in flip-flops and a threadbare white T-shirt with 30 years of experience. Another self-styled kopi purist, 60-year-old Poon Luan Yak, scoffed, "Starbucks -- that's for youngsters."
Indeed, Ms. Ong acknowledges that her taste for coffee never ventures beyond the ice-blendeds. These frosty coffee-flavored smoothies account for roughly 40 percent of Coffee Bean's overall sales, according to Mr. Sassoon. The only special skill required to make one is the ability to mix the prescribed ratio of coffee syrup, milk and ice in a blender.
"There's no style here," said one Coffee Bean barista as he pureed yet another ice-blended. "The blender is my style."

HEADLINE: U.S. Retail Sales Remain Strong; Wholesale Prices Jump 1 Percent

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Sales by retailers were surprisingly strong in March, while soaring energy costs caused a spike in wholesale prices, the government said today in reports that reinforced the expectation of more increases in interest rates.
The Commerce Department said retail sales increased 0.4 percent to a seasonally adjusted $269.2 billion last month, and, excluding a slump in new cars after four straight months of big sales gains, were ahead 1.4 percent. That followed upwardly revised sales gains of 1.8 percent in February and 0.7 percent in January, underscoring the powerful thrust the economic expansion is receiving from consumer spending, which fuels two-thirds of national economic activity. 
 "Nothing seems to slow the consumer down," said Joel Naroff, an economist at Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa. "Spending in the first quarter was once again out of this world."
The report triggered some selling in Treasuries but had little effect on stock markets.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said that the Producer Price Index jumped 1 percent in March, matching February's increase, but that the closely watched core rate, which strips out volatile energy and food costs, added only 0.1 percent, down from 0.3 percent in February.
Analysts said the rise in wholesale prices was not threatening because so much of it could be traced to energy costs that appear to have peaked or to be near a peak. Imported oil prices hit $32 a barrel in mid-March, but on Monday were down to $23.85 after an agreement on March 28 by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase output.
The retail sales report showed strong March spending increases on a wide range of goods, from building materials to clothing to food and drugstore items.
With the spring construction season at hand, March sales of building materials rose 3.8 percent, to $15.97 billion, more than recovering from a 1.5 percent dip in February.
Reflecting higher prices, gasoline sales rose 4 percent, to $18.32 billion, after soaring 6.8 percent in February. For the year ended March 31, gas prices climbed 31.2 percent, the biggest annual rise in nearly two decades, the Commerce Department said.
Although the producer prices report indicated only muted price increases for goods aside from food and energy, reports from a business economists' group indicated that there were pressures in the pipeline that might eventually pass through to consumers.
The economists' group, the National Association for Business Economics, said its latest survey found a growing willingness by producers to push prices up during the first quarter after years of restraint.
"We have seen a distinct upward shift in pricing momentum in recent months, particularly in the ability of firms to realize planned price increases," said Diane Swonk, president of the association and chief economist for the Bank One Corporation in Chicago.

HEADLINE: General Motors Says Profit Fell Slightly in First Quarter

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 13

 BODY:
General Motors announced today that its profits fell slightly in the first quarter as an unexpected turnaround in its international operations was not enough to offset unusually heavy discounting in the United States and rising costs at its Hughes Electronics subsidiary.
G.M.'s earnings from continuing operations edged down 2 percent, to $1.78 billion, compared with $1.82 billion in the quarter a year earlier. But because the automaker has been steadily buying back stock, its earnings per share actually climbed, to $2.80 from $2.68 in the quarter a year earlier. 
 Analysts had expected the company to earn $2.66 a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. Shares edged up 50 cents, to $88.
For the last three years, G.M. has earned ever higher profits from its North American automotive operations while struggling to prevent earnings from disappearing entirely overseas. G.M. reversed that pattern in the first quarter.
Its European automotive operations posted a 27 percent increase in profits while its Latin American and East Asian operations moved back into the black after suffering losses a year ago. G.M.'s huge Brazilian operations, one of the newest and most efficient auto divisions in the world, became modestly profitable again, as did G.M.'s new joint venture in Shanghai, where a factory has been producing Buicks for less than a year.
But earnings slipped 8.4 percent at G.M.'s North American division, which represents the bulk of the company's sales and profits, even though the United States auto market was running at its highest seasonally adjusted rate of sales ever in the first quarter.
G.M. continued raising sticker prices slightly in the first quarter but offered so many discounts that the average price for which it was able to sell a vehicle actually declined 0.7 percent, excluding changes in the types of vehicles and how they were equipped, said Michael Losh, G.M.'s chief financial officer. He said that it was premature to conclude whether G.M.'s earnings in the coming quarters would also depend more on foreign results and less on the United States.
"We expect to have continued strong results in 2000, and that'll be driven by strong demand in the U.S. and Europe particularly," Mr. Losh said. He predicted that the industry's sales in the United States would be 17.3 million to 17.7 million vehicles this year, a torrid pace and an increase from G.M.'s previous estimates that the industry would sell about 17 million vehicles this year.
Wall Street analysts had a mixed reaction to G.M.'s earnings. David Bradley, an auto analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities, said that he had expected the strength of the American auto market to do more for G.M.'s bottom line.
"I'm questioning that thesis of whether they're going to be able to take advantage of this cyclical boom and make more money," he said.
But Mr. Bradley also expressed enthusiasm about G.M.'s improvement overseas, saying that the company would benefit in the long term from being less dependent on the United States market. "There's more stability, predictability and breadth" in the earnings, he said.
In a conference call this morning with analysts and reporters, Mr. Losh warned that G.M.'s 49 percent stake in Isuzu Motors of Japan would result in a loss of about $100 million in the second quarter. While G.M. has already recognized the pension costs that will cause Isuzu to post a loss for the year ended March 31, Isuzu is also trying to reduce its excessive inventory in Japan at a time when demand is slow, particularly for Isuzu's heavy trucks, Mr. Losh said. G.M. expects that profits elsewhere in the company will make up for the loss at Isuzu and allow the company to meet analysts' forecasts for the quarter, he added.
G.M.'s revenue rose 10 percent in the first quarter, to $46.9 billion from $42.4 billion in the period a year earlier. G.M.'s net income fell to $1.78 billion from $2.06 billion, but almost all of this drop reflected the spinoff last May of the company's auto parts unit, Delphi Automotive Systems; as a result, Delphi's profits were included in the first quarter last year, but not this year.
The G.M. earnings today included a $77 million loss by Hughes, compared with a $78 million gain a year ago. Hughes, which had heavy promotional and equipment costs to add 405,000 new subscribers to its DirectTV service, announced its results separately on Wednesday.
G.M.'s auto financing arm, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, earned $397 million, up from $392 million a year earlier. Automakers' lending divisions tend to fare poorly when short-term interest rates are rising, as they have been this spring. But the division has had little problem with debtors' staying current with their bills, Mr. Losh said, probably because of the strong economy.

HEADLINE: G.E. Reports Strong Revenue In First Quarter

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
General Electric, benefiting from resurgent global economies and its push into e-commerce, announced robust first-quarter revenue and earnings yesterday.
For the quarter ended March 31, the company's revenue surged to $30 billion, up 24 percent from $24.2 billion in the period a year earlier. Net income rose to $2.6 billion, or 78 cents a diluted share, a 20 percent rise compared with the $2.16 billion, or 65 cents a share, earned in the quarter a year earlier. 
 The solid performance surprised no one. In March, in a preannouncement that was highly unusual for G.E., the company told analysts that its earnings would most likely hit 77 cents a share, 2 cents more than the company and Wall Street had predicted. G.E. beat that by a penny.
"Matching or beating by no more than a penny, that's typical of G.E.," said Charles L. Hill, director of research at First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks analysts' recommendations. "They have a great investor relations policy, which is that there should be few surprises."
Shareholders seemed unimpressed, though. Shares of G.E., which had soared in March on the promise of 77-cents-a-share earnings, fell on the reality of 78 cents yesterday. The stock closed at $150, down $6.625. G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., plans to split its stock 3 for 1 later this month.
For the first time in a long time, G.E.'s industrial businesses grew as fast -- and in some cases, even faster -- than GE Capital, its huge finance arm. Airlines stepped up ordering jet engines this year, and GE Aircraft Engines won more than half the orders. GE Medical Systems received $50 million in orders for two new digital X-ray machines.
Revenue at GE Power Systems rose nearly 90 percent as utilities scrambled to meet the rising energy needs of a booming economy.
"The tremendous surge in demand for power gave Power Systems an absolutely blowout quarter," said Kent A. Newcomb, an analyst with A. G. Edwards.
All of G.E.'s businesses benefited from G.E.'s Six Sigma program, a complicated quality control plan that G.E. expects will yield $2.5 billion in savings this year. G.E.'s Six Sigma specialists have begun to help customers cut their own costs; the help is free, but analysts say that grateful customers are responding with larger and longer-term contracts.
"G.E. has made customer focus its mantra, and that is resulting in real dividends," said Nicholas P. Heymann, an analyst with Prudential Securities.
G.E.'s 18-month-old effort to harness the power of the Internet has also begun to yield results. Power Systems sold more than $120 million in parts through its new Web site, GEPartsEdge.com. Last month GE Medical Systems joined with four other companies to form the Global Healthcare Exchange, an online marketplace for health care products and services.
G.E. has not yet quantified the effect its move onto the Web has had on its bottom line. "But we know it's there, we know it's real, we know it's electrifying the company and having tangible results," said Gary Sheffer, a G.E. spokesman.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Investors Are Puzzled by Stock Woes

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that he views investors in the gyrating financial markets of the last few weeks as having been "groping" for the proper valuations of stocks, especially those of technology companies.
In an appearance on Capitol Hill, Mr. Greenspan also urged Congress and financial regulators not to overreact to technology-driven changes in the ways that stocks are traded. 
 And while he said nothing to suggest that the central bank will not continue to raise interest rates in coming months, he said he saw no signs that inflation is becoming embedded in the economy, despite the 1 percent rise reported today in the producer price index for March.
Testifying before the Senate Banking Committee a day after the Nasdaq composite index officially entered a bear market, Mr. Greenspan suggested that the stock market's ups and downs of late have been the result not of rampant speculation, a herd mentality or even the Fed's own interest rate increases. Rather, he said, it reflected a natural effort on the part of investors to make sense of the ways in which technology is altering business and the economy.
He said the surge in technology stocks over the last few years had been driven by continually upgraded earnings estimates.
"Because these judgments are so difficult to make, we are also getting a high degree of instability and volatility," Mr. Greenspan said. "So I think what's happening is the markets are groping for the correct balance underlying the system."
Mr. Greenspan added, however, that he would "scarcely want to get involved in the exercise of trying to determine at what point the prices should stabilize."
The Fed chairman also ducked a question about whether stock prices have fallen sufficiently to allay his concerns about the "wealth effect," the tendency of consumers to spend a portion of any money they make on their investments. Mr. Greenspan has frequently described the wealth effect as one of the major causes of potentially inflationary imbalances in the economy.
But he noted that even after the sharp fall in the Nasdaq and the smaller declines in other market gauges, stock prices over all were still ahead of where they were a year ago.
Faced with questions about whether he was "jawboning" the stock market down, Mr. Greenspan insistently said he was not. And he again emphasized that the Fed's five quarter point interest rate increases over the last year were not aimed at the stock market but at supporting the higher long-term rates being set in the credit markets.
For the Fed to have left unchanged the short term rates it controls during a period when market rates were rising, Mr. Greenspan said, would have required the central bank to inject money into the financial system. In that sense, trying to hold its rates down would have been inflationary.
In Mr. Greenspan's view, many of the same forces generating uncertainty among investors are reshaping the structure of the stock exchanges.
The rise of alternative trading systems -- so-called electronic communications networks -- is not only posing a challenge to the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq, but also raising concerns among regulators about a fragmentation of the equity markets.
To the degree that markets are broken up into chunks that do not allow buyers and sellers to get a complete picture of bid and ask prices, the rise of new trading systems threatened to make markets less efficient, less liquid and more apt to shortchange the investor, he said.
Mr. Greenspan said such concerns were justified, but he put his faith in competition to offer investors an improved service.
Even the New York Stock Exchange could become marginalized if it did not respond, he said. Fragmentation of the marketplace would be a "necessary consequence of the process of competition" that probably "cannot be avoided entirely."
From a regulatory perspective, Mr. Greenspan said, the government should let the marketplace work it out.

HEADLINE: Serbia's Bickering Opposition Plans Rally Against Milosevic

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, April 13

 BODY:
Serbia's political opposition, superficially united after months of squabbling and pressure from the West, will hold a major political rally here on Friday but with no hope of pushing President Slobodan Milosevic out of power anytime soon.
With unclear goals and few specific plans for what to do next, the opposition hopes the rally will give voice to the widespread dissatisfaction with Mr. Milosevic, but no longer expects to attain its original aim of forcing early elections at all levels. Still, opposition leaders say pressure for elections is the most efficient and least risky tactic they could find. 
 "We're pressing for early elections -- what else can we do?" said Ognjen Pribicevic, chief adviser to the dominant opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic of the Serbian Renewal Movement. "Our only weapon is elections, elections. This rally will be a big 'no' to the regime and to state terrorism and a big 'yes' to elections. But after a million quarrels, we will be united on stage for the first time since 1997."
The rally will call for elections with no expectation of having even local elections before autumn. And the organizers also don't expect the crucial Serbian elections, which will not take place until at least the summer or autumn of 2001 -- after the Clinton administration has left office -- to result in any quick or peaceful transfer of power.
Speaking privately, they say their main hope is that a good showing by a relatively united opposition -- say, 10 or more percentage points better than the ruling coalition in the Serbian elections -- would lead the Milosevic regime to finally crack apart.
Moreover, the rally will not erase the festering fissures within the opposition, and its central dilemma: while most Serbs don't like Mr. Milosevic, they don't like this generation of opposition leaders much either.
Even Zoran Djindjic, who heads the Democratic Party and has had a long-running rivalry with Mr. Draskovic, acknowledges that opposition leaders have a credibility problem that is rooted in political failure. And new faces are also having a hard time. Mr. Djindjic's popular young deputy, Slobodan Vuksanovic, challenged him for the party leadership when Mr. Djindjic did not resign his post in January, as he had promised to do if Mr. Milosevic remained in office.
Mr. Djindjic, organizing a trip to Washington and a brief meeting with President Clinton just before the party convention, barely beat off Mr. Vuksanovic's challenge. Mr. Djindjic has since moved harshly to rid the party of Mr. Vuksanovic's main supporters.
"Djindjic staying contributes to the sense of a frozen political system, and a frozen political system is what Milosevic wants," Mr. Vuksanovic said. "People are very angry with the Milosevic regime, but they don't trust the opposition."
Radomir Diklic, who runs the independent news agency, Beta, says the opposition needs new faces and a change of generation, and notes that one such fresh face, 36-year-old Goran Svilanovic, is running advertisements to promote himself that way. "There's no energy, no self-confidence and lost credibility," Mr. Diklic said. "Maybe 80 percent of the population are unhappy with the present situation, but maybe 60 percent are not happy voting for this opposition."
The rivalry between Mr. Djindjic and Mr. Draskovic is legendary, and stems from their broken alliance in 1997, when the opposition won the last local elections and Mr. Milosevic's effort to rob them of the victory brought hundreds of thousands of protesters onto the streets every day for three months.
But Mr. Djindjic's efforts to overthrow Mr. Milosevic through daily rallies last summer and fall, after the loss of Kosovo in the war, were a clear failure. Mr. Draskovic's strategy to force the regime into having early elections on all levels -- local, federal and state -- has also failed.
"Our unity is produced by these two failures," said Mr. Svilanovic, the leader of the Civic Alliance, a small party in the Alliance for Change that Mr. Djindjic's party dominates and that Mr. Draskovic refused to join.
With Mr. Draskovic again dominant, the formally allied opposition announced on Jan. 10 that it would have a rally by the end of March to press for early elections. There was so much infighting about whether to have such a rally, who would speak, in what order and on what topics that Mr. Svilanovic said the other day that he was "ashamed" of the opposition.
With the rally now going ahead on Friday, April 14, the joke is that it will take place on the "45th day of March." But there are few hopes that it will have any major impact, unless it turns violent, and real concerns that it will simply disappoint normal citizens who will attend and want a clear strategy for change.
The rally is being held on the Square of the Republic, which will look packed with even 50,000 people.
"In January, the rally was part of our common strategy for early elections," Mr. Svilanovic said. "Then it became an issue on its own, without a strategy, to show unity. But it must be followed by some action to show people that we are alive."
Srdjan Bogosavljevic, a respected pollster who runs the Strategic Marketing and Media Research Institute, says that Mr. Milosevic "still has a lot to play for" in the vital Serbian elections. His polls show that 39 percent of the electorate are undecided and nearly 12 percent will not vote -- half the voters. Of the other half, the opposition is only 5 percentage points ahead of the ruling coalition.
And he points out that the nationalist Radical Party always wins more votes than the polls indicate, making the race now nearly neck-and-neck, with the regime in control of the main television station, which is the way most people get news.
"People are dissatisfied with Milosevic and want change," Mr. Bogosavljevic said. "But they also believe what they hear about the opposition leaders," who are labeled corrupt, traitors in the pay of NATO and worse in the official media.
Although many oppose him, Mr. Milosevic has earned some credit for keeping promises and getting the population through its first post-bombing winter. Despite widespread predictions from the opposition and NATO capitals that severe energy and heating shortages would occur because of bomb damage, Serbs were warmer this winter than the residents of Kosovo, where NATO and the United Nations administration had enormous trouble providing electricity. The government has rebuilt many of the highway and railway bridges NATO bombed and rebuilt or repaired many houses and apartments that were damaged.
The economy is in poor shape and the average monthly wage is now about $50, but the opposition has been incapable of capitalizing on the hardship or even laying out a coherent program for social and economic change.
"We know there are social and economic problems," said Goran Matic, the Yugoslav Information Minister. "But people also know we've worked very hard after the war to try to solve them, and in very difficult circumstances."

HEADLINE: Flag Compromise Resisted in South Carolina House

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., April 13

 BODY:
Even as the South Carolina Senate gave its overwhelming final approval to a compromise plan that would remove the Confederate battle flag from the State Capitol's dome, the bill ran into heated opposition today from black members of the state's House of Representatives, who said the flag's location in front of the building would be no less an affront to black citizens.
The flag issue has exposed a deep rift between black senators -- six of seven voted for the bill -- and black House members, who represent smaller districts and tend to be less inclined to compromise. One legislator said that 24 of the 26 black representatives were opposed to this compromise and that many would actually prefer to keep the flag on the dome rather than move it out front. The House is likely to vote in the next two or three weeks on the bill, which cleared the Senate by 36 to 7 on Wednesday and by the same tally in one last, technical vote today. 
 In addition, the N.A.A.C.P., which is engaged in an economic boycott of the state because of the flag's display, said today that the boycott would continue if it was moved to the front of the Capitol. James Gallman, president of the group's South Carolina chapter, said a flag in front of a public building conveyed the same sense of sovereignty as a flag above it.
Several state officials said privately that they expected the bill to pass the House with the approval of most black members, after some initial resistance intended largely to satisfy the black lawmakers' constituents. The legislation's chances will improve, these officials said, when members realize that it is the only way to get the flag off the dome. In fact, the speaker of the Republican-controlled House, David H. Wilkins, an avid flag supporter, said today that the Senate compromise was the only plan he would allow to pass.
Under that plan, the rectangular Confederate flag would be removed from the dome and from the two legislative chambers. A smaller, square version of the flag, similar to the one carried by Lee's Army of Northern Virginia, would be placed on a 20-foot flagpole in front of the Capitol, adjacent to a 33-foot-high memorial to the state's Confederate soldiers.
Atop the dome, the flag can be seen throughout the city, but it is so high that it is actually hard to see on the Capitol grounds. Its position closer to eye level near the main entrance to the Capitol, several black representatives argued, would make it more prominent to anyone passing by.
"It's right in your face," said Representative J. Todd Rutherford, a black Democrat from Columbia. "Any rally or march or protest at the Statehouse will have to take place directly under that flag. It's not the proper place for it, and I'd rather leave it up on the dome than put it there."
Although one black senator has said he voted for the plan because the flag would be smaller, that argument did not seem to carry much weight among blacks in the House.
"Would you ask the Jewish community to accept a smaller swastika flag?" said Representative Fletcher N. Smith, a black Democrat from Greenville. "This is the flag of treason against the United States government, and it should not be celebrated or put in any kind of prominent position."
But Darrell Jackson, the Senate's leading black opponent of the flag, said the proposal, distasteful though it was to him, was the best compromise that could be struck.
"At the end of the day, this will pass," said Mr. Jackson, a life member of the N.A.A.C.P. "This gets rid of three flags in positions of sovereignty, and replaces them with one. My colleagues in the House will have to realize they can accept the compromise or maintain the status quo. And if we adjourn and leave the flag up there on the dome, they will have to answer to themselves and their constituents."
The bill could pass the 124-member House without any black votes, but the majority leader, Representative Richard M. Quinn Jr. of Columbia, said today that the Republicans would not support it without being joined by a substantial number of Democrats.
The issue has festered in South Carolina since legislators first unfurled the flag in 1962 as part of the centennial observance of the Civil War. Later the state kept it flying in defiance of the civil rights movement. This year, after the boycott made it a national issue that reached even into the presidential campaign, lawmakers have been under tremendous pressure from business and political leaders around the state to adopt any kind of compromise that would get the flag off the dome. The South Carolina Chamber of Commerce, for example, has said it does not care where the flag goes, as long as it does not fly from the Capitol.
Several House members suggested today that the pressure for a compromise had led the Senate to be too generous to flag supporters, whose standard would be the only one flying in front of the Capitol. (Atop the dome, it flies with both the American flag and the state flag.) But even critics said they could understand such an accommodation, given the fiercely held belief among many white lawmakers that the flag is a noble symbol of their families' Southern heritage.
Representative Curtis B. Inabinett, a black member from the coastal town of Ravenel, noted that he reluctantly voted on Wednesday for a bill creating a state holiday to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., making South Carolina the last state to do so. His reluctance, he said, resulted from a provision, attached by white lawmakers, that would also create a Confederate Memorial holiday.
"That was the hardest vote I ever cast, but it was that or nothing," Mr. Inabinett said. "And if it turns out this is the best we can do on the flag, well, then, I suspect a lot of us will turn around and vote for it."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Gasps for Air, Then Faints Away Again, by 2.5%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
A modest rebound in technology stocks vaporized in midafternoon yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index fell for a fourth consecutive day, dragging a broad swath of other shares down with it.
Although government reports early in the day of strong retail sales and faster, oil-driven inflation added to uneasiness about an overheated economy, the sell-off came long after that news had been absorbed and after a spate of surprisingly good earnings reports. 
 The economic news hurt financial stocks, which suffered all day as investors anticipated that further interest rate increases to forestall inflation would put pressure on those companies' earnings. Weighed down by American Express and J. P. Morgan, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 201.58 points, or 1.8 percent, to 10,923.55.
Falling nearly 150 points in the last 45 minutes of the day, the Nasdaq composite index finished the day down 92.85 points, or 2.5 percent, at 3,676.78. The technology-heavy index is now 27.2 percent below its March 10 peak, firmly in what is regarded as bear-market territory.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 26.66 points, or 1.82 percent, to 1,440.51.
Stock analysts said they had seen a shift in psychology in recent weeks that has taken a huge toll on technology stocks. The rush to buy on the dips, which has often pulled the market out of slides, has faded and been replaced by a different mentality.
"If you're in a bear market, instead of buying on weakness you think in terms of selling on strength," said Robert Bloom, president of Friends, Ivory & Sime, a New York money manager.
That certainly seemed to be the approach yesterday. The Nasdaq index climbed as much as 3.84 percent, regaining somewhat more than half the ground it lost in Wednesday's downdraft. At that point, investors with paper gains on stocks they have held over the last year or two saw an opportunity to lighten up on their technology portfolios. Notably, the Nasdaq finished the day very near the low point of 3,649.11 it reached during the April 4 session. Though the technology gauge came roaring back late that same afternoon, it has since retraced the downward path, leaving the 5,000 mark a fleeting memory. Strategists now fear that a breach of the 3,650 mark could bring on a fresh wave of heavy selling.
"There are still a huge number of companies selling at astonishing levels compared with their revenue," said Ned Riley Jr., market strategist at State Street Advisors in Boston. As an example, he said the peg ratio -- the stock price as a multiple of the growth in earnings -- is well over three for leading technology stocks, more than twice the level that has traditionally appealed to buyers.
If the downturn of the Nasdaq over the last month is "cleansing the system," Mr. Riley added, "we still have a way to go." The Nasdaq composite posted a whopping 86 percent gain in 1999.
Yesterday's slide, which followed the second-biggest point drop on record, took the Nasdaq back to its lowest level since mid-December. So far this year, it is down 9.65 percent, compared with losses of 4.99 percent for the Dow Jones industrials and 1.96 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500.
Sizable amounts of money being pulled out of technology in recent weeks have been redirected into the stocks of smokestack America or into such established sectors as banking and drugs.
But financial stocks were among the larger casualties yesterday as analysts fretted about the seemingly irrepressible spending of the nation's consumers and a second consecutive sizable monthly rise in producer prices, albeit mainly from oil.
A statement by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, that he saw no evidence of acceleration in unit labor costs did little to dispel assumptions that more interest rate increases lie ahead.
J. P. Morgan, down 53/16 to 131 1/2, and American Express, down 4 1/2 to 146, were two of the biggest losers among Dow components. General Electric, which has a major financial unit, was the biggest drag of all on the index, falling 6 5/8, to 150, even though G.E. reported earnings that were better than it had predicted on March 21. General Motors, which also reported earnings higher than predicted, gained 1/2, to 88.
Cisco Systems, one of the brand-name companies that have been caught up in the technology downdraft that began with Internet stocks, slumped 3 7/8, to 61 1/8, sharply below its peak of 82 reached less than three weeks ago. It was the biggest drag on the Standard & Poor's 500. More than 104 million shares of Cisco changed hands, compared with 47.2 million for No. 2, Microsoft, which lost 1/8, to 79 1/4.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Yields on Treasuries Drop
 Treasury yields moved slightly lower yesterday after volatility in the equity markets sent investors fleeing to the relative safety of government securities.
The flight-to-safety pared earlier losses in Treasuries that resulted when strong consumer data raised investor fears that the Fed would raise interest rates again.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32, to a price of 106 15/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.79 percent, from 5.81 percent on Wednesday.
For the first time in weeks, the Treasury bond market had a noticeably negative reaction to stronger-than-expected economic data. Retail sales increased 0.4 percent last month on the heels of upwardly revised gains of 0.7 percent and 1.1 percent in January and February, respectively.
Don Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, called it "a clear sign that personal consumption expenditure during the first quarter surged forward at a scorching pace."
The 1 percent jump in the March Producer Price Index matched a similar increase in February and doubled expectations.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

G.M. Profit Declines 2% But Still Beats Forecasts
Profit at General Motors edged down 2 percent in the first quarter as an unexpected turnaround in its international operations was not enough to offset unusually heavy discounting in the United States and rising costs at its Hughes Electronics subsidiary. Despite the decline, the results beat Wall Street forecasts.
In the United States, G.M. continued raising sticker prices slightly in the first quarter but offered so many discounts that the average price for which it was able to sell a vehicle actually declined 0.7 percent. Page C2. 

G.E. Posts Solid Gain in Earnings
General Electric, benefiting from resurgent global economies and its push into electronic commerce, announced robust first-quarter revenue and earnings. Net income rose 20 percent, to $2.6 billion, or 78 cents a share, while revenue surged to $30 billion, up 24 percent. The results beat Wall Street estimates by a penny. Shareholders seemed unimpressed, though. Shares of G.E., which had soared in March on the promise of 77-cents-a-share earnings, fell on the reality of 78 cents. The stock closed at $150, down $6.625. C2.
 
Worries in the Dot-Com World
The recent tumble in technology stocks hasn't just unnerved investors -- it has made some employees in the thick of the dot-com whirlwind look warily over their shoulders. In the much-heralded exodus from old-line companies to dot-com start-ups, some have found great wealth, but others are finding the promised land does not offer the riches or satisfaction they had expected. A1.
 
Greenspan Offers View on Stocks
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said that in his view investors have been "groping" for the proper valuations of stocks, especially those of technology companies. In an appearance on Capitol Hill, Mr. Greenspan also urged Congress and regulators not to overreact to technology-driven changes in the ways that stocks are traded. C2.
 
3-Way Aluminum Deal Collapses
Alcan Aluminium of Canada abandoned plans to merge with Pechiney of France but said it still intended to buy Algroup of Switzerland. The failure of the proposed $17 billion three-way deal came after European regulators objected to the dominance that the planned combination would have exerted. C4.
 
British Telecom Plans to Reorganize
In an effort to strengthen its slumping stock price, British Telecommunications announced a wide-ranging plan to reorganize into a half-dozen units and spin off its Yellow Pages business, with hopes of spinning off still other units. Peter Bonfield, the company's chief executive, argued that the changes would make the company more agile, allowing it to respond to increasing competition. C4.
 
Ad Executive Switches Destination
Just two weeks ago, Gary Topolewski, a leading creative advertising executive, agreed to leave the Southfield, Mich., office of FCB Worldwide for McCann-Erickson/A&L in San Francisco. But he unexpectedly announced that he would instead join the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C5.
 
Retail Sales and P.P.I. Increase
Retail sales increased 0.4 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted $269.2 billion, while soaring energy costs caused the Producer Price Index, which measures wholesale prices, to jump 1 percent last month. C6.

HEADLINE: Congress Adopts Pared-Down Budget Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Congress gave final approval tonight to a $1.87 trillion Republican budget outline for next year that includes tax reductions and cuts in many domestic programs, setting up an election-year showdown with Democrats over how the nation should put its current prosperity to use.
Even before the House and Senate passed the measure in largely party-line votes, President Clinton said the Republican approach risked squandering what he called "this magic moment of possibility." 
 Speaking to the American Society of Newspaper Editors here, Mr. Clinton said the insistence by Republicans on big tax cuts would require unacceptably deep cuts in programs affecting "everything from reducing class size to cleaning up toxic waste dumps to putting more police on our streets," and could ultimately mean a return to budget deficits.
Most of Mr. Clinton's comments were aimed at Republicans in Congress, but he also made clear that he intended to hammer away in coming months at the tax-and- spending proposals being laid out by their party's presumptive presidential nominee, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
Mr. Bush has called for a tax cut of $483 billion over five years, and this week proposed a $35 billion plan to help low- and moderate-income people purchase health insurance. The tax cut would swell to more than $1 trillion over a decade.
The budget resolution adopted by Congress today, which worked out small differences between versions passed earlier by the House and Senate, calls for at least $150 billion in tax cuts over five years and perhaps as much as $175 billion.
It increases spending on the Pentagon and education, provides extra aid to farmers, cuts most domestic programs after taking account of inflation and sets aside at least $20 billion to help establish prescription-drug coverage within Medicare.
The vote on the budget in the House was 220 to 208. The vote in the Senate was 50 to 48.
"Today we have a responsible and balanced budget, which keeps America on the right track," said House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois.
But as the Republicans moved ahead with the plan, which serves as an outline for the enactment of specific tax and spending bills and is not subject to a veto, they were set back in their efforts to pass a centerpiece of their tax-cutting package.
On a procedural vote, Senate Democrats blocked a Republican bill that would give a tax cut to married couples. Democrats said that while they favored efforts to end the so-called marriage penalty that results in many two-income couples paying a bigger tax bill than if they were single, the Republican proposal, valued at $248 billion over five years, was excessive.
The vote left the bill in limbo. A similar measure has already passed the House.
In his address, Mr. Clinton said he had learned when he put together his first budget, in 1993, that fiscal responsibility requires making tough choices about spending. But he said the Republican proposals this year are built on completely unrealistic assumptions that spending will be cut substantially.
Mr. Clinton said the Republicans were going to run into a problem with their budget arithmetic, just as they did in the 1980's, when President Reagan pushed through big tax cuts, and budget deficits began rising rapidly.
"This year, from Capitol Hill to the campaign trail, we are hearing positive statements about investing in health care, in prescription-drug coverage, in education," Mr. Clinton said, referring to Republican proposals.
"But after a trillion dollar tax cut -- and I believe the one they are running on this year is even bigger -- there will be no room left for these investments, or for saving Social Security and Medicare, unless we are prepared to go back to the bad old days of deficits," the president said.
Mr. Clinton said Congress should adopt his plan to use some of the interest savings from reducing the national debt to shore up Social Security and Medicare, both of which face financial problems in coming decades as the population ages.
There is little prospect, however, for any action on Social Security this year. Congress will now shift its attention to passing spending bills. Republicans have found it difficult in the last several years to remain within the spending targets set out in their own budget plans. And at the end of each of the last several years they have been forced to negotiate with Mr. Clinton, who has vetoed all their big tax bills and extracted more spending from them.
Both sides expect much the same thing to happen this year, with the stakes increased by the presidential race and the effort by Democrats to regain control of the House.
