HEADLINE: Some Enticed by Dot-Coms Now Have Second Thoughts

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON and KATIE HAFNER 

 BODY:
The recent tumble in technology stocks hasn't just unnerved investors -- it has made some employees in the thick of the dot-com whirlwind look warily over their shoulders.
At a party on Saturday in San Francisco, the room buzzed as a group of Stanford University business graduates, class of '99, commiserated about all the wealth they had lost in the market. Margie Backstrom, one partygoer, told of a gathering weeks earlier to celebrate the vesting of a friend's stock options. While such events usually have a festive air, Ms. Backstrom said, the woman bemoaned the fact that her options amounted to far less than expected. Another friend has watched his company's stock plummet more than 60 percent since Jan. 1; his options are now worthless, his prospects unclear. 
 "People are questioning whether they made a mistake by giving up the security of a big salary for all those options that aren't worth much anymore," said Ms. Backstrom, who is immune to market gyrations so far because the Internet company she works for is still private. Her friends, she added, wonder "whether it was such a good idea to not go to the Morgan Stanleys of the world."
In the much-heralded exodus from old-line companies to dot-com start-ups in recent years, while some voyagers have found great wealth, others are finding the promised land does not offer the riches or satisfaction they had expected. Not everyone finds it easy to adjust to bosses who will not focus, work spaces that double as kennels and a culture in which self-conscious jollity comes at the expense of real work. Others are recognizing that part of the challenge these days is turning traditional concerns into new-economy companies. Those who stay can help their employers think like dot-coms.
And some, in the end, decide the toll they were asked to pay for Internet riches is too high.
"The downdraft in the market, if it continues, will cause people to move away from the new economy to more stable companies," said James Citrin, a headhunter at Spencer Stuart in Stamford, Conn. Severance packages have already become a hot topic, he said. And last week, with a prospective employer's preoffering valuation down, one client requested more options before taking a job. "The stock market and the talent market are inexorably linked," Mr. Citrin added.
Already anecdotal evidence suggests that the dot-com luster is fading. Consider Tsan Merritt-Poree. She was general counsel for a new Web site but left in January after repeated problems with computers and fax machines. Or Allison Johnson, who stayed at Hewlett-Packard because she thought she could have a bigger impact there.
Isaac Lasky, a 55-year-old consultant in Denver, said he was burned by a telecommunications start-up in December. This week, he said, "I would much rather be unemployed than involved with a shaky dot-com."
To be sure, it is too soon to say there is a clear exodus from companies that have built the new economy. Investment banking firms cannot seem to give employees enough casual-dress days and free cappuccinos to keep them at their desks. And for many who have jumped to dot-coms already, it has become a way of life, said Daniel DiCaro, a veteran of many technology start-ups and now managing director of Gray Drake Partners, a consulting firm in Mount Prospect, Ill.
"Most people, when they get that fever, it's hard to shake," he said. "It may burn people out, but you just can't get that when you're in a more traditional job."
But if the Internet generation, whose rewards rise and fall on options, faces many more weeks like this, with the Nasdaq index plunging 17 percent in four days, all that could change. Many dot-com deserters -- particularly those who join the ranks of newly public companies which continue to lose money -- are lured back to established companies, mainly in technology.
At Cisco Systems, which rivals Microsoft in size, resumes for certain marketing jobs from dot-com defectors are up 10 to 20 percent in the past three months, said Larry Lang, a vice president. Just two weeks ago, after a spate of new hires from a few volatile start-ups, Mr. Lang thought to himself, "Aha, there is a pattern emerging here."
In the end, it may have been the dogs that ended Carla De Luca's dot-com career.
A year ago, Ms. De Luca, a former CNN producer, moved from Atlanta to California and took a job at Beyond.com, an e-commerce services provider which was based in Sunnyvale but has since moved to Santa Clara. She quickly put together an ambitious plan for hiring people to write about the site's wares. But she grew frustrated at the time it was taking to put it into action. "It seemed indefinite to me when it would materialize," she said.
Top executives, she said, spent a lot of time spinning their wheels in endless meetings. But what really bothered her was the atmosphere of mandatory fun. Employees were told that if they wanted to have a meeting over a game of Ping-Pong, they should. And a "dogs welcome" policy turned the office into a near-kennel.
Ms. De Luca lasted four months, leaving behind a pile of stock options when she quit in May.
"There was certainly an emphasis on camaraderie and fun and a lot of team building and bonding, which I'm all for," Ms. De Luca said. "But often I felt that it was at the expense of some good work getting done."
Many people do just fine in dot-com land, she said, but she prefers the stability and the ample resources at her new job. "The corporate culture and the right fit for me is really important," she said.
A Beyond.com spokeswoman, Laura Fulda, would not address Ms. De Luca's comments but did say, "When you go to an Internet start-up you can expect the unexpected, that's for sure."
The company has gone through hard times. In January, the chief executive quit and 20 percent of the staff was laid off in a restructuring. In the fall, the company moved. And the dogs were banished. Yesterday, the company's stock price ended at $2.8125, an all-time low closing price.
A common argument among the dot-com cognoscenti is that employees can have a greater impact at a start-up.
But resources at small companies are slim, and this can wreak havoc with those used to an army of secretaries and support staff. Ms. Merritt-Poree, a 37-year-old lawyer, took a job late last year as general counsel with NetNoir.com. It did not take long to realize the fit was less than ideal. She complained that the fax machine was always busy and, when she asked for her own printer to receive faxes, did not get it. Instead she brought one from home and kept it on her desk to guard confidential faxes regarding company financings.
Her e-mail at times did not work, she said, so she got a private account. But the final straw was when her computer broke down in December and she could not get access to the Internet for nearly a week. She left the office, telling a colleague to keep tabs on the repair: "Here's my cell phone number. Call me when it is done."
Ms. Merritt-Poree talked to her old boss at Cooley Godward, a San Francisco law firm, and asked if she could come back. She did in January.
E. David Ellington, who founded NetNoir in January 1995, said the problems Ms. Merritt-Poree had were resolved, and her successor had thrived. Some of the problems, he said, were because the company was moving to different offices. "It was a very bumpy two-month period over a five-year history," he added. "I understand her frustrations, but they were frustrations expressed by others, too. The others have stayed."
Ms. Merritt-Poree does not regret leaving, or giving up a generous options package. "My resolve is strengthened that you should do this for love, not money," she said.
Some executives stay behind, comforted by the security of a large organization and attracted to helping it transform into a new-economy player.
In September, Allison Johnson, a 39-year-old Hewlett-Packard vice-president, was offered a rare opportunity: becoming a founding partner -- employee No. 6 -- at Loudcloud Inc., which helps speed the growth of Internet start-ups by managing all their computing needs.
Loudcloud is the brainchild of Marc Andreessen and a few others from Netscape. Ms. Johnson resigned from Hewlett-Packard within two weeks of being asked. But the day before she was to leave, Hewlett-Packard announced a major restructuring, and she had second thoughts.
While deciding, she said, she "took the money issue off the table." Staying at Hewlett-Packard meant living comfortably, while going to Loudcloud could bring great riches.
But Ms. Johnson said it came down to this: "Where do you have the opportunity to have a giant impact?" The answer, she decided, was at Hewlett-Packard, which is strengthening its Internet presence.
Money was not the issue in talks with Hewlett-Packard, she said. "It was more the sense that, 'Look, this is what we're going to do, and we want you to be part of this team.' "
Ms. Johnson says she has not regretted her decision for one minute, though she does wonder how she will feel the day Loudcloud goes public.
For the most part, employers are only too happy to take defectors back. "We welcome returnees with open arms," said Katie Cotton, spokeswoman at Apple Computer.
So eager is Autodesk, a large software company in San Rafael, Calif., that it even sends a postcard to former employees a few months after they leave, asking if the grass is really greener.
"We want to send the message that good employees are always welcome back," said Fred Kohler, a manager of human resources at Autodesk, which has started giving out more frequent bonuses and options.
Wall Street may be the exception. Publicly, most companies say returnees are welcome. But privately executives bristle at the notion of watching high-priced talent waltz out the door only to return if things go sour. "We cannot send the message that you can leave at no cost," one executive said. "People have to feel that if they leave they are toast."
The new model for those who want both stability and the charge of a dot-com is a dot-com linked to an old-economy corporation. James Breyer, a partner at the venture firm of Accel Partners in Palo Alto, Calif., said he had received several inquiries lately from employees interested in Walmart.com, the partnership between Wal-Mart Stores and Accel.
The decision may rest with where employees can be most content. Just ask Ms. De Luca. Many people she knows are still chasing the dot-com dream, but she's not convinced they are terribly happy. "When you're working all the time you really have to love what you're doing," she said. "I don't feel that everyone I'm talking to is necessarily loving all the time they're putting in."

HEADLINE: Congress Agrees to $7.1 Billion in Farm Aid

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Congress once again is spreading billions of dollars to fertilize American agribusiness. House and Senate negotiators agreed this week to a new $7.1 billion bailout for farmers. But those farm subsidies were supposed to be drying up by now.
Four years ago, the Republican-led Congress proclaimed an end to what its speaker, Newt Gingrich, called the "East German socialist" farm programs of the New Deal. Congress passed, and President Clinton signed, the Republicans' Freedom to Farm Act. 
 The new farm law pledged to phase out many of the government's Depression-era price-support programs and intended to wean farmers from subsidies by 2002. The idea was that farmers would flourish in an unfettered market.
But Congress has since repeatedly passed emergency increases in spending for agriculture. And the subsidies have been an unfailing spring, now flowing faster than ever.
Government payments to American agriculture have tripled since the act was passed, to a record $22.7 billion in 1999. The new $7.1 billion approved on Wednesday will be spent in the fall.
Despite the huge government subsidies, farm income will fall below $50 billion this year for the first time since 1986, the Agriculture Department said. The law did not change the fact that much of the money goes to huge operations growing basic commodity crops like corn, wheat and soybeans for cattle fodder and chicken feed. The subsidies have fueled huge surpluses, sending prices plummeting, and the new law has not helped that situation, either.
"Freedom to Farm was supposed to revolutionize farm policy, but it has pointed out the failures of farm policy," Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said in an interview.
The new farm law did not change the essence of that policy, which forces the farmer to get big or get out, said Chuck Hassebrook, project director for the Center for Rural Affairs, a nonprofit advocacy group in Walthill, Neb., that works for family farms and rural communities.
Above all, the law did not stop Congress from writing giant checks to giant farms, subsidizing multibillion-dollar conglomerates while small farmers struggle to get by, Mr. Hassebrook said.
"The Freedom to Farm act embraced and in fact worsened Congress's tendency to say the bigger and richer you are, the more money you get," he said. "Congress has subsidized big operations and driven smaller farms out of business."
Mr. Glickman does not dispute that. "There's no question that a big chunk of payments go to larger producers," the secretary said. "The more pounds you produce, the more money you get. Congress has always resisted changing that."
The more the big farms produce, the more government money they get, and the more money they get, the more they produce. This contributes to a huge oversupply in basic commodities. And the oversupply drives prices down. The big agribusinesses that buy and process commodities like low prices. Small farmers do not.
"All subsidies do in the long run is induce more supply," said Bruce A. Babcock, an agricultural economist at Iowa State University. "We increase supply when we have oversupply. We do not have a coherent policy. It is not designed to help the small dirt farmer; the biggest gain is obtained by the largest farmer.
"But everyone finds it politically expedient to think they're doing something for the family farmer. It still serves a purpose to have that myth, the myth of the small family farmer who needs government help."
A drought is predicted this year, and already Congress has passed a bill, which the Clinton administration supports, that will sharply increase crop insurance payments.
Last year, there was a drought, too. Congress used it to justify a record $8.7 billion emergency increase in farm subsidies. But there were record harvests in basic commodities, rain or no rain.
Now, due largely to those enormous harvests and a national glut, the Agriculture Department has forecast that this year the price of soybeans will be the lowest in 27 years and the price of wheat and corn the lowest in 13 years.
Over the years, stepped-up subsidies have not helped the average farmer flourish. The farmer received 37 percent of the dollar spent at the supermarket in 1980, Mr. Glickman said; today, the farmer receives 22 cents. Corporate food processors and middlemen take an ever-larger share.
Mr. Hassebrook said, "The farmer's share of the profit in the food system is shrinking so fast that at this rate in 2030 it will be zero."
The subsidies have helped the biggest producers, packers and processors in an increasingly industrialized agricultural system dominated by fewer and fewer corporations. A handful of companies now control an overwhelming share of the nation's beef, poultry and pork production, as well as production of the wheat, corn and soybeans that fatten the cattle, chickens and pigs.
"The big players avoid day-to-day competition by locking up markets, and by dealing only with other big players," said Keith Collins, the Agriculture Department's chief economist. "The very big players are using their market power to gain dominance." This kind of clout may be prohibited by antitrust laws, Mr. Collins said, but prosecutions are rare.
Mr. Glickman said there were changes afoot that would help small farmers, like the growing realization that "you can make more money growing 30 acres of tomatoes and selling them to a restaurant than by growing 1,500 acres of wheat" for a corporation.
The changes include a revival of farmers' markets and agricultural marketing cooperatives, and, above all, the rapid growth of organic farming, now a $6 billion-a-year business, Mr. Glickman said.
"No matter what we've done, though it's helped keep people in business, it hasn't stemmed the tide of consolidation and concentration, of people leaving agriculture, selling off the farm for a strip shopping center," he said. "Farm policy has been focused on commodities. In fact, the problems are much much bigger."
Mr. Glickman said it might be that the desire of the White House and Congress to keep the subsidies flowing for big agribusiness is too great for changes anytime soon.
Overhauling farm policy, Mr. Collins said, is "like pushing the stone uphill." "Incredibly powerful economic forces are driving the changes that have occurred," he said.

HEADLINE: Summers Says Growth Is Trade Gap Solution

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
The best way for the United States to reduce its trade deficit is for Europe and Japan to increase growth, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said today.
The International Monetary Fund has called the United States trade deficit, which widened to a record $99.8 billion in the fourth quarter of 1999 and a record $338.9 billion for the full year, the biggest threat to the global economy. 
 Mr. Summers said the deficit was "a matter of concern," but he also said the solution was for other countries to increase growth, raising their appetite for goods made in the United States.
"It will be healthier for the world economy, as well as for the United States economy, for the adjustment to take place through increased exports, rather than reduced imports," Mr. Summers said at a news conference before the meeting this weekend of the seven leading industrial nations. "We believe the global expansion needs to be balanced up, not balanced down."
Europe must do more to increase structural reform, he suggested, while Japan must continue the fiscal stimulus of the last few years.

HEADLINE: Public Interests;
Rudy's Identity Crisis

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
Our topic for today is "Rudy Giuliani and the Senate: A Cry for Help."
People, this is a man fraught with inner turmoil. He loves being mayor of New York City -- he'd try to do it forever if it weren't for term limits. Being president would be nice too, of course. Commander of NATO might be O.K., if they were willing to overlook that draft exemption. 
 But the Senate is the job that's open, and although Mr. Giuliani has raised pots and pots of money for his campaign, he appears about as interested in being a legislator as he is in becoming a pastry chef.
One of the ways you can tell whether a New York City politician is really committed to running for higher office is by his or her willingness to campaign upstate. Those of us who live in the metropolitan area and are particularly shallow tend to regard upstate as a combination of half-empty strip malls and attractive but hard-to-reach scenery.
Hillary Clinton, who has not lived here long enough to absorb local prejudices, really likes it up there. "Last week I was in Binghamton and Rochester and Corning and Albany, and I'm back in Albany today. I'll be back in Buffalo tomorrow," she said brightly this week. (For those of you who read the Harry Potter books, Mrs. Clinton as a candidate is Hermione Granger. She wants to sign up for all the courses, and if there's a scheduling conflict, she'll replicate.)
There's no actual proof Mr. Giuliani is a downstate snob who hates driving three hours to have dinner at a place where the steak comes wrapped in cheese. But it is an absolute fact that his associates have found it almost impossible to drag him up north.
Last week the mayor's staff announced he would travel to Rochester on Wednesday to have lunch with Republican women. But on Tuesday Mr. Giuliani canceled the trip, saying he wanted to go to the Yankees' home opening game instead.
Never called his upstate hosts, never apologized. The county's Republican chairman had to learn about the cancellation from reporters. His wife, who organized the event, had to track down 400 guests and tell them not to come.
"Opening Day is something of great significance to me," the mayor said. ". . . you can raise money any time."
Now people, this is clearly the sound of a conflicted soul. Or an incredible jerk.
"He's setting himself up to announce that the city needs him so desperately he's going to have to forgo the race," predicted former Mayor Ed Koch. Mr. Koch once knocked himself out of a race for governor by telling Playboy that if you live upstate you have to "drive 20 miles to buy a gingham dress or a Sears, Roebuck suit." He also made uncomplimentary, but accurate, comments about the quality of the restaurants.
"Unconsciously, maybe I didn't want to be governor," he said. "Anyway, it worked out for the best. I'd have been so unhappy in Albany, I'd have come home every night."
Upstate New York is a perpetual economic basket case, the sort of place where politicians keep hoping a gambling casino might turn things around. Even the areas that are doing well have insecurity complexes. (The Syracuse Chamber of Commerce calls its annual retreat an "advance" to combat negative thinking.)
Mrs. Clinton, as you might expect, has a four-part strategy for reviving the economy, including subsections on entrepreneurial incubators and the alternative-fuels tax credit. As a test, I challenged her to say something optimistic about Utica, and she went on for some time about demolition incentives to level parts of the downtown, followed by a paean to residents' "gritty persistence to keep trying."
Her opponent is not into position papers. "The mayor has a long record of job creation," said a campaign spokesman when asked for the Giuliani plan for economic development upstate. "The same kinds of things he did for New York City he could do for the state."
But being a senator is not like being mayor, and upstate is most definitely not like New York City. Its problems can't be solved by making people behave. No wonder the mayor doesn't want to go there.
He can probably adapt, but I think we're talking long-term therapy.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Parsing the Protests

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Washington is now playing host to protests against the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, globalization and free trade. If this were a baseball game, someone would sell programs to help follow the action. Here's how mine would read.
Facts you won't hear: You will hear much blarney in coming days. Fortunately, a major study of how globalization has affected 34 developed and developing countries was just published by the consulting firm A. T. Kearney. It concludes what economists have long known: "Overall, countries integrating rapidly with the world economy have fared better than those integrating more slowly . . . because the fastest globalizing countries have enjoyed rates of economic growth that averaged 30 to 50 percent higher over the past 20 years. The same countries also enjoyed greater political freedom . . . more social spending and received higher scores on the U.N. Human Development Index, an indicator of longevity, literacy and standard of living." 
 On the downside, the report found, "rapid globalizers have witnessed a growing gap between rich and poor . . . rising corruption and higher levels of environmental pollution." The report adds, though, that while some 34 percent of the world's population lived in absolute poverty in 1980, by 1990 that number had dropped by more than half. "In other words, 1.4 billion people escaped absolute poverty as a result of economic growth associated with globalization."
Whom to root for: There are many activists gathered in Washington who understand that globalization has its upsides and downsides, and they have come not to destroy this system but to improve it -- by agitating for the World Bank to be more sensitive to the environment in its building projects, by urging rich countries to write off the debts of the poorest countries, and by urging the I.M.F. to be more open to alternative, possibly less harsh remedies for rescuing countries in financial distress. All worthy issues.
Whom to root against: Root against the economic quacks peddling conspiracy theories about globalization; the anti-free-trade extremists, such as Ralph Nader's group, Public Citizen; the protectionist trade unions; and the anarchists. These groups deserve to be called by their real name: "The Coalition to Keep the World's Poor People Poor."
These characters are fighting free trade. But they can't point to a single country that has flourished, or upgraded its living or worker standards, without free trade and integration. And they offer the third world no coherent plan for how to develop and preserve the environment. Their only plan is that developing countries stop developing. This coalition is supported by U.S. unions that have launched a protectionist jihad against more free trade with the developing world, for fear of competition. The unions don't want to say that out loud -- so they tell you they are for free trade with countries that get their worker standards up.
Yeah, sure. Unite, the reactionary garment union, is currently blocking a compromise bill aimed at giving the poorest countries in Africa duty-free access to the U.S. apparel market, even though this bill would link these trade benefits to improved worker standards. After Cambodia made an unprecedented effort to improve its worker standards -- in order to win greater access to the U.S. apparel market -- Unite still opposed increases in Cambodia's quota, citing areas where Cambodia wasn't perfect. Read the fascinating Jan. 10 piece in The New Republic entitled "The Man Behind the Anti-Free-Trade Revolt." It's about the relationship between Ralph Nader's and Lori Wallach's Public Citizen group and Roger Milliken, the far-right billionaire textile factory owner -- one of America's legendary union-busters and a longtime backdoor funder of protectionist groups. Nice company.
There's nothing wrong with unions or owners protecting their interests -- it's just when they do it in the name of helping the poor that's contemptible. So as you watch this demo, give your heart to those who not only care about the poor and the rain forest but have real ideas of how we can help both grow in a more integrated world. And give the back of your hand to those who pose as friends of the downtrodden but whose real goal is to take care of themselves and keep the poor poor. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Company Aims to Reap the Wind As a Clean Source of Electricity

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
On two windswept farms 80 miles west of Albany, construction is scheduled to begin today on seven towering windmills, each as tall and broad as a football field stood on its end, that together will constitute the largest effort in the East to turn energy in the turbulent air into electricity.
Wind farms have already sprung up in the Midwest, California and other places with open spaces and strong breezes, but most of them have been built by utilities, with the construction costs passed along in electric bills. 
 In contrast, the $16 million wind project planned for Madison, N.Y., a rural town of 2,800 people, is being built on speculation, without a guaranteed set of customers, by PG&E Generating, which owns a fleet of conventional coal- and gas-powered plants and some hydroelectric dams around the country and sells power on the open market.
The customers for the power from the Madison wind farm are expected to be companies and institutions, like universities, that are willing to tack on an additional 5 or 10 percent to electric bills in return for being able to say they are using some power generated without pollution, said Christopher R. Sauer, a senior vice president of PG&E Generating, which is based in Bethesda, Md.
While local officials and the farmers who have leased land for the project expect it to revive the local economy, the broader goal, company officials said, is to supply and nurture the nascent American market for "green power," electricity produced without pollution or the hazards of nuclear power.
Over the last 20 years, improved technology has cut the cost of power from wind turbines by more than 80 percent, energy experts say, from about 38 cents a kilowatt-hour to 3 to 6 cents a kilowatt-hour.
It is still more costly than power from conventional sources, which is often less than 3 cents a kilowatt-hour, but there is rising demand for power produced with no pollution, even if it costs more.
Just as car companies are finding the need to build electric cars while still churning out Cadillacs and Lincoln Navigators, so, too, are power producers trying to cater to every part of their market.
And for this environmental market, there is no source purer than the wind. "It's the greenest of the green," Mr. Sauer said.
The project benefits from some public aid. New York State's Energy Research and Development Authority awarded a $2 million grant for initial research, and the company, by investing in wind power, gains a federal tax break.
But it is still one of the first private-sector experiments in the East trying to create a nonpolluting energy source and build demand for the product: guilt-free electrons.
"It's our money that's at risk here," Mr. Sauer said. Mr. Sauer said that PG&E Generating was close to signing deals with several customers, but declined to name them while negotiations were under way.
Together, the turbines in Madison will generate 11.5 megawatts, enough power to supply 5,000 average-size homes, company officials said.
The wind-power project in Madison is also distinguished by the size of the turbines, which are built by Vestas Wind Systems, a Danish company. The 100-foot blades of each of the windmills, whooshing slowly through the air as cows graze far below, will reach 328 feet high, as tall as a 32-story building.
Only one other wind project in the United States, in Texas, uses the same size turbines, although they are in fairly wide use in Europe.
An American branch of Vestas Wind Power is planning similar wind farms in other parts of central New York, state energy officials said.
So far, only California and Pennsylvania have significant demand from homeowners or businesses that want cleanly produced electricity. But New Jersey, New York and several other states are poised to join them, energy experts say.
The United States energy secretary, Bill Richardson, who plans to attend a groundbreaking ceremony for the windmills today, said last night that the time was right for a host of such projects.
"I'm confident that this is the beginning of major investments in wind energy across the Northeast," he said.
Ashok Gupta, an economist for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private conservation group, said that with costs for wind power dropping and restrictions on pollution from old-style power plants growing, almost all power producers will eventually offer cleanly generated electricity along with power from conventional sources.
"Eventually, all power sellers will have a green product to offer, like cereal companies that offer 'junk' and 'health' cereals," Mr. Gupta said.
The market for wind power, with its environmental cachet, is spreading. Last year, the New Belgium Brewing Company, in Fort Collins, Colo., signed an agreement with its regional utility to buy power produced at a windmill being built nearby.
The brewery's 70 employees voted unanimously for the change, even though it would cut into their bonuses, brewery officials said.
In central New York, where the economy -- agriculture in particular -- has been ailing for many years, the project is seen as a significant boon by local officials, who predict that there will be an influx of tourists curious to see the computer-controlled turbines.
As another side benefit, the town of Madison and the local school district will each get $30,000 a year for 15 years from the power company as payments in lieu of taxes.
The farmers who have leased their land for the wind project said the income should help them stay in business, essentially providing a new cash crop.
Carl Stone, who with his brother owns one of the farms, said it would be a little strange to have his herds ranging while giant blades slowly sliced the sky overhead.
"The wind was just a part of my life all my life," he said yesterday. "Now it may keep us in business."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Reissue of Gore Book May Be a Two-Edged Sword

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore's 1992 environmental credo, "Earth in the Balance," is being reissued next week in conjunction with the 30th anniversary of Earth Day, and Republicans say they could not be happier.
In a new foreword, Mr. Gore writes that "the environment should be a central issue in the year 2000" and argues that the threat of global warming, the focus of his book, has only become more apparent and more urgent since he wrote it. 
 Mr. Gore acknowledges that his adversaries consider him "too environmental" in the book but he says he welcomes the accusation. He even provides a helpful footnote directing critics to the most controversial suggestion in the book, calling for a worldwide effort aimed at "eliminating the internal combustion engine over, say, a 25-year period."
Since the book was first published by Houghton Mifflin, just months before Mr. Gore became the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, Republicans and conservatives have viewed "Earth in the Balance" as rich political fodder.
Many can quote chapter and verse about Mr. Gore's rallying cry to try to replace the internal combustion engine, his plea for a worldwide Marshall Plan to deal with environmental problems and his repeated plea to make "the effort to save the global environment the central organizing principle of our civilization."
Democrats and Mr. Gore's allies in the environmental movement counter that "Earth in the Balance" simply shows that Mr. Gore was ahead of his time. They maintain that concerns over issues like global warming have become so solidly mainstream, so middle-class American, that Republicans raise them only at their own risk.
For example, Dan Weiss, political director of the Sierra Club, said his organization recently asked voters in focus groups in Michigan and New Jersey about Mr. Gore's comment on the internal combustion engine, and the general reaction was that it was a good idea but unlikely to come about. Still, the fact that Democrats and their allies are studying the political implications of "Earth in the Balance" so intensely suggests the struggles to come.
A spokesman for the campaign of the apparent Republican nominee, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, offered a relatively low-key response to the reissue. "Al Gore will have plenty more time to become an even better author beginning in 2001," said the spokesman, Ari Fleischer.
But elsewhere in the party, the attack is unstinting. Indeed, Republicans have a full-blown critique of the book that revolves around the accusation that Mr. Gore is not an environmentalist, but an environmental extremist.
"Like Gore's nearly quarter-century of public life, 'Earth in the Balance' is plagued by a combination of liberalism, elitism, hypocrisy and hyperbole, punctuated by an unhealthy extremism," assert materials prepared by a Republican research analyst developing a critique of the book.
"When Al Gore writes that 'we must make the rescue of the environment the central organizing principle of civilization,' Gore is saying that his governing philosophy would be influenced less by the need for jobs and new technologies than by Gore's personal environmental concerns," the document adds.
Clifford May, communications director of the Republican National Committee, said of Mr. Gore: "I think he'll be seen by anybody who reads his book as an environmental extremist -- somebody who wants gas prices to go up, somebody who wants to take middle-class people out of their S.U.V.'s and to prevent inner-city people from moving to the suburbs. And his view of America as a dysfunctional society should give everybody pause."
The committee has sold copies of the book "equipped with an environmentally safe, nonozone depleting candle to read it by."
And Grover Norquist, who heads a conservative group called Americans for Tax Reform, has devoted part of his group's Web site to quotations from "Earth in the Balance," interspersed with quotations from the manifesto written by Theodore J. Kaczynski, who pleaded guilty in 1998 to the Unabomb killings. The headline: "Did Al Gore Say It, or Was It the Unabomber?"
Laura Quinn, Mr. Gore's communications director, countered, "If the Republicans think the vice president is extreme because he's working with the Big Three auto makers to help them develop cleaner cars, if they think he's extreme because in the Clinton-Gore years we've had the cleanest environment in a generation with the longest economic expansion ever, then they're so far to the right they've fallen off a cliff."
In fact, the environmental issue is complicated for both sides. Pollsters in both parties say that environmentalism is now a "national value," and thus no candidate can afford to be perceived as "anti-environment."
As Robert Teeter, a pollster who was the chairman of President George Bush's 1992 re-election campaign, put it, "We're now 30 years after Earth Day, and there's a huge number of Americans who consider themselves environmentalists in one way or another."
Being considered sensitive on the environment is thus a threshold test of national credibility, and Democrats and their allies contend that the younger Mr. Bush will have trouble passing it.
Mr. Weiss, the Sierra Club official, asserts, "Republicans run a real risk every time they bring up the environment because it creates an opportunity to remind voters of Bush's terrible environmental record in Texas."
In his new foreword, Mr. Gore notes that since he wrote "Earth in the Balance," "Houston has taken over as the city with the worst air pollution in America."
But Mr. Teeter says that in an election dominated by middle-of-the-road voters, the one thing a candidate has to avoid is the image of extremism -- "on anything."
This helps explain the Republican strategy against Mr. Gore. And there is some irony here; in the primaries, Mr. Gore worried about losing support from some people active in the environmental movement who questioned his commitment to the cause.
In the midst of this partisan swirl is the publisher, Houghton Mifflin, which decided to reissue the book because "it was on the New York Times best-seller list for 28 weeks and it's become a classic," said a spokesman, Walter Vatter.
Mr. Vatter added that there were no other changes to the book besides the new foreword.
In that foreword, Mr. Gore strikes an unapologetic tone. On replacing the internal combustion engine in 25 years, Mr. Gore says that "it is possible, it neeeds to be done, it will create more jobs not destroy jobs."
"Earth in the Balance" has a strikingly reflective tone and is widely considered to be Mr. Gore's midlife crisis book, written when Mr. Gore was trying to recover from his disastrous 1988 campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination, while coping with the serious injuries of his son, who had been hit by a car.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
For Clinton Corner, More Apartments

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A 102-unit apartment building is to rise this summer on West 50th Street off Eighth Avenue on a site that has been used as a parking lot since the 1970's. The building will be the third rental housing project to be developed on or near that corner in the Clinton section of Manhattan in the last two years.
The seven-story building, at 311 West 50th Street, will have studios and two-bedroom apartments, with 475 square feet to 1,000 square feet on average. Plans also include a 60-car parking garage and 5,200 square feet for medical offices, according to the developer, Levine Builders of Douglaston, Queens. Financing for the $25 million project is coming from the Bank of New York and the developer's equity. 
 It joins the two earlier rental buildings, which industry professionals said helped establish Eighth Avenue in the 50's as a residential address. One is the 292-unit, 26-story Longacre House at 50th Street and Eighth Avenue; the other, diagonally across the street on the east side of the avenue, is the 41-story, 550-apartment Gershwin.
The latest project is modest in comparison to its two neighbors because it is in the Clinton Special Preservation District, which extends from 43rd to 56th Street and from just west of Eighth Avenue to the midblock of 10th Avenue. The area's zoning requires that new buildings be no taller than seven stories and cover no more than 60 percent of the lot to blend with the low-rise structures that line Clinton's side streets.
Despite the restrictions, Jeffrey E. Levine, president of the development company bearing his name, said the project was economically viable for several reasons. Among them, he said, are the reasonable land price and the lower costs to construct a midrise structure. And since his company will develop and construct the project, "we will be able to build it more efficiently and with competitively priced units," he said.
Rents are expected to be $1,800 to $3,300 a month, which Mr. Levine said were less than those in high-rise structures in the area but more than those for apartments in walk-ups.
More importantly, he said, "the area obviously has been transformed into a residential area, and people are not only willing but eager to live there, close as it is to the theater district, Central Park and Midtown."
A strong housing market, along with the revival of 42nd Street to the south and the proposed redevelopment of the New York Coliseum site to the north at Columbus Circle, has brought renewed developer interest to the Eighth Avenue corridor in the 50's and up. In addition to the Longacre House and the Gershwin, another anchor is Worldwide Plaza, a mixed-use complex built in the 1980's. That project, which occupies the entire block between Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 49th and 50th Streets, has a residential component with 654 condominium units.
There are other residential projects under way or planned in the 50's, as well as in the greater Clinton neighborhood. Estimates from Community Board 4, which guides growth in the neighborhood, were that there were at least six projects in various stages of planning that would produce more than 1,000 residences in the next year and a half.
Meanwhile, leasing has remained steady and rents have increased, said Andrew S. Heiberger, president of Citi-Habitats, a residential brokerage in Manhattan. "The West 50's generally is considered a B-plus or A-minus neighborhood, but 50th Street is the strongest location within it," he said, noting that average annual rents are $51 a square foot. That puts rents for a typical 700-square-foot one-bedroom apartment at $2,800 to $3,200 a month.
The average per-square-foot rents at 311 West 50th Street will be $42.50. Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a rental brokerage in Manhattan, said the proposed building "will give people location without sticker shock." Ms. Packes, who is also the project's leasing consultant, said another factor in the building's favor was that 20 percent of the units, a requirement of the zoning, would have two bedrooms.
If a small building like this was being put up in an area where there was nothing else around, she said, it would be hard to lease. "Here," she said, "the market was made with the Longacre House and the Gershwin."
Mr. Levine said all those factors entered into his decision last May to buy the 50th Street site and design a building that complied with the zoning. Plans for the parking garage require a special permit from the City Planning Commission, and an application for it has been filed, said Michael T. Sillerman, a partner at the law firm of Rosenman & Colin, which represents the developer.
Complying with the zoning rules will produce a building that is longer than it is high. But it will have "an undulated facade of honey- and burgundy-colored brick to create the feeling of a number of smaller buildings," said James S. Davidson, design partner at the Manhattan firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman & Efron, the project's architect. It will, he added, "be a simple affair, enhanced by a polished granite base and minimum decorative trim, not unlike the architecture of the side-street buildings that line Clinton."
Occupancy is expected to begin by the end of 2001.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Nielsen Releases Local Internet Data

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOT 

 BODY:
The first monthly data on Internet use in the 20 largest local markets from Nielsen Net Ratings, an Internet measurement service, show interesting variations among different parts of the country.
In the study, compiled in February, four of the five top local markets with the largest percentage of people with Internet access were on the West Coast: San Francisco, with 61 percent; San Diego, 58 percent; Seattle, 55.9 percent; and Portland, Ore., 54 percent. The exception was Washington, at 56.1 percent. 
 In terms of Internet audiences, the total number of people online, the No. 1 market was New York, followed by Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago and Boston. San Diego had the highest average time spent online per person, at almost 11 hours and 16 minutes during the month. Nielsen Net Ratings, which continues to issue national Internet data, is a joint venture of Nielsen Media Research in New York and NetRatings Inc. in Milpitas, Calif.

HEADLINE: New Problems With Welfare-to-Work

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration faces a new set of problems from the latest setback to its welfare-to-work program.
Welfare recipients who need help getting private-sector jobs can no longer be referred to Maximus, the Virginia company whose $104 million in contracts with the city were thrown out yesterday by a judge. The company, which was supposed to handle about 2,000 people a month, has suspended its operations in the city in response to the ruling. 
 Debra Sproles, a spokeswoman for the Human Resources Administration, said it was too soon to say what approach the city would take to handle those referrals in the short term. "We expect any adverse impact to be limited because we believe the appeal decision will reverse this decision," she said.
Public assistance recipients will still be required to work at city jobs like park cleanup and filing in exchange for their benefits.
But they may have difficulty making the move into private-sector jobs, because in anticipation of the large contracts with Maximus and other winning vendors, the city allowed old contracts for smaller-scale job training and placement programs to lapse over the last several months. Some of the losers in the contracting process that Maximus won were forced to close their doors months ago.
Maureen Bentley, assistant executive director of Fedcap, a nonprofit vocational agency that had run job placement programs in seven city welfare offices, said that those programs had been continued month-to-month for a while at the city's request, but that the last ones had ended on March 31 when the nonprofit group's lease ran out and much of its staff was hired away by the winning contractors.
Executives at several other nonprofit agencies complained that referrals of welfare recipients had slowed to a trickle late last year, apparently in anticipation of the new contracts.
The other winning vendors, including Curtis & Associates, a Nebraska-based profit-making rival of Maximus, are still gearing up to fulfill their own new contracts. Those contracts were delayed for weeks as the city comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, challenged the mayor's use of an award process that restricted competition.
"It would be silly for anyone to say there is going to be no disruption," said Dean Curtis, of Curtis & Associates, which has $34 million in contracts. "We will work with them to help them out, but our capacities at this point are pretty tight, so we'll have a hard time providing additional services with any quality."
He said that uncertainty over the contracts had prompted him to give his staff 10 days' notice, which he rescinded, and that he had lost an office lease when he hesitated to sign it.
Though the city estimated it would send 1,000 welfare recipients a month to Curtis, Mr. Curtis said referrals were running around 400, in part because of "bugs to be worked out" in the process. And the booming economy may be absorbing the more job-ready recipients without the contractors' help, he said.
Critics of the contracting process say it would be unfair to divide $104 million in Maximus contracts among other winning vendors.
"All we ask is for an equal playing field," said Glenn Pasanen, director of City Project, a budget watchdog organization that has called for all the contracts -- nearly $500 million worth -- to be rebid in a fully open and competitive way. The city could use short-term contracts for any clients needing immediate service, he said, "but the fair and proper thing to do is to quickly open up the $104 million worth of contracts to rebidding."
He added: "An open process means current contractors can expand and that contractors who lost have another chance."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had vigorously defended the contracting process as a speedier way to put public assistance recipients to work before they reach the federal five-year time limit on benefits.
Late last year Mr. Giuliani announced that he had fulfilled the pledge he made to end welfare as New York City knows it by shifting thousands of recipients into work, job training or treatment, and taking away benefits from the rest.
Mr. Giuliani said that all able-bodied welfare recipients without infant children were now either in jobs or taking steps to get them. His critics on the City Council immediately challenged his numbers, saying he counted recipients who had merely been referred for evaluation for work or other programs, like the programs thrown into confusion yesterday by the judge's ruling.

HEADLINE: ART IN REVIEW;
Craigie Aitchison

BYLINE: By Ken Johnson 

 BODY:

 Ramis Barquet
 41 East 57th Street
 Manhattan
 Through May 6
Craigie Aitchison has had a distinguished enough painting career in England to earn a C.B.E. (Commander of the British Empire), but until now he has never had a solo exhibition in the United States. This uneven show of mostly recent works, including many little confectionery sketches, makes one wish for a more judiciously selected retrospective.
Born in 1926, Mr. Aitchison turned from law studies to art in the early 1950's. Inspired by early French Modernism and American Color Field painters of the 50's, he has always favored thin, broad areas of pure color, abbreviated, sometimes childlike imagery and a mood of poetic sweetness bordering on the saccharine. 
 The exhibition includes a number of crucifixions, one of the artist's favorite themes. In a five-and-a-half-foot-high canvas from 1979, a small cartoonish representation of an armless Christ on the cross is isolated against a barren but intensely colored landscape. In the orange ground, purple mountain and red sky, subtly mottled, rubbed-in paint calls to mind Mark Rothko or Milton Avery.
Mr. Aitchison is good when he abstracts from life, as in recent paperback-size still lifes made with Bonnardian economy. But he is best in portraiture. In a 1984 picture of a beautiful young Indian man, his features rendered in deftly brushed lines and his green jacket set off by a flat background of vibrant orange, there is a perfect balance of cool formality and warm intimacy. KEN JOHNSON

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

THE AMERICAS
 
CANADA: FRENCH RULING
A Quebec court ruled that the government of the mainly French-speaking province has the right to limit use of English and to impose French as the dominant language on commercial signs. In reversing a lower court decision, Justice Paul-Marcel Bellavance of the Superior Court noted that Quebec's six million French speakers are surrounded by 300 million English speakers, saying, "Quebec is in a unique linguistic situation in the world." James Brooke (NYT)
 
COLOMBIA: LIMITED TRUCE
The second-largest leftist guerrilla group, the Army of National Liberation, has announced a limited 10-day Easter truce and said it would release the four-member crew of an Avianca Airlines flight hijacked a year ago. The truce will apply only to civilian targets. Larry Rohter (NYT)

President Gustavo Noboa has petitioned Congress to grant an amnesty to more than 100 soldiers and civilians who took part in the coup that overthrew his predecessor, Jamil Mahuad, in January. Noting that the uprising "was not bloody," Mr. Noboa argued that a pardon would "help peace and tranquillity in our country." The proposal must be passed by a two-thirds vote. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
BRAZIL: SQUABBLING AIDES FIRED
A public dispute between the justice minister and Brazil's anti-drug czar over management of counter-narcotics policy has resulted in the firing of both men by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso. The two had been feuding over control of the federal police, who are increasingly being deployed in drug operations along Brazil's borders. Jose Gregori, above, the human rights secretary, becomes the third justice minister in less than a year. Larry Rohter (NYT)

In the stepup of a drug war at the United States border, three drug agents, including an army captain, were killed in Tijuana, said the head of Mexico's anti-drug operations. The agents were investigating a cocaine syndicate run by the Arellano Felix brothers, he said. Julia Preston (NYT)

Orange Order marchers planning their first parade in Dublin since the 1930's next month will not be able to use a downtown church for a service, the Church of Ireland, the main Protestant body, said. HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Business Group Urges Delay in New Investments in Zimbabwe

BYLINE: By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, April 14

 BODY:
In a warning that underscores the widening reach of Zimbabwe's economic and political meltdown, the biggest business and trade organization in South Africa this week urged its 40,000 members to delay any new investment in the crisis-ridden neighbor.
Already, a number of South African companies with significant interests in Zimbabwe have taken steps to shield themselves from the escalating problems there, said Kevin Wakeford, the chief executive of the trade organization, the South African Chamber of Business. 
 Hundreds of farms in Zimbabwe have been raided in recent weeks by black squatters, raising concern about the state of the country's important agricultural sector and heightening fears about the deeply unsettled political situation.
The squatters, led by veterans of the 1970's guerrilla war against white minority rule, say they are reclaiming land stolen decades ago from their ancestors by white settlers. President Robert Mugabe, who has made little progress in redistributing land in his 20 years in power, has condoned the farm invasions despite a Zimbabwe court order against them. Mr. Mugabe considers the squatters disenfranchised peasants who make up most of the country's population and who have been the base of his party's power.
Trade with Zimbabwe, South Africa's largest trading partner in the region, makes up about 3.5 percent of South Africa's total exports and heavily favors South Africa. Still South Africa, with its far bigger economy, sees trade with its neighbor, though small in total volume compared with the European Union and the United States, as strategically important.
The economic troubles have hobbled that trade, in both directions. Zimbabwe has been short of cash, and after international donors accused the government of mismanagement and cut off loans, the shortage worsened.
Currency and credit problems have followed, and now the volatile atmosphere has added another obstacle, with traders in recent days finding it increasingly difficult to insure goods.
On Thursday, after days of futility, National Ingredients Supplies, a South African food processing company and a unit of Anglovaal Industries, finally found an underwriter for the $8 million of soybeans it bought earlier this year. Only Lloyd's of London was willing to insure the stockpile, much of it sitting in a silo on an occupied farm. The insurance will cost five times the normal price, said Steve Brooks, National's logistics manager.
Business leaders said such problems, if they persist, would erode all of southern Africa's reputation.
The depth of Zimbabwe's economic problems are reflected in the basic financial data on the country.
Inflation in Zimbabwe soared 70 percent last year and is projected at 65 percent this year, according to the World Bank. Gross domestic product growth was zero last year and is forecast to fall 1 percent this year. The fiscal deficit is growing, and the value of the Zimbabwe dollar has fallen by half in the last year.
Foreign exchange reserves have plunged, making it much harder for the country and its businesses to pay for imported goods, notably fuel.
African Oxygen, a South African producer and distributor of industrial gases and a unit of the BOC Group, sells supplies to a sister company, BOC Zimbabwe, and the effects of the foreign currency shortage have been severe, said Jimmy Marriott, executive director for industrial operations at African Oxygen.
"They are certainly not getting the level of foreign exchange that they used to in the past," he said. "It hasn't been available to them."
South Africa's Tongaat-Hulett Group, a large producer of sugar, employs 8,000 people in Zimbabwe and for the last three years has been sitting on plans for a $100 million expansion in Zimbabwe. The country's unpredictable land politics, the crumbling economy and now the breakdown of law and order have kept Tongaat-Hulett from moving forward with its plans, the company's chief executive, Cedric Savage, said.
"Ironically, it's still one of the best places to invest in agriculture," Mr. Savage said. "It's the lowest cost producer of sugar in the world. It's a place where economically you'd want to invest money, but politically, just about every political action taken discourages that."

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 4; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1512 words

HEADLINE: A Sojourner In the Past Retraces His Steps;
In a New Cultural History, Jacques Barzun, 92, Finds the West Decadent Though Not Hopeless

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
Before coming to the United States to begin his studies at Columbia University in 1923, Jacques Barzun perfected his English by studying Swift's "Gulliver's Travels." It was an unusual primer, but Barzun's childhood, like Swift's, had been shattered by war, and disarray and darkness were on his mind. A few years earlier, at the age of 12, the young Barzun had contemplated suicide. The First World War had left many he knew dead or maimed. His parents' salon in their house in Creteil, near Paris, at which artists and writers like Apollinaire and Cocteau gathered, had come to an end. The French universities at which he would have studied were decimated. So he devoted himself to learning English under the tutelage of the sardonic Swift before beginning his own travels among peoples that were to him only a bit less exotic than Gulliver's Yahoos and Brobdingnags.
"I had read a lot of books about the Indians," Mr. Barzun recently explained in an interview at his daughter's apartment in Manhattan. "I thought that I would come here and see Indians galloping across the plains." 
 Instead, as he settled into New York, he began a series of intellectual journeys, turning his back on any chance he might have had to become a French diplomat and writer like his father. He became, instead, one of the founders of the modern discipline of cultural history. He wrote about 18th-century France and 19th-century Europe, about the art of the detective novel and the life of the composer Hector Berlioz. For nearly 50 years he taught history at Columbia, eventually becoming its provost, and led seminars with Lionel Trilling that were legendary for their rigor and range. He wrote over 30 books, translated nearly a dozen more, and now, at the age of 92, has finished an epic chronicle of his historical forays, a survey of 500 years of Western cultural life, "From Dawn to Decadence" (HarperCollins), to be published next month.
Its 800 pages condense his teaching career, surveying the tumultuous mixing of intellectual, religious and cultural traditions that make up what we now call the West, creating, as Mr. Barzun puts it, "the mongrel civilization par excellence." When he talks about his vision of this civilization and its discontents, his conversation ranges as widely as the book, touching on Kant, amateur musicianship, Trilling, the Rhodes scholarship, the counterculture and the Protestant Reformation. Mr. Barzun's face is leaner and more lined than it once was, his voice is less vigorous, and he walks carefully with a cane. But the only other sign that he is in his 10th decade is that he has accumulated a long lifetime of literary references and historical arguments.
He recalls the atmosphere at Columbia during the 1920's, when cultural history was just taking shape as a discipline. During the 1890's, he explains, the social sciences underwent "a great upheaval." Emile Durkheim was transforming sociology and William James, psychology, not by defining narrow professional boundaries but, as Mr. Barzun puts it, by starting to pay attention to "the most generalized form of cultural activity."
"Anthropologists put the final touch to it," he continues, "by defining culture among primitive peoples as everything they did: the way they ate, their canoes, their marriage customs -- nothing was left out. When that idea is applied to history, you find that the arts, social customs, government, religion and so forth all become part of cultural history." At Columbia, Mr. Barzun recalls, C. J. H. Hayes, the author of a widely used two-volume textbook "The Political and Social History of Modern Europe," was planning its revision as "The Political and Cultural History of Modern Europe." Mr. Barzun, Hayes's student, assisted in the research and was, as he says, "launched."
The cultural study of history has now become so thoroughly mainstream -- even mutating into contemporary forms like cultural studies -- that it might seem strange to hear just how novel it once was. What made it distinctive, Mr. Barzun explains, was that it refused to be bound by categories of politics, economics or philosophy. Every thinker, Mr. Barzun suggests, "is born into a cultural situation, and we must find out why he picks up the thread here and not there, and why he modifies it and how it is related to what else is happening at the time."
Cultural history creates a web of interrelationships. Understanding the past does not just mean, say, tracing a philosophical idea through time, but seeing how that idea is woven into a cultural fabric. And cultural history, as Mr. Barzun thinks of it, traces the evolution of that fabric through time. It creates a coherent view of the past and its relationship to the present. By showing continuities and transformations in a tradition, it makes sense of the idea of a civilization.
The challenge for the cultural historian, watching these complex relationships unfold, is even more difficult because the frame of reference for judging those past eras is the constantly shifting present. In his book "Classic, Romantic, and Modern," Mr. Barzun points out that a cultural historian "must lead a double life": he must "see the strivings of past epochs with generous fellow feeling" and must also feel "the needs -- which includes the lacks -- of his own time." The fellow feeling means that the past is understood in comparison with the present; the present is understood in comparison with the past.
This is also what Mr. Barzun tries to accomplish in "From Dawn to Decadence," which focuses on a series of evolving ideas -- ideas he capitalizes throughout the text, like emancipation, abstraction, individualism, secularism.
He suggests that there have been four principal eras in recent Western history. The first, which started with the Protestant Reformation in 1517, dealt with the issue of "what to believe in religion." The second, which encompassed the 18th century and ended with the French Revolution in 1789, dealt with the issue of "what to do about the status of the individual and the mode of government." The third, which started with 19th-century Romanticism and ended with Modernism after World War I, tried to determine "by what means to achieve social and economic equality."
The fourth is ending now. As he sees it, the fundamental themes are less clear than they were in past eras, partly because old certainties are unraveling. The West may be politically and economically triumphant, but it is plagued by doubts. Postmodern assertions that there are no absolute truths and that all cultural suppositions are relative displace the rigors of scrutiny that marked the development of the West. The nation-state, which evolved out of Western political thought during the last 500 years, is being challenged by separatist passions. The central Western notion of emancipation has now come to mean that "nothing stands in the way of every wish," in Mr. Barzun's words. And in the arts, creativity is celebrated as a universal talent, diminishing the achievements of genius. Our age is, in Mr. Barzun's words, decadent.
A decadent era, in Mr. Barzun's lexicon, is a period in which there is a kind of "falling off," a restless period in which "there are no clear lines of advance." "When people accept futility and the absurd as normal," he writes, "the culture is decadent. The term is not a slur; it is a technical label." And though it often seems a slur in Mr. Barzun's book, its intimations of decay also provide some reason for hope.
After all, Mr. Barzun suggests, other more extreme periods of decadence -- which include the corrupt 17th-century universe of Swift or the 15th century before the Reformation challenged the corruption of the medieval Church -- were followed by periods of reconstruction, in which Western culture was re-examined and reconstituted. For example, he says, the Romantic movement of the early 19th century is too often considered a celebration of passion, irrationality or sentiment. Instead, Mr. Barzun argues, it was an attempt to construct a cultural order out of the wreckage of the French Revolution. Romanticism did not destroy an order; it created one.
That is also, in Mr. Barzun's view, what the West may be looking forward to. If Western traditions are worn and frayed, that is "all to the good, because it clears the ground," he says, leaving the way open for future construction. This tension between destruction and creation is also, he suggests, an essential aspect of Western culture. The West has itself been so successful, Mr. Barzun says, partly because of "continual debates between orthodoxy and rebellion and the strange ability of individuals to stand out for their accomplishments." Out of such tensions, decadence may lead to a new dawn.
Mankind is resilient, Mr. Barzun believes, despite his mordant view of the present. What is to come can only be imagined: "It is only in the shadows; when some fresh wave, truly original, truly creative, breaks upon the shore, that there will be a rediscovery of the West."

HEADLINE: Developing Nations End Meeting With a Call to Share the Wealth

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HAVANA, April 14

 BODY:
Leaders of developing nations, ending a three-day summit meeting here today, called for a "new global human order" to spread the world's wealth and power.
"One day, humankind will be called to account," said Belize's prime minister, Said Musa. "How come you never made no connection between growing poverty for the many and booming wealth for a few?" 
 Dozens of presidents and prime ministers complained during the conference that globalization of the world's economic and information systems had done little but damage their countries.
Draft resolutions due to be adopted late today called for a shake-up of the world financial system to give developing countries greater say over economic and trade policies, for forgiveness of foreign debt and for sharply increased foreign aid.
Many leaders here were sharply critical of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, asserting that both organizations, which are set to begin meetings of their own in Washington on Sunday, force governments to make painful policy changes in exchange for aid.
"They told us these measures would stabilize our economy," Mr. Said said. "Instead, they have stabilized poverty."
The World Bank reported Thursday that the global financial crisis of 1997-98 had dealt a setback to efforts to relieve poverty. Some 1.2 billion people were forced to survive on less than $1 a day in 1998, it said.

HEADLINE: Hunt for Holocaust Victims' Property Turns in New Direction: Toward Israel

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, April 14

 BODY:
In a basement meeting room in the Israeli Parliament, a committee of legislators is trying to unravel a tangled and troubling legacy of the Holocaust that has gone unexplored for decades.
The committee, led by Colette Avital, a lawmaker from the governing One Israel Party and former Israeli consul general in New York, is investigating what happened to bank accounts, plots of land and other assets that were held in Israel by Jews who died in the Holocaust. 
 Begun in February at Ms. Avital's initiative, the parliamentary inquiry reflects a growing sense here that Israel should practice what it has preached. In recent years Jewish organizations, backed by Israel, have demanded, with a significant measure of success, that foreign banks and governments disclose possible holdings of accounts and other property of Holocaust victims and survivors, so the assets can be returned to the victims' relatives.
Switzerland agreed more than a year ago to pay compensation of $1.25 billion after more than 54,000 dormant accounts traced back to World War II or earlier were found in Swiss banks.
An international panel investigating insurance policies held by Holocaust victims announced last week that it would publish 19,000 names of policyholders who are owed money.
But it has also emerged that there are untraced assets of Holocaust victims in Israel. Although the property is thought to be far less than the assets held in Europe, its very existence here has raised unsettling questions, especially among survivors and their children.
"We have to come with clean hands when we make demands on foreign institutions," said Gil Raveh, a lawyer from Tel Aviv who is trying to trace what became of 1,000 deposited in the 1930's in British-ruled Palestine by his great-grandfather and a business partner.
Moshe Sanbar, chairman of the Center of Organizations of Holocaust Survivors in Israel, said that when it came to tracing property of Jews who died in the Holocaust, "Israel has a greater moral responsibility and should set a good example, not a bad one."
Jewish investments in Palestine were of a different nature than the money transferred to Swiss banks for safekeeping. Jews in Europe bought plots of land and opened bank accounts in Palestine in the 1920's and 1930's as a way of taking part in the Zionist enterprise or as nest eggs for possible immigration by them or their children.
The sum of the investments has never been determined. Estimates range from $40 million in deposited money to land believed to be worth tens of millions more, including prime real estate in the heart of Israel. European Jews also bought stocks and bonds from Zionist agencies and kept money in safe deposit boxes whose whereabouts are unknown.
After the outbreak of World War II, land and bank accounts held by Jews from countries under Nazi rule were seized by the British mandate government in Palestine as enemy property, and most of the money was transferred to England.
Under a settlement with Israel in 1950, the British government paid back 1.4 million as compensation for the removed funds. Records of the seized accounts and land were turned over to the Israeli government, and some restitution payments were reportedly made, but the fate of other accounts and properties remains unclear.
For decades the matter generated little interest here. Holocaust survivors who came to Palestine and later to the nascent state of Israel were focused on rebuilding their lives and tracing missing relatives, not recovering lost property.
In those early years of nation-building and in subsequent decades there were other priorities, said Dr. Yossi Katz, a professor at Bar-Ilan University near Tel Aviv whose study of Holocaust-era assets in Israel, "Forgotten Property," was published this week.
"Until the 90's the issue didn't trouble the public," Dr. Katz said. "Other matters were seen as far more important, such as security and absorption of immigrants. It's safe to assume that had the issue not come up recently in Europe, it would not have come up in Israel."
"There was a reluctance here to deal with the the Holocaust in economic terms," Dr. Katz added. "It was inconceivable to turn the Holocaust into a material issue. A younger generation had to come along that was not directly linked to the Holocaust and could deal with it less sentimentally."
Ms. Avital said that on the official level, bureaucratic inertia had prevented effective action to trace and return the unclaimed assets. "There was a lot of neglect and lack of sensitivity," she said.
Even as Holocaust-era claims were pressed loudly in Europe, concerns were voiced that a similar campaign to find assets here would provoke foreign demands that Israel first put its own house in order, undercutting the drive for full disclosure abroad.
"My argument was exactly the opposite," Ms. Avital said. "We have a much better moral position when we can go to the Swiss banks and say we're asking of you what we're asking of ourselves."
Bank disclosures abroad led to similar steps in Israel.
Prodded by hearings in a parliamentary committee, Israeli banks last year handed over lists of 5,000 dormant accounts to the administrator general, a Justice Ministry official who manages unclaimed property. In 1997 the administrator general's office published a list of more than 11,000 unclaimed bank accounts and real estate holdings it manages.
In January, Bank Leumi, an Israeli bank that succeeded the pre-independence Anglo-Palestine Bank, where many of the deposits by European Jews were made, published on its Internet site a list of accounts that have been inactive since 1955 or earlier. The Jewish National Fund, a land development agency, published on its site a list of plots it holds that were sold to Jews before World War II and remain unclaimed.
An Israeli lawyer, Roland Roth, has filed suits on behalf of relatives of Holocaust victims against Bank Leumi and the privately owned Israel Land Development Company, originally set up by the Zionist movement to buy land in Palestine. Contending that the bank has not reported all of the dormant accounts in its possession, Mr. Roth is demanding full disclosure of the accounts and of lands bought by Jews who died in the Holocaust.
Although Israeli banks and the land company have resisted opening their records to outside scrutiny, their stance and the government's inaction are not seen here as comparable to past attempts in Switzerland and elsewhere to deny the existence of Holocaust-era assets and to even cover up their traces.
"Here it was negligence at best; in Switzerland it was a crime," said Yona Yahav, a former legislator who as chairman of the parliamentary banking committee pressed for the Israeli bank disclosures.
Even if no moral equivalence can be drawn between banks in Israel and Switzerland, the banks here are motivated by a similar desire to preserve their assets, Mr. Roth argued. "Every economic body has an interest in holding on to what it can," he said.
Yet it remains unclear how many Holocaust-era assets are unaccounted for.
Shmuel Tsur, the administrator general, says there are few if any Jewish-owned bank accounts and properties that were not confiscated by the British in wartime Palestine as enemy property and later either returned to their owners or transferred for management by his office. Of the list of unclaimed accounts and properties published by his office, fewer than 10 have been recovered after claims to them were confirmed, he said.
"This shows that there is no real problem here," he said in an interview. "I don't know of any reservoir of money or property that is hidden away somewhere in Israel. The public sense that property is being concealed is wrong."
Yet when he was questioned last month by Ms. Avital's committee, Mr. Tsur acknowledged that he could not be sure that he had received full reports from the banks of all dormant accounts, adding that he was not authorized to audit bank records. "I start from the assumption that the bank reports are correct," he said.
Under pressure to do more to find properties of Holocaust victims, Mr. Tsur's office has begun an examination of the 15,000 files of unclaimed property in his office to find evidence of assets that belonged to Jews who died in World War II.
The parliamentary committee is considering ways to empower Mr. Tsur or an independent auditor to examine bank records, as part of a more active government policy to find heirs to property owned by Holocaust victims. "We do have a moral obligation towards these people," Ms. Avital said, noting that in some cases sums returned by Mr. Tsur's office were absurdly low, an indication that deposited money had not been invested by the banks or maintained at its real value.
Relatives of Holocaust victims who have gone to court to claim their inheritance say they are not motivated by a desire for material gain.
Eleazar Shafrir, 76, a retired biochemistry professor who fled a Nazi labor camp in Poland and fought in Israel's war of independence, is trying to locate a plot of land bought in 1938 by his father, who died in Auschwitz.
"I'm not going to get rich from this," he said. "I just want justice to be done. The state should give people back what they deserve."
