SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 714 words

HEADLINE: Stopping the World

 BODY:
In Washington this weekend, a disparate gathering of protesters will be rallying against what they view as the malign forces of economic globalization. The dissidents' message is sometimes confused and misplaced, especially in wanting to dismantle essential institutions like the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization. But the protesters, who call themselves the Mobilization for Global Justice, also represent a popular response -- misguided but heartfelt -- to a worldwide economic transformation that is not fully comprehended even by the experts. To be sure, some interest groups are trying to manipulate public concern for their own advantage. But it would be dangerous to ignore a growing popular unease over these trends and the need for broader educational efforts.
Despite the dramatic stock market decline yesterday, the fact remains that the United States has on balance benefited from the unbridled flow of capital, goods, people and information that is called globalization. The dislocations felt by American workers have been far outweighed by the benefits of cheap imports, low inflation and expanding opportunities for American businesses overseas. Abroad, the poor countries benefiting from expanded markets outnumber those hurt by them. 
 Nevertheless, the new world order has created hardship in declining or newly uncompetitive industries. Some nations see globalization as a code word for American domination. Many fear that the World Bank, I.M.F. and W.T.O. are pursuing the interests of an American-led elite, to the detriment of the poor and the environment. Critics on both the left and right have begun to question whether the world would be better off without these institutions.
Certainly the institutions that manage the world economy must be more sensitive and transparent. But their real challenge is to help everyone understand that there is no realistic -- or beneficial -- way to reverse or even slow the forces that are driving the world economy. Just as American businesses have begun to discover that in the world of an Internet-driven economy the old rules have to be scrapped or adjusted, so countries around the world will have to learn to adjust to the new market forces if they want to harness them to their advantage. Underdeveloped countries have to learn that capital is voluntary, and does not flow to countries that do not obey its rules.
Since the end of the cold war, there have been at least four major currency crises that threatened to destabilize regional economies: in Europe in 1992-93, Mexico in 1994-95, East Asia in 1997 and Russia and Brazil in 1998. Each had the potential for spiraling out of control. The critics descending on Washington argue that the I.M.F. and the World Bank sometimes made these crises worse, while their defenders assert that without the difficulties inflicted, the crises would have grown worse. One thing is certain. There will be more crises to come in the years ahead. The institutions that handle them need to be reformed, not weakened.
The anti-globalization protesters invoke the tactics and styles of the 1960's. But a closer analogy may be early struggles over the burgeoning of capitalism in the 19th century. It was then that disputes between owners and workers and about public costs and private gain led to an age of ideological conflict.
Today's struggle has the added element ofchanging definitions of national sovereignty. Indeed, poor countries are not the only worriers. Europeans are also increasingly wary of American demands to open their economies to American products. As boundaries become more economically irrelevant, one question is whether people will seek refuge in their national identities or in the familiar if transitory comforts of placards, chants and street theater in places like Washington.
Yet today's global economic drama is deeply familiar to students of American history -- how to reconcile the demands of economic growth and opportunity with the need to preserve fairness, stability and the health and welfare of each country's citizens. It is today a challenge without borders. Meeting it calls for more sophisticated international institutions, not a retreat into nostalgia and economic nationalism.

HEADLINE: Nafta Scorecard on Jobs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your April 13 news article about union protests against the potential trade agreement with China states that unspecified studies have found that the North American Free Trade Agreement "created fewer jobs than its proponents predicted and killed fewer than its critics have asserted."
This statement misses the point of the debate. Nafta's supporters predicted a net gain in jobs because the trade surplus with Mexico would rise. But after Nafta went into effect, the small trade surplus with Mexico turned into what is now a $23 billion deficit. Using the Department of Commerce's formula, this translates into 90,000 jobs eliminated in the last year alone. 
 People may differ over the exact numbers, but simple arithmetic shows that Nafta has eliminated more jobs in the United States than it created.
 
JEFF FAUX
Washington, April 13, 2000
 
The writer is president of the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: Inflation Spreading Beyond Fuel and Energy;
Recent Robust Market Is Linked to Rising Prices

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
For weeks an accelerating inflation rate was confined to fuel and energy, but in March it spread to other areas of the American economy. The change suggests that the robust demand generated by the stock market had finally given business the power to raise prices and make them stick.
The announcement of the inflation breakthrough -- in the form of a 0.7 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index -- came from the Labor Department yesterday an hour before the stock markets opened and contributed to the huge sell-off. 
 "Markets move on emotion," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities. "They were nervous coming into the trading day and traders seized on the C.P.I. as justification for continuing to be bearish."
The chief concern is that rising inflation will encourage the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates even more than the quarter-point increases that Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, has promised over the next two or three months to slow the economy and ease down stock prices. Rich stock portfolios financed much of the spending that has created so much demand and helped to increase the inflation rate in March.
Rising energy prices made the biggest contribution to the rise in the overall rate, which was the largest one-month jump since last April. Gasoline prices alone rose 11 percent, to $1.594 a gallon, on average, the highest level -- ignoring inflation -- ever recorded by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
What caught the market's attention, however, was the so-called core inflation rate, which measures all price increases except those for energy and food, which are considered too volatile to provide a clear picture. This core rate rose 0.4 percent in March, double the monthly increase over most of the last two years. Not since January 1995 has the core rate risen this much.
"It is hard to draw any grand conclusions from this core number," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities. "Whether it signals an inflection point or is simply the result of a number of aberrations, no one can say yet. I am more in the aberration camp."
The increases were fairly widespread. Furnishing, renovating and repairing a home, for example, grew more costly in March, perhaps because families cashed in stock or borrowed against their portfolios to upgrade their homes. Hotels and resort rates also rose smartly. "You have a lot of people with a lot of money and they apparently want to take time off and vacation," said Patrick Jackman, a senior economist in the bureau's division that produces the price index.
Rising wages in these industries may also have helped to nudge up the inflation rate, analysts said. Certainly labor costs played a role in March's 0.5 percent increase in medical care costs. Most of that was a result of higher doctors' fees, although hospital charges also rose.
"Tight labor markets are almost certainly beginning to have some impact on consumer prices," said Chris Varvares, a partner at Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis.
Airline fares jumped 4.6 percent in March, pushed up by the cost of fuel, airlines say. Tobacco prices jumped, primarily because of increases in cigarette taxes, especially a 55-cent-a-pack rise in New York State. And vehicle prices rose, mainly because General Motors canceled a $500 rebate on most of its vehicles.
In March, the still-booming stock market helped sustain the demand for new cars, but if this week's sell-off continues, auto sales are likely to fall, prompting car companies to step up discounts and generally easing the pressure on prices.
"Everything could change in the next few weeks," said Edward Hyman, president of the ISI Group, a Wall Street investment firm. "The market is getting crushed, and if demand weakens with the market, pricing power is going to be crushed, too. This morning the report I got from our auto survey showed that luxury car sales in the New York City area were as good as they could possibly be. That cannot last without a strong stock market, and the car companies will respond with discounts."
For all of 1999, the core inflation rate was only 1.9 percent, but with last month's jump the average over the previous 12 months moved up to 2.4 percent. When food and energy are added back, the 12-month moving average in the overall price index has gone from 2.7 percent in December to 3.7 percent in March.
That is well above the inflation target of about 2 percent that has guided Fed policy in recent years. If the higher inflation rate endures, the Fed will almost certainly continue to push up rates, probably a quarter point each time its policy makers meet. The next meeting is on May 16. But if stock prices keep falling or fail to rebound, that could alter the Fed's thinking. Mr. Greenspan has said he would cut rates if he thought that a market sell-off was endangering the economy.
"The good news is that another Fed rate increase is no longer as inevitable as it seemed early this week," Mr. Yardeni said. "The Fed does not like to act in periods of market uncertainty."

HEADLINE: Albert Turner Is Dead at 64; Strove for Civil Rights in South

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
Albert Turner, a civil rights leader and adviser to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Thursday in Selma, Ala. He was 64.
Mr. Turner's heart stopped while he was being prepared for an operation to stop abdominal bleeding, said his brother, Robert. 
 Mr. Turner helped lead the voting rights march from Selma to Montgomery, on March 7, 1965. Stick-wielding state troopers turned the peaceful protesters back on the Edmund Pettus Bridge over the Alabama River in a confrontation that became known as Bloody Sunday. Protesters were beaten, chased and tear-gassed. Mr. Turner, wearing a cap, can be seen in contemporary photographs of the front lines of marchers.
Describing the events of that day, Mr. Turner said in an interview: "I fell down and ran. Then I fell down again and ran some more."
J. L. Chestnut, a Selma lawyer and longtime friend, said, "Whenever there was something of unusual danger, and nobody wanted to, you could count on the fact that Albert and John Lewis would lead it." Mr. Lewis later went on to become a Democratic Congressman from Georgia.
Mr. Turner, who was Alabama field secretary for the Southern Christian Leadership Conference at the height of the civil rights movement, was chosen three years after the march to lead the mule wagon that carried the body of Dr. King at his funeral.
The son of a sharecropper, Mr. Turner was born on Feb. 29, 1936, in a four-room shack outside of Marion, Ala. He was the fourth of 12 children. He studied bricklaying and later graduated from Alabama A & M. In July 1963, with the help of a federal injunction, Mr. Turner and about 40 others registered to vote at the county courthouse in Marion. Lawsuits surrounding these efforts to register formed a model for President Lyndon B. Johnson's voting-rights bill.
"I really do not know of a single individual in Alabama who has given more to the political progress of African-Americans in this state than Albert," Mr. Chestnut said. "Albert would hide the fact that he would have a college degree because he was trying to reach always those people at the bottom. Martin understood that, and that's what endeared Albert to Martin, and why Albert was the point man in Alabama."
With his wife, Evelyn, Mr. Turner was cleared of voter fraud in the 1980's, when prosecutors charged them with altering absentee ballots collected from rural blacks.
After the not guilty verdict, President Ronald Reagan nominated Mr. Turner's prosecutor, Jefferson B. Sessions, to the Federal District Court in Alabama. The nomination died in the Senate Judicial Committee after concerns were raised about the voter fraud prosecutions.
"The indictments come because blacks have gotten too well organized for political empowerment in the Black Belt of Alabama," Mr. Turner said at the time he was acquitted. "They didn't spend a million dollars because they think a few old folks' ballots were changed."
In recent years, Mr. Turner, an insurance salesman, served on the Perry County Commission, where he was active in preserving adequate health care in the county, where many hospitals serving rural communities are closing. He was also on the search committee to find a new police chief for Marion, the county seat.
"He was very smart and knowledgeable about politics in this area of Alabama," said another commissioner, Charles LeCroy. "He supported everything Dr. King advocated, and he brought his people up socially, economically and politically during his time in office. He'll be missed by people here in Perry County."
Mr. Turner is survived by his wife; three sons, Barrett of Indianapolis, Eric of Birmingham, and Albert Jr. of Marion; a daughter, Eldra Marcus of Tuskegee, Ala.; and nine brothers and sisters, and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Causes That Are Too Celebre

BYLINE: By Gregg Easterbrook; Gregg Easterbrook is a columnist for BeliefNet.com and author of Beside Still Waters: Searching for Meaning in an Age of Doubt.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Fourteen-year-old girls everywhere can breathe now that ABC News has decided to go ahead and broadcast its Earth Day special in which Leonardo DiCaprio, crusading journalist, questions President Clinton about global warming. Personally, I know I'll be waiting for his question on the latest Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change science-assessment revisions, especially as they apply to new studies on ocean-current fluid dynamics when compared to the watts-per-square-foot forcing of anthropogenic gases, and how this will affect the Kyoto Annex I plans for joint implementation of carbon sequestration.
Be these things as they may, ABC asserts that it is sending a teen heartthrob to interview the president about global warming in order to raise public awareness of the issue. But it's fair to suppose that one reason public concern over the greenhouse effect is low is exactly that Hollywood is on the case. When the networks and movie studios treat global warming as a subject so trifling, it can be safely passed off from serious discussion to glam events hosted by celebrities. 
 This is hardly the first time the entertainment world has tried to raise awareness on global warming. In 1993, CBS broadcast a preposterous miniseries, "The Fire Next Time," to great fanfare. It depicted the United States in the year 2007 as a nation destroyed by global warming. In the miniseries, a man and boy attempt to travel a nation wracked by searing heat, sustained droughts, monster storms and dangerous exposure to bad dialogue.
Conservative critics were aghast, saying the miniseries indoctrinated mass audiences with greenhouse scenarios far worse than any predicted even by the most pessimistic scientists. Yet there was no evidence that public concern for the environment rose in the wake of the CBS broadcasts, and shortly afterward Americans voted in the anti-environmental Gingrich Congress. By trivializing the greenhouse effect into something as ludicrous as the subject of a sci-fi miniseries, the network might have convinced mass audiences that global warming was just another Hollywood gimmick, which, unfortunately, it may not be.
Ditto for Kevin Costner's "Waterworld," a sci-fi epic that depicted an Earth inundated with oceans engorged by greenhouse-induced melting of the polar ice caps, again a much worse outcome even the most pessimistic models project. Mr. Costner justified his movie and its inflated budget with some blather about raising public awareness. It didn't help the planet or the box-office numbers.
How many stars have really "raised awareness" about an environmental cause in a lasting way? A decade ago, when concerns about the rain forests were rising, Sting made himself Mr. Rain Forest; today the rain forest continues to shrink and public concern hovers near zero (although the Rainforest Cafe chain has been packing in customers).
No doubt most stars are sincere about the causes they attach themselves to. The problem is, while the public admires stars, it also sees them as about the most pampered people around, with little connection to real life. Thus the public can be forgiven if it suspected that Ted Danson, founder of the American Oceans Campaign and host of the TV documentary "Danger at the Beach," might have been primarily concerned about the waterfront near his Martha's Vineyard home.
Global warming is a slow-building problem for which scientific evidence is beginning to increase. Reform is possible but will take many years. In the interim, how many celebrities will get bored with the details and jump on to the next fad?
It is always possible that ABC is on to something with the actor-as-journalist approach, and a Leo-Clinton pose fest will get young people excited about working for greenhouse-effect reform. But it seems more likely that the program will serve to make the issue seem simplistic. The alternative -- slow-moving interviews with scientists, thinkers and economists who have just slightly less than Mr. DiCaprio's squeal appeal -- will never be a ratings winner. But it would be credible, and the gradual accrual of credibility is what is needed today for greenhouse effect concerns.

HEADLINE: Returns of Long Census Forms Lag; Bureau Cites Privacy Fears

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Facing concerns in Congress that the questions in this year's census are intrusive, Census Bureau officials said today that they saw new, worrying signs that many people were refusing to complete and return the longer version of the form.
The bureau's latest figures show that 65 percent of all households that received the short version of the form had returned it, compared with 51 percent of those that received the longer version. 
 That 14 percentage-point gap differs markedly from the results of the 1990 census, when the gap was only 6 points. In 1990, after households that did not return the forms were visited, the gap closed to 4.5 points.
The long form, which has 53 questions, is mailed to 1 in every 6 households. It seeks data on a variety of subjects, including income, education and disabilities. The short form has only eight questions.
Census officials did not draw a direct connection between the shortfall in households completing the long form and the recent comments of lawmakers on Capitol Hill who have suggested that the questions in the form are intrusive.
Last week the Senate passed a resolution urging that people who refuse to answer particular questions on the census not be prosecuted, though it was doubtful that anyone would be charged with the crime.
Still, there is concern among census officials that the privacy debate may lead some people to refuse to fill out the long form.
The results compiled from the long forms are considered vital to both the government and private companies. Data from the long form is also used in developing key economic indicators, including the Consumer Price Index.
The problem with the long form was a major blemish on what otherwise was a good week for the Census Bureau. Earlier this week, census officials announced that the overall mail return rate for census forms had reached 62 percent.
"It's a strong 62 percent," said Kenneth W. Prewitt, the census director. "I think we're in reach of getting to 65 percent before we close down this part of the thing."
If that trend holds, census officials would have made good on their desire to halt the long-term decline in mail-back response rates that had dropped to 65 percent in 1990 from 83 percent in 1970, the first year they were mailed.
Census officials say they are unsure of the extent of the problem at the moment.
Right now, bureau officials are merely calculating the number of long and short forms that have been returned. They have yet to check to see what proportion of those forms have been completely filled out.
If, as some politicians have suggested, households have provided only the bare minimum of information on the long forms, the problem of a lack of data may even be worse.
Officials are concerned that the lagging response rate on the long form may mean that census takers will encounter more resistance when they visit the households that did not return the forms in order to get the information in person.
No one can say at this moment how much the lagging return rates for the long form will affect that quality of data available to government agencies, private companies and researchers.
"If the long form response rates stays low across the country on a random basis, it will be less serious," Mr. Prewitt said. "If it clusters geographically, then there will be parts of the country where we will not have very good data."

HEADLINE: The Clintons Pay $92,104 In Federal Income Taxes

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Raising money for the down payment on their new home in Chappaqua, N.Y., caused President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, to pay substantial capital gains taxes last year, the couple's tax return, released by the White House yesterday, showed.
The Clintons paid $92,104, or 22.1 percent, in federal taxes on income of $416,039. 
 Capital gains accounted for $179,849 of their income, of which $122,094 were long-term gains on which they paid a tax of $24,419. The short-term gains were taxed as ordinary income.
The couple put down more than a third of a million dollars on their new home, said Jim Kennedy, a White House spokesman. The house was bought a few months before Mrs. Clinton formally announced her candidacy for the United States Senate from New York.
Vice President Al Gore and his wife, Tipper, reported income of $240,930 and paid $59,178, or 24.5 percent, in federal taxes.
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the presumptive Republican nominee for president, plans to release a synopsis of his income tax return on Monday and expects to release a finished tax return in the fall, said his spokesman, Ari Fleischer.
For the third time in four years, the Clintons paid more in federal taxes than the law requires, the result of their decision four years ago to take as income royalties from Mrs. Clinton's book "It Takes a Village" and then to give away the after-tax value. Mrs. Clinton received $20,214 in royalties in 1999 on which she paid $2,856 in self-employment taxes to cover Social Security and Medicare taxes.
In all, the Clintons have given away $937,358 to children's and health charities since 1996, $109,000 less than they could have if they had given ownership of the book to a donor-advised or donor-directed fund at a community foundation. The difference went to income taxes and to self-employment taxes, which will increase Mrs. Clinton's Social Security income when she turns 65 by 3 percent.
Mrs. Clinton followed a different approach with her second book, "Dear Socks, Dear Buddy," about letters children had written to her family's pets. She gave the copyright to the National Parks Foundation in 1998, which meant that all of the royalties flow untaxed to this charity.
The Clintons gave $39,200 to charity last year, of which $17,358 was the net royalties from the Village book, $12,000 came from a "pin money" fund for first ladies and $9,842 came from their pockets.
Mr. Clinton earned $200,000 as president, the couple had $6,008 in interest, $11,396 in dividends, $20,214 in royalties and $179,849 in capital gains, and received a deduction for half of Mrs. Clinton's self-employment tax, giving them an adjusted gross income of $416,039. The couple also received $9,917 in tax-exempt interest.
The Clintons declared themselves residents of Arkansas, as the tax law allows, avoiding the much higher income taxes imposed by the District of Columbia. They paid $18,850 in Arkansas state taxes and $13,081 in property taxes on their Chappaqua home in Westchester County, which they bought in November.
Because of the size of their deductions and the components of their income, the Clintons also had to pay $4,943 in alternative minimum tax.
That tax, enacted in 1969, was intended to make sure all high-income Americans paid at least some federal income tax, but because it has not been fully adjusted to reflect inflation it now applies to people making as little as $28,000 annually and 1,800 people last year still paid no federal income tax despite an income of more than $200,000.
The Gores' tax return, which listed them as residents of Tennessee, showed that they own far fewer assets than the Clintons. In addition to Mr. Gore's salary of $175,400, the couple reported taxable interest of $1,267, but no dividends or tax-exempt interest. The Gores reported $29,260 in capital gains and $20,371 in income from renting real estate.
Mr. Gore also received $16,457 in royalties on the re-issue of his 1992 book "Earth in the Balance," on which he has built an image as an environmentalist. He took $2,468 in unspecified expenses, reducing the taxable proceeds to $13,989.
The Gores gave $15,000 to charities and listed areas of giving like illnesses, religious organizations and educational institutions, but did not specify whether any were environmental organizations.
In 1998 the Gores gave $15,197 to charity, but in 1997 they gave just $353, less than two-tenths of 1 percent of their income, prompting intense criticism. In 1996 the couple gave away $35,530, all but $530 of it royalties from a book.

HEADLINE: Deal Reached on Bill to Help African and Caribbean Trade

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
House and Senate leaders have reached broad agreement on a bill to give African and Caribbean countries wide-ranging trade benefits intended to help their flagging economies by opening new markets.
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, personally intervened on Thursday night to resolve differences that had deadlocked the measure for months. Left unresolved, the impasse could have imperiled a landmark accord to grant China permanent normal trading privileges that the House is scheduled to vote on next month. 
 House and Senate negotiators still have to work out many details in the bill, which would reduce or eliminate tariffs and quotas on a wide range of goods made in sub-Saharan Africa, Central America and the Caribbean.
Supporters voiced confidence that the House and Senate were highly likely to approve the bill when Congress reconvenes early next month. Last year, the Senate approved the bill, 76 to 19, after the House had passed it, 234 to 163.
President Clinton strongly supports the measure, which would be the first major trade-promotion agreement enacted in the United States since the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993, a law that established duty-free commerce among Canada, Mexico and the United States.
"This bill is a win-win proposition for the United States and for our friends in Africa and the Caribbean Basin," Mr. Clinton said today.
The House agreed to grant many of the same duty-free benefits on apparel and textiles to 24 Caribbean and Central American countries that will be extended to 48 African nations.
The House had not included the Caribbean in its bill mainly because lawmakers from textile states and those with many union constituents argued that exports from that region would threaten American jobs. The American Textile Manufacturers Institute said today the deal could harm 600,000 workers in the industry.
The Senate dropped a requirement that limited duty-free status to clothing made with fabric, thread or yarn from the United States. But in a concession to textile makers, the agreement initially caps the volume of duty-free goods at 1.5 percent of textile imports. That cap grows to 3.5 percent over eight years, to encourage foreign investment in fledgling African markets.
The poorest African countries would be eligible for duty-free treatment with no restrictions for four years.
Proponents of the measure argue that it would increase economic growth in a continent where United States trade is relatively small. Last year, American merchandise exports to Africa totaled $6.7 billion, while imports amounted to $13.4 billion, or slightly more than what Japan exports here in a month.
The two Republican leaders worked out the major sticking points on Thursday night. But the deal still has to be formally approved by negotiators from each chamber.
"This agreement marks a significant milestone for a strong and meaningful trade mechanism in the African and Caribbean Basin regions," said Representative Bill Archer, a Texas Republican who heads the Ways and Means Committee, which oversees trade legislation.
Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the senior Democrat on the committee, said: "This bill will make a significant difference in the lives of millions of Africans. It will create jobs in Africa and jobs in America."
Critics said that multinational corporations would exploit African workers and that the compromise failed to address crucial issues like debt relief and AIDS in Africa. "This bill is worse than no bill at all," said Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., an Illinois Democrat who opposed the original House bill.
Some other Democrats who supported the House bill, like Jim McDermott of Washington and William J. Jefferson of Louisiana, grumbled that the compromise might fall short of what they could accept.
That is significant, because both legislators have indicated that their support for the China trade deal hinged on a satisfactory outcome for the Africa measure, which they say has been receiving short shrift from the White House and Congressional leaders.
Nailing down an acceptable Africa bill could swing three to five critical Democratic votes for the China measure, said Representative Robert T. Matsui of California, a chief Democratic vote counter.
Mr. Lott, anticipating dissent from textile-state senators, strongly endorsed the deal, saying, "These are free-trade provisions that will help business and industry in America, everything from cotton to retail to textiles to yarn."
One provision, to create a mechanism to retaliate against unfair trade practices committed against the United States, was included as a favor to Carl H. Lindner, an Ohio executive and big political fund-raiser whose Chiquita Brands International is locked in a trade war with Europe over bananas
Another provision for American garment makers, including Fruit of the Loom, a big political donor to both Republican and Democratic causes, would cut the cost of manufacturing apparel in the Caribbean with yarn and fabric from the United States.

Not the Corporate Elite: A Sampler of Protest

A movement known as Jubilee 2000, backed primarily by Catholic and Protestant churches
 
That many of the poorest nations are overburdened with international debt and deserve debt forgiveness.

Friends of the Earth, the Sierra Club and the Rainforest Action Network
 
That the spread of free-market capitalism is damaging forests, silting rivers, contributing to greenhouse gas emissions and destroying the natural resources of poor nations.
 
Some accuse the World Bank of funding energy and road projects that hasten environmental degradation. These groups contend that the I.M.F. encourages governments to curtail spending on environmental protection in return for aid.
 
Organized labor
 
The A.F.L.-C.I.O., the United Steelworkers of America and the Teamsters Union
 
That global trade will have a negative effect on workers' jobs in wealthy countries. Labor groups have pushed for stricter trade and labor standards worldwide.
 
Some say the lenders encourage poor nations to develop big export-oriented industries, costing U.S. jobs. Labor's main goal, however. is to rewrite trade rules enforced by the World Trade Organization.

That U.S. consumer products companies sometimes tolerate poor working conditionsin overseas factories.
 
Some student groups accuse the World Bank and I.M.F. of protecting the interests of corporations over the rights of workers abroad and of forcing third-world companies to open their doors to investment by multinational companies.
 
Ad hoc coalitions
 
Global Exchange, 50 Years Is Enough, and the Ruckus Society
 
That globalization worsens social injustice, poverty and animal rights, and speeds the erosion of indigenous cultures.
 
The World Bank and the I.M.F. are seen as the main villains of globalization, capitalist enforcers trying to make the world safe for big corporations.

HEADLINE: Ford Motor to Pay $10 Billion Dividend andEnsure Family Control

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., April 14

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company announced a complex revamping of its ownership structure today, including the payment of a $10 billion special dividend -- the largest ever by an American company -- and the issuance of additional stock to the Ford family, cementing its grip on the world's second-largest industrial corporation.
The plan is designed to let Ford distribute nearly half its $24 billion cash hoard, one of the largest of any company in the world, while minimizing taxes for its shareholders and giving the Ford family greater financial flexibility, particularly for estate planning. But the big cash disbursement could leave Ford somewhat more vulnerable in a recession, although the company would still have as much cash after the special dividend as General Motors has now. 
 The big dividend may limit somewhat Ford's ability to undertake further large acquisitions; Ford bought Volvo Cars a year ago and agreed last month to buy Land Rover from BMW. But Jacques A. Nasser, Ford's chief executive, said that the company would not rule out further deals.
The recapitalization plan unveiled today was a delicate balance between the interests of Ford Motor's public shareholders and the interests of Henry Ford's descendants. Big institutional shareholders and Wall Street analysts have been urging Ford Motor since the mid-1990's to disburse some of its enormous cash hoard by buying back stock. But the Ford family has always resisted share buybacks, insisting on dividends instead because of the special class of stock that the family holds.
The Ford family holds all 71 million shares of the company's Class B stock, along with a small number of the company's 1.1 billion common shares. Under rules designed to preserve family control and drafted when the company went public in 1956, the family holds 40 percent of the voting power at the company as long as it continues to own at least 60.7 million shares of the Class B stock -- even though the Class B shares make up only 6 percent of the company's overall equity.
If the family sells too many shares of its Class B stock, whether to pay estate taxes, cover personal expenses or simply participate in a stock buyback, then the family's influence shrinks. If the family's holdings fall to between 33.7 million and 60.7 million shares of Class B stock, the family wields only 30 percent of the voting power. And if the family's holdings fall below 33.7 million shares then all special voting privileges are lost.
When Class B shares are sold outside the family, they revert to common stock. Under today's plan, each holder of Ford's common or Class B stock will be given a choice of receiving $20 a share in cash or additional common stock. William C. Ford Jr., Ford's chairman and one of Henry Ford's 13 great-grandchildren, said that the members of the Ford family would take additional stock for all of their Class B stock. Most if not all family members will put the additional distribution into the family's voting trust, he added.
The extended family faces the problem of covering estate taxes while preserving family control of the company upon the deaths someday of Henry Ford's two surviving grandchildren, Josephine F. Ford and William C. Ford Sr., who are in their mid-70's. Today's arrangement will give family members $1.42 billion of common stock to sell without touching their Class B stock.
Ford Motor is reissuing its common and Class B stock as part of the recapitalization, allowing the $20 special dividend for other shareholders to be taxed at the lower rates for capital gains instead of the higher rates for income taxes.
Ford Motor said that after the recapitalization, it would also spin off its wholly owned auto parts subsidiary, the Visteon Corporation, by distributing all of the shares to holders of common and Class B stock. Visteon has $19 billion a year in sales, of which $17 billion are to Ford.
Mr. Ford said that he would definitely retain the Visteon shares he received, and other family members were also likely to retain them, providing another big asset for the family to sell someday while safeguarding the Class B shares.
The family had partially addressed the estate tax problem in 1998, when Ford distributed to shareholders its 80 percent stake in the Associates First Capital Corporation, a consumer lending business.
Ford officials said that their plan would not require special approval by the Internal Revenue Service or the Securities and Exchange Commission. Robert Willens, a tax expert at Lehman Brothers not involved in putting the deal together, agreed with that assessment. He said that the special dividend would easily be the largest cash dividend ever paid, and that the overall deal did not appear to favor the Ford family at the expense of other shareholders.
Stephen Girsky, an auto analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said that the distribution of common stock to the Ford family would also align the family's interests more closely with those of other shareholders in the future. The family will henceforth have common shares to tender in any future stock buybacks by Ford Motor, he said.
The stock market welcomed Ford's plan, bidding up its stock immediately after the morning announcement even as the rest of the market plunged, although Ford shares also began to fall by early afternoon and closed at $53.1875, down $1.25. But Standard & Poor's, the credit rating agency, lowered the rating on Ford's long-term debt to A from A+, saying that Ford would have less of a cash cushion for making bond payments.
Mr. Ford has talked frequently in interviews over the years about his desire that his children and grandchildren keep a strong link to Ford Motor. Although hostile or friendly approaches by potential merger candidates have sometimes forced special dividends and share buybacks at other companies, Mr. Ford said that the company was not under outside pressure and that the family's role would continue to prevent this.
"Our goal has always been, and will be as long as there is a Ford family, to keep Ford an independent entity," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Ice for a Hot Economy?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The American economy boomed as the stock market, particularly technology stocks, soared to unprecedented heights. Now, with stocks suddenly much lower, will the economy cool off quickly?
Some economists say so. "We are going to find that this tech wreck and Nasdaq crash will have a much more immediate impact on consumer spending than the interest rate hikes the Federal Reserve has given us," Edward Yardeni, the chief economist of Deutsche Bank Securities, said yesterday. 
 Whether his forecast turns out to be true depends on psychology at least as much as it does on economics. After all, even after losing a quarter of its value this week, and a third since it peaked barely more than a month ago, the Nasdaq composite index is still higher than it was in November. Other stock indexes have suffered much less damage.
The booming stock market has clearly aided the economy, as investors who felt wealthier spent more. The anticipation of higher stock prices also helped. One survey late last year showed that the typical investor expected the stock market to gain an average 19 percent a year for the next decade, a figure that is in line with recent experience but far larger than long-term growth of the economy is likely to support. Investors who held such expectations could have felt less need to save, since they thought their investments were likely to keep rising.
"The retracement so far takes away only a small part of the increase in financial asset values over the last few years," said Henry Kaufman, an economist who runs his own money management firm. He said the decline was likely to have "only a modest economic retarding influence." But he added that changes in expectations could have a larger impact on consumer spending.
Until recently, the so-called new economy was considered largely immune to higher interest rates. The stock prices of many older companies came under pressure after the Federal Reserve began raising interest rates last June, on the expectation that such increases would eventually slow their business. But the high-technology part of the stock market soared as investors thought that the demand for such products would not suffer much even if the old economy faltered.
Now, however, the sudden weakness of the stock market may have a much more direct effect on the new economy. Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, noted that initial public offerings and venture capital investments had brought in $150 billion for hundreds of new companies since the beginning of 1999.
Much of that money was spent by new companies on computers, software and communications equipment purchased from older technology companies. A precipitous decline in such financings would directly affect companies like Intel, Compaq and Lucent Technologies.
"The impact on the real economy will be faster than people expect, and concentrated in technology," Mr. Barbera said.
Nearly 13 years ago, when the stock market crashed in 1987, many economists assumed that a recession would follow. The stock market was viewed as a leading indicator of the economy, and surely a fall as large as that one indicated a deep economic problem.
In fact, it did not. In retrospect, the severity of the 1987 crash reflected market imperfections more than economic realities. Many institutional investors thought they could protect themselves by selling stock index futures when prices fell. Such selling accelerated the decline.
After the crash, the Fed immediately changed its policy and began to lower interest rates. The New York economy, far more dependent on Wall Street than other regions were, suffered to some extent. But most of the country continued to grow until a brief recession arrived in 1990.
The Fed also moved to cut interest rates when world stock markets plunged in 1998, after the crisis in Asia and Russia's default on some of its debts alarmed investors. There was talk of a worldwide recession, but it did not materialize.
Recently, as in 1987, the Fed has been raising interest rates in an effort to slow the economy. But it is not at all obvious that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, will again reverse course. The Consumer Price Index report released yesterday morning was far worse than expected and helped to accelerate the selling of stocks; some economists viewed it as a possible reason for the Fed to decide to raise rates by half a percentage point, rather than the quarter-point that was expected, at its meeting next month.
At a minimum, the Fed is not likely to stop raising rates until there is clear evidence that something -- whether rising rates or a plunging stock market or a combination of the two -- is significantly slowing the economy.
Another economic issue that could arise concerns the dollar. Thanks in part to surging consumer demand, the United States has been running a record trade deficit. The deficit has not hurt the dollar because foreigners were willing to invest their dollars back in this country, many of them in stocks. A slower flow of foreign money into American investments could put pressure on the value of the dollar.
There is no assurance, of course, that the recent decline of the stock market will continue. Investors have responded to many falls since 1987 by buying the dips, and headlines about plunging stock prices soon gave way to articles about new highs for major indexes. The fall of 7.3 percent for the Dow Jones industrial average this week was the worst since the index fell 7.6 percent in the week ended Oct. 13, 1989. On the following Monday, the Dow leaped 3.4 percent, and the fears were soon forgotten.
That could happen again. But if it does not, one factor that has pushed the economy to new heights will have been removed. At a minimum, that means slower growth.

HEADLINE: As Port Authority Stalls, Ex-Governors Urge Talks

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
At least five people are looking on with particular interest as the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey remains stuck in the mud, putting major projects on hold because of a feud between Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey.
They are the five former governors who, to varying degrees, negotiated the delicate balancing act between two states and sets of economic priorities that have made the Port Authority one of most important generators of the region's economic activity. 
 None of the governors says he has a magic solution to the impasse at the authority, which manages the two states' airports, ports, Hudson River crossings and other transportation systems. But all agreed that the authority depended on various kinds of political, personal and economic diplomacy to work. And they cited a need for a personal connection between the two governors that seems absent now.
"The more you know each other, the more you talk, the harder it is to fight," said Thomas H. Kean, the only Republican among the five, who was New Jersey's governor from 1982 to 1990. He recalled the monthly dinners he had with New York's Democratic governor, Mario M. Cuomo, specifically to avoid problems over the Port Authority. "It may have been fun for both of us to holler at the other across the Hudson River," Mr. Kean said, "but like it or not, we are tied together."
In contrast, Governors Pataki and Whitman, both Republicans in their second terms, have had few private meetings, and aides say there are no plans for any now.
For the last year, New York representatives to the agency's board have refused to approve a staff-negotiated, 30-year lease intended to keep the container operations at the Elizabeth Marine Terminal competitive, charging that it represents a deep subsidy to New Jersey.
New Jersey's representatives have countered by refusing to move on the privatization of the World Trade Center and the leasing of air rights over the Port Authority Bus Terminal -- projects that New York dearly wants.
The deadlock showed no sign of easing in the last month as the agency postponed its monthly board meeting while aides to the governors discussed their differences.
A common thread in the recollections of the former governors -- Mr. Cuomo and Hugh L. Carey of New York, and Mr. Kean, Brendan T. Byrne and Jim Florio of New Jersey -- was an often-complex balancing of Port Authority spending in each state and a mutual sensitivity to their counterparts' political problems. Many praised the agency's professional staff members, who often smoothed over conflicts.
None was so disingenuous as to suggest that during his tenure the Port Authority engaged in purely regional projects of clear and equal benefit to both states. Few glossed over the occasional blatant horse-trading over agency projects. But they all said that it was pragmatism and principle that led them to avoid protracted and public bean counting over how much the agency had spent in each state.
Any New York governor must make a crucial attitude adjustment, Mr. Cuomo said. "This bistate agency was set up as if the two states are equal," he said, "and it treats them as equal when we all know that New York is bigger, more powerful and has more of everything than New Jersey does. It's lopsided, and a totally unnatural situation in which it is tempting for New York to insist they should get more. But you just have to put that out of your head."
Mr. Kean said of his relationship with Mr. Cuomo, "The thing we decided that these two governors seem not to have decided was to leave the past alone and look toward the future."
Still, some critics of the agency say that the past governors are rewriting history. Many New York governors, flush with funds and revenue sources that did not require bistate agreement to spend, mostly ignored the Port Authority, said Mitchell Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University.
The result, he said, was that shrewder, more attentive and less flush New Jersey governors used the authority to "subsidize New Jersey in a hundred different ways."
"Governor Pataki should be congratulated for deciding that he is no longer going to let New Jersey governors use the Port Authority as a cash machine," Mr. Moss said.
Congress created the Port Authority in 1921 as the nation's first bistate compact, modeling it after the London Port Authority. Charged with coordinating the two states' transportation and port projects to enhance regional commerce, it was supposed to be independent, professional and beyond politics and patronage.
The authority began by building the Hudson River crossings, bringing in the George Washington Bridge on time and under budget. It was led by a series of master builders: Eugenius H. Outerbridge, Major Gen. George W. Goethals and Austin J. Tobin, the agency's longtime executive director, who served from 1942 to 1972.
"I remember Austin Tobin from when I was a child in Brooklyn," said Mr. Carey, who was New York's governor from 1975 to 1983. "He had the most significant position in the community, and we knew we had something valuable there."
From across the river in those days, Mr. Kean said, the agency seemed to be bathed in the aura of New York's governor, Nelson A. Rockefeller. "It was his, Rockefeller's, agency," he said. "But even though it had the Rockefeller glow, we felt that they had a professional staff and what they were doing, they were doing well."
The staff often mediated disputes, Mr. Kean said, recalling that when his term overlapped with Mr. Carey's, the New York governor was facing a budget crisis and sought his support on a proposal to sell the World Trade Center and divide the proceeds.
Mr. Kean said that he knew that Peter Goldmark, then the agency's executive director and Mr. Carey's former budget director, opposed the sale. So Mr. Kean deferred to the staff opinion, and Mr. Carey gave up the end run around his own appointee.
Mr. Byrne recalled the time he saw Mr. Carey being tugged between opponents and supporters in New York of allowing supersonic aircraft from landing and taking off from Kennedy International Airport.
"I got him off the hook and solved the problem for him by vowing to veto agency minutes and thereby stop all agency activities if the planes were not allowed," the former New Jersey governor said. "And he on the other hand understood politically that I could not support an increase in the PATH fare, and so he never bothered me on it."
The extent to which the former governors saw the agency as regional or simply an extension of their own fiscal and economic development policies varied widely. Mr. Kean said that the agency was "owned" by the two governors, who then had to agree on what it should do.
Neither Mr. Byrne, who was New Jersey's Democratic governor from 1974 to 1982, nor Mr. Carey would go quite that far in laying claim to the agency, and both spoke of reliance on the staff and the independent-minded business leaders they had appointed to the board.
"I didn't focus on the Port Authority to solve our problems fiscally or otherwise," said Mr. Florio, who was defeated by Mrs. Whitman after a single term in 1994 and is now seeking the Democratic nomination for the Senate. "There are some things that can be done in a rational way for both states that can't really be quantified for each."
And Mr. Cuomo, who was turned out of office by Mr. Pataki in 1994 after three terms, said that there were times when he wanted to raise tolls and PATH fares, moves that would increase authority's revenues but fall mainly on New Jerseyans. But he knew he could not convince Mr. Kean and later Mr. Florio of such a move. "There was no use in trying it and going to the press to embarrass them," he said.
Most of the former governors said the current impasse was embarrassing and mystifying. Mr. Kean said the problem could not be ideological, since Mr. Pataki and Mrs. Whitman were moderate Republicans with similar views on most things, including the role of government.
"They are two peas in a pod," Mr. Cuomo agreed. "Both liberal Republicans from the Northeast, both pro-choice and both being considered by their party for vice president."

LENGTH: 594 words

HEADLINE: The Market's Breathtaking Plunge

 BODY:
Economists have warned for years that stock prices are unrealistically high, needing to fall by about a third, by one prominent estimate, to regain financial sense. But no amount of warning could take the fright out of yesterday's record drops in all major stock averages. Investors lost more than $2 trillion this week. Besides the horrific blow to personal wealth, there is the added threat to the health of the overall economy.
How important an event yesterday's plunge proves to be depends on how much the market bounces back next week, and on other factors as well. Will people reduce their spending enough to trigger a recession? Will businesses, finding it harder to raise money on Wall Street, cut back investment plans, delivering a blow to long-term economic growth? On these scores, there are firm reasons to remain optimistic. For example, on a single day, Oct. 19, 1987, stocks lost an astounding 23 percent. Yesterday's major averages dropped between 5 and 10 percent. Yet even the 1987 debacle caused relatively little hardship on Main Street. Under the shrewd leadership of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve kept the economy growing. Mr. Greenspan is still in charge of the Fed, and he has the tools to make sure that Wall Street and Main Street do not rise and fall in lockstep. 
 Whatever the stock market decline portends for the economy, the sheer size of yesterday's losses was stunning. The index of 30 stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average fell a record 618 points, more than 5.6 percent. That is about 65 points more than the previous record. The Standard & Poor's 500 index, a more representative sample of American stocks, lost a record 84 points, almost 6 percent.
The biggest losers yesterday were owners of Nasdaq stocks, especially technology stocks. The Nasdaq lost a record 355 points, or almost 10 percent. The index is off about 35 percent in the past month alone. Many will regard the drop in technology stocks -- Microsoft has lost more than $200 billion in value from its peak, Intel about $100 billion -- as an inevitable correction. Often prices have little connection to the profits these companies can be expected to earn anytime soon. Some investors might have convinced themselves that technology stocks operate by a different set of financial rules. But this week, ordinary algebra reasserted itself.
Forget about finding a single, decisive explanation for the plunge. Everyone will seize a favored candidate. The important point is that when stocks lose touch with their economic moorings, anything -- an ugly inflation report, as occurred yesterday, or a judicial blow to a prominent company like Microsoft, which triggered an earlier slide -- can frighten investors.
In the recent past, investors have taken falling stock prices as a golden opportunity to buy, so stock prices have quickly rebounded. No one can know if that pattern will reappear when the markets open on Monday, but every study of stock prices is reassuring. Take any reasonably long-term period, and stock investments do just fine.
As a political footnote, it is worth adding that Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas will be watching the markets closely. Both Mr. Bush's tax-cut proposal and Mr. Gore's health and education plans depend on surplus revenues. A good chunk of the current surplus has been supplied by a boom in tax revenues from capital gains. A downturn could affect not only productivity and pocketbooks, but the way politicians and voters behave later this year.

Russian Legislature Approves Arms Treaty
Parliament's lower house approved the Start II treaty, the landmark agreement, negotiated seven years ago, that calls for cutting the American and Russian nuclear arsenals by half. The vote represented passage of Vladimir V. Putin's first legislative initiative since his election as president. The upper house must still approve the treaty, which is not in doubt. The United States Senate has yet to approve several protocols to Start II, and the Russians made clear that they would not implement Start II until the Senate acted. A1

HEADLINE: New Formula For Sharing State Funds Is Criticized

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, criticized state legislative leaders yesterday, singling out the New York City delegation, over a proposed $77 billion state budget that he said would shortchange the city of money the state distributes to municipalities.
Mr. Vallone said he had written to Gov. George E. Pataki, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, asking them to change a provision in the budget proposal that would use surplus funds to raise revenue-sharing appropriations by 5 percent around the state, excluding New York City. If the city were excluded, Mr. Vallone said, it would forgo $28 million during fiscal year 2001, which begins July 1. 
 "New York City is the engine that gave this surplus to the state," Mr. Vallone said, "and all we are asking for is our fair share."
But in a letter to Mr. Vallone, Mr. Silver defended the budget proposal, saying it was intended to help economically depressed parts of the state.
"Several upstate cities have not reaped the benefits of the current economic boom," Mr. Silver said. In a personal rebuke to Mr. Vallone, a candidate to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in 2002, he said, "It is unfortunate that for your own personal benefit you have chosen to disparage the fine work of the entire city delegation."
Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, and the Assembly carried more weight than Mr. Bruno or the Senate in shaping the new revenue-sharing proposal. A separate Senate proposal would have extended the same 5 percent increase to New York City.
Mr. Silver's role in the matter may have other political dimensions, since he is widely believed to have supported a change in the revenue- sharing equation to provoke Mayor Giuliani. An aide to one senior state legislator who spoke on the condition of anonymity said yesterday that Mr. Silver, an outspoken supporter of Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign for the United States Senate, intended to place the mayor in the position of having to face off against upstate legislators over the budget, perhaps alienating upstate voters in his Senate bid.
Mr. Giuliani said at a news conference late yesterday that he supported Mr. Vallone's criticism, but he did so in a way that appeared politically cautious.
"It's not final yet," the mayor said of the proposed budget, which is expected to win approval sometime next week. "As for revenue sharing, it may not turn out that way.
"It is right for the speaker to note these issues and put some pressure on them to make sure the city does not get hurt too much."
He went on to repeat some of his positions on federal tax policy, including a call to reduce income taxes, that he said would help upstate voters.
Mr. Vallone, acknowledging that the city, with a strong economy, could forgo an increase in revenue sharing this year, said he was opposed to the new formula because it would set a precedent. In recent years, the city has received a nearly constant 57 percent of all state revenue-sharing funds, and its share would be reduced slightly in the proposed budget.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE THIRD PARTIES;
Nader Runs Again, This Time With Feeling

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
The students with purple hair, the graying academics with Jerry Garcia beards and the union organizers with their anti-W.T.O. buttons had crowded into a college auditorium in Minneapolis to hear some red-meat -- make that green-vegetable -- radicalism. And Ralph Nader, America's foremost anti-corporate curmudgeon, did not disappoint:
Global corporations are sucking the life out of small businesses and family farms. Pollution is poisoning our rivers and air. Inner-city schools and health clinics are crumbling. And while the nation corrodes, the rich are buying and selling politicians like baseball cards. 
 "Big business is on a collision course with American democracy, and American democracy has been losing," said Mr. Nader, who in his dark suit was the most conventional-looking person in the room.
The man who became famous by killing off a sporty but unstable little car called the Corvair some 35 years ago is at it again, running for president on the Green Party line.
But unlike his previous presidential run, in 1996, when he refused to raise money, spent less than $5,000 and attracted barely 1 percent of the vote, this time he is serious, Mr. Nader insists.
"I specifically said I wasn't going to campaign in '96," he said in an interview. "This is a campaign."
Mr. Nader is cranking up that campaign just in time to step onto the world stage this weekend, when tens of thousands of protesters descend on Washington to demonstrate against the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Green Party affiliates from around the world are playing a major role in the protests, and Mr. Nader himself will address demonstrators near the White House on Sunday.
The goal of Mr. Nader's run is not to win, of course, but to get more than 5 percent of the vote, the number that would qualify him for millions in federal campaign matching funds that he says he would use to build the Green Party.
"If the Green Party breaks 5 percent, the Democratic Party won't be the same again," Mr. Nader, still irrepressibly dour and hauntingly hungry-looking at 66, said in reflecting on the prospect of undercutting the centrist Democratic Leadership Council and its president, Al From. "If you think Al From and the Democratic Leadership Council has a grip on the Democratic Party, wait and see what a significant and growing progressive third party can do."
Aides to Vice President Al Gore, the apparent Democratic nominee, say they are not losing sleep over a Nader challenge. Mr. Nader is not the most skillful of campaigners, and even many liberal allies question his ability to move voters. Further, the Green Party is better known for its internal squabbling than for its ability to run campaigns or raise money.
But Mr. Gore's yielding even a few percentage points to Mr. Nader would be damaging to the vice president if the election was tight. And a recent poll by the Zogby Group showed Mr. Nader receiving more support than Patrick J. Buchanan, the likely Reform Party nominee, 5 percent to 3 percent. The poll indicated that the vast majority of Mr. Nader's support came from Democrats and that he was doing particularly well in California, considered a vital state for Mr. Gore.
All of which suggests that an aggressive Nader campaign could entirely offset advantages Mr. Gore might gain from Mr. Buchanan's candidacy, which is expected to siphon votes from the apparent Republican nominee, Gov. George W. Bush.
Mr. Nader intends to remain a thorn in Mr. Gore's side by promoting causes that many liberals, large numbers of whom chose Bill Bradley in the Democratic primaries, say the Clinton administration has lacked the will to see through: universal health care, the environment, campaign finance reform and an attack on urban poverty.
And unlike Mr. Bradley, Mr. Nader is a fierce opponent of the North American Free Trade Agreement and the World Trade Organization, endearing him to traditionally Democratic union members who feel that the administration's free-trade policies have hurt American workers.
As evidence that this year will be different from 1996, Mr. Nader says he has hired 15 full-time campaign workers in Washington and will soon dispatch 10 others, perhaps former Bradley campaign organizers among them, to get the Green Party on the ballot in every state. (The party is already on the ballot in 13 states, including New York and California.)
He has also vowed to raise $5 million, and says he may get help from celebrities like Paul Newman, Warren Beatty, Susan Sarandon, Bonnie Raitt, Jackson Browne and the Indigo Girls. His first major fund-raising event, in Washington tonight, drew 300 people, who paid $25 to $1,000 each, adding to the $210,000 or so that the candidate's aides said they had already raised.
But to get anywhere near 5 percent of the vote, Mr. Nader will have to overcome some big obstacles, not the least of which is the Green Party itself. The party is notoriously disorganized and divided. Some members oppose any involvement in electoral politics; others are supporting another candidate, Jello Biafra, former lead singer of the rock group the Dead Kennedys.
And then there is Mr. Nader, who is the first to acknowledge that he is not the best campaigner. Gawky and prone to long speeches, he is also shy and painfully uncomfortable with asking people for their votes. When a Delta Air Lines worker stopped him in the Minneapolis airport last week and said, "I'm a big fan," all he could say in reply was "thanks."
"Campaigning takes a level of political ego I just don't have yet," he said after the man had sped off.
He is also notoriously private, refusing to tell even co-workers where he lives. (It is in an apartment he rents in the Dupont Circle section of Washington.) The only crumbs of biographical information he sprinkles into his hourlong speeches are passing references to the town of his birth, Winsted, Conn. Rarely does he mention that he is a son of Lebanese immigrants, that his father owned a restaurant, that he studied Chinese at Princeton and law at Harvard.
His secretiveness has spawned a host of dark theories among his critics. Some contend that he lives in a million-dollar town house here, not in the ill-furnished apartment of Nader lore. (Mr. Nader says the town house he has been spotted entering is his sister's.) They say that despite his seemingly penurious way of living, he is actually quite wealthy, that he purposely spent almost nothing on his 1996 campaign to skirt federal election laws, which require candidates who spend more than $5,000 to file reports disclosing their assets.
Mr. Nader says he will file a financial disclosure report next month. Despite the concerns he frequently voices about the dangers of too rapid an advance in technology, the report will show, he says, that he owns technology stocks. It will also disclose, he says, that he earned about $200,000 in speaking fees last year but gave half of it to charities. He says that most of the other half went toward "projects" and that he lives on about $25,000 a year.
Asked how so private a man could run for so public a job, Mr. Nader, a lifelong bachelor, replied: "When you work all the time, you don't have a problem in terms of private time. There is no private time."
Even among many on the left, Mr. Nader is not considered the dream candidate. In a recent essay in The Nation, Katha Pollitt complained that his 1996 campaign had focused too much on trade issues, to the exclusion of matters like race relations, health care, and gay and abortion rights.
"The idea of progressives cranking up an organization, raising funds, fomenting energy and enthusiasm on behalf of this doomed project," Ms. Pollitt wrote, "well, it's just too depressing. If working on Nader's campaign is the best way progressives can spend the next eight months, it's time to hire a hearse and lie down in it."
Mr. Nader, who says he is running partly at the behest of Green Party leaders, replied, "I think she ran out of material that week."
Still, his platform seems to reflect some of the criticisms of progressives like Ms. Pollitt. At the top is universal health care, followed by an antipoverty program built heavily on consumer-protection ideas, including provisions against loan discrimination by banks, high auto insurance rates and landlord abuses.
"Corporate welfare," one of his favorite issues, will also be front and center: he will campaign against tax breaks and government subsidies that allow big companies "to privatize profits and socialize risk."
And, in an effort to win support from social conservatives, he plans to attack big media corporations, saying they exploit children with racy programming and aggressive marketing practices.
Although he is counting on the anti-globalization protests this weekend to raise his national profile, Mr. Nader says his best hope for gaining attention would be to squeeze between Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush in televised debates.
The commission that determines presidential debate participants has said a candidate must be receiving 15 percent in national polls to be included. Mr. Nader contends that the threshold is ridiculously high, and hopes to unite with Mr. Buchanan to protest it. And if he prevails, he says, he will pose in those debates the kind of questions that will spark interest in his campaign.
"Candidates are asked, 'What is your position on welfare, what is your position on crime?' " Mr. Nader said. "That's not the right question. It needs an adjective: 'What is your position on corporate welfare? What is your position on corporate crime?' We're going to open this up. We're going to provide adjectives to these issues."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Frenzy of Selling in Stocks Caps a Disastrous Week
Investors turned away from stocks in a sharp wave of selling that closed one of the worst weeks in the history of United States markets. The catalyst was a Department of Labor report showing that core consumer prices rose 0.4 percent in March, more than economists had predicted. 
 The Nasdaq composite index plunged 355.49 points, or 9.7 percent, to 3,321.29, finishing the worst week in its history with a 25.3 percent loss. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 617.78 points, or 5.7 percent, to 10,305.77. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slid 83.95 points, or 5.8 percent, to 1,356.56. Page A1.
 
A Breather for a Hot Economy?
The American economy boomed as the stock market, particularly technology stocks, soared. Now, with those stocks suddenly much lower, will the economy cool off quickly? Some economists think consumer spending will slow, but that will depend on psychology as much as economics. News Analysis. A1.
 
Software Glitch at H & R Block
H & R Block warned 3,080 customers who used the company's tax-preparation software that payments they authorized the Internal Revenue Service to take from their bank accounts will not be made because of a software error. The affected taxpayers must mail their payments to the I.R.S., which is reviewing the accounts to determine whether late fees or penalties should be waived. The company said it would pay any penalties or interest. C15.
 
Vote Backs Nasdaq Public Offering
Members of the National Association of Securities Dealers voted overwhelmingly to turn the Nasdaq stock market into a for-profit company. The approval clears the way for the association to sell Nasdaq by September. C3.
 
Agreement Reached on Trade Bill
House and Senate leaders have reached agreement on a bill to give African and Caribbean countries wide-ranging trade benefits intended to help their flagging economies. A1.
 
New Leaders at Los Angeles Times
The Los Angeles Times is about to be turned over to new leadership. According to editors briefed by top newsroom leaders, Michael Parks, the editor, will be replaced by John S. Carroll, the editor of The Baltimore Sun. The publisher, Kathryn M. Downing, will be replaced by John Puerner, the publisher of The Orlando Sentinel. A11.
 
Businesses Cautious on Zimbabwe
The South African Chamber of Business urged its 40,000 members this week to delay any new investment in Zimbabwe, its crisis-ridden neighbor. Hundreds of farms in Zimbabwe have been raided in recent weeks by black squatters, raising concern about the country's important agricultural sector and heightening fears about the political situation. C2.
 
Sao Paulo Facing a Debt Crisis
In Sao Paulo, Brazil, Mayor Celso Pitta is embroiled in a scandal that includes an estranged wife, accusations of vote-buying in the city council and a questionable loan worth nearly $500,000. Yet the most pressing crisis is that the city is facing the prospect of drowning in about $4 billion in debt it cannot repay. C2.
 
BMW Gets a Counterbid for Rover
BMW of Germany said that it had received a counterbid for its money-losing Rover division from a British consortium seeking to rescue the Rover name and thwart plans by Alchemy Partners, a venture capital firm, to turn the company into a niche producer. C2.
