SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1400 words

HEADLINE: Globalization Unifies Its Many-Striped Foes

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Protesters for global justice call their headquarters a convergence center, and the abandoned downtown warehouse does seem to attract all kinds.
Propped up against a mound of backpacks and surrounded by the remnants of a donated macrobiotic lunch was James Osborne, 23, a self-described transient from St. Louis. Mr. Osborne said he took a Greyhound bus to Washington because someone told him about destructive pipeline projects and bad trade policies. "I believe there should be no leadership and no organization," he said, though he rejected the label of anarchist. 
 Not far away, David H. Richardson, 57, an economist at the Department of Labor, checked the schedule for civil disobedience actions intended to shut down the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Richardson, a shop steward of the American Federation of Government Employees, said he worked hard to persuade the national union to endorse the officially sanctioned portion of the demonstrations scheduled for Sunday, which it did.
"Labor is at the point that it needs support from outside the movement," Mr. Richardson said, looking a little like a school headmaster. "Globalization brings a lot of different people together."
If they accomplish nothing else, the protests this week against the financial institutions and in favor of debt relief for the third world seem likely to confirm Mr. Richardson's observation.
Globalization and the backlash against it bring disparate people together. The call to temper the capitalism around the globe comes from parties as diverse as the Catholic Church and a cell of anarchists, and many people and organizations in between.
The question is whether members of this unlikely coalition of protesters and interest groups will, like so many grains of sand blown together, scatter once they make a collective point or achieve individual goals.
Or, as some leaders hope, whether it is the foundation of a new social movement that will apply sustained pressure on national governments and international institutions to rewrite the rules of globalization and limit the power of corporations.
Though some environmental groups began pressuring international financial institutions to become more ecologically sensitive two decades ago, and groups wary of globalism became a popular force in Europe long before they attracted attention in the United States, the movement is still in its infancy.
The Big Bang for American organizers came only a few months ago, during the Seattle protests against the World Trade Organization, when they took credit not only for befuddling police but also for contributing to the collapse of world trade talks.
The Washington protests, which began last Sunday with a quiet rally for debt forgiveness and will culminate this Sunday with an effort to prevent world finance ministers from attending the spring meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, are the second big test for the movement. While it is having some social and political impact, its main achievement is probably logistical, uniting groups with different agendas around a common cause and attracting new recruits, especially college students and unionized workers.
"I met some steelworkers and we bonded right away," said Margareta Lelea, 20, a sophomore at the University of California-Davis who is majoring in agricultural development. Ms. Lelea, who wore a stick-on green star on her face for "ecological awareness," came early to Washington to attend nonviolence training seminars at the convergence center. It is the first major protest she has attended, though she sympathized with those who opposed NATO's bombing of Kosovo last year.
"I never thought of union people as interested in the same issues, but they are," she said. "There's all kinds of interconnections being made. Without interconnections there's no progress."
The joke among lieutenants who pulled together the protest is that there are as many 501-C-3's in their ranks as there are people, a reference to the Internal Revenue Service form that independent, nonprofit groups must file each year. The movement against the international financial organizations is in some ways less a mobilization of the masses than a convention of citizens groups that have individual agendas, fund-raising campaigns, and, in many cases, leaders with large egos.
"The way we got people together is that we let everyone represent their group. They don't have to join our group," said Kevin Danaher, a founder of Global Exchange, a social issues campaigner and one of the groups instrumental in igniting the protests in Seattle and Washington. "It's a lot easier for people to compromise when they don't really have to subordinate their egos."
Mr. Danaher, 49, tall and bald with a white goatee, traces his roots as a protester to the anti-apartheid movement in the 1980's. More recently, he has led campaigns against Nike, persuading the company to improve conditions for foreign factory workers, and against Starbucks, successfully urging the chain to sell coffee produced under the TransFair "fair trade" label, which claims profits are shared with farmers.
He is has traveled the country, speaking at scores of campuses as a kind of Paul Revere of globalization's woes. But he described himself as just an adviser to the protests against the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
The movement, Mr. Danaher said, has thrived in part because it rejects the straitjacket of a typical political or social movement, with leaders and head offices and official strategies. That allows groups to flow in and out.
The unofficial lieutenants of the Mobilization for Global Justice, as the Washington protests were named, have used the Internet to bridge environmental, religious, labor and student groups that would otherwise not be in regular contact, some 500 of them in total.
They created an Internet mail group of people willing to press a campaign against globalization's main agents. They use "vibe monitors" to make sure everyone stays civil at strategy sessions.
The phenomenon of citizens groups autonomously coordinating strategy sounds arcane, but it has proved its effectiveness. A Rand Corporation study for the Pentagon detailed how Mexico's Zapatista rebel movement in 1994 used publicity tactics -- a "social netwar," the study dubbed it -- to generate support abroad for its campaign against the North American Free Trade Agreement. The study said swarms of independent citizens groups can prove far more effective than hierarchical movements when combating established institutions because they can't easily be "decapitated."
Mr. Danaher admires the Zapatista model. "We also have a mosquito-bite strategy," he said.
That may be the movement's strength, but it is also a weakness.
Some of the main backers worry that the movement's successes to date have been purely tactical -- headline-grabbing civil disobedience and a flair for organization. They fear that the coalition could blow apart as quickly as it came together.
Already, the strains are showing.
Though religious groups are one of the main forces behind debt relief, they have refrained from any direct involvement in the demonstrations this Sunday. Instead, they scheduled their own rally last Sunday.
Oxfam and Greenpeace, two of the best-known names in social and environmental activism, have severed formal ties to one of the major coalitions of protesters, though members of both groups are still participating in the protests.
The split came about partly over goals. Oxfam officials, for example, say they have made progress trying to reform the World Bank, and getting governments to agree to debt relief. Global Exchange, in contrast, wants the bank and fund abolished.
"Too much of this has been about tactics, getting all these groups together and keeping things moving," said John Sellers, of the Ruckus Society, based in Berkeley, Calif.
The observation is especially poignant coming from Mr. Sellers, who runs training camps around the country to teach varied protesters the mechanics of civil disobedience.
Over a beer at a Washington bookshop-cafe one recent evening, Mr. Sellers seemed unsure whether the movement can sustain momentum.
"I guess if we're going to have a center of gravity we have to figure out really what we want and where we go from here," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
SOLECTRON TO MOVE 850ATLANTA JOBS TO MEXICO

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The Solectron Corporation plans to move 850 jobs, or more than half of its work force, from its cellular telephone manufacturing plant in suburban Atlanta to its plant in Guadalajara, Mexico. Of the cuts, 475 are full-time jobs and 375 are temporary. The plant employs about 1,500 people. Fred Forsyth, president of Solectron Americas, said yesterday that the company was forced to move the jobs to Mexico to stay competitive in the cell phone business. Solectron employs about 6,700 workers in Guadalajara. Solectron, which is based in Milpitas, Calif., and makes electronic equipment, said the jobs would be moved by July.

HEADLINE: First Lady Criticizes Giuliani's Call for Tax Cuts and Urges Paying Debt

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WOODBURY, N.Y., April 14

 BODY:
Highlighting what has emerged as perhaps the sharpest policy difference between them in the Senate race, Hillary Rodham Clinton asserted today that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's call for deep, across-the-board tax cuts financed by the national surplus was a threat to prosperity.
Instead, Mrs. Clinton said, the surplus should be used primarily to pay off the national debt, and she offered a plan to do that by 2013. 
 Mrs. Clinton, taking a position that closely tracks President Clinton's posture in Congressional budget talks, said that she would support using only $250 billion of the projected $746 billion surplus for tax cuts, and that the reductions should be directed at specific groups, like first-time home-buyers and parents putting children through college.
By contrast, Mr. Giuliani, answering questions about Mrs. Clinton's proposal at a news conference at City Hall, said he would support sizable cuts in personal and capital gains tax rates. Although he declined to endorse any specific plan, he clearly sided with Congressional Republicans who are pushing a tax cut plan that could be twice as large as that advocated by Democrats.
Mrs. Clinton offered her views on taxes, the national debt and the surplus -- subjects that seem likely to shape many Congressional elections this year, including the one in New York -- in a speech in which she sought to present herself as the fiscal conservative in the race for Senate.
Mrs. Clinton repeatedly assailed Republican tax proposals as "risky," as she offered herself as a lifelong advocate of fiscal discipline and approvingly noted Mr. Clinton's successful effort to eliminate the deficit during his presidency.
"I want to be -- and I will be -- a steady and strong voice for fiscal discipline and a balanced budget in the United States," Mrs. Clinton, the Democratic candidate for Senate, said to 1,300 people who turned up for a breakfast here sponsored by the Long Island Association, a Commack-based business group. "I grew up with a father who didn't believe in credit cards, who paid cash for our house. And I have a hard time breaking those habits, and will put them to work in the Senate."
Mr. Giuliani told reporters in Manhattan that he believed that sizable reductions in both the income and capital gains tax rates would be a boon to New York State's economy, and would be particularly helpful upstate, which has suffered economic decline.
"It's the best way to help upstate New York," Mr. Giuliani said. "If you want to help upstate New York cut some of the taxes, particularly the income tax, where we disproportionally pay it, and you're going to leave money in the upstate economy, that then can be used for more jobs, more commercial activity, more economic activity."
Their remarks today underscored a strong point of disagreement between two candidates who share a number of similar views. With his comments, Mr. Giuliani signaled that he -- like his party's presumed presidential candidate, George W. Bush -- believed that cutting taxes was an issue that held sway with voters, notwithstanding evidence in polling and some recent political contests that it is not as potent an issue as it once was.
Mrs. Clinton is embarking on a fairly unorthodox route in her campaign: running against a tax cut. That said, her emphasis on eliminating the $3.5 trillion debt is part of her continuing effort to portray herself as a moderate Democrat, at a time when Mr. Giuliani has sought to present her as far more liberal than most New York voters.
The first lady's speech contained a fairly detailed accounting of some of her economic positions, and represented, to some extent, an attempt to point up what she has called Mr. Giuliani's reluctance to talk about how he would vote in the Senate.
Mr. Giuliani was invited along with Mrs. Clinton to offer his views on the economy to the Long Island Association, its president, Matthew T. Crosson, said today. "Mrs. Clinton accepted the invitation and is with us this morning," Mr. Crosson told the audience. "Mayor Giuliani has yet to respond."
A spokeswoman for Mr. Giuliani said tonight that the Long Island Association had asked him to commit to the date a month in advance, which, she said, he was unable to do because of the demands of his job.
At City Hall, Mr. Giuliani would not comment on the details of Mrs. Clinton's proposal. "I haven't seen her plan," the mayor said. "I've been at two funerals and a wake today, so I have not had a chance to see her plan and don't intend to give you a reaction to it just because she wants one today."
As reporters pressed Mr. Giuliani to offer details of his views on the subject, he responded: "Oh, come on, Mrs. Clinton, Mrs. Clinton. You guys, you're unbelievable. You're, like, knee-jerk, knee-jerk, knee-jerk. Thank you!" As he walked away from the lectern, he tossed a parting shot to the reporters gathered in City Hall's Blue Room: "Join the Democratic National Committee."
Until today, Mrs. Clinton has repeatedly said that education is the most pressing issue facing the nation. Today, she suggested that it was the economy, in language that echoed a famous sign on the wall of Mr. Clinton's campaign headquarters in Little Rock in 1992.
"Every time someone asks me what I would work on first and foremost in the Senate, my answer is always the economy," she said. "Because it still is the economy."
There is a dispute between Republicans and Democrats about the size of the projected 10-year surplus; Mrs. Clinton, like her husband and most Democrats, embraced the lower figure of about $750 billion. Of that, she said, 40 percent, or $350 billion, should go to paying off the national debt, with $250 billion for tax cuts. The remaining $150 billion, Mrs. Clinton's aides said, would go to financing various programs, like a prescription drug plan for Medicare.
In offering her proposal, Mrs. Clinton -- using language that echoed much of what Mr. Clinton has said -- asserted that the tax cuts proposed by the Republicans would undermine the prosperity that Mrs. Clinton said was the result of the economic policies of the last seven years.
"I will not support a tax cut that would force us to abandon the force of fiscal discipline and spend the surplus before we have paid down the debt," she said. "We all know that some of the noisiest voices in our country are those who say we should spend the surplus on a large, untargeted, across-the-board tax cut. You know, the road to risky tax cuts may appear to be easy -- and it certainly has short-term political gain attached to it -- but it will, inevitably and ultimately, lead to exploding deficits and a return to the higher interest rates."
Mr. Giuliani said he would "fight really, really hard" for two tax cuts that he argued would help New York's economy.
"One would be the income tax," he said. "That would leave money in the New York economy, because we pay a higher income tax per capita than most of the rest of the country. The second tax that would be a windfall for New York would be to reduce or eliminate the capital gains tax, because it would stimulate a hometown industry, and create a lot more activity there."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
STOCK MARKET IN STEEP DROP AS WORRIED INVESTORS FLEE; NASDAQ HAS ITS WORST WEEK

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER and ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Investors turned away from stocks yesterday in sharp waves of selling that closed one of the worst weeks in the history of United States markets.
The beleaguered Nasdaq index plunged nearly 10 percent to finish the worst week in its history with a 25.3 percent loss. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.66 percent and ended the week down 7.3 percent in its worst performance since 1989. Both indexes had their biggest losses ever in terms of points yesterday, and both finished the day near yesterday's lows, a development that does not bode well for Monday. 
 The catalyst for yesterday's sell-off was a Labor Department report that core consumer prices -- excluding food and energy -- had risen 0.4 percent in March, more than economists had predicted.
That news caused investors to dump technology stocks, deepening a rout that began in mid-March and has sent shares in many well-known technology companies down 30, 40 or even 50 percent in just three weeks.
But as the day wore on, the selling spread across the board. While technology stocks led the plunge, few companies escaped unscathed. All 30 stocks in the Dow fell, while all but 16 stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped. And only 5 of the 100 biggest companies in the Nasdaq index managed to finish up on the day.
"The market was levitating on hope and irrational concepts of stock market value, and now it's coming down to earth, but it's probably not down yet," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
On the positive side, the outlook for the economy, despite a surge in inflation last month, is still good. And if a decline in the market helps dampen consumer spending, the Federal Reserve may be able to get the economic slowdown it has been gunning for since last June.
The stock rout began on March 28 when Goldman, Sachs's chief investment strategist, Abby Joseph Cohen, warned that technology stocks were "no longer undervalued." The selling deepened the next week after a federal judge ruled against Microsoft in its antitrust case with the government, a decision that seemed to finally pull the rug out from the technology sector.
And while a lot of the so-called old-economy stocks resisted at first, they have now been caught in the downdraft.
Traders and investors offered many rationales yesterday for the deepening skid, with the most common explanation involving overextended investors who have to sell stocks to pay off margin loans and tax bills.
But underlying the explanations was a deepening sense of worry that this sell-off would not follow the pattern of previous years, in which nearly any slide was followed by an immediate and strong bounce. Many of the investors who were most enthusiastic about high-flying technology stocks have no spare cash left to invest.
More conservative investors are not yet ready to buy technology issues, many of which remain quite expensive by historical standards, with price-earnings ratios of 100 or higher despite their recent slide.
Even so, the sell-off has already proven painful for many investors. Between Monday and Friday, investors lost more than $2 trillion, or $7,000 on average for each person in the United States, according to Tony Crescenzi, chief bond market strategist at Miller Tabak & Company.
Meanwhile, short-sellers, who make money on market declines and have been battered over the last several years by what they see as the irrationality of many technology investors, said yesterday's action vindicated their long-held views that many stocks were overvalued.
"The lesson is going to be the market is not a game, the market is not a casino, it's a serious thing for serious people, and if you're wrong, be prepared to lose," said Marc Cohodes, general partner of Rocker Partners, a hedge fund that has both long and short positions. "There are some people who are broke, and they only have themselves to blame."
There are signs in stock mutual fund data that fresh money is still flowing nicely into stock funds and that those who have sold technology stock have bought stock in other companies, rather than abandoning the stock market. But many would-be buyers yesterday seemed content to wait for shares to fall even further, rather than jumping in as they often have when a market plunge made companies look cheap.
Jim Welch, who stopped by a Charles Schwab branch in midtown Manhattan around 1 p.m. to check his account, said he thought technology stocks were still too expensive. Mr. Welch, 64, a stock market veteran, said he might step in to buy technology shares if the sell-off continued "for a month or two."
In Washington, government officials played down the effects of the plunge, saying there were no signs that it had put any major strains on the financial system.
The Securities and Exchange Commission said in a statement that "clearing systems and the markets are successfully dealing with processing orders and distributing price information."
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers told CNN that the government was "watching developments in markets as we always do," but that the economy remained fundamentally strong.
Government officials said there had been no need to convene the working group of top financial officials that coordinates a response in the event of a market crisis.
In a speech earlier in the day, Mr. Greenspan warned banks and investment firms not to be complacent about risk, but he did not comment on the markets or on the outlook for further interest rate increases.
With its 355.49 point decline, the largest ever, to 3321.29, the Nasdaq fell 9.67 percent yesterday, its second-worst daily decline in percentage terms. The technology-heavy index is now down 34.2 percent, or 1,727 points, since its record high of March 10. That is well into bear market territory, which is considered a decline of at least 20 percent from the most recent record high. And it is just short of the 35.9 percent decline, peak to trough, in 1987.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 617.78 points, or 5.66 percent, to 10,305.77, is off 8.7 percent since Tuesday.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index, meanwhile, finished the day down 83.95 points, or 5.83 percent, at 1,356.56, and is now down 11.2 percent from its record high on March 24.
By most standards, the news on inflation, although not terrible, was unexpectedly bad. Core consumer prices jumped 0.4 of 1 percent in March, the largest monthly increase in more than five years.
That report, coupled with the recent rise in hourly earnings, intensified the threat of rate increases from the Federal Reserve, which has already raised its short-term interest rate target a quarter of a point five times since June.
But before yesterday many investors could argue that there was no pressure on the Federal Reserve to move aggressively to slow growth because there was no sign of inflationary pressure, outside the recent surge in oil and gasoline prices. Yesterday's report blunted that hope.
"In a less pregnant moment, people would say it's the first bad core C.P.I. number in some time and let's wait for another one," said Robert Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company in Rye Brook, N.Y. "But because the economy is flat out booming and the stock market is so expensive, no one is going to wait around for the next three," he said. "This could unsettle the Fed and the markets enough to make the economy have a harder landing."
For investors looking into next week, the question is whether the doubts generated by this sell-off, and the volatility associated with it, will be able to be overcome by the good news on first quarter earnings, which begin to come out in earnest next week, and the still positive outlook for the economy.
"This is not a problem of the economy or of earnings," said Mr. Wien of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "They are both doing well." Morgan Stanley is forecasting first-quarter earnings growth for the S.& P. 500 of about 20 percent, compared with the first quarter of 1999. For the technology sector, earnings should rise about 30 percent.
The consumer price report initially sent Treasury prices plunging as investors feared that higher inflation would erode the value of their bonds. Yields, which move in the opposite direction of prices, shot higher. For instance, the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note leapt to 6.02 percent, from 5.91 percent Thursday.
But as the selling in the stock market accelerated, some investors seemed to take refuge in Treasuries and the bond market gained. In late trading, the 10-year note rallied, with the yield dropping to 5.85 percent.
The flow of money into mutual funds indicates that investors have not lost their taste for stocks. Instead, they seem to be shifting money from one sector to another.
According to AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual fund flows, $8.4 billion flowed into equity mutual funds in the week ending Wednesday April 12. Nearly half of that rushed into large cap growth funds, which concentrate their investment in what are now called old-economy companies.
But still $923 million flowed into technology mutual funds and $1.8 billion into what are called aggressive growth funds, which also invest in technology stocks.
According to Robert Adler, the president of AMG, there was an outflow of $760 million from technology funds in the week ending April 5. That was the first net outflow from such funds since August of 1999 and the largest weekly outflow he has recorded. But that outflow was more than offset this week.

HEADLINE: An Effort To Preserve A Monolith

BYLINE: By DANIEL J. WAKIN 

 BODY:
In a city where putting up buildings, tearing them down and protesting in the streets are part of daily life, this demonstration was somewhat different.
There was the writer Tom Wolfe in a pale checked suit, the architect Robert M. Stern and a corps of New York City's preservationist elite. And behind them yesterday was a building with no windows other than footwide portholes, tennis racket-shaped columns and arches evoking Venetian palaces. 
 The building is 2 Columbus Circle, the white marble monolith on the southern end of the circle that has looked up Central Park West and Broadway since 1964. Vacant for two years, the property has been put up for development by the city, drawing fears from preservationists that it will be torn down for an office or apartment building.
Once the home of the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, 2 Columbus Circle was designed by the architect Edward Durell Stone for Huntington Hartford, the heir to the A.& P. supermarket fortune. It was built to house Mr. Hartford's art collection, and his name is still inscribed in front.
The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has declined to give it landmark status, and the city's Economic Development Corporation is soliciting bids from developers, calling it "prime location for residential apartments, as well as hotel and other commercials uses." The deadline is May 2.
The city's proffer, plus a previous bid by Donald J. Trump to build a 12-story hotel, translated into the fears that Stone's building would fall.
Now, support for the building is growing. Its circle of public champions has widened to include Mr. Wolfe and some local politicians.
"I think this is one of the few candles lit in the dark ages of New York architecture, which ran from the 1950's almost to the present day," said Mr. Wolfe, who said he held his first book party in the Gauguin Room, a two-story restaurant that was then atop the building.
Preservationists may take heart from Mr. Trump, who owns a complex across the circle and suggested yesterday that he might not go forward with his plans for 2 Columbus Circle. "It's so small, it's very possible that I won't be bidding," Mr. Trump said. "It's very tough to make any money there."
Whether he bids or not, Mr. Trump gave the building an aesthetic demolition. "I think it belongs in the middle of Jiddah, not in the middle of New York City," he said of Stone's work. "He's a very important architect. It is a very unimportant building."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is also said to be no great admirer of 2 Columbus Circle. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch has called the building downright ugly.
Even some preservationists are not convinced of its merits. Peg Breen, president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy, said that the organization's board was deeply divided about whether the building deserved landmark status. She and others at yesterday's protest said they were merely calling for an open hearing by the Landmarks Commission.
After the earlier request for proposals on the site, in 1997, the city also received a bid from the Dahesh Museum, which wants to leave its cramped quarters on Fifth Avenue and 48th Street. The museum is based on the collection of a Lebanese writer who favored 19th century academic art.
But that round of bidding was suspended after developers were chosen for the nearby Coliseum site, where the $1.6 billion Columbus Center is rising, city development officials have said. City officials said the construction would change the area, and they wanted to give prospective bidders a chance to reassess it.
But a person familiar with the negotiations at the time said that the bidding was suspended because there were only two entrants -- the Dahesh, with a $10 million proposal, and Mr. Trump, for less -- and because the bids were too low.
The Landmarks Conservancy has complained that the city's new offering encourages a commercial use at the site, since a commercial property would bring in more tax revenue to the city.
To architects like Mr. Stern, the building is worth preserving regardless of what would be put up in its stead.
"To tear it down to build another apartment house or condo is preposterous," Mr. Stern said.
Others defenders include State Representative Richard N. Gottfried, State Senator Eric T. Schneiderman, City Councilwoman Ronnie Eldridge and leaders of the local Democratic Party club.
The man who was responsible for it all, Mr. Hartford, is 90 and in a nursing home, his daughter Juliet Hartford said.
"He never could believe it would be torn down," Ms. Hartford said. "When I tell him, he thinks I'm kidding."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Valentine's Comments Prompt Visit by Phillips

BYLINE: By TYLER KEPNER 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, April 14

 BODY:
Mets General Manager Steve Phillips goes to great lengths to edit himself, to keep private everything that is remotely controversial. His manager does not share this trait; it is Bobby Valentine's nature to speak his mind, even when that may not be appropriate. The question of whether two such divergent personalities can coexist is alive again.
Phillips, who had planned to scout a Mets minor league team this weekend, flew instead to Pittsburgh today to try to put out the latest fire sparked by Valentine's comments. 
 On Wednesday, Valentine, responding to an e-mail request from a student, spoke to about 100 students at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania. The topic of the 90-minute talk was the business of baseball, but Valentine also spent time answering questions about the Mets. That was where the trouble started.
Valentine said he told the students not to repeat what he said, but one student recounted Valentine's opinions in a message on the Mets' official Web site early Thursday morning. According to the student, who identified himself as Brad34, Valentine said he was not in favor of the signing of Todd Zeile to play first base, that he is forced by management to start Derek Bell because of Bell's high salary, and that he did not understand the trade of pitcher Masato Yoshii, among other critical comments.
"This is ridiculous," Valentine said of the controversy surrounding the comments. "More than ridiculous. It's outrageous. I had little conversations, I addressed the whole group, I talked to guys privately. For it to be an issue with you guys and my team and the front office I think is ludicrous."
But it has become an issue, partly because it is not the first time Valentine has made negative comments. In an article in Sports Illustrated late last season, Valentine said there were "five losers" in the Mets' clubhouse, and he boasted that he could expose the ignorance of other managers. Also late last year, he made his uncertain future an even bigger issue by saying he should not return if the Mets failed to make the playoffs.
Valentine, like Phillips, is unsigned past this season, and in spring training, the co-owner Fred Wilpon said Valentine would have to be accountable for his words. Wilpon declined to comment tonight, saying he would speak to the news media after he had spoken to Phillips.
Phillips said this issue would not affect Valentine's status. "It's something that I need to talk to him about," Phillips said, "but he's not going to get fired over this."
Phillips said his absence in Pittsburgh would have been more conspicuous than his presence, and he felt he needed to come to Three Rivers Stadium to meet with Valentine and representatives of the news media. He spoke with Valentine by telephone after Thursday's game, and met with him for 10 minutes before tonight's game against the Pirates. Phillips would not characterize those conversations, but he was not happy when he read the posting on the Web site.
"I was surprised and curious," said Phillips, who walked out of the stadium with Valentine after the game and planned to discuss the issue further. "Surprised in a bad way."
The message was deleted from the Web site this afternoon; Phillips said the company that filters postings on the Mets' site took it down, independent of the club.
Valentine confirmed that he had discussed all the topics noted, but he disputed the context, said he was not really saying anything new, and characterized many of his responses as "yes" or "no."
On the Web site, Valentine was said to have favored signing the Japanese reliever Kazuhiro Sasaki over Zeile, and that Jorge Toca and Matt Franco could have been adequate replacements for John Olerud at first base. Valentine said that he was asked by a Japanese student if the Mets had considered Sasaki, but that he never said he preferred Sasaki to Zeile; he also said at the start of the winter that Franco and Toca could fill Olerud's spot, if needed.
Valentine spoke to Zeile for a few minutes around the batting cage before the game. Zeile said he was not taking this seriously.
"This is something that I guess makes more interesting propaganda for people outside the loop, because I don't particularly care," Zeile said. "It is what it is, and it's not going to affect my feelings here one way or the other, my effort or my performance or anything else. I'm not in any rush to make an issue out of something I don't even know conclusively about."
As for Bell, Valentine said: "I'm sure I said a guy who's making a lot of money should play. That's the economics of it." But, Valentine said, a player of Bell's status has earned the right to continue playing despite early-season struggles.
Bell was testy when first told of the Web site report, but he later explained he was only joking. He peeked into the manager's office while Valentine was addressing reporters, and assured Valentine that the incident would not come between them.
"Bobby loves me, and I respect him to the utmost," Bell said.
Valentine said he did understand the trade of Yoshii to Colorado, but that several of the Mets' plans for replacing Yoshii did not work out.
Phillips said the incident could be "a potential distraction," but in an interview on the Mets' telecast during tonight's game, he said the same passion that sometimes gets Valentine in trouble also makes Valentine a good manager.
Valentine sounded as if he felt his privacy had been violated by a new medium.
When asked if this issue would affect his relationship with Phillips, which was already uneasy, he said: "It might. Maybe it'll bring us closer. Maybe we'll get down to issues of the baseball team rather than issues of the media.
"Because this takes it another step, I think -- Internet chat rooms takes it to a whole other step. Now it's going to be that I said something to the guy in the cab, or the guy in the restaurant. I don't know if any of this stuff is substantiated or ever will be."

HEADLINE: After Deaths, City Plans Millions for Livery-Cab Safety

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
Hours after the fatal shooting of the sixth livery-cab driver slain this year in his car, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the city would create a $5 million program to provide independently owned and operated livery and medallion taxis with safety partitions or security cameras.
The mayor announced the initiative, to be administered by the Taxi and Limousine Commission and the Police Department, at a City Hall news conference yesterday afternoon. 
 A short while earlier, livery drivers had gathered at the site of the killing in the Longwood section of the Bronx to honor the dead man and ask the city for a number of measures, including partitions and cameras.
Mr. Giuliani said the program would be financed through the city's Economic Development Corporation. The money would buy $400 bullet-resistant partitions or digital security cameras, which officials said cost $600 to $800.
"The safety of these drivers is very important to the city, and this program will provide meaningful relief," Mr. Giuliani said in a prepared statement. Eleven livery-cab drivers were killed on the job in 1999. So far this year, three drivers have been killed in the Bronx, two in Brooklyn and one in Queens.
The mayor said he had offered his condolences to the widow of Luis Francisco Perez, the driver slain yesterday, and had told her that the police were doing everything they could to catch the killer.
Mr. Perez, 30, who had worked as a livery driver for Premium Radio Dispatch for three years, was shot twice in the head around 12:30 a.m. in his Lincoln Town Car on a street dotted with auto repair shops beneath the elevated Bruckner Expressway, the police said.
Although they have reached no conclusions about the motive for the killing, investigators said that Mr. Perez was probably not killed during a robbery, because he had more than $500 in his pocket. They said that he had apparently finished work for the night and that his dry cleaning was hanging from a hook in the back seat.
The police said Mr. Perez was shot as he sat behind the wheel, apparently by someone who was seated beside him. A single spent bullet was recovered from the car.
About 12 hours after the shooting, Mr. Perez's widow, Ana Maria Estrella, and Fernando Mateo, the president of the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers, gathered at Whitlock Avenue and Aldus Street, the site of the killing, for a news conference.
Mr. Mateo said he had met with the mayor on Tuesday to discuss driver safety and had called for safety devices like partitions, cameras and tracking devices as well as for increased police patrols aimed at thwarting taxi robberies.
The news conference ended abruptly when Ms. Estrella began sobbing and then fainted as she spoke to the crowd of reporters, photographers and television crews. She was taken away in an ambulance.
Before she broke down, Ms. Estrella talked briefly about her husband. "He was a good man, he was a happy man," she said in Spanish, with Mr. Mateo translating. "I lost it all. I have nowhere to turn." The couple's 16-month-old son slept through the event.
Mr. Perez, who came to the United States from the Dominican Republic, had been driving a livery cab in New York for about seven years, as one of the roughly 41,000 drivers in the city who cruise for fares in neighborhoods where medallion taxis are seldom found. Yellow cabs are the only ones allowed to pick up fares on the street; livery drivers are required to be dispatched to pick up passengers. But many livery drivers pick up fares who hail them on the street to make extra money.
 The police said yesterday that statistics showed that 82 percent of livery drivers robbed since the beginning of this year were held up by fares who hailed them in the street. The police urged the drivers not to pick up street fares. Lt. Dennis Cirillo, a police spokesman, said that the department had formed a task force of 40 detectives to investigate and try to prevent taxi robberies and homicides.
Taxi and Limousine Commission rules require livery and medallion cabs that are operated by more than one driver to have partitions, but many livery drivers who use their cars for both work and personal use do not want the partitions. Cars owned and operated by drivers make up 90 percent of all livery cabs.

HEADLINE: An Idea Whose Time Will Not Go

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley is the Allan Nevins professor of history at Columbia and the author, most recently, of "Liberalism and Its Discontents."

 BODY:

WAY OUT THERE
 IN THE BLUE
 Reagan, Star Wars and the End
 of the Cold War.
 By Frances FitzGerald.
 592 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $30. 
 Between 1983, when Ronald Reagan first proposed what he called the "Strategic Defense Initiative," and 1999, when Congress most recently financed it, the United States spent over $60 billion on research and preliminary testing of a system to defend the nation against strategic missiles. It has already become the single most expensive research project in the history of the federal government. And so far there is almost nothing to show for it. Despite some important technical advances, there is still no workable system of missile defenses and no realistic prospect of an effective system any time soon.
Most Americans probably think of S.D.I., popularly known as "Star Wars," as a relic of the Reagan years, long since abandoned. That it survives still, after over 16 years of futility, is only one of many things that may surprise some readers of Frances FitzGerald's "Way Out There in the Blue," an exhaustive account of the fate of S.D.I. in the 1980's and beyond. FitzGerald is an eminent writer and nonacademic historian, and the author of, among other things, a Pulitzer Prize-winning study of the Vietnam War, "Fire in the Lake." This book is a significant departure from her previous work. It is an excursion into the intricacies of complex public policies and, in particular, into the arcane political and technological details of nuclear diplomacy. A less talented writer would have a hard time telling this difficult story in a way that ordinary readers would find accessible or interesting. What is perhaps most striking about "Way Out There in the Blue" is how clearly, eloquently and engagingly FitzGerald manages to describe a set of obscure and complicated events.
Little in this book will be new to those who have closely followed the vicissitudes of S.D.I. over the past 17 years. Almost everything in it is drawn from previously published sources. What makes this story so absorbing is FitzGerald's skill at tying S.D.I. to the larger history of its time. In particular, she provides one of the best inner histories of the Reagan administration yet to appear.
S.D.I. was born out of the convergence of political crisis and scientific hubris. In the first two years of the Reagan administration, the United States redefined its relationship with the Soviet Union and, in the process, produced not only a heightened level of hostility between the two superpowers but a complete stalemate in the slow progress of arms control negotiations that had then been in progress for over a decade. Most of the leading military and foreign policy figures in the administration's early years did not believe in negotiating with the Kremlin. They preferred a confrontational escalation of the arms race, which they believed the United States would win.
Two unforeseen political developments threatened this agenda. One was the serious recession that began in 1982 and that greatly increased the already large deficits that the administration's supply-side economics had helped produce. The other was the emergence of the nuclear freeze movement in Europe and America and its rapid transformation into a major political force. Fearful that budgetary constraints and popular fears would derail the administration's military and foreign policy, a number of Reagan aides began to take an interest in what until then had been a relatively obscure proposal from a small group of important, if somewhat erratic, scientists. It was a plan for developing a laser-guided, space-based defense against ballistic missiles, and its principal scientific sponsor was Edward Teller, a distinguished physicist who was also known as a hyperbolic enthusiast for visionary schemes that existed largely in his own imagination.
Teller and those who shared his vision talked ecstatically about the new technologies that they claimed were already available to create such a system, and they persuaded many within the administration to go along with the wishful and entirely erroneous idea that effective deployment was within easy reach. For policy makers trying to quell popular opposition to the arms race, the idea of a shield against incoming missiles seemed a godsend, and they promoted it fervently and boldly -- most notably by advancing a novel "broad" interpretation of the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty and arguing that S.D.I. was compatible with that agreement.
To President Reagan, FitzGerald says, S.D.I. was appealing for other reasons. It was, in essence, a route to achieving an old American dream: isolation from the dangers of the outside world. In the past, the dream of isolation had led to efforts to keep the United States unconnected to other nations, an idea clearly obsolete in the 1980's. Now a miraculous new technology promised to do what diplomacy could not. Reagan always presented S.D.I. as an impenetrable barrier that would protect the American people (even though, very early in the research process, almost every scientist understood that at best it would be able to protect only American land-based missiles, not the population). Much of the public believed Reagan's rhetoric, and the growing popularity of S.D.I. helped undercut the power of the nuclear freeze movement in America (although not in Europe), making it easier for the administration both to finance its military program and to continue the stalemate in arms control negotiations.
Three figures stand at the center of FitzGerald's oddly gripping story. One is George Shultz, who succeeded the prickly Alexander Haig as secretary of state in 1982 and set out to place American relations with the Soviet Union on a more conciliatory course. Shultz was always skeptical about S.D.I., and always more willing than others to treat it as a bargaining chip in negotiations with Moscow. But he did not try to scuttle the program. Instead, he waged a battle against those in the administration who opposed arms control and did not believe in any real negotiations with the Soviets.
His chief antagonist was Caspar Weinberger, the combative secretary of defense, who decided very early in his tenure in office that his mission was to defend the administration's military buildup relentlessly and uncritically. Weinberger was a devoted servant of bureaucratic self-interest, not an ideologue; and within the Pentagon bureaucracy, the principal self-interest was defending the Reagan increases in the military budget. Weinberger sided with those who opposed arms control negotiations less because he had strong beliefs about Communism or the Soviet regime than because such opposition was consistent with his own goal of military expansion. FitzGerald says he supported S.D.I. for the same reason.
Weinberger and Shultz were at war with each other from the beginning of Shultz's tenure in 1982 to the end of Weinberger's in 1987, and the political and bureaucratic intrigue with which each tried to undercut and outmaneuver the other is a recurrent and fascinating theme of FitzGerald's book. But what made their battle so intense was the character of the man whose support they were both trying to attract: Ronald Reagan.
Much has been written about Reagan's detached leadership style, his legendary ignorance of the details of his own policies and his unwillingness to support anything firmly, other than a few very broad principles. FitzGerald does not substantially revise this already well-established portrait, which is visible in the work of Lou Cannon, Edmund Morris and almost all the many memoirists from Reagan's own administration. But she does make unusually vivid the degree to which Reagan dwelled in a world apart from those around him; the way he clung determinedly to myths and fantasies regardless of evidence refuting them; the way he reinterpreted his conduct to fit his own vision of himself (most famously in his stubborn insistence, and his apparently real belief, that he had never agreed to trade arms for hostages in Iran, even though he clearly had).
FitzGerald makes clear, however, that one thing always trumped even Reagan's most fervently held beliefs, and that was his own political fortunes. Despite his image as a man of rock-solid conviction who ignored politics in pursuit of his goals, he was at least as much of a political man as any other occupant of the White House. He embraced S.D.I. because it fit comfortably with his romantic beliefs, to be sure. But, according to FitzGerald, he embraced it most of all because he was in political trouble in 1983 and saw it as a way out. He sided with, or at least refused to repudiate, those in his administration who opposed negotiations with the Soviets as long as that opposition was not politically costly. But once Mikhail Gorbachev skillfully mobilized world opinion behind his reforms in the Soviet Union and, even more, once the Iran-contra scandal blighted Reagan's reputation at home, the president embraced summit diplomacy, and even arms control, as an effective vehicle for restoring his own popularity. Reagan never took sides consistently in the battle between Shultz and Weinberger until he realized that siding with Shultz was the course more likely to benefit him politically.
By the end of the Reagan administration, almost nothing survived of its early militant posture toward the Soviet Union. The great military buildup of 1981-1983 had been terminated. Arms control negotiations were advancing rapidly. Reagan himself had all but declared the cold war over. All that remained, in the end, was S.D.I. -- not as a politically valuable program (the public had long since lost interest in it, and many Americans assumed the project was virtually dead), but as one now with a large constituency within the bureaucracy, in a few corners of the scientific community and in some defense industries, all of whom fought to keep lavish spending for the program alive. Eventually, after 1994, they were joined by the new Republican leadership in Congress, committed to an agenda in many ways well to the right of Reagan's. They were attracted to S.D.I., FitzGerald argues, because they, like Reagan at his most ethereal, continued to imagine a world in which the United States could stand alone, impervious to the interests or needs of other nations. In 1999, with broad bipartisan support and almost no public debate or popular notice, Congress authorized an additional $6.6 billion to deploy an antimissile defense system. Ronald Reagan's strange and alluring dream now seems almost certain to outlive him.

HEADLINE: Third-Party Candidate

BYLINE: By Nelson Lichtenstein; Nelson Lichtenstein teaches history at the University of Virginia.

 BODY:

American Dreamer
 The Life and Times of Henry A. Wallace.
 By John C. Culver and John Hyde.
 Illustrated. 608 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $35. 
 Henry A. Wallace has long been an unwelcome guest at the table of New Deal remembrance. He was a crusading secretary of agriculture during the Depression and an outspoken, progressive vice president in World War II. But after he ran for president on a Communist-backed Progressive Party ticket in 1948, his political legacy found no champions.
Liberals thought him little more than a woolly-minded foil for Harry S. Truman's brand of tough anti-Communist internationalism. Conservatives pointed to Wallace as the embodiment of New Deal social planning and collectivism. And leftists remembered that in the 1930's Wallace sided with the plantation owners who used New Deal farm policy to throw sharecroppers off the land.
But Wallace has at long last found a defense team worthy of his remarkable scientific and political career. In this expansive and engaging biography, John Hyde, a journalist long associated with The Des Moines Register, and John C. Culver, a former Democratic senator from Iowa, give us a life with plenty of blunders and eccentricities. However, the portrait that emerges in "American Dreamer" is one of an increasingly combative liberal whose 15 years in the public spotlight put him not at the margins but close to the animating center of American politics during the heyday of the New Deal.
To follow the long road Wallace took from farm-state worthy to postwar villain, one has to start with Iowa's great crop, corn. Farmers raised too much of it, and the corn they grew often fell victim to hail, drought, pest and rock-bottom prices. Farm income followed an unpredictable boom-and-bust cycle.
Wallaces' Farmer, the influential journal published by three generations of the family, argued that the solution lay not with populist hell-raising or Wall Street-bashing but with the application of science, planning and good management to the agricultural enterprise. The Wallaces were Republicans in the 1920's, working closely with the powerful, socially conservative American Farm Bureau Federation. Young Henry was a skilled econometrician and one of the inventors of hybrid corn, whose commercialization would eventually make his family wealthy.
But Wallace was hardly an advocate of laissez-faire. He believed that agricultural capitalism was but an extreme variant of all free-market systems -- inherently unstable, and thus inefficient and socially dangerous. In the depths of the Depression, such ideas mirrored the nation's desolate reality; thus, as President Roosevelt's agriculture secretary, Wallace won near-universal consent for a farm program designed to limit production, subsidize growers and raise prices. To the horror of urban consumers, six million baby pigs got their throats slit, but hog prices did rise. In later years the regulatory effort would proceed with more subtlety. Indeed, for more than half a century the market-shaping apparatus established by Henry Wallace made government planning in the farm belt as American as corn on the cob.
Wallace's commitment to a well-ordered political economy was strangely offset by an inner turmoil. His biographers see Wallace as a "dreamer," a restless, "ardent seeker of cosmic truth." They track a frenzied spiritual voyage. During the 1920's and 30's, Wallace explored Roman Catholicism, theosophy, astrology and Native American religions. During his early years as secretary of agriculture he corresponded with the expatriate Russian mystic Nicholas Roerich. Wallace took more than his share of invective when his political enemies later made these "guru letters" public, and by 1948 his covert spirituality seemed but one more indication of his political unreliability.
In 1940, Roosevelt told Democrats he wanted Wallace on his ticket for his try at an unprecedented third term, and Culver and Hyde detail the intense intraparty opposition generated by the choice. But they neglect the larger political dynamic that made Wallace both highly useful to Roosevelt's re-election and exceedingly controversial as an outspoken World War II liberal. As a set of policy initiatives, the New Deal was in retreat by 1940. But as an electoral coalition, the Democratic Party that had been formed by the New Deal was hardly finished: it was based on the support of organized labor, urban liberals and African-Americans, just the kind of voters who applauded Wallacite reformism.
The new vice president therefore infused the war effort with the kind of visionary New Dealism that had grown stale in Washington's corridors of power. But Wallace's politics, and his own power, were put to the test in 1943 when he tangled with Jesse Jones, Roosevelt's staunchly conservative commerce secretary, who was in charge of financing the purchase of war materials abroad. As the head of a new Board of Economic Warfare, Wallace wanted to put a New Deal stamp on this process. He would ensure labor rights and decent wages for foreign workers who produced the rubber, tin and copper purchased for the Allied military cause. Jones and his conservative allies denounced the effort; the racists among them called it a "quart of milk for every Hottentot." When Roosevelt failed to back his vice president in this battle, Wallace's ouster from the 1944 Democratic ticket was virtually assured.
Wallace felt "liberated" by this defeat. Now he would begin a long embattled march toward political independence -- and marginality. Culver and Hyde offer a sympathetic but hardly fawning account of this, the most controversial phase of Wallace's career. He was often blind to the horrors of the Stalin regime, readily accepting Soviet domination of Eastern Europe. Soon, Wallace was anathema among anti-Communist liberals like Hubert Humphrey and Eleanor Roosevelt, and his views helped facilitate the increasingly large Communist role in the Progressive Party campaign of 1948.
However, this hardly constitutes the most significant part of the Wallace legacy. He insisted that the militarization of the cold war was neither wise nor necessary, and he recognized that the ideological constraints imposed in that crusade endangered American liberties. But of even more usefulness today may be the lessons Wallace derived from his effort to discipline the market, and not only in corn or cotton. Someday, the economy may take a big lunge downward, and if it does, even the most savvy Web capitalists will find new merit in some of the regulatory tools deployed by Henry Wallace when he joined Franklin Roosevelt's cabinet 67 years ago. 
http://www.nytimes.com

TYPE: Review

TITLE: AMERICAN DREAMER (BOOK)

INDUSTRY: NAICS511130 BOOK PUBLISHERS (91%); SIC5192 BOOKS, PERIODICALS, & NEWSPAPERS (91%); SIC2732 BOOK PRINTING (91%); SIC2731 BOOKS: PUBLISHING, OR PUBLISHING & PRINTING (91%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC ISSUE;
Bargains Are Fading In Asia

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH; HOWARD W. FRENCH is chief of the Tokyo bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
THE bad news these days about travel to eastern Asia is that the region has reverted from being the certifiable steal that it was at the height of the economic crisis two years ago to once again being comparably priced with many other parts of the world -- or even pricier.
The good news, if that's the right term when bargains are evaporating, is that the region's many currencies seem finally to have stabilized, and budgeting for travel once again seems possible throughout much of the area, even when making reservations a few months in advance. 
 Most Asian currencies have strengthened handsomely from their lows of two years ago, accounting for the largest rise in costs for travel by Americans and others with United States dollars. A dramatic case in point is Japan, where the yen has appreciated by 22 percent since early April 1998, to about 105 yen to the dollar from about 135 yen.
Prices in yen have scarcely changed in two years' time; indeed many have decreased marginally in the recession that hangs over the country. But that will be little comfort to holders of dollars, who will have to buy yen at a much higher rate.
Visitors to Tokyo today will pay about 44,000 yen, about $420, to stay in a double-occupancy room at the Okura Hotel, one of the city's top business hotels, and 38,000, $360, for one in the Westin Tokyo, another favorite among visiting business people. Those rates in yen have barely budged in the last two years. Unfortunately, the difference in dollars -- an increase of close to $100 in each case -- will be keenly felt.
It has been a long time since Japan has been considered a bargain by travelers from anywhere. For many visitors -- and residents -- it often seems to be the most expensive place on the planet, what with tiny $5 cups of coffee and taxis whose meters start at $6.50.
One of the best bargains, though, remains the Japan Rail Pass, available from the Japan National Tourist Organization offices in the United States. A one-week pass, which covers wide-ranging tours of the country aboard Japan's famous bullet trains, is 28,300 yen, or about $270 at current exchange rates.
In China, the currency is held steady by a Government-fixed exchange rate. Room rates in Beijing have remained fairly stable as well. Double rooms are available at the China World Hotel in Beijing for $210, plus 15 percent service and tax charge. Another central city establishment, the New World Hotel, offers doubles for $120, including breakfast, service charge and tax.
In Thailand, a favorite tourist destination for visitors from both the West and elsewhere in Asia, prices have been on a slow, steady rebound since the Asian currency crisis. Compared with precrisis days, many of the country's top hotels are still a bargain, but if the current trend continues, that won't be true for very long.
At the high-end Shangri-La in Bangkok, a double now goes for $210, including breakfast, laundry and dry cleaning, rising to $290 for a deluxe room. Scarcely three years ago, those rooms were $220 and $310, respectively. In the interim, though, a standard double had fallen to as little as $180.
And at the legendary Oriental Hotel, the rate is $250 a room, single or double occupancy, plus 10 percent service charge and 7.7 percent tax, up from $220 two years ago. The Westin Banyan Tree's doubles are $190, up from about $150 two years ago. And the Delta Grand Pacific, a popular destination for more-budget-oriented travelers offers doubles for $85, plus service and tax charges, up from $75 two years ago.
For beach vacationers, a week for two at the Club Med Phuket is $3,200, including three meals a day, drinks and sports activities. That high-season rate falls to $1,400 for the same package during the off season. These are the same as two years ago.
In Singapore, the venerable Raffles Hotel says its rates haven't changed in two years, with a double costing $700, plus 10 percent service, 1 percent government tax and 1 percent goods and services tax. A double at the Westin Plaza is also unchanged from 1998: $360, plus tax.
No country was harder hit by the region's currency collapse than Indonesia. At the height of the country's woes, deluxe taxis could be chartered for less than $10 a day, and rooms at the Shangri-La in Jakarta, with its marble-clad health club, could be had for under $100.
Indonesia remains the region's best bargain. It has gone through rocky political times with the secession of East Timor and the recent presidential elections. Indonesia's currency has been rising slowly, but visitors will find that prices are far below precrisis levels and still eminently reasonable.
The Shangri-La, for example, offers double rooms for $155, plus 21 percent for tax and service, and doubles can be had at the Crowne Plaza Jakarta, another top hotel, for a mere $88, with breakfast included. At the Westin Surabaya, doubles are $63, and deluxe rooms are $79, including breakfast.
The dream air fare to Asia -- $999 round trip for two people from the United States to Hong Kong on Cathay Pacific, with five nights' lodging included -- offered briefly in 1997, may have been the ultimate deal. But air fare to Asia is still a relative bargain. Cathay has expanded its $999 round-trip all-Asia pass, which allows a traveler to visit 16 cities in 30 days; departures from the United States are from New York, San Francisco or Los Angeles, with the first and last stop in Hong Kong.
An Internet search this month for the lowest air fare from Los Angeles to Bangkok found $555 on China Airlines and $559 on Korean Airlines. Continental, Northwest, American and United Airlines all offered a $638 ticket, just over half of what it was in spring 1997. The best price for a mid-May departure was $680 on Northwest and Thai.
Not all cities are quite that cheap, though: the lowest Los Angeles-Tokyo fare for mid-May departure was $811 on Korean Air and Northwest. The best New York-Tokyo fare for mid-May was $1,161 on four airlines, which was $200 less than a month earlier.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 11; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2513 words

HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC ISSUE;
Hong Kong Is Humming Again

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER; MARK LANDLER is chief of the Hong Kong bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
NEARLY three years later, residents of this former British colony still get starry-eyed when they recall the rituals that marked Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997: The stately transfer of power, the blazing fireworks, the lavish receptions and balls.
For Hong Kong, the handover, not the millennium, was its fin-de-siecle party. And the hangover that followed was worse than any Y2K bug. 
 But now, after two years of recession and hand-wringing about its future, Hong Kong has come out of its funk. The stock market is humming, business is booming and construction cranes once again swoop above the city's serrated skyline. Most tellingly, Hong Kong thumps with the percussion of pile-drivers pounding in foundations for the next generation of high-rise towers.
Hong Kong is also coming back to life as a destination for tourists. Visitor arrivals, which plunged from 11.7 million in 1996 to a low of 9.5 million in 1998, rebounded last year, to 10.7 million. The Hong Kong Tourist Association predicts arrivals will grow to 11.4 million this year. "We have successfully put Hong Kong on the world map as a city of diverse attractions that offers great value for money," said Amy Chan, the association's executive director.
Ms. Chan's claim about value for money is debatable. Hong Kong remains one of the most expensive cities in Asia -- a room at the midrange Excelsior Hotel in Causeway Bay costs $175 -- though the rebound in the currencies of other Southeast Asian countries is closing the gap somewhat. And while this city of seven million does offer breathtaking sights -- natural and man-made -- its most talked-about new tourist attraction is still on the drawing board.
Last fall, the Walt Disney Company announced it would build a theme park in Hong Kong, its third outside the United States and second in Asia, after Tokyo Disneyland. The 311-acre park, to be built on Lantau Island west of Hong Kong, is not scheduled to open until 2005. But it has already become part of Hong Kong's marketing pitch: a cosmopolitan city, with Western flavor as well as Chinese characteristics.
If that sounds a bit all-encompassing, it may reflect Hong Kong's deeper struggle to fashion an identity after its reversion to China. The tourist association promotes Hong Kong as the "City of Life," and lively it is. But the slogan seems a place-holder for a city still not sure of its new role.
In some matters, Hong Kong is clearly starting to put East above West. On New Year's Eve, for example, the local authorities, shunning the Western calendar, did not stage fireworks in Victoria Harbour, despite the pleas of harborfront hotels. Instead, the city sponsored a postmidnight horse race, which it proclaimed the first of the new millennium, at the Happy Valley Racecourse.
The following month, Hong Kong illuminated the harbor with fireworks for the Chinese New Year. The only other holiday that rates harbor pyrotechnics is Oct. 1, anniversary of the Communist takeover of China in 1949.
Yet Hong Kong does not wish to disappear into China either. English is still widely spoken here, although -- frustratingly -- not by cabdrivers. And the English street signs have not been taken down. From Connaught Road to Pedder Street, parts of Hong Kong still recall Mayfair more than mainland China.
The prospect of a Disneyland has aroused little debate, unlike in Paris, where it was derided as a cultural Chernobyl before opening in 1992. Aside from a token nod to Chinese food and festivals, Disney says its park will celebrate Mickey Mouse and evoke the Main Street ambience of its American parks. But that doesn't bother the residents, who are used to imported culture coexisting with their own.
Neither a crown colony nor merely a Chinese metropolis, Hong Kong is trying to be a bit of both. Indeed, it is attracting visitors for the same reasons it always did: its dual identity as a Western-style commercial center and a resolutely Chinese place. Wired with fiber optics but redolent of burning incense, Hong Kong remains the quintessential meeting point of East and West.
Most visitors arrive at the nearly two-year-old Hong Kong International Airport, itself an attraction. A soaring pterodactyl-like structure, built on reclaimed land west of the city, it is one of the last great engineering projects of the 20th century. After a glitch-ridden opening in July 1998, it now operates almost flawlessly. With flights to about 40 cities in mainland China, it is the largest gateway to China. And with more than 60 airlines serving 120 other cities, it is challenging Singapore's claim as the regional aviation hub.
Much of the airport's success is due to an express train that runs from the terminal to stations in Kowloon and Central Hong Kong. Passengers can check luggage and pick up a boarding pass in town; this arrangement has reduced airport lines and relieved much of the stress of traveling here.
Hotel rooms remain plentiful, from exotic Asian palaces to spartan guest houses. Among the most gilded are the Peninsula, which serves a glorious afternoon tea in its lobby near the waterfront in Kowloon, and the Mandarin Oriental, which holds court in a slightly faded building in Hong Kong's Central district.
Among the options for budget-minded travelers are two convenient guest houses in the hills above the Central district: Garden View International House, at 1 Macdonnell Road, and Bishop Lei International Guest House, at 4 Robinson Road.
After a lull in construction, Hong Kong may soon get its first new luxury hotel in several years. A shopping center, hotel and 88-story tower are rising in front of the Airport Express station in central Hong Kong. Two luxury chains, Four Seasons and Ritz-Carlton, are among those bidding to put the city's first six-star hotel in the building. It is scheduled to be finished in 2004.
One of Hong Kong's landmark hotels, the Hilton, was torn down a few years ago to make room for the Cheung Kong Center, the monumental 62-story headquarters of a local tycoon, Li Ka-shing. Mr. Li has hung thousands of tiny bright bulbs on his building, and after dark, it becomes a giant light show -- kaleidoscopic patterns and colors change according to the occasion. Last month, the lights spelled the name "tom.com" in blocklike, flickering letters. It was a not-so-subtle plug for Mr. Li's new Internet portal, which went public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange and immediately soared to astronomical levels. Like tulip bulbs in 17th-century Holland, the Internet has fueled a speculative mania here. Chancy as that is, it has done much to restore Hong Kong's spirits.
While the Cheung Kong Center may be the most dramatic, it is only one of several brightly lighted buildings that are remaking Hong Kong's skyline. In contrast to New York, where landmark buildings are bathed in light from spotlights mounted on neighboring buildings, developers here tend to wrap their towers in ribbons of neon. The lights blink on and off and change color in often-manic sequences.
The effect of these garish, flashing monoliths is striking, especially when seen from the promenade on the Kowloon waterfront, across the harbor. It is a short ride from Central Hong Kong on the Star Ferry, which runs about every 10 minutes between 6:30 a.m. and 11:30 p.m.
ONCE in Kowloon, visitors can plunge into the teeming, clamorous streets that mark Hong Kong as an indisputably Chinese city. The neighborhoods of Mongkok and Yau Ma Tei are especially packed. Yau Ma Tei is home to the Temple Street Night Market, which, in addition to selling every imaginable type of counterfeit goods, also has open-air stalls selling delicious food. Known as dai pai dong, these stalls specialize in seafood.
For those who want to explore beyond Hong Kong and Kowloon -- and gauge the results of an even-more recent handover -- the former Portuguese colony of Macao is less than an hour away by high-speed hovercraft. Macao was reclaimed by China's leaders on Dec. 20, 1999, after more than four centuries of Portuguese rule. Visitors do not need a visa, but should have passports.
Beyond the immaculate ferry terminal, Macao, like Hong Kong, shows little outward change. Colonial buildings, their pastel colors meticulously restored, huddle between dilapidated high-rise apartments. Though the Chinese army has established a garrison there, the tiny enclave retains the feeling of a louche, vaguely sinister gambling den.
One of Macao's colonial treasures, the Bela Vista Hotel, has been converted into the Portuguese consulate, depriving visitors of a sublime view from the veranda. But other landmarks, like the Governor's Mansion and the San Francisco barracks, have changed only their occupants. To savor a sense of colonial-era Macao, have lunch at the Clube Militar de Macau on Avenido da Praia Grande near the Hotel Lisboa. With its langorous ceiling fans and elegant tables, it was the preferred lunch spot for Macao's Portuguese administrators. The rich Portuguese duck rice and African chicken remain.
The casino of the sprawling, seedy Lisboa Hotel has long been the flagship of Macao's gambling trade. Weekend wagerers from Hong Kong, Taiwan and mainland China crowd around blackjack tables, as clouds of cigarette smoke curl above them. In the hallways outside the casino, prostitutes trawl for customers.
In the depths of the recession, Hong Kong briefly flirted with the idea of opening casinos in the territory. But wiser heads prevailed, and speculation is restricted to the stock market, the track and games of mah-jongg played in houses or clubs. Still, consumerism is so pervasive in Hong Kong that it has constrained the development of other forms of culture, either literary or artistic.
For a city of its size and sophistication, Hong Kong has a remarkable dearth of cultural attractions. Its museums are small and none has an international reputation. One of the few interesting exhibits under way is a display of Chinese seals dating from the Warring States period (475-221 B.C.) to the Qing dynasty (1644-1911). About 500 seals, ranging from signature seals to literary seals, are being shown in the West Wing of the Art Museum at the Chinese University of Hong Kong. The exhibit, jointly organized by the Chinese University and Zhejiang Provincial Museum in Hangzhou, runs until May 7.
Performing arts are stronger. Hong Kong's large film industry is showing signs of revival after a long slump. And arts organizations import symphony orchestras, musicals and plays. The popular revival of "Chicago" begins a limited engagement at the Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts on April 22. From late April to late June, the French Consulate and the Hong Kong government are sponsoring a French arts festival, featuring classical and rock music, jazz, ballet, cinema, painting, even equestrian events.
Hong Kong still caters wonderfully to the more earthly senses, with a staggering array of restaurants and nightclubs. Half-empty during the recession, its hottest spots are now packed. A decade ago, the focus of night life began shifting from Wanchai, the bar district immortalized in the 1960 film "The World of Suzie Wong," to Lan Kwai Fong, a hilly neighborhood near the business district. Now, it is shifting again -- to a warren of streets that lie to the west of Lan Kwai Fong. Known derivatively as SoHo (for "South of Hollywood Road"), the area boasts a variety of upscale ethnic restaurants and trendy bars. Many are squeezed next to shops selling Chinese herbs and porcelain. The cramped atmosphere is magnified by an elevated pedestrian escalator that snakes above the neighborhood, carrying office workers to their flats in the hills.
On a sultry Friday night in SoHo, when Hong Kong's newly wealthy Internet entrepreneurs mingle with the usual crowd of lawyers and stockbrokers -- their laughter echoing through the narrow streets -- it is hard to remember that Hong Kong was ever depressed.
 
Palaces, guest houses, dim sum and dance
 
Getting Around
Trains run between the airport and Hong Kong every 10 minutes between 5:50 a.m. and 12:48 p.m. They stop at Tsing Yi, Kowloon and Central Hong Kong. One-way fare: $9. Star Ferry runs every 5 to 10 minutes between Tsim Sha Tsui in Kowloon, and Central and Wanchai in Hong Kong; the fare is 28 cents.
 
Where to Stay
One can opt for opulence or for something on the modest side.
The Peninsula Hong Kong, Salisbury Road, Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon; (852) 2366-6251, (852) 2722-4170. Evocative, colonial-era lobby and glorious harbor views from rooms on high floors.
