HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
High-Tech Firms Power an Office-Market Rebound

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
BUOYED by an infusion of Internet and telecommunications companies looking for a less-expensive alternative to Manhattan and Fairfield County, Westchester's office market is continuing its rebound from an almost decadelong malaise.
"The numbers this quarter are just unbelievable," said Dean J. Shapiro, the executive director of the Insignia/ESG real estate services company in Westchester and Connecticut. "Last year we really started to see an improvement, and it's just continuing." 
 At the end of the first quarter of 2000, Westchester's vacancy rate fell to 13.8 percent, the lowest in more than 10 years, according to an Insignia/ESG report. The figure represents a drop of more than four percentage points compared to the same time last year, when the rate was 17.9 percent.
A total of 712,140 square feet of office space was leased countywide in the first quarter, Insignia/ESG said. "That's 16 percent more than was leased in the first quarter last year," Mr. Shapiro said, "which is particularly impressive when you consider that the first quarter is usually pretty quiet."
Mr. Shapiro attributed the improvement to many factors, most notably the robust economy. "A lot of Internet and telecommunications companies are coming into Westchester now," he said, "especially White Plains, where they can hook up with lots of connectivity and high-technology infrastructure. These companies are also bottom-line oriented, and they're attracted to Westchester because of the comparatively lower rents."
While the average annual rent in Westchester increased 15 cents from 1999 to $23.80 a square foot, it is far lower than typical rents in Stamford and Greenwich, Conn., which can be 25 to 50 percent higher, Mr. Shapiro said, and in Manhattan, where annual rents for prime space can be $70 a square foot and up.
Another factor helping Westchester is the growing lack of suitable space elsewhere, said Frank Boccanfuso, president of FMB Real Estate Services in White Plains. "Westchester's success this quarter is really by default," Mr. Boccanfuso said. "With practically no space available in Fairfield and Manhattan, Westchester is like the last person at the dance. If you want to dance, you're going to have to deal with Westchester."
The central business district of White Plains saw the greatest improvement in the first quarter, with the vacancy rate falling to 19 percent, compared to 22 percent last year and 30 percent the year before.
"Dropping 11 percentage points is just amazing," Mr. Shapiro said. In the first quarter, White Plains accounted for 38 percent of all leasing in the county. And in White Plains, Mr. Shapiro said, 79 percent of the space leased -- a total of eight leases, for 210,700 square feet -- was taken by technology firms.
FIVE of the county's 10 largest lease transactions were for space in the central business district of White Plains. One of the most significant, Mr. Shapiro said, was a lease for 79,736 square feet taken by Metromedia Fiber Network Services at 360 Hamilton Avenue in White Plains. The fiber-optic communications company is expanding and relocating from 1 Lexington Avenue in White Plains.
"That lease is significant because it's a major high-tech company that chose to expand in White Plains," Mr. Shapiro said, "but also because it involves the turnaround of one of the most problematic buildings in the county. That building and 120 Bloomingdale Road, also in White Plains, were vacant buildings just languishing on the market. Now they're back. That's very critical to the improvement of White Plains."
The owner of 360 Hamilton, Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, reopened the 380,000-square-foot building last December after completing a $50 million renovation. It had been vacant for 10 years, after being vacated by its only tenant, I.B.M.
Since its reemergence in the marketplace with a new name, the Reckson Metro Center, a total of 172,000 square feet has been leased, and an additional 160,000 square feet is now out for negotiation, according to Salvatore Campofranco, managing director of Reckson's Westchester division.
"We're more than pleased," Mr. Campofranco said. "Obviously this building was needed in the marketplace." He said that before Reckson decided to invest in the building's capital improvement, it determined that "with New York City's market tightening, there was a lot of demand for this type of building -- and we were right."
The building's rapid success indicates a "sea change in how people perceive the central business district," Mr. Campofranco said. "Well-capitalized companies from a variety of industries now have White Plains on their radar."
The building has attracted a variety of businesses, he said, including high-technology, financial services and sales firms. "The average lease size is 28,000 square feet," he said. "These are not little companies."
At 120 Bloomingdale Road, all 150,000 square feet are now leased.
ANOTHER sign pointing to the renewed health of Westchester's market, brokers say, is the increased interest in the county's office buildings from outside investors, including some from abroad.
The latest example is the acquisition last month of the former Nestle USA headquarters in Purchase by a German-led investment group. The group, BfG/LaSalle Investment, a partnership involving a German bank and a Chicago-based real estate company, paid $47.5 million for the 280,000-square-foot building on 35 acres.
Nestle vacated the building in 1991 when it moved its headquarters to Glendale, Calif., but it continued to own the property, which is fully leased.
"Nestle was just waiting for a good time to sell," said Patrick Colwell, an investment services group senior manager with Grubb & Ellis, which represented Nestle in the sale. "Westchester has been lagging behind Fairfield and Manhattan. But now there's no space in those places anymore, and everyone's looking at Westchester. That created the kind of market conditions that were conducive to a sale."
Mr. Boccanfuso of FMB said that the market conditions had spurred him to invest $16 million this year to buy and renovate a vacant building at 287 Bowman Avenue in Purchase that had been owned by the New York Life Insurance Company.
He said that the 120,500-square-foot building was vacated three years ago by its primary tenant, R. H. Donnelley, an advertising marketer. "We're planning on spending $5 million to completely redo it," he said.
Mr. Boccanfuso said that because the building is vacant, "the buyers better be pretty sure that the market is coming their way -- which we are."
"We're confident in that," he said, "or we wouldn't be investing the money."

HEADLINE: Colombia to the East End: A Tale of Success

BYLINE: By JOY ALTER HUBEL 

 BODY:
IN these heady days of stock-market surges and overnight millionaires, success stories are everywhere. Most are high-tech, dot-com tales, but they often feature young, hard-working businessmen, like Fredy Bedoya, a landscape contractor who held tightly to the reins of the galloping economy and rode it to success.
Except that Mr. Bedoya, a native of Colombia, is probably the only businessman to have started his ride on a rusty three-speed bicycle, peddling his landscape services door to door, Montauk to Bridgehampton. 
 Working as a dishwasher for $3 an hour, and then as a seasonal landscaper for twice that, he was eventually able to buy a rake, a pair of hedge shears and an edging tool -- the limit to what could be carried on the back of a bicycle.
"I would knock on people's doors and offer to do clean-ups and lawns, but because my English was so bad, they couldn't even understand me," he said.
Today, nine years after clipping his first Island hedge, Mr. Bedoya, 32 years old and the owner of Sag Harbor Landscaping, operates seven trucks and a $500,000 business and counts among his clients an impressive roster of East End regulars, including George Plimpton, Tom Wolfe and Chuck Close.
Last December he purchased a six-acre former potato farm in Jamesport for $400,000, and is making it the site of a new nursery that he hopes will double his operation.
But the distance Mr. Bedoya hopes to go seems modest compared with the distance he has come, a 6,000-mile pilgrimage from Colombia to the United States, partly on foot.
"I always knew I could make it in the U.S.," said Mr. Bedoya, who eagerly gave up a sales job in Pereira, Colombia, where he earned the equivalent of $50 a month, for the possibility of something better.
"I sold my motorcycle, bought a ticket to Panama, and from there made my way, on foot, one country at a time, through Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala and Mexico," he said. "I just thought of it as a big adventure -- always to go forward, never back.
"People in Colombia struggle so hard just getting from day to day that often they don't care so much about life and death. They are happy to take their chances through the tunnel," says Mr. Bedoya, referring to his uncertain underground journey.
By the time Mr. Bedoya reached Mexico, he was rail-thin from hunger and half hoping to be arrested just so he could get fed. But when this wish came true and Mexican law enforcers finally did throw him into a detention center, he was badly beaten. Fortunately, a sympathetic officer allowed him to escape.
Once out of prison he hired a guide who, in exchange for a $1,200 i.o.u., agreed to escort Mr. Bedoya and 300 other immigrants to the United States border. Traveling mostly at night, he eventually made his way to Los Angeles, where he worked long enough to buy a plane ticket to the East Coast.
"They told me how much higher the salaries were in the East, but they didn't say how much colder it was," he said. "I remember driving my bicycle through terrible snow storms, and my hair turning into the shape of an ice cube."
But Mr. Bedoya did not let frozen winters chill his resolve.
"What is different is his determination, perseverance and ambition," said Michelle Stark, business adviser at the Brookhaven satellite of SUNY-Stony Brook's Small-Business Development Center, where Fredy Bedoya is her client. The same mix of tenacity and resourcefulness that carried him from South America to Sag Harbor is what makes him successful in business, she added.
The same might be said about countless other Latino immigrants who will risk everything for a foothold in a financially secure life. One sly suggestion about how to solve immigration problems is making the rounds: expel everyone from the United States, including the native born, then allow only those resourceful enough to make it back across the border to stay.
"Through every cycle of economic innovation in this country, immigrants have been a force of transformation and have changed the face of the economy's distressed areas," Ms. Stark noted.
Today that distress arises from the shortage of manual labor that the Island faces. The contractors and landscapers who have been buoyed by the economic expansion of the past 10 years have grown dependent on immigrants.
"We like our lawns green on Long Island," said Margarita Grasing, executive director of the Hispanic Brotherhood of Rockville Centre, which offers employment referrals and counseling to the Latino population. "Thirty years ago, no one had landscapers; now most of us do. And as you walk past them, you hear only Spanish being spoken."
Hispanic immigration has come in waves, starting with Cubans and Puerto Ricans 40 years ago, then Dominicans and now Central Americans. And while many of the earlier immigrants ended up in the restaurant and grocery business, Latinos have now been turning to landscaping and construction.
Unfortunately, Ms. Grasing notes, "Today many of the Hispanic communities are welcomed as workers, but not so as neighbors."
This is particularly true on the East End, where many immigrants are drawn by tourist dollars, according to Edna Stech, social worker for the Hispanic outreach program of the East Hampton Town Department of Human Services.
"Although they do find seasonal jobs, they are finding it hard to make homes here," Ms. Stech said. "There is little housing, transportation, day care and health services available. One of the problems is that the 1990 census has greatly underreported their population. We are trying to encourage them to participate in this census, and to assure them that it won't get them into trouble."
Nevertheless, a mutually dependent economic lifeline has linked the agricultural and Hispanic communities.
"Many Hispanic immigrants have worked their way up from laborers and crewmen to foremen," says Ellen Talmadge, president of the Long Island Nursery and Landscape Association, and director of marketing for Talmadge Nursery. "It's a great place for people to start out. If they don't know the language, they learn from other workers. And the nice thing about growing plants is that you don't need English skills."
She estimates that about half of the agricultural and landscaping work force is Hispanic. Job opportunities are still plentiful, from crew members to truck drivers.
Mr. Bedoya said most of his employees are Latino, and he is ready to pay for landscaping courses that his workers may want to take, and otherwise give them an opportunity to learn a business that they may be able to start for themselves one day.
But Mr. Bedoya is still the exception. According to the Long Island Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, there are about 3,000 Latino-owned businesses on the Island, but more than 300,000 Latino residents. Luis Vazquez, president of the chamber, said that though economic success is coming for many Hispanic residents, the pace is relatively slow.
"It is still very hard to break into corporate or administrative positions," Mr. Vasquez said, "and most successes occur in small retail businesses where a few thousand dollars of investment can go a long way in starting a service-oriented businesses, like a maintenance company, bodegas and now landscaping."
But Hispanic entrepreneurs still face a longer, slower path than their American counterparts. Mr. Vasquez estimated that where it may take an American two to five years to get a business going, Latinos take 5 to 10 years.
"Within that time period a lot of dreams die," he added. "People go through so much just to get here, and when they do they realize the struggle is really just beginning and that there is no welcoming committee, they get very discouraged."
Still, many of the hopeful who fill parking lots in the early morning hours waiting for contractors to give them a day's work reflect not only the successful Latinos who have come before them, but the successes of other immigrant groups, too. The Italian stonemasons in the early 20th century, the Polish potato farmers of the 40's, they and many others managed to weave themselves permanently into the fabric of the Island's economy.
"I think there is room for everyone," Mr. Vazquez said. "And if everyone pulls together to help, we won't have to look at immigrants standing around in parking lots."
 
A Diverse Island
Articles in this series are looking beyond the stereotypes that sometimes taint relations between immigrants and native-born Long Islanders. Future articles will examine immigrants' lives and how they are being woven -- or not -- into the social and economic fabric. Previous articles examined the lives and aspirations of Muslims on the Island, and a Korean entrepreneur and her American-raised son.

HEADLINE: Raking In Taxes Is Hard Work For the I.R.S., Too

BYLINE: By CAROL STEINBERG 

DATELINE: HOLTSVILLE

 BODY:
WHEN Theresa Colangelo was hired as a temporary data-transcriber at the Brookhaven Internal Revenue Service Center in Holtsville last tax season, she learned the true meaning of number crunching.
To meet her quota, she had to process 27 documents and tap 6,600 keystrokes an hour. If she could get the pace up to 31 documents an hour and keep her error rate low, she could get incentive pay. 
 Ms. Colangelo recalls the long hours saddled in front of the computer -- and the pressure. "The numbers would start to jump all over the page," she said.
So when she returned in February as a four-month employee, Ms. Colangelo cut her hours from eight to six each day. Still, she said, "It's crazy over there."
As taxpayers scurry to meet the deadline for filing their returns by midnight Monday -- an extra two days because the traditional April 15 fell on a Saturday -- the 67-acre complex is running on overdrive.
Temporary employees like Ms. Colangelo inflate employee ranks here to 5,200 during the peak season, from 2,400 workers in the quiet of November.
Inside a beige brick building that spans the space of five football fields, I.R.S. administrators are bracing for a swelling avalanche of returns while striving to project an image warmer than bean counters.
The public relations effort is part of an agency-wide strategy to balance business results with customer and employee satisfaction. The program grew out of Congressional hearings three years ago that disclosed many problems, including poor service, inadequate technology and overly aggressive enforcement tactics.
Open since 1972, the facility operates round the clock, seven days a week, but the public's only contact is by mail or telephone. One of 10 processing centers nationwide, it handles federal returns from individuals and businesses in New York City, in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland counties, and in New Jersey.
In all 1999, 7.9 million individual and 4.3 million business returns moved through the pipeline here, of the 228.1 million paper and electronic returns filed nationwide.
The first big rush -- mainly from refund-seekers -- comes in early February, and then the flow recedes. New York area residents are notoriously last-minute filers, with 50 percent of the returns -- usually with payments due -- swamping Brookhaven in April. If history repeats itself, 1.8 million returns will deluge the center the week before the deadline.
The center here handles paper returns only. Electronic returns from the New York-New Jersey area are processed in Andover, Mass. As of April 7, such e-filings had risen 19.2 percent, to 1.46 million, from the corresponding period last year, and paper returns were down 12.6 percent, to 3.75 million.
Despite fewer paper filings, the center has maintained the staff levels of last year because of procedural changes that require additional keystrokes, according to James Gaither, director of the submission-processing division.
Carol M. Landy, the director of the customer-service division, added: "If the trend continues, it may have an impact."
The Brookhaven center is also one of 25 sites nationwide that answer I.R.S. toll-free hotlines. Six hundred customer-service representatives, including six who speak Spanish, take inquiries about accounts and refunds; technical questions go to other sites. After 11 p.m., calls are routed farther west.
Last year the center answered 1.2 million calls, fielding 13,527 inquiries on April 15 alone. As the deadline nears, average "on hold" time swells from four or five minutes to 12 minutes.
If anything, several operators said, their stress level builds after April 17, when calls are related to late payments and penalties and tend to be more complicated -- and when they have to deal with occasional suicide threats from taxpayers despondent about the money they owe.
To prepare for the rush, the agency relies on seasonal workers with minimal qualifications, paying $8.38 to $10.33 an hour. Although the I.R.S. was still seeking tax clerks in late March, 200 temporary tax clerks started work last Monday to fill the last open positions. Because of labor shortages last year, they said, the center offered four-hour shifts and flexible hours as incentives.
Mr. Gaither said there has been a "significant improvement in the caliber of people we're getting this year, many of them middle-aged and older."
Inside the complex, a visitor sees a giant labyrinth, but the processing is an exact science.
The Postal Service delivers sacks of mail daily, peaking at 10 deliveries a day just before deadline. The envelopes and the returns inside weave through manual and automated areas divided by function. Processing a return takes 10 days from start to finish, on par with the national average, according to Ken Hubenak, an I.R.S. spokesman in Washington.
Despite the electronics, paperwork is everywhere. Hundreds of rolling beige carts stocked with returns line various floor areas and even hallways, awaiting steps in the assembly line.
Security is tight. A visitor, for example, can view the data-transcription section where, during peak season, 794 casually dressed employees are packed in gray desk upon gray desk, row upon row. But the visitor dare not approach an individual desk, risking a glimpse of even one number being entered into the computer.
The workers are not bonded, but according to federal government regulations, they will lose their jobs if they breach the confidentiality of any taxpayer information.
In the first step after returns arrive, they are sorted by two conveyor belts and manually into 25 categories.
Returns with payments filter into the "remittance processing room," a restricted area where operators enter taxpayer information and payments, and a computerized system checks accuracy, credits taxpayers' accounts and endorses checks, which are deposited nightly in the Bank of New York and credited to the United States Treasury. Last year, $41.3 billion was collected here.
One vital checkpoint is the "code and edit" room, where mostly seasonal tax clerks and examiners scan returns for omissions or errors and code them accordingly.
From there, processors enter data from batches of returns into new computers installed last year. The computers fix some errors, like mistakes in arithmetic. Five percent of all returns checked here are returned to taxpayers because of errors like missing signatures and incorrect Social Security numbers.
At the end of the processing road here, information from correct returns is transmitted electronically each night to the Martinsburg, W.Va., computing center. The Treasury issues refunds within three to four weeks for returns processed before April 1, or five to six weeks for later filers.
So far, Mr. Gaither said, "we're all looking at one of the better processing years." Employee mistakes are down 3 percent, although the error rate has never exceeded 1 or 2 percent, he said, attributing the improvement in part to the return of more experienced seasonal workers.
In addition, Ms. Landy said, the replacement of the quarter-century-old computers phased out last year "is uplifting for employees."
"If you work in shabby surroundings, you do shabby work," she said.
The new system should cut processing time by 10 percent, officials said.
Patricia Donahue, vice president of Chapter 99 of the National Treasury Employees Union at Brookhaven, while noting that employee morale "went down the tubes with the Senate hearings" three years ago, said employee-employer communication has increased and more training has been given. Employee stress -- "one of the biggest problems here" -- is being addressed with stress-relief classes and focus groups, she said, though she urged still more training.
As for the "customers," the center last year received 632 compliments and 119 complaints about employees' behavior, almost double the 1998 figures of 335 and 61. No comparable national figures were available.
Customer-service representatives say taxpayers do not seem as irate as they were after the Senate hearings. "This year it's calmed down, and we've made more of an effort to be sympathetic to taxpayers' needs," said Stan Showell, who handles 60 to 80 calls a day during refund season.
Ms. Landy said that the strong economy and fewer changes in tax law contributed to the mood swing. But, she added, "there will always be negative publicity; it's a fact of life."
Jim Montes, the Brooklyn district chairman of the Citizen Advisory Panel, a volunteer group overseeing I.R.S. activity, said the public has noticed "a pretty remarkable change in the attitude of employees and their willingness to help."
But that raises another concern. "It's been reported in the papers that now I.R.S. employees feel they should be more lenient," he said. "So that's something we're looking at, to make sure the scales do not tip so far to the side that tax collection is being compromised."
The Brookhaven center expects to conduct 79,557 audits by mail this year, 4,000 more than in 1999 but below the 190,486 in 1998, when three years of returns were audited. These typically involve suspicions of refund fraud, inappropriate filing status or improper claims for dependents. The Brooklyn district office handles face-to-face audits.
Taxpayers can seek help for unresolved complaints at the taxpayer advocate's office, also at Brookhaven, which was set up as an independent office under the I.R.S. Restructuring and Reform Act of 1998.
Last year the office handled 17,000 cases, 3,000 fewer than in 1998. Most involved refund inquiries.
"There are a lot of times that taxpayers don't understand the process," said a local taxpayer advocate, Patricia Berliner. "This is a very scary agency. They need people to speak on their behalf."

LENGTH: 792 words

HEADLINE: Bargain Basement for the Internet

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
ON the morning of Sept. 18, 1999, Arthur Frischman was the president of a successful company in Elmsford. By that evening, he was out of business.
"Hurricane Floyd came through and wiped us out," he said. "The Saw Mill River rose more than three feet, flooding half our warehouse. The water destroyed 40,000 pieces of software waiting to be shipped. It was valued at $250,000, and we had no flood insurance." 
 Mr. Frischman, 35, was forced to lay off all his employees, and he has been unable to pay his suppliers.
But six months later, Mr. Frischman has a new company in Elmsford. And he is already turning a profit. His idea: creating a bargain basement for the Internet.
His original company, the Arch Publication Group, sold educational software and entertainment products to consumers and schools. The new company, 999central, sells software, videos and other products priced at $9.99 or less.
"I did some research and found plenty of Web retailers selling discount items, but none in the odd lot category," he said. "So I leased space in a small building owned by my original landlord and started stocking the shelves with software inventory, mainly movies, DVD's, music, toys and books."
Mr. Frischman has held several different jobs during his career, but he has long been fascinated by computers and the potential of the Internet. His computer experience dates back to his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland in College Park.
"My brother-in-law gave me an old computer I took to college. In the 80's, not many people had them," he recalled. "I majored in economics, but I was always on the computer."
His first job after graduation, as a broker for PaineWebber in Manhattan, was not a success. "I wasn't a very good salesman, and after 18 months I was laid off," he said.
He fared better at Thomas Cook Travel, where he worked as a financial analyst, eventually managing corporate travel for companies like A.I.G. and Philips Electronics.
"Philips was a major developer of the CD technology I kept seeing at their Manhattan headquarters," he said. "I thought, 'This is something good.' " Good enough to inspire his first start-up software development company in 1995.
"My cousin Andrew Schulkind, who became my partner, had a big apartment. We used one of the rooms as an office, and we put in $75,000 apiece coming from savings and family loans to buy equipment, and we started Arch Interactive. It was a development company, writing educational and entertainment software."
The partners did well enough to expand into an office in little more than a year. But by the end of the second year, they split up.
"I didn't want to continue development work," Mr. Frischman said. "It meant selling besides coming up with products. And there were too many development companies out there competing for distribution."
Instead, he opened a company to distribute existing titles to the K-12 school market. And he quickly acquired Educorp, a much larger company, which was in the same field.
He moved into larger quarters and hired more employees. "The orders were flowing in," he recalled. "Business was growing at a fantastic rate, and I started thinking about other ways to sell directly over the Internet. I needed a concept that would give me an innovative marketing niche."
Eventually, he hit on the idea of a software variety store, with every item priced under $10, he said. "I called it 999. We were just getting started. Jennifer, my wife, was scanning pictures into the database at home. We had about 100 software titles. That's where we were when the flood hit."
And that is when Mr. Frischman said he was forced to build 999 into a company.
"I buy remainders, excess inventory, closeouts and product returns from companies like Wal-Mart, Costco and Sam's Club and from liquidators, distributors and companies going out of business. I pay up front, in cash."
Most items are priced the same at $9.99, even those that may list at $25 to $60 in catalogs or retail stores. Some items are even less. Shipping costs an additional $5, for up to 10 items sent to the same address.
"It was a struggle at first, and it's still a business with a lot of headaches," Mr. Frischman said, but the company is thriving.
"We were in the black by the end of the Christmas season," he said. "And we already have an e-mail database of 11,000."
Meanwhile, as money trickles in from customers of Arch Interactive, he said, he is paying off his suppliers, with an eye toward dissolving that company sometime next year.
To insure customer loyalty for 999central, the company has "eight real live people who take orders and deal with problems over the phone," he said.
The company can be visited at www.999central.com.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
If the House Is New, It May Well Be Big and Costly

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WITH all signs of the state's housing market pointing upward, developers are seizing the moment and building large and expensive homes for move-up buyers.
Demand continues to outpace supply, and sale prices keep rising. And with the economy strong, the stock market still churning out profits and consumer confidence high, buyers "are willing to spend money on homes they want," said David J. Schoner, the vice president of the new homes and land division at the Coldwell Banker residential brokerage company in Parsippany. 
 His company lists 167 subdivisions where a total of some 3,000 homes are under way (or soon to be) in 14 north and central New Jersey counties. Of those projects, about half are homes with prices of $500,000 or more, Mr. Schoner said, adding that the average sales price for a new house in those counties is $550,000, up from $397,000 in 1998.
Prices of existing homes are also increasing. Last year, the average sales price of the 141,900 homes sold in the state was $205,000, compared with $197,300 for the 129,900 homes sold in 1998, according to the New Jersey Association of Realtors, in Edison. During the same period, the number of homes sold at prices of $500,000 or more rose to 4.7 percent of the total, up from 3.9 percent.
Jeffrey Otteau, the president of the Otteau Appraisal Group in East Brunswick, put the increase in production and sales of expensive homes in perspective.
"Real estate markets improve from the bottom up in terms of price," he said, noting that as more first-time buyers enter the market, they create a ripple effect of additional sales up the housing ladder, increasing the demand in the highest price ranges as well as those at the low end and in the middle.
On the production side, Mr. Otteau said, the scarcity and high cost of available building sites is contributing to the run-up in prices. And though the number of expensive homes being built is inching upward, he added, there are still more buyers than there are homes to buy.
There were 32,154 housing permits issued in New Jersey in 1999, compared with 31,345 permits in 1998, according to state figures. But last year's total is far below the 57,000 permits issued in 1986, at the height of the last construction boom.
If all factors remain constant, Mr. Schoner said, "we can look for prices to continue to move up." The increases will stop, he said, only when first-time buyers can no longer afford to enter the market.
Mr. Otteau added that he foresees prices rising through this summer, saying that after that, he expected them to "plateau and then remain flat through the fall and winter." Beyond that, "it is an unknown," he said, adding that "there is at least another year left in this housing cycle."
Historically, he said, in a down market the first housing segment to fall is low-priced homes in secondary locations, and the last is high-priced houses in prime locations.
AND location is what K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank is banking on to draw buyers to the 48 homes it is building on half-acre lots at Fairway Oaks off Paramus Road in Paramus. Prices are expected to start at $685,000, and each house will have 3,500 to 4,400 square feet. The 55-acre site, eight miles from the George Washington Bridge, was part of the adjacent Arcola Country Club in the 1940's. Later, it was privately owned and remained undeveloped.
Paramus is known more for the shopping malls within its borders than for high-end housing. But Ara Hovnanian, the company's president and chief executive, said he proceeded with the Fairway Oaks project because "the market is on fire, and to get new housing this close to Manhattan is unusual and offered us a rare opportunity."
The project represents part of a broadening of market focus by Hovnanian, which is best known as a builder of town houses for first-time buyers.
"We decided to dedicate a segment of our business to the luxury end because with the U.S. standard of living increasing, it makes sense for us to play in this arena," Mr. Hovnanian said.
That does not mean that "we've abandoned selling $100,000 town houses," he said, adding that with a "broad array of product, we can cover our bases." The company also has town houses on the Hudson River that sell for "north of $1 million," he said, "giving us comfort that we will do well in this market."
At Fairway Oaks the company will offer six designs, each with four bedrooms and two-car garages. Some of the homes will have a large butler's pantry off the kitchen, porches or a bonus room over the garage. Buyers can also choose optional features like conservatories. Sales will start next month.
Location was also a factor in the decision by the Wharton Development Corporation of Manhattan to build 19 semicustom homes at the Enclave in Englewood Cliffs, about a mile from the George Washington Bridge. The 4,000-to-4,500-square-foot houses on quarter-acre lots are rising along Marietta Street, not far from Route 9W.
"The beauty of this project," said Peter C. Lewis, Wharton's president, "is that we are creating a new neighborhood, which hasn't been done in this community in 30 years."
He said in the year since sales started, base prices have risen from $850,000 to $950,000 and final prices, once buyers have customized their houses with upgraded moldings and appliances, have reached $1.2 million. So far, 15 houses have been sold to empty-nesters and move-up buyers from the Englewood Cliffs area and from Manhattan, he said.
As for the remaining four houses, Mr. Lewis said he is taking a "build them and they will come" approach and will construct them on speculation.
Another luxury project rising in Bergen County is Round Hill on Alford Drive in Saddle River, with 18 custom homes on a minimum of two acres. Most of the 50-acre wooded site was formerly an estate, with a century-old house and a horse barn that have been razed.
Pinnacle Custom, a division of Pinnacle Communities of Millburn, is Round Hill's developer. Prices begin at $2.3 million, with deed restrictions and architectural controls "to protect buyers' interest and the project's integrity," said Michael Cantor, the director of construction.
The houses must be at least 7,000 square feet but no more than 10,000 square feet. And while buyers work with the company's architect in designing their houses, Pinnacle has the final say on the designs, Mr. Cantor said.
Sales began a year ago, and so far, eight houses have been sold, Mr. Cantor said. For such projects to succeed, he added, "they have to be in the right location, so we limit our choices to unique properties in upscale communities."
IN two months, the company expects to start a nine-home subdivision on a hilly 16-acre tract off Shrewsbury Road in Livingston in Essex County. The site was previously owned by former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who sold it a year and a half ago. Mr. Kean, now the president of Drew University, lives in Far Hills, but his former hilltop house, which has been resold, has provided a name to the development, called Governor Hill at Livingston.
The new development will have architectural controls and restrictions similar to those in Saddle River. Lots will be an acre to one-and-a-half acres, and house prices will begin at $1.3 million, Mr. Cantor said.
In Manalapan in Monmouth County, Toll Brothers Inc. of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., which specializes in houses for move-up buyers, is developing 55 "estate homes," each with four or five bedrooms and at least 4,300 square feet. The houses at Manalapan Hills, which is rising on a 120-acre former farm on Sweetman Lane, will have lots of 1.38 acres to 7 acres.
Sales began in January 1999, and so far 31 homes have been sold. Prices begin at $527,000, an increase of $81,000 since the start of the project, said Douglas Yearley, a vice president at Toll.
About half of the houses Toll has built in New Jersey in the last few years have been these large "estate homes." "It was not a concerted effort, but a response to market demand," Mr. Yearley said. "We continue to be amazed at the depth and breadth of this market."
